HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Shares Close Out Vigorous Week In Quiet Fashion

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
After surging sharply in the previous three sessions, the stock market finished its best week since September yesterday with stocks mixed but modestly higher.
 The 33-point rise in the Dow Jones industrial average was enough to push it to its highest level since the market fell to five-year lows last month. Its 5.2 percent rise for the week was the best since September. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index edged up 3 points and finished the week up 5.1 percent, also its best performance since September. Although the the Nasdaq composite index slipped 10 points, it ended the week up 4.7 percent, its strongest showing since May. 
 Yesterday's small moves were in sharp contrast to the tumultuous ups and downs of the rest of this week and previous weeks. Daily trading volume was just more than half the average for the last three weeks. After the three main market gauges dropped 3 percent on Monday, they surged on Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday, with the Dow and the S.& P. 500 rising 2 percent or more each day. The Nasdaq had one 4 percent surge.
While investors may have been taking a break after this wild ride, they also had plenty of reminders yesterday of the troubled financial plight of some companies and the accounting manipulations at others. And they also may be looking ahead to next week, when Federal Reserve policy makers meet on Tuesday to consider their next move on interest rates. While most analysts do not expect the Fed to cut rates, no action could rattle investors if they decide to focus again on recent data that indicate a slowing economy.
"The stock market rally is partly a rally on the sense that the Fed will ease" monetary policy, said Richard Berner, chief United States economist at Morgan Stanley.
Conseco, the financial services company, announced before the market opened yesterday that it would stop paying interest on its bonds while it tries to restructure its finances. Gary C. Wendt, Conseco's chief executive, said, "Our judgment is that the continued gradual financial restructuring that was the goal of the turnaround plan is no longer the best course." Shares of Conseco, which closed on Thursday at 34 cents, down more than 98 percent from the Wendt-era peak of $20.24, were not allowed to trade after the announcement.
WorldCom announced late Thursday that it had found an additional $3.3 billion in accounting irregularities, on top of the $3.8 billion in improperly recorded expenses that drove the company into bankruptcy protection last month. Shares of WorldCom fell to 10.9 cents yesterday from 12.4 cents on Thursday.
On the positive side, the government reported yesterday that worker productivity rose at an annual rate of 1.1 percent in the second quarter, a bigger increase than was forecast. That could be a good sign for corporate earnings. Companies have two main options now for improving their profits, cutting costs or increasing productivity.
At the close, the Dow was up 33.43, or 0.4 percent, to 8,745.45, just above the recent high of 8,736.59 reached on July 31. The S.& .P 500 climbed 3.18 points, or 0.4 percent, to 908.64. The Nasdaq was down 10.40 points, or 0.8 percent, to 1,306.12.
In the bond market, yields fell and prices rose. The yield on the Treasury's 10-year note dropped to 4.26 percent, from 4.40 percent on Thursday, while the price, which moves in the opposite direction, rose 1 2/32 , to 100 28/32 . The yield on the 30-year bond fell to 5.11 percent from 5.23 percent; its price rose 1 22/32 , to 103 28/32 .
Despite this week's rally in stocks, individual investors still appear leery about them and continue to take money out of stock mutual funds. According to AMG Data Services, there was a net outflow from equity funds of $1.9 billion in the week ended Wednesday. For the month of July, the net outflow was $40.9 billion, the worst month since AMG began collecting data in 1992.
Since the market hit five-year lows on July 23, stocks have rallied, sold off and rallied again, giving a stronger sign that a bottom for the market has finally been found.
But this second rebound may be challenged by the Fed meeting. Policy makers will consider whether their benchmark short-term interest rate should be lowered because of recent signs that the recovery from last year's recession is slowing. It was fear of a slowing economy -- or even the threat of a recession -- that stopped the first stock rally, which ran from July 24 to July 31.
The signs of a weakening recovery, including anemic second quarter growth and slowdowns in both the manufacturing and services sectors of the economy in July, have led several Wall Street firms to predict that the Fed will cut rates in the months ahead.
But Mr. Berner of Morgan Stanley predicted that the Fed would cut its interest rate target, now at a 40-year low of 1.75 percent, by half a percentage point on Tuesday.
"The reason is that we are dealing with a crisis of confidence," he said. The signs of consumer hesitation on spending, including weak airline bookings and electronic sales, are very worrisome, he said. Referring to Fed policy makers, he said, "I believe they think if they move, they have to move more dramatically than a quarter-point cut."
But most Wall Street analysts think the Fed will wait until September to cut rates. They are predicting that the Fed policy makers will, instead, send a signal in their post-meeting announcement that the central bank is ready to reduce rates in the near future, especially if economic indicators continue to be weak.
Chris Wolfe, equity market strategist for J. P. Morgan's private clients, said he thought a Fed rate cut could be interpreted as a sign that policy makers think the economy is even weaker than the current data indicates. If investors believe that, stock prices could be pushed lower.

HEADLINE: A Return to Profitability; 
Big Recall Behind It, Tire Maker Regains Its Footing

BYLINE:  By KEN BELSON with MICHELINE MAYNARD 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Aug. 9 

 BODY:
Two years ago, Japan's major tire maker, the Bridgestone Corporation, was staggering from a huge, embarrassing recall of Firestone tires that threatened to crush its American subsidiary. Today, Bridgestone reported strong profits for the first half of the year, and said for the first time that it expected its American operations to turn a profit for the year.
 Though Bridgestone is still grappling with stiff industry competition and the uncertain economic outlook in its main markets, executives celebrated today a return to stability that few analysts thought possible in 2000. "The recovery has been remarkable," said Michael K. Gorey, chief financial officer of the company's American arm, Bridgestone/Firestone Americas Holdings. 
 The positive results came on the second anniversary of the recall of 6.5 million Firestone tires, most of them installed on Ford Explorers and other sport-utility vehicles, after safety authorities linked the tires to a series of fatal accidents. 
The recall and surrounding recriminations set off a bitter fight by Bridgestone and Ford Motor over responsibility for the crashes.
The dispute destroyed the 94-year relationship of the companies, and it helped spur the removals of chief executives at Ford and at Bridgestone's American arm. Analysts said at the time that Bridgestone would probably have to scrap the Firestone brand and spend years slowly building a new identity in the United States.
The company did neither. Instead, it reorganized its American operations, retaining Firestone as a mass-market brand but putting greater emphasis on Bridgestone as a premium brand. And as its contracts with Ford expire unrenewed this year, Bridgestone is shifting away from sales to carmakers and concentrating on the consumer market, where it can make more on each sale. (Carmakers typically pay about half the retail price for the tires they buy.)
Mr. Gorey said today that Bridgestone's gross margins on American tire sales had jumped by 7 percent, a figure he called "unbelievably large" in the tire market, where margins are generally thin. Sales in America recovered somewhat in the first half of 2002 from the depressed levels of 2001, and the company now expects full-year revenues of $7.6 billion and profits of $50 million in the United States, it said today. 
Mr. Gorey gave credit for the rebound to Bridgestone's dealers and distributors, who praised the company for its candor and vigor in dealing with the Firestone crisis. "They handled everything as professionally as any company that I've ever seen," said Richard P. Johnson, president of American Tire Distributors in Huntersville, N.C. American Tire supplies retail dealers through 62 wholesale outlets and sells about 1.7 million Bridgestone and Firestone tires a year. When the problems with the Firestone tires arose, "they said, 'We'll take care of it, and we'll take care of you,' " Mr. Johnson said of Bridgestone.
The rebound in the United States was, in turn, crucial to Bridgestone's improved results worldwide, executives said.
Bridgestone is dominant in its home market, making two out of every five tires sold in Japan, but growth there has been flattened by the country's extended economic weakness.
The company depends on the United States for 40 percent of its sales; it reported a small net loss there of $14 million for the first half, but nothing like the huge recall-related setbacks of past years, so the company as a whole earned 24.5 billion yen ($203 million) in the period ended June 30. 
With its Ford business falling away, Bridgestone shut a plant in Decatur, Ill., and set a goal of reducing its reliance on sales to carmakers, which accounted for 40 percent of its business before the Firestone recall, to just 30 percent.
But it cannot afford to forsake sales to automakers entirely because when American consumers replace their tires, they buy the same brand that originally came with their car at least one-third of the time, industry figures show. 
Nor can the American carmakers afford to drop Bridgestone. They have much to gain from keeping it in balanced competition with Goodyear Tire and Rubber and Michelin, their other two main suppliers, both to hold prices down and to make substitutions easier if problems develop with tires in the future.
"The car companies want a diverse group of tire suppliers, and Bridgestone tires are viewed as relatively solid," said Stephen Girsky, an auto industry analyst at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter in New York. "As things have calmed down on the Firestone front, it's an opportunity to rebuild." 
The chief executive of the American unit, John Lampe, and William Clay Ford Jr., chairman and chief executive of Ford Motor, have hinted at a reconciliation in recent months.
Mr. Ford, whose mother is from the Firestone founding family, mentions the tire company's founder, Harvey Firestone, in Ford's current TV ad campaign. But Shigeo Watanabe, chairman and chief executive of Bridgestone, said that though the companies have been in contact, they have made no decisions about their future relationship. 
Its relations with other carmakers are more fruitful. Nissan Motor recently chose Bridgestone tires for its latest ZX sports car, and General Motors uses Bridgestones on cars made by its Saturn division.
But the company has suffered from rising materials costs, from adverse shifts in the yen-dollar exchange rate and from a trend toward smaller cars in Japan, where new car sales have fallen for 11 straight months.
"The Japanese market has turned out to be a basket case," said Chris Redl, who covers the company for UBS Warburg in Tokyo. "This is significant for Bridgestone because they have so much market share here."

HEADLINE: Productivity Rise Is Tied to Agility OfEmployers In Rapid Layoffs 

BYLINE:  By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
By cutting back the hours of workers without reducing the workload, employers pushed up the nation's annual growth rate of productivity by 1.1 percent in the second quarter, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.
 Though the gain was not particularly strong, it was higher than most forecasters had expected and appeared to demonstrate how skilled the private sector has become in responding rapidly to a fall-off in demand and a flattening out of production. Rather than keep idle employees on the payroll, companies now lay them off and cut overtime so quickly that output per hour in the second quarter continued to rise despite almost no increase in production. 
 The production of goods and services rose by an almost imperceptible 0.3 percent, while the hours needed to produce such output fell by 1.1 percent, the bureau said. Employees still on the job worked faster. Even so, unit labor costs -- the wages and benefit payments needed to produce, say, a loaf of bread or to launder a shirt -- rose by a mild 2.4 percent after having fallen in the two previous quarters. 
But what distinguished the second quarter, economists said, was the rapid adjustment to falling demand as a nascent recovery from recession showed signs of weakening.
Demand briefly surged in the first quarter, and executives dealt with it by increasing production while cutting back on workers and hours. Because people worked faster and more efficiently to increase production without working more hours, the productivity growth rate shot to 8.6 percent at an annual rate.
"It is easy in the United States," said Robert J. Gordon, an economist at Northwestern University, "to get sharp and sudden declines in hours by laying off workers and eliminating overtime, and this contributes to healthy productivity growth in hard times."
Productivity, which measures how much a worker produces in an hour, matters. The greater the output and the revenue from selling the extra output, the more opportunity workers have to share in their efficiency through raises.
In the past, when times were hard, the raises dried up but companies were more reluctant to shed workers and cut hours. Productivity suffered, and, as a result, so did profit. Profit no longer shrinks as much now that companies are quicker to cut labor costs by shedding workers and hours. That, in fact, is what has happened as the economy struggles to recover from recession.
"You need to generate jobs eventually," said David Wyss, chief economist at Standard & Poor's, "and I think that will happen once demand grows more rapidly than workers can increase their output through greater productivity."
The second-quarter number provided more evidence that the nearly generation-long stagnation in productivity growth had ended. The stagnation lasted from 1973 to 1995, and then, in the late 1990's, productivity surged.
Some economists greeted the improvement as evidence that a new high-technology economy had raised business to a higher level of efficiency. But others wondered whether the improvement was a flash that would fade once the stock market bubble burst and the nation passed through a fresh cycle of recession and recovery, as it has been doing for the last 18 months. 
The message in the productivity report released yesterday was that some of the late 1990's improvement has indeed stuck, even after the numbers were adjusted to account for downward revisions in output and in economic growth in recent quarters. The revisions meant that productivity growth, instead of rising at 3.3 percent in 2000 and 1.9 percent last year, as previously announced, rose 2.9 percent and 1.1 percent, respectively, the bureau reported yesterday.
Still, productivity benefited from the rapid spread of computers in the 90's and the introduction of innovative technologies, many economists contend. As a result of the enhanced efficiency, the productivity growth rate will probably settle at an average of 2 percent a year over the next decade, Mr. Wyss says. His 2 percent estimate is becoming the consensus view among economists. 
There are skeptics, of course, among them Stephen S. Roach, chief economist at Morgan Stanley. "My guess is that when the dust settles, you will have seen a pickup in the latter half of the 90's that has continued to this day," he said, "but that does not mean it is sustainable. It simply may reflect a shift from a pre-Internet to a post-Internet world, which implies replacement of one technology with another and, during that transition, higher productivity."
If the consensus view turns out to be correct, a 2 percent growth rate would mean a more rapid rise in living standards than was possible from 1973 to 1995, when the productivity growth averaged only 1.5 percent a year.

PERSON: Edsger Wybe Dijkstra 

HEADLINE: Edsger Dijkstra, 72, Physicist Who Shaped Computer Era 

BYLINE:  By JOHN MARKOFF 

 BODY:
Edsger Wybe Dijkstra, whose contributions to the mathematical logic that underlies computer programs and operating systems make him one of the intellectual giants of the field, died on Monday at his home in Nuenen, the Netherlands. He was 72.
 The cause of death was cancer, said officials at the University of Texas, where Dr. Dijkstra held the Schlumberger centennial chair in computer sciences from 1984 to 1999, when he retired. 
 Dr. Dijkstra is best known for his shortest-path algorithm, a method for finding the most direct route on a graph or map, and for his work as the co-designer of the first version of Algol 60, a programming language that represented one of the first compiler programs that translates human instructions.
The shortest-path algorithm, which is now widely used in global positioning systems and travel planning, came to him one morning in 1956 as he sat sipping coffee on the terrace of an Amsterdam cafe.
It took him three years to publish the method, which is now known simply as Dijkstra's algorithm. At the time, he said, algorithms were hardly considered a scientific topic.
Of even greater importance was his solution to what he originally called the dining quintuple problem, but which later became known as the dining philosophers' problem.
He conceived of the problem faced by five philosophers sitting around a table, each with a bowl of rice and a single chopstick. Because eating requires two chopsticks, the challenge was to find an equitable method that would permit all of those at the table to eat without having anyone starve or having the entire table face deadlock. Dijkstra's original solution ensured that each diner took turns using a pair of chopsticks.
The problem has applicability to both computer operating systems and to network design. 
Several years after Dr. Dijkstra solved the problem, he was surprised to learn that the Massachusetts Institute of Technology designers of the pioneering Multics operating system had not grappled successfully with the issue of deadlock. The consequence was that on occasion their system would abruptly halt.
"You can hardly blame M.I.T. for not taking notice of an obscure computer scientist in a small town in the Netherlands," he was quoted as saying in "Out Of Their Minds: The Lives and Discoveries of 15 Great Computer Scientists."
Dr. Dijkstra, an advocate of an approach known as structured programming, wrote a short research note in the March 1968 edition of the journal Communications of the ACM that became legendary. Titled "The GO TO Considered Harmful," it argued against the complexity of a feature in programming languages like Fortran and Basic that permitted programmers to write convoluted programs that jump around haphazardly.
A theoretical physicist by training, early in his career he observed that many problems required extensive calculation and so in the early 1950's he taught himself how to program.
In March 1952 he took a part-time job at the Mathematical Center in Amsterdam, immersing himself in the challenges of instructing the primitive computers of the era.
When he married in 1957, the Dutch marriage rites required that he state his profession and he attempted to say he was a programmer. The municipal authorities in Amsterdam did not accept his answer on the ground that there was no such profession. As a result, his marriage certificate described his profession as "theoretical physicist."
He was born May 11, 1930, in Rotterdam, the Netherlands. His father was a chemist and his mother was a mathematician. In 1942, at 12, Dr. Dijkstra entered an elite high school where he studied classical Greek and Latin, French, German, English, biology, mathematics, physics and chemistry. During the German occupation his parents sent him away for a brief period to the countryside. He earned degrees in mathematics and theoretical physics from the University of Leyden and a Ph.D. in computing science from the University of Amsterdam.
He worked as a programmer at the Mathematical Center from 1952 to 1962, taught mathematics at Eindhoven University of Technology from 1962 to 1984 and was a research fellow at the Burroughs Corporation from 1973 to 1984.
Dr. Dijkstra was the recipient of many awards, notably the Association for Computing Machinery's prestigious Turing Award in 1972.
He is survived by his wife of more than 40 years, Maria C. Debets Dijkstra, who is known as Ria; three children, Marcus, Femke and the computer scientist Rutger M. Dijkstra; and by two grandchildren.
Throughout Dr. Dijkstra's career, his work was characterized by elegance and economy. His love affair with simplicity came at an early age and under his mother's guidance. He once said he had asked his mother whether mathematics was a difficult topic. She replied that he must learn all the formulas and that furthermore if he required more than five lines to prove something, he was on the wrong track.

CORRECTION-DATE: August 13, 2002

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an obituary on Saturday about Edsger Wybe Dijkstra, whose contributions to mathematical logic underlie modern computer programming, misstated the day of his death. It was last Tuesday, not the previous day.

HEADLINE: THE AD CAMPAIGN; 
Invoking Corporate Greed

BYLINE:  By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD 

 BODY:
 The campaign of Andrew M. Cuomo, the former housing secretary and a Democratic candidate for governor in the Sept. 10 primary, said it planned to broadcast a new commercial beginning today in the New York City region. Another commercial, a negative advertisement in response to what his campaign considers political attacks from his opponent, H. Carl McCall, the state comptroller, is also scheduled to be broadcast today.

PRODUCER -- Squier, Knapp and Dunn.

ON THE SCREEN -- A long corporate banquet table. The camera moves past expensive-looking silver candlesticks, china, caviar, half-eaten meals. Shots of place cards with the names of corporations caught up in fraud scandals, including WorldCom, Adelphia and Tyco International. Money is scattered around the table.

THE SCRIPT -- Announcer: The economic devastation of corporate greed. Executives cooked books to get fat bonuses, as employees lost their jobs and life savings. $400 million in state pension funds lost.

Andrew Cuomo: New York can no longer afford business as usual. As a member of President Clinton's cabinet, I stood up to mortgage rip-offs, gun manufacturers -- even the K.K.K. As governor, I won't do business with companies that don't provide full disclosure. We'll protect pensions and put C.E.O.'s who lie in jail. New times need new leadership.

ACCURACY -- The $400 million refers to State Retirement Fund losses from investments in Enron, WorldCom and Global Crossing. All investors in those companies suffered losses, though independent analysts have given the comptroller's office high marks for its financial strategy. The other claims are supported by press releases from the Department of Housing and Urban Development. The Ku Klux Klan reference derives from the 2000 settlement of a civil suit filed by the Department of Housing and Urban Development against a self-described chaplain of United Klans of America who was accused of harassing a social worker who helped people file housing discrimination complaints.

SCORECARD -- Mr. Cuomo takes a subtle swipe at his opponent with the reference to the state pension fund that Mr. McCall oversees, but it is doubtful that all but the most astute viewers will catch it. But the commercial does provide an effective way to promote one of Mr. Cuomo's main campaign issues, corporate responsibility, which Democrats across the country believe will resonate with voters fed up with the near-daily torrent of news reports about fraud. It remains to be seen, however, if this issue will energize voters and endear them to Mr. Cuomo, who is fighting negative impressions among voters, according to several public opinion polls. Mr. Cuomo also seems to make a play for minority voters, considered Mr. McCall's base, with his reference to fighting the K.K.K. RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD

HEADLINE: Shifting Colombia's Aid: U.S. Focuses on Rebels 

BYLINE:  By JUAN FORERO 

DATELINE: BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 9 

 BODY:
Just as a new president, Alvaro Uribe Velez, begins his term determined to combat Colombia's leftist guerrillas, the Bush administration has delivered a powerful new tool: authorization to use nearly $1.7 billion in American military aid directly against the rebels.
 Under a little-remarked provision in the antiterrorism package President Bush signed last week, President Uribe can now use dozens of American-supplied helicopters as well as Colombian soldiers who were trained by United States troops in operations against the rebels and also right-wing paramilitaries. Previous guidelines limited the use of the helicopters and soldiers to antidrug operations, restricting Colombia's armed forces from using some of its best equipment and troops to fight the rebels. 
 The policy shift, coming at a time of escalating guerrilla violence, represents a significant intensification of United States involvement in the long and intractable conflict in this country. This week the rebels launched a mortar attack here in the capital during Mr. Uribe's inauguration. 
The redirection of aid came after Colombian officials and their American supporters in Congress and the Bush administration argued that the change was part of the global campaign against terrorism. 
American troops will continue to be barred from participating in Colombia's 38-year-old conflict, but the package includes $6 million for an oil pipeline protection program that will involve the training of a new Colombian Army unit by American soldiers. The pipeline, which is crucial to Colombia's economy, is frequently bombed by rebels.
The legislation, part of a broad $28.9 billion supplemental package, says that military aid already provided to Colombia "shall be available" against "activities by organizations designated as terrorist organizations" by the State Department. Those organizations are identified as the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, the country's largest guerrilla group; the National Liberation Army, a smaller left-wing insurgency; and the nemesis of both, the right-wing United Self-Defense Forces of Colombia, which is financed by landowners to battle the rebels. 
All three groups have drawn much of their financing from protecting or participating in the drug trade. Officials in Washington said the new guidelines take into account the reality that drugs and terrorism are combined in Colombia.
"There has been a mistake in trying to identify those who are in drugs and those that are not," said John Walters, the White House drug policy chief. A State Department official said the legislation "removes an ambiguity in the law." He explained that under previous guidelines American-trained troops using American helicopters could not attack a guerrilla column or stop a rebel attack. 
"That has all changed." Now they can go after guerrillas, he said, although the equipment and troops will still be used against drugs. "The equipment is now available for both," he said.
American congressional aides familiar with the legislation said the authorization goes into effect immediately. But there are requirements for Mr. Uribe, a technocrat who won election in May by promising to bring order to Colombia. Under the terms, which the government has accepted, it must devote more money to the army while establishing comprehensive policies to combat drugs, bring government authority to rural areas and ensure respect for human rights.
Colombian officials say the change greatly enhances the army's combat capability. Most of the benefits come from 53 helicopters, 14 of them high-tech Black Hawks, that Colombia's army has received as part of the $1.1 billion Plan Colombia aid package Washington approved in 2000. Another 19 helicopters, all of them Huey II's, will arrive by mid-fall.
The guidelines also mean that Colombia will be able to use a 3,000-man counterdrug brigade trained by American Special Forces directly against the rebels. The brigade has, until now, focused on securing dangerous, drug-controlled regions to allow crop dusters to fumigate without being attacked by rebel forces.
"It will give us more mobility, much more capacity, much more firepower," Francisco Santos, Mr. Uribe's vice president, said in an interview this week. " It helps to change the military balance, and it helps to contain the violent ones."
Bush administration officials emphasize that the equipment and American-trained troops will still primarily be used for counterdrug operations. Congress will decide if $500 million in military and police aid being proposed in 2003 can also be used directly against the rebels. Since 1999, the United States has provided Colombia with $1.7 billion in military aid, making this nation the third-largest recipient of American assistance.
The shift in policy has concerned human rights groups and some members of Congress, who say escalating violence may become a byproduct of the redirected aid.
But it became clear through spring and early summer that a growing number of lawmakers on Capitol Hill had sided with the Bush administration's call for a shift in tactics for two fundamental reasons. The antidrug fight here has not worked as planned, with coca plantings continuing to rise, and there was a general feeling that something drastic needed to be done to help Colombia battle the surging rebels.
Senator Patrick J. Leahy, the chairman of the foreign operations subcommittee and a Vermont Democrat who has criticized American policy toward Colombia, said he supported the legislation because the new policy called for the aid to also be directed against the paramilitaries and requires that human rights conditions be met by Colombian units that use the assistance.
"It is what the majority of Congress is willing to support," he said.

HEADLINE: Reflective Mood Stills Breezy Summer Days 

BYLINE:  By JANE GROSS 

DATELINE: WESTPORT, Conn., Aug. 8 

 BODY:
Martin Olivieri, a chemistry teacher, frets that America could be on the verge of war with Iraq. His brother-in-law, Ken Ricci, a computer consultant, nervously follows the stock market and wonders if he will find himself out of work when a contract ends in a few months. 
 Mr. Olivieri's companion, Elmar Lipp, worries about his immigration status as a German on a work visa. A cousin, Gina Barone, is saddened that security concerns mean no picnicking on the grounds of West Point. And relatives from Sicily almost canceled a summer holiday with the Olivieris living in the United States because of fear of terrorism. 
 Yet three generations of Olivieris gathered at Compo Beach here this week, coming together from the Bronx, Yonkers, Cross River, N.Y., and Italy. They grilled zucchini and peppers as the sky turned opalescent over the Long Island Sound. They laughed, swam and horsed around with the three Ricci children. They knew that the world was a scarier place than it had been a year ago, before the shock of Sept. 11 and the collapsing economy. But they still found summer sweet, and in some ways even sweeter. 
Mr. Lipp, stoking the grill with fresh charcoal, pondered whether the harrowing events of the past year had cast a pall over this most carefree of seasons. "Maybe it enhanced it," he said. "Private things matter more, the sense of calm and security we have as a family. This summer, we went twice to Tanglewood. Who knows what next year will be? So we must make use of our time, enjoy what there is to enjoy." 
For sure, this is a summer like no other for the Olivieris and others throughout the metropolitan region, where the loss of life in the World Trade Center attack touched so many and the jitters on Wall Street spared so few. People are staying closer to home, taking shorter trips and avoiding air travel. Movie attendance is up, and international travel is down. Whether on vacation or in the office, people are following the stock market and the news more closely -- or avoiding both altogether because it is too much to bear. 
The idea of a carefree summer seems a thing of the past to Sally Silvers, a choreographer who lives in the East Village and went on vacation this summer in Bermuda, where she had a one-week reprieve from the drumbeat of bad news, and in Cape May, N.J., where American flags flew everywhere. "Carefree doesn't seem to be on the horizon," Ms. Silvers said. "There's too much going on. I don't know when that's coming back, if ever."
This summer brought dislocations, major and minor, good and bad. 
Lisa Grenadier, sunbathing here at Compo Beach, in prosperous Fairfield County, said that her inheritance had dwindled to the point that her 13-year-old son's college fund and her own retirement savings were in jeopardy. Her husband, a writer, might have to take a teaching job, she said, and this could be her last summer lazing, jobless, on the beach. A vacation in Santa Barbara, Calif., was shorter than it might have been and was spent in a less expensive hotel than usual.
A canceled European vacation, "mainly because of the economy but also because we were a little skittish because of terrorism," opened new vistas for Deborah Dudley of Brooklyn, an art director for the Center for Reproductive Law and Policy in Lower Manhattan. Instead, Ms. Dudley, her husband and 2-year-old daughter made short trips to visit the grandparents and attended to family business -- writing wills and discussing powers of attorney, debating the timing of another child -- that felt more pressing after Sept. 11. 
Knowing she would be home all summer, Ms. Dudley also took a plot in a community garden, grew herbs and reawakened her interest in cooking. Planting and harvesting were a far cry from touring Germany and Ireland, her family's original plan. But the results were unexpectedly pleasant. "I would have focused on planning, traveling and recovering," Ms. Dudley said. "So in that sense, my summer was definitely easier and more relaxing."
Rosemary and Steve Halstead, who took early retirement from executive positions at Citibank and I.B.M., stayed home this summer so their college-age son did not turn their Westport home into "party central," Mrs. Halstead said. Still, the lessons of Sept. 11 made a miracle of a quiet day at Compo Beach. "What 9/11 said to me is that simple things are more important," she said. 
Her husband, looking up from a kayaking magazine, agreed. "It's easier now to pause and smell the roses rather than feel compulsive about having to go somewhere and do something," he said. "A lot of people who used to go, go, go all the time now find this more fulfilling." 
Not everyone found the changed contours of summer so pleasing. Teresa Rose Darcy, a florist from Edison, N.J., used to do things like take spontaneous trips to Hawaii with her daughter. Not in this bear market. Instead, she will soon be driving to Saratoga, N.Y., to visit family and go to the track, without betting. Overall, Ms. Darcy said, this season had a "darker feeling" than summers past. "There is all this bad news floating around that really can turn a good day bad," she said.
Several people commented that the patriotic holidays were celebrated with a new sincerity. Gina Barone, a parochial school teacher who is part of the Olivieri clan, said that the most significant difference this summer for her had been the Fourth of July. "People were so much more expressive," she said.
Maureen DeLouise of the Bronx, an administrative assistant for the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, said that the annual Independence Day block party on Tomlinson Avenue had never been better attended. "It used to be, 'Oh, it's July Fourth, big deal,' " she said. "Now, to be an American, we're more aware of what those words mean." 
The stock market plunge, and the loss of faith in corporate leadership, seemed to weigh heavier on beachgoers here than fear of new terrorist attacks, perhaps because it was fresher in their minds and so personal in its consequences. But this week, when a spell of oppressive weather gave way to cloudless cobalt skies, it could have been Sept. 11 all over again. 
Ms. Grenadier was walking along the water here, as she had been that terrible morning when smoke blackened the sky between the Norwalk Islands. She felt the similarity between that day and this one before clear thoughts formed: The color of the sky. The slant of the light. The cool air on her skin. 
"You have these sense memories, and that is one that will live with us forever," she said. "We'll never be able to totally enjoy those beautiful cloudless days again."

HEADLINE: Turbulent Times for Airlines 

 BODY:
Last fall's $15 billion aid package for the nation's airline industry was a bold move within days of the Sept. 11 attacks to shore up the nation's transportation system. The $5 billion in grants helped airlines weather their unprecedented grounding, and the $10 billion loan guarantee program, by its mere creation, served as a form of terrorism insurance that helped airlines tap capital markets in subsequent months. 
 Almost a year later, it is important to remember that airlines were facing serious financial troubles well before Sept. 11. The government's extraordinary intervention was meant to address the attacks' aftermath, not to resolve all the industry's pre-existing woes. The Air Transportation Stabilization Board, with representatives from the Federal Reserve, the Treasury and the Transportation Department, must be guided by this principle as it assesses the applications filed by the June deadline. 
 The board should reject the application of United Airlines, the nation's second-largest carrier, for a $1.8 billion guarantee. Though deeply troubled, United still has enough resources to pursue other options, and has not proposed to undertake enough cost-cutting measures to deserve a bailout. Other airlines have shown that it's possible to obtain private financing, and have not sought federal loan guarantees. Taxpayers should not be asked to give United an unfair competitive advantage. 
So far the board has proved a tough guardian of taxpayer interests, and it must now resist heavy Congressional lobbying on United's behalf. It has turned away a number of smaller airlines, and approved America West's request for a $360 million guarantee only after the carrier granted Uncle Sam an option to acquire a third of its stock. 
Last month US Airways, the most beleaguered of the major carriers, became only the second airline to obtain a loan guarantee, for $900 million. It was conditioned on the airline's labor unions' approving painfully deep but needed concessions, without which US Airways might founder. United's unions have not been willing to consider equally significant sacrifices. And unlike United, US Airways lacks unencumbered assets to help it secure private financing. 
United and US Airways also want to enter into a marketing alliance, one that regulators should allow. This page supported the airlines' proposed merger last year, which was blocked by the government. The industry's continuing troubles make the need for consolidation more apparent than ever.
Even after accounting for the federal aid, the airline industry lost a record $11 billion last year, and the tide of red ink is not yet ebbing. Currently, among the eight largest carriers, only low-cost Southwest Airlines is breaking even.
Passenger loads have not returned to their pre-Sept.-11 levels, and the economic slowdown has kept away the most profitable business travelers. But major airlines like United can also blame their unsustainable cost structures, and equally unrealistic pricing models, for their financial troubles. Regardless of the economic climate, the days are ending when airlines can automatically charge passengers not staying over a Saturday night five times more than those who do.
The industry is evolving into two tiers, with fewer coast-to-coast megacarriers and a greater number of nimble niche players, like the increasingly successful JetBlue, that are modeled after Southwest. These airlines are providing travelers with meaningful new choices and competitive fares. The government should not block this evolution.

HEADLINE: HORSE RACING; 
Saratoga Yearling Sales Fall 44 Percent From '01

BYLINE:  By JASON DIAMOS 

DATELINE: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 9 

 BODY:
With gross sales down 44 percent from last year's record figures, almost everyone involved in this week's Fasig-Tipton Saratoga Selected Yearlings Sale agreed that the market was depressed this year. Not everyone agreed on why.
 "We are missing some stars at the top and missing some people, one in particular," Walt Robertson, the president of Fasig-Tipton, said, referring to the absence of foals from Seattle Slew, who died in early May, and Mr. Prospector, who died in 1999, as well as the death last month of Prince Ahmed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia, a leading buyer at the upper echelon of thoroughbred sales for years. 
 "And I think the economy is responsible for some people lowering their sights," Robertson added.
This year 140 horses sold for $35,242,000 during the three-day sales. Last year 162 horses sold for $62,412,000. The average price this year was $251,729, off 35 percent from last year's average of $385,259. This year's median price, $180,000, was down more than 23 percent from last year's median price of $235,000.
That continued a trend seen last month at the Keeneland select sales, where the average price, $481,184, was down more than 31 percent from last year's record average, $710,247, and where the median price declined about 29 percent, to $300,000 from $427,500.
"What has happened," the trainer D. Wayne Lukas said, "is that people have become much more sophisticated in their selection process, and have therefore become more critical of what they want to take a run at and what they want to leave alone. This was a great selection of horses. I think it was the best selection of horses they ever had. Having said that, I also think a lot of people zeroed in on 50 to 60 lots and the others suffered because of that."
Lukas purchased 11 yearlings for his owners, including a $950,000 colt by Forestry out of the Conquistador Cielo mare Alexandrina on Thursday night, the final night of the sales. Lukas had underbid on a son of Unbridled's Song that went to Aaron and Marie Jones for $1 million and a son of Grand Slam that went to John Oxley for $900,000.
A Storm Cat filly out of Sacahuista brought this year's highest single price, the $1.3 million paid by John Sikura on Wednesday. Last year a son of Storm Cat brought $3.3 million from Sheik Mohammed bin Rashid al-Maktoum.
Last year nine yearlings sold for $1 million or more. This year two did. Last year there were eight buyers who spent more than $2 million. This year there was one, Satish and Anne Sanan's Padua Stable of Ocala, Fla. That does not include the $3.8 million buyback of the full brother to Forestry that Robert Evans took back on Wednesday.
Duncan Taylor, whose family's Kentucky firm, Taylor Made, is one of the industry's leading consignors of horses for sale, said he felt the market was depressed this year "mostly at the very top end." Taylor Made had brought the Evans colt to the sale.
"There are not as many million-dollar horses," said Taylor, who pointed to the decline in the stock market, a cutback in Sheik Mohammed's activity and the death of the prince as reasons. "But the two hundred-, three hundred- and four hundred-thousand-dollar horses are still selling. So I think the industry itself is healthy."
Bill Farish, the president of Lane's End farm, one of the premier Kentucky breeding operations, agreed with Taylor.
"I think it is a little bit of a depressed market," Farish said. "The big Arab and Irish buyers have not been as active as they usually are, and that really hurts the top end of the market. But we've been happy with the middle market."
As for the absence of chart-topping purchases by the sheik and the bigger Irish buyers at this year's sale, Farish said, "They've focused in on a few very narrow type horses they look for." Horses, Farish said, with sires like Storm Cat and Sadler's Wells.
"Every sale can't have 15 Storm Cats," Robertson said. "Had we sold two horses for $3 million, what would our average have been then?"
Last year three horses sold for $3 million or more.
The trainer Nick Zito said he felt Fasig-Tipton had slightly compromised the August sales because of its July sales in Kentucky. "You've got 220-something horses in this sale, and out of that there were probably 10 outstanding horses," he said.
About the economy's impact on the sales, Zito said: "What is it that you read about in the papers every day? Criminals. Scandals. Which meant it wasn't real money to begin with."
There was real money here this week. It was just not spent in record numbers.

FINISH LINES
Celtic Sky caught the front-running Reluctant Groom at the wire to win the 23rd running of the $75,000 West Point for New York breds by a nose at a mile and an eighth on the turf in Friday's feature race. Ridden by JOSE SANTOS and trained by CHRISTOPHE CLEMENT, Celtic Sky returned $8.40 on a $2 bet to win.

HEADLINE: U.S. Seeks to Limit Environmental Law's Reach Over Coastal Waters 

BYLINE:  By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 

 BODY:
The Bush administration is arguing that a major environmental law does not apply to the vast majority of oceans under United States control, a move that environmentalists say could allow military maneuvers, oil and gas pipelines, commercial fishing, ocean dumping and scores of other activities to escape public environmental review.
 In a federal court case in Los Angeles that involves the testing of a new type of sonar system by the Navy, the Justice Department said that the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969 -- landmark legislation that requires federal agencies to review the environmental implications of their projects -- did not apply beyond the nation's territorial waters, which traditionally extend three miles from shore. 
 That view is being challenged by the Natural Resources Defense Council, which asserts that in addition to the territorial waters, the act covers all activity within the nation's "exclusive economic zone," which extends 200 miles from shore.
A decision in the case is expected later in the summer. 
Environmentalists say that barring application of the act in these zones would open up the oceans to unregulated activity that could damage them and destroy marine life.
In addition to the sonar project, which they say could disorient and kill whales and dolphins, they say other unregulated activity would include commercial fishing for depleted species, proposals for liquified natural gas plants and pipelines, and other energy projects.
Offshore oil and gas drilling would not be affected by the administration's position because another law, the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act, specifically requires that the environmental law apply to such activity.
At issue is the National Environmental Policy Act, often referred to as the Magna Carta of environmental law. Signed by President Richard M. Nixon on Jan. 1, 1970, the act requires all federal governmental actions to be reviewed and analyzed for their effect on the environment.
In an indication of the importance of the matter, the White House Council on Environmental Quality convened with ranking officials from five agencies and departments to discuss the implications of the Justice Department's position both before the department filed its brief and then again this week, administration officials said. They plan to discuss it further in September.
Administration officials said there was little disagreement at the meeting, which was first reported today by The Times-Picayune of New Orleans, about the administration's approach. And the Justice Department has argued in the sonar case that federal agencies should decide case by case whether to apply the National Environmental Policy Act in the oceans.
But e-mail messages written before the meeting suggested that officials from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration disagreed with the Navy.
One message written by a Navy official hailed the "good news" that the Justice Department agreed with the Navy, "over NOAA objection," that the environmental law "does NOT extend beyond the limits of our territorial waters."
Administration officials said that the Justice Department position and the meeting did not represent a change of policy, but environmentalists disagreed.
"This is a major policy change," said Andrew Wetzler, a lawyer with the Natural Resources Defense Council in Los Angeles. "For the first time, the White House is considering stepping in and seeking to impose the Navy's restrictive view of the statute on the entire federal government."
The Navy has long believed that the act does not extend to activities conducted within the nation's "exclusive economic zone," which stretches 200 miles off all coastal waters and thus covers more than one million square miles off all American coasts, including those of Alaska and Hawaii. The Navy appears to be the driving force behind the Bush administration's discussion of whether to apply that concept to all federal activity in the zone. 
Administration officials believe that the environmental act is too restrictive, that it spawns nettlesome lawsuits and that most ocean activity is already regulated by an executive order signed in 1979 by President Jimmy Carter, according to administration officials and internal e-mail correspondence that was obtained by environmental groups opposing the administration's view.
Environmental groups assert that the Carter executive order is too weak to guarantee enforcement. They say it does not provide for lawsuits or public review, meaning that an array of damaging activities could take place far out at sea without public knowledge or recourse.
Michael Jasny, a senior policy analyst at the Natural Resources Defense Council in Los Angeles, said that the National Environmental Policy Act "depends on public comment and public scrutiny and judicial review for its effectiveness, and if you do away with it, all of that would be lost -- we'd have no public accountability" about military and industrial activities in the oceans.
Tim Eichenberg, a lawyer with Oceana, a group in San Francisco dedicated to preserving the oceans, called the executive order "a very poor cousin" to the policy act.
"The executive order doesn't provide for public input or any analysis of alternatives and it doesn't allow for judicial review -- there is no recourse for the public," he argued.
Administration officials said that their position in the California case did not represent a change of policy. They said that the National Environmental Policy Act, signed into law before the United States established its exclusive economic zones, was never intended to apply to the ocean beyond the territorial waters and did not apply now.
But an internal Navy document contradicts that view, noting that the Justice Department and the Council on Environmental Quality in the Clinton administration "pressed to apply N.E.P.A. worldwide."
Senator John Kerry, the Massachusetts Democrat and chairman of a subcommittee on oceans and fisheries, issued a statement saying: "I am incredulous that the Bush administration may actually be considering rolling back central environmental protections of our oceans and marine environment. The National Environmental Policy Act is the cornerstone of protection for our citizens and natural resources -- and new limits on the law would have profound impacts on coastal issues from fisheries management to marine protection to ocean dumping."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Michael Jasny, right, of the Natural Resources Defense Council, in San Francisco with lawyers Andrew Sabey, left, and Andrew Wetzler. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: World Business Briefing Americas: Mexico: Apple Dumping Duties 

BYLINE:  By Ginger Thompson (NYT) 

 BODY:
 Mexico's economic minister, Luis Ernesto Derbez, said the government would impose a 40 percent tariff on fresh apples imported from the United States because American growers were selling the fruit at unfairly low prices, hurting Mexican growers. Consuming $118 million worth a year, Mexico accounts for about 30 percent of American exports of fresh apples. Mr. Derbez also said that he would ask Congress to pass a law that would give President Vicente Fox a kind of fast-track authority to impose antidumping duties on other products. HEADLINE: Palestinians Say Sharon Is Trying to Undercut U.S. Talks 

BYLINE:  By JOHN KIFNER 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Aug. 9 

 BODY:
Palestinian officials today accused Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of trying to sabotage their talks in Washington with a tough speech on Thursday in which he called the Palestinian Authority "a gang of corrupt terrorists and assassins."
 Lashing back, the Palestinian cabinet secretary, Ahmed Abdel Rahman, called Mr. Sharon's government "a coalition of terror and a gang of killers." 
 "He wanted to intimidate the Americans and to warn them against reaching any agreement with the Palestinian delegation by describing the Palestinian Authority officials as people against peace," Mr. Abdel Rahman said. "If we are like that, why are we in the States, now exerting every possible effort to reach a way out?" 
A delegation appointed by Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader -- with whom President Bush says he will not deal -- met on Thursday with Secretary of State Colin L. Powell and the national security adviser, Condoleezza Rice. 
At the same time, Mr. Sharon went on national television with a speech that his advisers said was meant to prepare Israel for a long struggle.
"We can't hold talks with the gang of terrorists that is the Palestinian Authority," Mr. Sharon said. "Rooting them out is the only way to reach peace."
Nabil Abu Rudeineh, a close adviser to Mr. Arafat, said today that Mr. Sharon's "declarations hamper international efforts to come back to the political process."
"Sharon's declarations are suitable to most Israeli officials who are war criminals and who must face international justice and be tried for the crimes they perpetrated against our people," Mr. Abu Rudeineh said.
Mr. Sharon's speech, Israeli political commentators said, was also meant to enhance his popularity, which has fallen recently.
Throughout the spring he was riding high in opinion polls, mainly because of his tough actions against the Palestinians, including the military incursion into West Bank areas ceded to Palestinian control under the Oslo accords of 1993 and 1995.
But polls published today in the newspaper Yediot Ahronot were headlined "Sharon Does Not Know How to Get Rid of Terrorism."
The numbers were grim. Does Sharon know how to eliminate the attacks? Yes, 36 percent; no, 60 percent. Since the Sharon government took office, who has been winning? Israel, 30 percent; Palestinians, 33 percent; neither, 30 percent. How long will the attacks last? A year, 28 percent; two years or more, 53 percent. Will attacks diminish? Diminish, 16 percent; increase, 67 percent.
"We are condemned to live with the terror attacks for years to come," Sever Plotzker wrote in the newspaper, summing up the poll. "Condemned to bleed and fear."
The mutual recriminations continued, too, over a breakdown in talks this week about a possible security plan to ease pressure on the Palestinians, whose economy and very lives have been disrupted by the Israeli takeover of the West Bank.
Defense Minister Benjamin Ben-Eliezer has put forward what he calls the "Gaza first" plan, in which Palestinians would begin by taking responsibility for stopping attackers from entering Israeli by way of the Gaza Strip. But the Palestinians accuse the Israelis of reneging on an offer to extend the trial to a West Bank city, probably Bethlehem, which has been quiet.
Much of the wrangling is regarded as political posturing on both sides. Indeed, any such initiative would face internal opposition among the fragmented leadership on both sides. 
That is particularly true of the Palestinians. Mr. Arafat's decision to have his aides meet with the Israelis this week -- an apparent effort to reclaim his diminishing relevance -- is being criticized not only by the militants in groups like Hamas and Islamic Jihad but also by his own base in Al Fatah.
The elements of a security plan have been endlessly rehashed, including the possibility of C.I.A. training of Palestinian security units or participation by intelligence agencies of Egypt and Jordan, both frowned on by human rights organizations. The difficulty with any such plan would be that it would require the Palestinians to be, in effect, the guarantors of Israel's security. Given the present emotional climate, that is an unlikely role.
On the ground here, today was what is now regarded as relatively quiet, with only one death, that of a 40-year-old Palestinian, Husni Damiri, shot by the Israeli Army in the Tulkarm refugee camp. 
As usual, accounts varied. Palestinians said he had been standing in his doorway when the Israelis imposed a curfew. The Israeli Army spokesman said soldiers had been shooting at a group of armed men when he was hit.
But nerves remained raw. The Israeli newspapers have been filled for days with speculation that President Saddam Hussein of Iraq might supply Palestinian militants with biological weapons, and there have been articles about whether there is a need for smallpox vaccine.
There were also warnings that gas masks from the Persian Gulf war of 1991 were now obsolete.
A settlers' road south of Jerusalem was shut for several hours today after soldiers fired at what were described as suspicious figures. It was later reported that they were shepherds, carrying crooks.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Bush Adopts New Rules For Medical Data Privacy
The Bush administration formally rolled back some major protections for the privacy of medical records adopted by President Bill Clinton. But at the same time, it also set new standards for the use of personal data to market prescription drugs and other health care products.
 The rules, the first comprehensive federal standards for medical privacy, will affect virtually every doctor, patient, hospital, drugstore, health insurance company and medical researcher in the United States. The rules embody more than five years of work and have the force of law. Page A1. 

European Airlines Alter Fares
This summer, British Airways, the largest airline in Europe, has done what almost no American full-service carrier has been willing to do: radically simplify its fare structure to keep business travelers from defecting to low-cost competitors. Other big European airlines are doing the same. A1.

MyTravel Group of Britain disclosed plans for a low-cost airline, intensifying competition for European leisure air travelers. C3.

Deal for Global Crossing Is Reached
Global Crossing and its creditors agreed to sell control of the company for $250 million to Hutchison Whampoa of Hong Kong and Singapore Technologies Telemedia. Creditors had rejected an earlier bid of $750 million. C3.

Microsoft Shares Stage With Linux
Microsoft will have a booth at the LinuxWorld Expo show next week. Its appearance may be construed as an olive branch, for Microsoft is seen as an enemy of the freely distributed Linux operating system. C2.

Ex-Lawmakers Lobby on Tax Bill
An armada of former lawmakers are suddenly lobbying against efforts in Congress to crack down on companies that shift their addresses offshore to lower their tax bills. A1.

Analyst Attended Board Meetings
Jack B. Grubman, the Salomon Smith Barney stock analyst who is under fire for his close ties to companies whose stocks he rated for investors, attended at least 10 corporate board meetings in four years, the firm has told a Congressional committee in a letter. Still, at least one lawmaker threatened to subpoena the firm for additional records. C2.

Emulex Shares Plunge on Forecast
Emulex, a maker of circuit cards for data-storage systems, said sales in its current fiscal year would fall short of analysts' estimates and its stock fell 35 percent. Sales will be $305 million to $325 million in the year, which began July 1, the chief financial officer, Michael Rockenbach, said. Analysts expected Emulex to have sales of $335.6 million. Its shares fell $8.34, to $15.27. C4.

Japan to Keep Surplus in Market
The Bank of Japan left its monetary policy unchanged. Though stock prices are near 18-year lows and the recovery is showing some signs of slowing, the central bank said it will continue to keep a surplus of as much as 15 trillion yen ($125 billion) in the money markets. C3.

Profit Jumps at Berkshire Hathaway
Berkshire Hathaway, the investment company led by the billionaire investor Warren E. Buffett, posted a 35 percent increase in second-quarter profit. C4.

Merrill Disagrees With S.E.C.
Merrill Lynch said in a filing that staff members of the Securities and Exchange Commission had "expressed concerns" about its role in the collapse of Enron. "We disagree with the views they have expressed to us and are in the process of responding," Merrill said. C2.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; 
Europeans Try Air Fares Without the Fine Print

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WONG 

DATELINE: LONDON 

 BODY:
The ads in the Underground are as subtle as the barking of a sideshow huckster. "You won't believe your eyes," they scream. Then come the prices: the equivalent of $107 round-trip to Paris, $154 to Marseilles, $201 to Lisbon.
 Those tickets on British Airways do not have to be bought in advance, do not require a Saturday night stay and are up to 80 percent cheaper than almost comparable fares two months ago. On most of the carrier's domestic and European flights, a traveler can walk up to the counter and buy a discounted ticket until a limited number of seats at those prices sell out. 
 This summer, British Airways, the largest airline in Europe, has done what almost no American full-service carrier has been willing to do, despite the industry's enormous losses: radically simplify its fare structure to keep business travelers from defecting to low-cost competitors. 
Other big European airlines are doing the same. KLM is paring to 8, from 25, the fare classes on 66 European routes, a change that includes replacing the Saturday-night-stay requirement with a two-night minimum stay. Lufthansa has cut off-peak fares on unrestricted, economy-class tickets in Germany up to 63 percent. SAS Scandinavian Airlines and bmi british midland have also retooled their fare structures.
It is too soon to tell whether the changes -- all sharp breaks from 20 years of pricing tradition -- foreshadow savings for business travelers in America. Airlines in the United States have tinkered with prices and minimum-stay rules on a handful of competitive routes. Yet even as they battle for market share with Southwest Airlines and its low-cost counterparts, they have generally been reluctant to make it easy for business people to get cheap fares.
But if an airline like British Airways, which is struggling financially, decides to extend its simplified fare structure to trans-Atlantic routes, that could force the hand of carriers in the United States. Already, domestic airlines are studying the new European pricing systems, as well as other strategies that are being used here.
"We look competitively at every step that's taken," said Leo F. Mullin, the chief executive of Delta Air Lines.
 Delta has also been examining how Europe's full-service airlines run their own low-cost carriers, and on Thursday it made an announcement hinting that it could start up such an operation by next year. 
Many of the giant European carriers still shoulder high costs that limit how aggressively they can compete with upstarts. And the airlines' ultimate goal has not changed: filling the most possible seats at the highest possible prices. 
But industry experts, not to mention passengers, are praising the European airlines for at least trying to fix complex fare structures that have driven many travelers to low-cost carriers or other modes of transportation.
"British Airways is ahead of the curve in recognizing the competitive threat that discount carriers pose to them," said Jonathan Schrader, an analyst at Morningstar. "Domestic carriers here in the U.S. recognize it but are not in long-term crisis mode to fight it. British Airways is attacking it head-on, which is something they should be applauded for."
Low-cost European carriers like Ryanair and easyJet started in the 1990's after studying Southwest's business model. By last year, four low-cost airlines carried 16 million passengers to and from Britain, according to the Civil Aviation Authority here -- up 26 percent from a year earlier. Such carriers will carry a quarter of the passengers in Europe by 2010, a fivefold increase from today, according to Mercer Management Consulting.
That trend has British Airways on the ropes. For the year through March, it lost $348 million on short-haul flights, largely because of low-cost competitors, said Martin George, the airline's director of marketing. 
Faced with such bleak numbers, British Airways decided it had to remake its fare structure. In April, it dropped Saturday-night-stay and advance-purchase requirements on 18 of its 189 routes within Britain and the rest of Europe. By the end of the summer, the new model will be in place for all such flights -- London to Rome and London to Glasgow, for example -- and British Airways will have cut its 26 fare categories to a dozen, all without restrictions.
Only a limited number of seats can be bought at the lowest fares, especially during peak hours. And the cheapest seats are still more expensive than no-frills competitors' prices on the same routes. For example, a London-Frankfurt round trip costs a minimum of $115 on British Airways, compared with $55 on Ryanair.
But Ryanair uses secondary airports, and British Airways' coupling of convenience and lower fares is winning back some travelers. The carrier said the number of passengers on its domestic flights is up 15 percent from a year ago.
"I've gone back to buying tickets on British Airways," said Krishan Arora, an executive at the BBC who has flown throughout Europe on all the major low-cost airlines. "It's more to do with the relaxing conditions. They always had this Saturday-night rule, and now that's gone, and the prices in some cases are closer to the low-cost airlines." 
Like their European counterparts, full-service airlines in the United States -- which lost $1.4 billion in the second quarter -- are finally acknowledging that they need to learn from their no-frills competitors. Last summer, some carriers began offering sales that dropped Saturday-night-stay requirements on selected routes and ticket types. This week, American Airlines and Northwest Airlines cut unrestricted walk-up fares on some routes by as much as 40 percent.
But the only carrier in the United States to really overhaul its fare structure is America West Airlines. In late March, it ended its Saturday-night-stay rule and simplified its fares. Now, walk-up tickets cost about double the lowest-priced ones instead of five times as much, similar to the structure at Southwest. For example, the price range on a flight from Boston to San Diego has narrowed to $364 to $842, from $362 to $1,488 before March.
Full-service competitors have retaliated not by changing their own fare structures, but by cutting prices on flights to Phoenix and Las Vegas, America West's two hubs. 
Jim Sabourin, a spokesman for America West, said there were signs that the new fare structure was working. In the second quarter, the carrier's revenue per available seat mile, a standard industry benchmark, fell 6.7 percent from a year earlier, better than the average industry decline of 10 percent. 
Mr. Sabourin said it was a challenge to maintain the simplified fare structure while still offering frills to customers -- food, for instance -- and operating from major airport hubs. Other airline executives say that teasing out the best way to overhaul fares is far from easy.
"I'm still waiting for someone to come up and tell me how to price my fares efficiently," said Gordon M. Bethune, the chief executive of Continental Airlines, which offers dozens of arcane fare combinations. 
Some analysts wonder whether British Airways can sustain its new fare structure, given the carrier's high costs. It has made some in-roads on cost-cutting, having reduced its fleet size and eliminated 10,000 jobs. Last week, it reported a first-quarter pretax profit of $101 million, up 63 percent from a year earlier.
But British Airways has not renegotiated wages or work rules with its unions, as some analysts say it must. And it intends to maintain its current level of premium services: flying from leading airports, providing lounges for frequent-fliers and offering free drinks and food.
"I see no evidence whatsoever that British Airways has done anything about their cost structure," said Daniel Solon, a senior airline consultant at Avmark International in London. "I happen to believe it's a very important competitive difference."
Besides remaking their fare structures, the big European carriers have turned with varying success to operating no-frills airlines themselves. KLM has Buzz and Basiq, Virgin Atlantic Airways runs Virgin Express, bmi british midland recently set up bmibaby and Lufthansa is considering a similar move. British Airways founded Go in 1998 before selling it two years later.
In the last decade, American carriers like Continental, US Airways and United Airlines have tried and abandoned the strategy. But experts said those efforts generally were tied too closely to the operations of their parent carriers, unlike in Europe. Delta faces similar problems with its stagnant Delta Express, but nonetheless seems to be leaning toward starting another low-cost carrier. 
Whether airlines in the United States will adopt the fare innovations from across the Atlantic is another matter. But industry experts say the carriers need to try something. 
"The airline executives are arrogant," said Joe Brancatelli, an on-line travel columnist who specializes in tracking air fares. "When it comes to business, they don't want to hear anything. But the market has spoken. Those who adjust will profit; those who don't will continue to lose money."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Carriers like easyJet, which placed this billboard in the London Underground this week, have forced bigger airlines to simplify fare structures. (Jonathan Player for The New York Times)(pg. C3)

HEADLINE: Candidate for Lieutenant Governor Facing Scrutiny Over Business Dealings 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

 BODY:
H. Carl McCall's choice for lieutenant governor, Dennis Mehiel, has thrived at running companies on the brink, amassing considerable wealth in the process.
The rewards of his success, federal records show, have also included several loans at below-market interest rates, somewith no interest at all, from the companies he controls. 
 The practice is legal, but the recent wave of corporate scandals has made it highly controversial. Congress recently passed, and President Bush signed, a bill that will prohibit such loans for companies whose stock is publicly traded, but that would not apply to Mr. Mehiel's companies, which are privately held. 
 Nonetheless, in the current corporate climate, the business practices of a candidate are considered fair political game. And, indeed, Mr. Mehiel's opponent in the Sept. 10 Democratic primary, Charles King, made an issue this week of Mr. Mehiel's loans and other business dealings, likening Mr. Mehiel's practices to those of corporate bogeymen in companies like Tyco and WorldCom.
Mr. King said Mr. Mehiel should be held accountable for the way he operates his companies, even if they are not affected by the new corporate laws.
"Clearly, the loans have all been legal, but that doesn't mean that they are right," Mr. King said. "Congress and the president have rejected that as a bad business practice, and Dennis has said, 'Judge me on my business record.' "
By his own account, Mr. Mehiel (pronounced MEEL) has grown wealthy in a high-risk corporate field. For decades he has specialized in taking over troubled companies, often from bankruptcy, eventually folding them into his existing companies. His enterprises have grown rapidly, mostly by such acquisitions. Because his companies are privately held, it is very difficult to estimate his personal net worth, and Mr. Mehiel said he did not know it. 
It is his wealth that heightens interest in the race for lieutenant governor, a primary contest that usually draws yawns. But this year, political analysts believe the choice could influence the results in November.
Candidates for governor and lieutenant governor compete separately in primaries, and those who win the primaries run together as a ticket in the general election. Mr. Mehiel is unofficially tied to Mr. McCall, while Mr. King is closely allied with Andrew M. Cuomo, Mr. McCall's primary opponent. Mr. McCall lags far behind the Republican incumbent, Gov. George E. Pataki, in fund-raising, but in the fall campaign, Mr. Mehiel's wealth could partially level the playing field.
Mr. Mehiel entered politics after years of using his wealth to support others. Since the beginning of 1999, Mr. Mehiel and companies he controls have given Democratic campaigns in New York state at least $396,000 in cash or in-kind contributions (services like holding fund-raisers or allowing the use of a corporate jet). He has also lent his own campaign more than $1.1 million.
The full picture of Mr. Mehiel's companies is murky, because their stock is not publicly traded, so most of them do not file financial reports with the Securities and Exchange Commission. But as Mr. Mehiel acknowledges, his companies operate on very thin profit margins, they carry significant debts and their bonds are rated as junk.
"The wolf's always been at my door," he said. "I've always run a highly leveraged business."
That explains many of the transactions between his companies, he said -- the credit of his main firms is "too ugly" to borrow the money needed to acquire new property or companies. So he creates a smaller entity with stronger credit to take on the debt. For instance, he said, he created a company solely to buy a jet, putting up the collateral and cash himself, and his bigger companies pay that company to use the jet. This practice has been cast in a negative light, in the case of publicly held companies like Enron, where it was used to funnel cash from one entity to another, inflate profits and hide debts.
But finance experts say there are significant differences between Mr. Mehiel's dealings and those of the foundering corporate giants. Foremost is that his companies are privately held and he is the majority owner -- in some cases the sole owner -- so that the transactions are akin to taking money out of one pants pocket and putting it in another. Mr. Mehiel does not carry the entire risk -- he has thousands of employees, bondholders, and a handful of other shareholders, including some pension funds -- but he bears most of it.
"There's no indication that any of these things were not on the up-and-up, and you frequently have this sort of thing with privately held companies," said Cynthia Werneth, a Standard & Poor's analyst who has studied Mr. Mehiel's holdings. "But when you have these kinds of deals, there's always a risk of things not occurring at arm's length."
Mr. Mehiel says that, in fact, that his companies have taken a number of unusual steps to prevent such abuses, and that the public documents that exist support his claims. "I'm the poster child for doing things 180 degrees opposite" from the companies tainted by scandal, he said.
Mr. Mehiel's best-known property is the Sweetheart Cup Company, bought in 1998 by SF Holdings Group, of which he and his former wife own 72 percent. SF Holdings reported $1.3 billion in sales and just $3.3 million in net income in the fiscal year that ended last September, and well over $500 million in long-term debt.
SF Holdings paid Mr. Mehiel, its chairman and chief executive, $1,075,576 in salary and bonus, and $409,960 for "personal expenses," which were not detailed.
For decades, Mr. Mehiel's main holding was Box USA, a major manufacturer of cardboard boxes of which he was the sole owner, chairman and chief executive. The company has not been required to file with the S.E.C. since 1997. Mr. Mehiel sold 49 percent of the company two years ago, and is no longer involved in its day-to-day operations.
Currently, he has a loan of more than $300,000 from SF Holdings, at 5.06 percent interest. In the mid-1990's, he had zero-interest loans of $1.5 million and $800,000 from Box USA, which he repaid, and there have been other loans, as well. Several times over the years, his companies have bought and sold materials and services from each other.
SF Holdings's board of directors includes prominent people from outside the company. Mr. Mehiel said the board must approve deals involving him or one of his companies. It includes John A. Catsimatidis, whose business empire includes the Red Apple supermarkets, and former Lt. Gov. Alfred B. DelBello. That degree of semi-independent review does not exist at most privately held firms. The company also voluntarily accounts for stock options as an expense. Many companies to not do that, making profits appear larger.
