HEADLINE: Modern Twilight 

BYLINE:  By Brooke Allen; Brooke Allen reviews frequently for The New Criterion, The Wall Street Journal and The Atlantic Monthly.

 BODY:
 THE MAN WHO RODE AMPERSAND
By Ferdinand Mount.
245 pp. New York:
Carroll & Graf Publishers. $25.
FERDINAND MOUNT, currently the editor of The Times Literary Supplement, is also the author of nine novels, five of them forming a linked sequence called "A Chronicle of Modern Twilight," which began in 1975 and whose most recent installment, "Fairness," was published just last year. Following the enthusiastic reception of that book, the first volume of the series, "The Man Who Rode Ampersand," is being released in the United States for the first time. A short and remarkably accomplished novel, it will be a treat both for newcomers to Mount's work and for those who are already familiar with it -- though the latter, unfortunately, are a small group, since Mount has always been better known in Britain than he is here.
The novel (like the others in the sequence) is narrated by Gus Cotton, a midlevel civil servant, and the title character is Gus's father, Harry, a jockey who, after one glorious moment on the back of the great racehorse Ampersand, drifts vaguely through the rest of his life: working as a barman in a rackety London club; falling in love with a Jewish woman of Polish-German ancestry and visiting her in Europe as the Nazis rise to power; fighting in North Africa during World War II; getting a rather disreputable government job recruiting Irish workers for English factories. Harry Cotton is an attractive character in spite of his passivity, or possibly because of it. His is a detached, disinterested sensibility in the middle of a greedy and violent age.
Mount's uncle by marriage was Anthony Powell, the author of another chronicle of modern twilight, the brilliant novel sequence "A Dance to the Music of Time," and Powell has clearly exerted a major influence on Mount's work. The two writers' books display a similar, slightly tortured perspective on the past, a combination of nostalgia and dyspepsia. Stylistically, too, Mount and Powell are similar. Neither could ever be called experimental, but they have both stretched the English language (of which they are masters) to its limits, producing a rich, almost clotted prose.
Mount's sheer virtuosity dates him. No one born since World War II could produce such unapologetically mandarin writing without frequent spasms of self-consciousness. But words like "gadoid," "halitotic" and "piscine" trip off Mount's pen quite naturally. Occasionally, the language takes the bit between its teeth and runs away with the narrative, but for the most part the effects are satisfactory. One can only relax and enjoy the exquisite geometry of sentences like the following (in which Gus tries to guess the age of a peculiar-looking barfly): "It was no more possible to preserve an analytical detachment towards him than it would have been to wrench open his jaw and, as with a horse, assess his age by the state of his teeth -- the latter course being in any case futile because in the interests of economy he had had them all removed and replaced by unnervingly regular dentures."
Another writer whose work Mount's often resembles is Angus Wilson, author of dense, baroque books cluttered with grandly grotesque characters. Some of Mount's creations rival Wilson's at their most colorful: Pip (also known as Polly) Parrott, "war hero, antique dealer and last of the Bright Young Things," and C. L., an obscenely rich racehorse owner, a "gargantuan, thyroid-eyed" woman who "had a passion for hard-boiled eggs and delighted to crack them in unexpected places -- on her secretary's head, on the ebony elephant in the hall, on the silver statuette on the bonnet of her Rolls."
Harry and Gus are the novel's only fully developed characters. Each of the others, however vividly depicted, has little more than a walk-on role. It is an obvious setup for a long novel sequence, for these people are too good, too lovingly invented, not to reappear at a later date. "The Man Who Rode Ampersand," then, does not entirely stand on its own; instead, it serves as a first course, a lead-in to the many pleasures of the series as a whole.

HEADLINE: Shtickball 

BYLINE:  By Joe Queenan; Joe Queenan's most recent book is "Balsamic Dreams: A Short but Self-Important History of the Baby Boomer Generation."

 BODY:
 THE RINGER
By Bill Scheft.
248 pp. New York:
HarperCollins Publishers. $23.95.
 IN his debut as a fiction writer, the humorist Bill Scheft attempts to build an entire novel out of wisecracks. The results are mixed and the book is flawed, but then again so is the Venus de Milo. On the negative side, the characters in "The Ringer" lack depth, and the plot meanders. On the positive side, the jokes are plentiful and very high in quality. Adroitly fusing what he learned from Philip Roth with what he learned from Don Rickles with what he wrote for David Letterman (for whom he has worked as a monologue writer for the last 10 years), Scheft has succeeded where more celebrated cutups like Al Franken and Michael Moore have failed. He has written a book that is actually funny. 
"The Ringer" is the story of a 35-year-old New York neurotic who supports himself and his gambling habit by slaving away as a hired gun (the "Lord of the Ringers") for 13 softball teams. For years, College Boy (ne Harvey Sussman) has been toiling on talent-strapped squads fielded by pizza joints, restaurants and Broadway theaters; he also has a one-day-a-year job on Wall Street enabling him to play for the Morgan Stanley team. Aside from a part-time gig as the designated chuckler on a local radio program, he has no career, no prospects, no social life. He is a self-involved, deeply confused loser "whose idea of planning for the future was deciding whether to set his VCR to tape the Yankees or Mets before he left his apartment." He has a bad job, a bad attitude and very bad legs. Worse still, his psychiatrist has just moved to Teaneck, N.J., and sextupled his rates.
One day College Boy receives a physically catastrophic "full-service muscle call" from two goons in the employ of the Dirt King, a small-time mobster who controls the coveted Central Park replacement soil market. Forced to leave town, College Boy retreats to Massachusetts, where he becomes a full-time nurse for his uncle Mort (ne Morton Martin Spell), a cantankerous old lush who has, among other maladies, Parkinson's disease. Once a revered sportswriter -- the only guy who still wore a hat in the press box" -- he has fallen on hard times ever since Ronald Reagan "deregulated the 10,000-word magazine piece." A cross between Jimmy Cannon and Henny Youngman, Mort is a throwback to an era when sportswriters both drank and knew the history of the Roman Republic, an inconceivable accomplishment today. Here is one of his jokes:
"Julius Caesar walks into a bar. Tells the bartender, 'I'll have a martinus.' Bartender says, 'Don't you mean a martini?' And Caesar says, 'If I wanted a double, I'd ask for it!' " 
The joke also works with "vodkum" and "vodka." 
For years, Uncle Mort has been having weekly sexual encounters with his housekeeper, Sheila, who runs an informal call-girl service out of his apartment when he is out of town. Now, at the ripe age of 75, Mort is merely trying to hang on, "with enough Valium in his system to get Liza Minnelli through a long weekend." This opens things up for College Boy and the Whore With the Heart of Gold, as she is the only female of marriageable age in this remarkably economic novel. Like many prostitutes, Sheila did not set out to become a hooker; she drifted into the profession. As Scheft describes her "date" with a Wall Street guy who is taking her to a movie at the Beekman Theater:
"Sheila could try and tell herself that she was equally surprised by the turn of events, but you don't buy a three-pack of condoms at Tower Chemists across the street from the Beekman because you're worried they might not have them at the concession stand. And you don't bring a strange man back to your apartment 15 minutes before a movie to feed your cat when it isn't your apartment, and it isn't your cat. Even if there is a cat, it ain't yours." 
As often occurs with books and films that start out brash and cynical, "The Ringer" ultimately becomes sweet and sentimental. College Boy must get a new attitude. Sheila must get a new occupation. The Dirt King must get a new lawyer. And Uncle Mort must get a new psychiatrist. Luckily, the merely functional story never gets in the way of the punch lines. In the same way that Prince and Beck can effortlessly produce wonderful new songs that sound a lot like other people's wonderful old songs, Scheft has studied at the feet of the masters, and effortlessly switches voices from Milton Berle to David Letterman to Woody Allen. A few examples:
"If Morton Martin Spell's tie was in a museum, several groups would be out front protesting the exhibit."
"He walked the six blocks north and three blocks east and almost let himself be sucked into the Medea Restaurant as if by some Greek coffee shop undertow." 
"As he disembarked from The Little Elevator That Might, the two J.V. goons stood up and simultaneously flicked away their cigarettes, as if they were there for a casting call of his building's production of 'West Side Story.' "
"There is no rejection in life quite like a canceled shrink appointment, even if that appointment never existed. Or especially if it never existed."
Readers under the age of 20 -- that is, folks who prefer Conan O'Brien to David Letterman -- may be baffled by references to demi-icons of yesteryear like Vada Pinson, Jacques Plante, Barbara Bain and Joe Valachi, or sentences like "The line drive . . . was handled like the editing of 'Heaven's Gate.' " Increasingly, commercial fiction is filled with pop-cultural references that should be accompanied by a time-expiration code. Let's face it, 20 years from now, how many people are going to remember Lamont Sanford? They're having enough trouble remembering Julius Caesar now. 
But this is nitpicking. Though Scheft seems to have written "The Ringer" with the idea that the guy who writes the most jokes writes the best book, he has indisputably written a lot of good jokes. Less a protege of Frederick Exley than of Freddie Roman, Scheft keeps the material coming at machine-gun pace, adhering to the time-honored comic principle that if you tell enough gags fast enough, no one will remember the bad ones. Here, for example, is College Boy's mother speaking to her son:
"Harvey, is it true? Mort had a seizure?"
"Yeah, Mom."
"I told you not to give him liverwurst."
Cymbal crash, heard in distance.

HEADLINE: Children's Books; 
Peace With Flashlights

BYLINE:  By Patrick Markee 

 BODY:
Street gangs have been part of American urban life for nearly as long as there have been American cities. From the 19th-century Irish gangs of New York City's Five Points district to today's Bloods and Crips and Latin Kings and multiple variations, common themes emerge: young, underemployed men and boys, discarded by labor markets and hampered by racism, join together under bonds of blood loyalty in an underground economy. And scared family members and residents of besieged neighborhoods are caught in the inevitable cross-fire between law enforcement authorities and rival gangs. 
 Barbara Joosse and the illustrator R. Gregory Christie focus on the family turmoil wrought by gang life in STARS IN THE DARKNESS (Chronicle, $14.95; ages 4 to 8), telling a deceptively simple but unusually moving story of a young boy's older brother who is drawn into the orbit of street-corner gangbangers. We are never shown the gang life of Richard, the brother, just the telling details as described by the young narrator: the new basketball bought with unexplained funds, the red bandanna, the lies about nights spent away from home, a bloody, bandaged arm. Richard's increasingly cold demeanor is all the more disturbing because of his closeness to the narrator at the beginning. 
 Christie's most moving illustration, reproduced on the cover, shows Richard hugging his younger brother to shield him from late-night sounds of fighting on the streets. The narrator and his mother, who at first feel helpless in the face of Richard's growing gang ties, finally take action by organizing their neighbors to form "Peace Walks." Theirs is the kind of real-life small victory that plays out in many poor neighborhoods, places abandoned and ignored by local government and the wider society. Most important, though, the narrator realizes something about the gangs through his brother's experience: "Richard's a banger, but he's still good inside. He's good to us," he tells his mother. "So maybe the other bangers are like that too." The narrator sees that Richard, like so many urban youths down the centuries, turns to gangs for brotherhood, for security, for something he can't find anywhere else. Like the flashlights of the peace walkers at the story's end, Richard and his family find ways to be stars in the darkness. Patrick Markee

HEADLINE: And Bear In Mind 

 BODY:
 (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)

VERSAILLES, by Kathryn Davis. (Houghton Mifflin, $21.) A reflective, mysterious novel about human development; it takes a soul's-eye view of the life of Marie Antoinette from her marriage at 14 to the guillotine at 38; narrated by herself sometime after her death, when she has had a chance to think some about her earthly life and its contents.

YOU ARE NOT A STRANGER HERE, by Adam Haslett. (Nan A. Talese/Doubleday, $21.95.) These nine short stories (Haslett's first collection) exhale a desiccated bleakness, a despair mitigated by the characters' continuing desire to be good, to do the right thing despite hopelessness, loss, disease and mental illness.

PRAGUE, by Arthur Phillips. (Random House, $24.95.) A first novel set in 1990, far beyond the recently fallen Berlin Wall, where young Americans reveal themselves not as travelers but mere tourists, detached from their surroundings, weightless and immaterial among time-battered buildings and people who have survived wars and uprisings.

RACISM: A Short History, by George M. Fredrickson. (Princeton University, $22.95.) A historian proposes that the distinctive ideology of Western racism was made necessary by the growing Enlightenment belief in equality; earlier and elsewhere, men had needed no theories to treat one another ill.

HALF IN LOVE: Stories, by Maile Meloy. (Scribner, $23.) Fourteen stories, set mostly in the author's native Montana, among small-time racetracks and failed oil wells, where brides choose wedding dresses to hide branding-iron scars; no one expects an easy life here, and even the young feel their choices constrained by economics and losing habits.

THE REAL McCOY, by Darin Strauss. (Dutton, $24.95.) An ambitious, thought-infested novel placed at the turn of the last century, in which a boxer who is also a confidence man helps America round the corner to a new world of mass communications, celebrity, product endorsement and the makeover.

SAVAGE REPRISALS: Bleak House, Madame Bovary, Buddenbrooks, by Peter Gay. (Norton, $24.95.) A distinguished cultural historian reads three landmark novels as propelled, respectively, by Dickens's resentment of his mean old mother, Flaubert's of the culture of the bourgeoisie and Mann's of his capitalist father.

CAMOUFLAGE: Stories, by Murray Bail. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $20.) Fourteen stories by an Australian who invests his space in satire, not character; in one story people hold races on the partitions of their office cubicles, while in another a conceptual artist offers to document the existence of everyone alive.

STRAVINSKY AND BALANCHINE: A Journey of Invention, by Charles M. Joseph. (Yale University, $40.) An engaging study, by a professor of music and intrepid researcher, of the remarkable collaboration between two emigres from Russia who revived and re-created, again and again, classical ballet in the 20th century.

HEADLINE: WHAT'S DOING IN; 
Indianapolis

BYLINE:  By DOUGLAS WISSING; DOUGLAS WISSING is a writer in Bloomington, Ind.

 BODY:
Long known as the Crossroads of America, Indianapolis has transformed itself over the last 10 years into a vibrant, more international city as its booming economy reaches out to global markets.
 This summer and fall, the world really is coming to Indianapolis. In August dozens of the top international players arrive in this basketball-mad state capital to battle in the World Basketball Championship. The cheers will barely have quieted when 50 of the world's most promising violinists between the ages of 16 and 29 begin the International Violin Competition of Indianapolis, a premier musical event held every four years. And in late September, seven 747's will touch down at Indianapolis International Airport, bringing the cars of the international Formula One auto-racing series to town for the SAP United States Grand Prix. 
 But Indianapolis is still a Hoosier town, ready to crow about joys of Indiana life. The Indiana State Fair, the nation's sixth oldest, began 150 years ago and remains a kaleidoscope of corn dogs, carnival rides, beauty queens and prize bulls. Newer but no less Hoosier, the recently reopened Indiana State Museum offers a panoramic view of Indiana history and living culture. The sprawling museum is an anchor of the White River State Park, a popular urban recreational area.

Events
The men's World Basketball Championship will be held Aug. 29 to Sept. 8, the first time in its 52-year history this event is in the United States. The national teams of 16 countries will play downtown in Conseco Fieldhouse and the RCA Dome. Eight players chosen in the most recent National Basketball Association draft -- including 7-foot-5 Yao Ming of China -- are expected to play. Game tickets cost from $10 to $58 at (866) 849-4922 or www.2002worldbasketball.com.
When the cars and drivers of the SAP Grand Prix begin to wind through the 13-turn, 2.6-mile track at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway, West 16th Street and Georgetown Road, Indy joins such storied international racing locales as Monza, Italy, and Monte Carlo. The Formula One race cars practice on Sept. 27, with qualifications the next day. On Sept. 29 -- before a crowd expected to be the biggest in Formula One -- the race begins when more than 20 cars scream toward the first turn in a high-stakes game of chicken. Tickets range from $30 to $150; (800) 822-4639 and www.usgpindy.com.
Aug. 28 through Sept. 2 at Indianapolis Raceway Park, some 10 miles west of downtown in Clermont, rip-roaring funny cars, dragsters, stock cars -- even motorcycles -- thunder down the quarter-mile drag strip at the U.S. Nationals. More than 90,000 spectators are expected over the six days, including on Friday and Saturday nights, when the nitromethane exhaust flames make the roaring 6,000-horsepower dragsters look like Roman candles. Tickets range from $5 to $60, and are available at (800) 884-6472 or www.irponline.com.
You'll want to remove your earplugs at the International Violin Competition, Sept. 6 to 22. The event consists of four juried rounds of performances, with the finals in the Hilbert Circle Theatre, 45 Monument Circle. Violinists in the final stages are accompanied by the Suzuki and Friends Chamber Orchestra and the Indianapolis Symphony Orchestra. Previous laureates include Kyoko Takezawa, Leonidas Kavakos and David Chan. Tickets: $12 to $50 at (317) 638-4824 or www.violin.org.
Through next Sunday, the venerable Indiana State Fair on East 38th Street bustles with farmers exhibiting prize produce and livestock, and cooks displaying a cornucopia of pickles, pies and casseroles. The midway rides entice all ages ($1 to $5 each). On Wednesday, the country singer Kenny Chesney appears at 7:30 p.m. ($29 to $31). Gate admission is $6; (317) 927-7500 or www .indianastatefair.com.

Sightseeing
The Indiana State Museum, (317) 232-1637 or www.indianamuseum .com, which opened in May in White River State Park just east of downtown, celebrates the state's rich history and culture. It is an enveloping universe of fossils, prehistoric peoples, frontier pioneers and industrial innovators. Indiana heroes such as the Revolutionary War leader George Rogers Clark and villains like the historically powerful state Ku Klux Klan both populate the cases. Open Monday to Saturday 9 a.m. to 5 p.m., Sunday 11 to 6 p.m. General admission, $7.
The museum is an ideal departure point to explore White River State Park, 801 West Washington Street, (317) 233-2434. Within walking distance, the park includes such attractions as the Indianapolis Zoo, White River Gardens, the Eiteljorg Museum of American Indians and Western Art, and the National Collegiate Athletic Association Hall of Champions -- all tied together by elegant promenades and green spaces.
The Eiteljorg Museum, 500 West Washington Street, (317) 636-9378, www.eiteljorg.org, includes the work of artists such as Georgia O'Keeffe and Frederic Remington. Open Tuesday to Saturday 10 a.m. to 5 p.m., Sunday noon to 5 p.m. Admission: $7.
The N.C.A.A. Hall of Champions, 700 West Washington Street, (800) 735-6222, www.ncaahallofchampions.org, is a Michael Graves-designed paean to the student-athletes of 22 collegiate sports, from football to lacrosse. Open Monday to Saturday 10 a.m. to 5 p.m., Sunday noon to 5 p.m. Admission: $7.
With the growth of galleries, antique shops, studios and lofts, the Fountain Square area continues its quirky renaissance. The Murphy Art Center, 1043 Virginia Avenue, (317) 686-0895, houses 22 artists' studios and four galleries. Six times a year the entire building stages a free open house, including one Sept. 6 from 6 to 11 p.m. The ornate Fountain Square Theatre, 1105 Prospect Street, (317) 686-6010, built in 1928, offers swing dancing under the ballroom's faux stars the second Friday of each month ($8).

Where to Stay
Rooms get tight in Indianapolis during peak events such as the Grand Prix. The Indianapolis Convention and Visitors Association, (800) 556-4639 or at www.indy.org, can help find accommodations.
A recently opened bed-and-breakfast in the Victorian Old Northside could easily fit in a Booth Tarkington novel. Built in 1906 as a magnate's mansion, the Villa Inn, 1456 North Delaware Street, (317) 916-8500, fax (317) 917-9086, www.thevillainn.com, is freshly restored and decorated in warm, mellow tones of terra cotta and caramel. The five posh rooms include high-speed Internet access and Jacuzzis for two. In the opulent breakfast room, opera often plays as guests are served fresh fruit plates and eggs Benedict. Double rates are $200 to $250.
The Residence Inn by Marriott, 350 West New York Street, (317) 822-0840, fax (317) 822-0848, is the only hotel on the downtown canal walk. This tidy brick-and-stucco property has an indoor pool, a Jacuzzi and two exercise rooms. Each suite has a complete kitchenette. The 134 suites range from $129 to $199.
Budget: Hunt-club colors predominate in the Hampton Inn Downtown, 105 South Meridian Street, (317) 261-1200, fax (317) 261-1030, in the heart of the shopping and entertainment district. There's a large exercise room and a generous Continental breakfast each morning. The 180-room hotel is housed in the historic 1929 Chesapeake Building, an imposing Classical-style nine-story structure topped by a stately cornice. Rates are $109 to $139.
Luxury: The Canterbury Hotel, 123 South Illinois Street, (317) 634-3000, fax (317) 685-2519, or at www.canterburyhotel.com, is a 99-room European-style property that pampers its guests with Chippendale four-poster beds, gold-plated faucets, marble vanities and plush bathrobes, as well as twice-a-day housekeeping. Suites and duplex penthouses offer whirlpool baths and wet bars. The refined lobby is a calm setting for Continental breakfast. Doubles: $245 to $275, including that breakfast.
The largest of the downtown hotels, the 615-room Indianapolis Marriott Downtown, 350 West Maryland Street, (317) 822-3500, fax (317) 951-0300, www.indymarriott.com, features an expansive marble-tiled lobby and traditional decor, as well as an indoor pool and a health club. Doubles from $199 to $259.

Where to Eat
At Peter's Restaurant and Bar, 8505 Keystone Crossing Boulevard, 15 minutes north of downtown, (317) 465-1155, the chef, Dave Foegley, deftly merges world influences into a regionally rooted menu. He offers entrees such as Spanish saffron-scented Alaskan halibut and Indiana bison chops. A dining loft above the bar serves as aerie to people-watch the dining room below, which is embellished with mahogany trim and vivid contemporary art. Dinner only Monday through Saturday; dinner for two with wine is about $150.
Lines of cheery diners await heaping plates of jambalaya and etouffee at Yat's Cajun Creole Restaurant, 5363 North College Avenue, (317) 253-8817, a celebration of neo-psychedelic paintings, great jazz and excellent food. Diners order at the register, grab their own soft drinks and take a seat to await their dishes. The king of this carnival is the owner, Joe Vuskovich, a hyperkinetic former New Orleans restaurateur who cooks with a complex blend of spices. Open for lunch and dinner daily except Sunday. A meal for two with drinks is less than $15.
Pancho's Taqueria, on the north side at 7023 North Michigan Road, (317) 202-9015, in addition to serving burritos and tacos, provides a flavorful array of home food such as tripas (tripe) and lengua (tongue). Open daily for lunch and dinner. Dinner for two with beer is under $20.
Since 1905, Shapiro's Delicatessen Cafeteria, 808 South Meridian Street, (317) 631-4041, has been serving immense corned beef sandwiches on crusty rye, and other deli favorites. It is still run by the Shapiro family, which cures the meat with an original family recipe. The Formica tables and tile floors wouldn't look out of place in Manhattan. Breakfast, lunch and dinner daily. A meal for two with drinks and a slice of the acclaimed cheesecake will cost under $25.
In a 1920's commercial building at the tail end of Massachusetts Avenue, Indianapolis's bustling boite and gallery street, R Bistro, 888 Massachusetts Avenue, (317) 423-0312, offers a respite from the workaday world. The chef and owner, Regina Mehallick, changes her menu weekly, utilizing local ingredients for her roast leg of lamb with saffron potatoes and vegetables. Her grilled halibut with a perky mango salsa is a refreshing dish on a sultry evening. Open for lunch Monday to Friday and dinner Wednesday to Saturday; dinner for two with wine, under $100.

Night Life
The Chatterbox, 435 Massachusetts Avenue, (317) 636-0584, is an atmospheric spot for an after-dinner drink and excellent jazz. The outdoor seating is particularly pleasant on the warm weekends when jazz floats out from the crowded bar. Open nightly except Sunday; cover charge $4 (Friday and Saturday only).
The Red Key Tavern, 5170 North College Avenue, (317) 283-4601, is a 1950's-era bar that has one of the best jukeboxes in town and an assemblage of hits by Benny Goodman, Perry Como and the Paul Whiteman Orchestra, among others. Run with an amiable iron fist by its owner, Russel Settle, since 1951, the tavern has a loyal clientele of moodily reminiscing oldsters and hip young folks from the Broad Ripple neighborhood north of downtown.

HEADLINE: Q. & A.; 
Tenant Who Needs to Break a Lease

 BODY:
 Q. I will be moving out of my apartment before my lease expires. What is the legal procedure for breaking one's lease? . . . Khalika Eodumegwuhu-Sanchez, Brooklyn.

A. Lucas A. Ferrara, a Manhattan real estate lawyer, said that neither a landlord nor a tenant is permitted to break a lease unless the right to do so is in the lease agreement or given to the parties by a statute or regulation. For example, he said, a rent-regulated tenant who does not occupy an apartment as a primary residence could forfeit the right to the apartment.
 Otherwise, Mr. Ferrara said, "a landlord must permit a tenant to remain in an apartment for the balance of the lease, while a tenant, in turn, is usually responsible for the payment of all rent."
Exceptions, however, could exist. For example, Mr. Ferrara said, when a tenant is forced to leave an apartment because all or part of the space is unusable, that could be a justification for breaking the lease. "If a tenant leaves because of issues relating to the apartment's livability, that could excuse a tenant from having to pay the rent for the time remaining on the lease," he said.
Otherwise, Mr. Ferrara said, market forces will play a critical role in a tenant's ability to break a lease without being held liable for damages.
"If the rent being paid is under market, and a landlord can increase income by leasing to a new tenant, a vacancy may be welcome news," he said. He added, however, that problems may arise when the owner has a difficult time finding a new tenant at the existing rent or is forced to rent the apartment for less money.
In such situations, Mr. Ferrara said, a tenant about to break a lease would be better off informing the landlord immediately.
"In my experience, in the interest of avoiding litigation, many landlords will work with their tenants to find a mutually acceptable solution," he said, such as releasing the tenant from the remainder of the lease in exchange for a waiver of the return of the security deposit and/or pre-payment of several months' rent. 
Mr. Ferrara said that in situations where an agreement cannot be reached, and the tenant breaks the lease, the legal question of whether the landlord is required to try to rerent the apartment -- and minimize damages for which the tenant is responsible -- depends in large part on where the building is situated.
As far as New York City is concerned, in Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island, a landlord is usually required to mitigate damages by making reasonable efforts to find a new tenant. In Manhattan and the Bronx, however, an appeals court ruled in 1997 that the owner has no such obligation.

Making Entrances Accessible

Q. The co-op in which I live has a doorman-monitored main entrance that has a few steps leading down into the lobby. A side entrance that leads directly to the street has two doors that can be opened only from the inside, making it impossible for someone in a wheelchair to enter the building without assistance. There are plans to renovate the lobby and build a ramp parallel with the existing main entrance, cutting through what is now a garden. Is this ramp mandated by the Americans With Disabilities Act if we renovate? . . . Christine Santoro, Manhattan.

A. Stuart M. Saft, a Manhattan co-op lawyer, said the Americans With Disabilities Act has only limited applicability to residential buildings. He added, however, that the New York City Human Rights Law bars discrimination against individuals because of their disabilities. And the city's Handicapped Accessibility Law, he said, requires buildings that make major capital improvements to be certain the areas under improvement are made accessible to people with disabilities, unless doing so would be physically or legally impossible or would create an undue economic burden on the building.
"The city's Human Rights Commission has been very proactive in taking cases involving disabled individuals," Mr. Saft said. If the lobby is being renovated, he said, it is likely the commission would insist on the installation of a ramp if the ramp can be put in without imposing an undue economic burden on the building. So, Mr. Saft said, it appears that the letter writer's board is acting prudently by installing the ramp.

HEADLINE: TELEVISION/RADIO; 
Birth of a Genre: The Black Hero Who Talks Back

BYLINE:  By HAL HINSON 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES 

 BODY:
IN the beginning, there was "Sweetback." As Melvin Van Peebles explains in "Baadasssss Cinema," Isaac Julien's definitive new documentary about the history of blaxploitation films, the idea for "Sweet Sweetback's Baadasssss Song" rose up in him out of a long-festering sense of frustration over what he was seeing on the screen.
 "The cause I had," Mr. Van Peebles proclaims between puffs on a cigar just slightly smaller than a Louisville Slugger, "was giving black folks a sense of self that had been stolen from us. And that's how I made 'Sweetback.' " 
 The film, about a pimp who stays one step ahead of a racist gang of cops, opened first in Detroit, on March 31, 1971, at the Grand Circus Theater, then two days later at the Coronet Theater in Atlanta -- the only theaters in the country that would show it. At the time, there were no black-owned theater chains. Also, the Motion Picture Association of America had given the film an "X" rating, which meant that most theater chains wouldn't book it, primarily because most newspapers wouldn't sell advertising space to an X-rated film. 
However, once Mr. Van Peebles discovered that the ratings committee was made up entirely of white men, he immediately began marketing the film as "Rated 'X' by an All-White Jury."
Those first audiences probably didn't know that they were watching a movie that would launch countless imitations, spark a revolution in the motion-picture business, and open the floor for a cultural debate that rages to this day.
But that's what happened, and in his documentary, Mr. Julien traces the development of the genre, using archival footage and interviews with directors, actors, critics and academics (including Elvis Mitchell, a film critic for The New York Times). The film, which has its premiere on the Independent Film Channel on Wednesday, kicks off a month-long blaxploitation festival on IFC. It will include three of the major blaxploitation films of the 1970's: "Foxy Brown," "Superfly" and "Shaft's Big Score!"
"Sweetback" was shot in only 19 days with a crew of veteran porno filmmakers and a shoestring budget of $500,000 -- $50,000 of which came from Bill Cosby. But it quickly became one of the highest-grossing independent films ever made. 
Julian Bond, chairman of the N.A.A.C.P., remembers watching the movie at the Coronet Theater. "It was just like, 'Wow!' " Mr. Bond said in a telephone interview. "You'd just never seen anything like it before. You'd never seen sex like that. You'd never seen a black guy beat up the police and get away."
What happened after that, Mr. Van Peebles said, was simple economics: "When Hollywood saw these huge returns from 'Sweetback,' they became aware that there was an enormous black audience that could be exploited."
Mr. Julien, a writer, artist and social critic, says the IFC documentary grew directly out of a course he taught at Harvard called "Black Film as Genre? Blaxploitation Cinema to Quentin Tarantino." In his research, he said, he realized that there was a story to be told.
As a teenager growing up in London's East End in the 70's, Mr. Julien said, the first film he ever saw in a theater was "Cleopatra Jones." And the other blaxploitation films -- "Shaft," "Superfly" and anything with the actress Pam Grier -- were formative experiences for him. But, he said, "my critical examination of these films didn't begin, really, until I began doing the research for my course." 
The timing of the documentary couldn't be more perfect. The genre's influence can be seen everywhere in pop music and film, in movies like "The Ladies Man," "Undercover Brother" and "Austin Powers in Goldmember." But in the 70's, to many audiences, black and white, these movies were troubling, especially because Sweetback and so many of the other heroes were pimps and drug dealers.
"Some of us want only the best depiction, that is the upright, the triumphant, law-abiding hero," said Mr. Bond. "And at that time, films that glamorized dope dealers and women with low bodices didn't conform to what we thought our image ought to be."
But, Mr. Bond said, the movies stirred something in audiences. "If you were sitting in the theater with a group of people, then you understood that they had enormous popular appeal," he said. "I guess in some ways it's like rap music today, and rhythm and blues years ago."
For Fred Williamson, the professional football player who starred in several of the films, it was all about heroes. "Black society needed these films," he said in an interview. "The blacks in most movies were still porters and bus boys. There were no black equivalents to the characters played by Edward G. Robinson and Humphrey Bogart and Jimmy Cagney."
These heroes were vastly different from the figures that Sidney Poitier played in 1960's films like "Lilies of the Field" or "Guess Who's Coming to Dinner." "Most black people were tired of the noble Negro," said Ed Guerrero, a professor of Afro-American studies at New York University who is also interviewed in the documentary. "These films represented the first time that black people really got on the screen more or less on their own terms."
The success of "Sweetback" made Hollywood aware of the enormous black audience, in much the same way that the success of "Easy Rider" had made Hollywood aware of the youth audience. But in the documentary, Mr. Van Peebles claims that when Hollywood produced its knock-offs of his film, it also surpressed the political content, added caricature, and "blaxploitation" was born.
"Did my film get the whole thing started? Yes," Mr. Van Peebles asserts. "But it doesn't really belong in there with the others." 
In October 1972, Newsweek ran a cover story on the new black movie boom, claiming that "talented black actors, directors and writers were suddenly plucked out of studio back rooms, modeling agencies and ghetto theaters, and turned loose on new black projects." 
The article even suggested that the black films were paying off so much better than their white counterparts, that the new black cinema deserved credit for keeping Hollywood from possible extinction. While this may have been a slight exaggeration of the facts, it is true that by the end of 1971, one out of every four films in production was designed to appeal to the black audience. 
And it's also true that the original "Shaft" went through preproduction as a film with a white director and a white cast, then was quickly retooled for a black cast, with Richard Roundtree in the lead, a black director, Gordon Parks, and a hot-buttered soul score by Isaac Hayes. The film grossed $12 million and rescued MGM at a time when the studio had literally pawned Judy Garland's ruby slippers to stay in business. 
Mr. Williamson, who starred in "Hell Up in Harlem" and "Black Caesar," among other films, questions whether the movies of the blaxploitation period are "black films" in the same sense that, say, the movies of Spike Lee are. 
"First of all," he said, "the movies were being financed by whites, so once the whites were in control, then they also controlled the subject matter. It is up to the actors themselves to portray the characters that they want to portray and the things that they want to see done."
Even at the height of their appeal, the movies usually followed a simple and predictable formula, with warring drug dealers and corrupt white cops. The one consistant ingredient underneath it all was the brilliant music, which, whether coming from James Brown or Marvin Gaye or Curtis Mayfield or Issac Hayes, added an element of depth and sophistication.
The blaxploitation era came to an end for precisely the same reason it started: money. Instead of diversifying and developing their audience, the studios kept churning out the same film over and over. "Shaft" was followed by "Shaft's Big Score!" and "Shaft in Africa." "Slaughter" gave birth to "Slaughter's Big Rip-Off," and eventually it was the audience that started to feel ripped off. 
"In the end, the films of the blaxploitation era didn't make that much money for black people," Mr. Guerrero explains in the documentary. "Ultimately, it was just a moment, an interlude." 
When the party was over, the morning after was grim for those who had relied on the industry to make a living. 
"It was a vicious time," recalls the actress Gloria Hendry in perhaps the documentary's most poignant moment. "When you start falling, you put your hands out and try to hold onto anything you can. And I was grabbing, but I couldn't get a hold of anything. There was nothing. Black films saved Hollywood, and when they were through with us, they dropped us. The door slammed."

Baadasssss Cinema
Independent Film Channel
Wednesday, 10 p.m., 9 p.m. Central

HEADLINE: Guard to Add a Canine Unit in Newtown 

BYLINE:  By NANCY DONIGER 

 BODY:
HOMELAND security is about to come closer to home for residents in western Connecticut. 
 Maj. Gen. William A. Cugno, adjutant general of the state Military Department, is honing plans to expand the Army National Guard presence at Fairfield Hills in Newtown with the formation of a military canine unit, new training and administrative facilities and a recruiting center. 
 The dogs and their handlers will be available for deployment anywhere in the world to respond to terrorist acts and will also protect the region, General Cugno said. The dogs will be trained to detect explosives and drugs and perform search-and-rescue operations. The unit will accommodate six dogs to start with an 18-dog capacity. 
With $2 million in federal funding, General Cugno plans to renovate a half-dozen dilapidated buildings at Fairfield Hills, the former Connecticut psychiatric hospital that closed in 1995. 
He plans to use the former storehouse, at the foot of Trades Lane, for an armory, which will be used to train guardsmen, not to store weapons, he said. The former machine shop will be converted into administrative offices. The former piggery, on seven acres of state Agriculture Department land, deeded for animal and agricultural use, will become a military working dog unit. 
The training facilities may contain a chemical decontamination unit to prepare guardsmen to respond to a chemical or biological attack, General Cugno said. But, he added, "No chemicals will be stored anywhere at Fairfield Hills."
"The guardsmen in this unit will be specialists in clean up and rapid response if, God forbid, there were ever an event of chemical warfare," General Cugno said. "If an adversary used chemical weapons against us in a war environment, the soldiers would know how to detect and minimize the effects, based on knowledge and training in decontamination."
Another building will become an indoor training center for the Second Company Governor's Horse Guard, military dogs and soldiers. The Second Company, already headquartered in the former hospital dairy barn, occupies 65 adjacent acres. The former slaughterhouse will be used as a feeding and comfort station for soldiers.
General Cugno is the only adjutant general in the country who commands two cavalry militias, the First Company Governor's Horse Guard in Avon plus the Second Company in Newtown.
"We are fortunate to have such a facility, co-located with the horse guard, and sandwiched between New York and Boston," General Cugno said. "It will be an asset to other law enforcement agencies, to the governor, and to the region, in the war against terrorism. It will contribute to the local economy with the creation of six full-time jobs."
It also will be the first Defense Department military canine unit under National Guard command, General Cugno said. The United States Military Department's main dog facility has its headquarters at Lackland Air Force Base in Texas. Dog units also are located at military bases across the country, but none is under the reserves, he said.
Plans for a heightened national guard presence at Fairfield Hills have been under way for more than a year, but have grown in importance "based on lessons we learned Sept. 11," General Cugno said. He intends to maintain the farm ambience and to preserve the original design elements in buildings he converts to military use, including the piggery's gambrel roof. 
"This man is a mover," said Julia Wasserman, a state representative who represents Newtown. "He has done nothing but good things at Fairfield Hills. The canine unit will be far enough away from habitation that I don't envision any problems. Whatever he does here, he does with precision and good judgment. It's all positive and good for the town and the state."
Fairfield Hills State Hospital opened in 1932 on 800 acres and housed more than 3,000 patients during the 1950's. Designed to resemble a college campus rather than an institution, the hospital included a fully-working farm that supplied food to patients and staff.
Representative Wasserman has been actively negotiating with the state for redevelopment since 1992. Ms. Wasserman initiated legislation that deeded 300 acres to the State Department of Agriculture in perpetuity. Two years ago, Ms. Wasserman secured $650,000 in state funding to refurbish the horse guard facilities, when General Cugno first took over. 
During the 1980's, the state allocated 120 acres to the Department of Correction for the Ward A. Garner Correctional Institution, a high security prison, which opened in 1992, over the protests of residents and town leaders who did not want it in Newtown. The objections have receded, as the town annually collects more than $1 million in payment in lieu of taxes from the state. Ms Wasserman objected when the D.O.C. wanted to convert one of the hospital buildings into an arsenal to store weapons, but said she supports the general's plans to build an armory for training. 
Newtown has a $3.9 million contract with the state to purchase 186 acres and the buildings on the main campus. Ms. Wasserman also has negotiated the transfer of almost 200 additional acres to Newtown, for a total of about 370 acres under town control. The state still controls more than 400 acres.
The purchase by the town was part of an overall $48.7 million bonding package, approved by taxpayers in June 2001 that included two related propositions. The first, for $21.7 million, included the campus purchase price, plus funding for a master plan, playing-field construction, asbestos removal, building renovation and demolition and environmental insurance.
Another $27 million was approved for a Grades 5 and 6 school at Fairfield Hills, under construction and expected to open in January, in close proximity to the buildings intended for military use.
First Selectman Herb Rosenthal has hired Harrall-Michalowski Associates of Hamden to design a long-term reuse plan. He plans to schedule a public meeting in September, with three alternative proposals, incorporating economic development, recreation, municipal use and open space. Mr. Rosenthal said he generally is aware of the anti-terrorism initiatives General Cugno is planning, but does not know all the details. Although not required, he said he would like the general to inform the town of his intentions.
"The general has a lot of freedom to do what he wants," said Mr. Rosenthal. "I can't see why there would be any objections as long as there are no harmful effects to the town. Improving and upgrading the buildings will make them tie-in better with the town's reuse plans."
Elaine McGuire, the board of education chairwoman, was not aware of the extent of the Military Department's pending presence in such close proximity to the new school, but said she would like to see it lead to a positive partnership.
"The presence of military personnel near the campus will only add to the already secure feeling of our school system," she said. "I am certain the state will work closely with our school administrators to enact the necessary safeguards and make sure the activities of the armory will not interfere with the activities of our student population."
Dr. Karin Harter lives and works at the Berkshire Veterinary Hospital, less than a half-mile from Fairfield Hills. "Well-trained dogs are a pleasure to watch," she said. "This sounds like marvelous opportunity for Newtown and an appropriate use of state lands." 
Mary Maki, president of the Friends of the Library and a member of the Friends of Fairfield Hills Committee, was surprised to hear about the military plans, but also reacted positively to them.
"I can't think of any down-side to the National Guard plans," she said. "On the positive side, it will act as a deterrent to crime around the school and the whole area."
Ms. Maki said the injection of federal money will bring more awareness to Fairfield Hills and may encourage investment of private money into re-development. "Dog shows, horse shows and antique shows are the kind of thing we want to encourage," she said. "This way people come to the campus, spend their money and leave. It's nice to see the property renovated for a good purpose."

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Westchester; 
Textile Company Relocates to Mt. Vernon

BYLINE:  By ELSA BRENNER 

DATELINE: MOUNT VERNON, N.Y. 

 BODY:
BERGAMO FABRICS, a high-end international textile distributor, has moved its world headquarters from the Flatiron district of New York City to a complex of derelict 100-year-old industrial buildings here. The buildings, which housed Consumers Union from 1954 to 1991, have been mostly empty since the nonprofit testing and information organization moved to larger and more modern quarters in Yonkers.
 Bergamo, which sells only to designers and architects, was "desperate for space and suffocating" in 7,500 square feet at 7 West 22nd Street, said Rosencrans Baldwin, the company's president and chief executive. He said the company -- owned by Lorenzo Rubelli, the Italian textile company, and Sahco Hesslein, the German fabric house -- needed to expand but did not want to continue paying $17 a square foot for space in New York City. 
 "In a recession, we felt it was important to work on a budget," Mr. Baldwin said. Bergamo will keep its 4,100-square-foot showroom in the Designers and Decorators building at 979 Third Avenue. But it will also have a showroom here, along with its corporate offices and a warehouse from which designer samples are shipped. 
Mr. Baldwin and Peter Conant, an architect, looked at more than 20 buildings throughout Westchester before making a final decision on the complex of three connected brick structures here. They had considered moving to Long Island City as well as to other locations in Manhattan but ruled them out because rents were too high.
"Actually, we could go any place FedEx and a high-speed transmission line could go," said Mr. Baldwin, who commutes from Darien, Conn., "but we finally focused on Westchester, both because we found space we could afford and because it's within comfortable commuting distance for the employees who moved with us.
"As for choosing the building itself, we just kept coming back again and again to this one. It had the brick walls, the wood floors and the 16-foot ceilings we were looking for."
There were drawbacks, though, that made Mr. Baldwin hesitate at first. "People kept saying, 'Do you really want to be in Mount Vernon? It's dangerous,' " he recalled. In the end, though, Bergamo took 25,000 square feet at $6 a square foot a year on the top two floors of the 85,000-square-foot complex at 256 Washington Street formerly occupied by Consumers.
"In more ways than one, it was a gutsy move," Mr. Conant said. "The space itself before it was renovated was pitiful."
HE said there was much work to do before Bergamo could occupy the building, including shooing off the pigeons that had squatted in unoccupied offices. Old and rotting windows, many stuck shut, were replaced with aluminum double-hung windows and screens, and new heating and air-conditioning were installed, along with wiring for high-speed computer connections.
Also, the warren of small offices and testing labs used by Consumers Union was ripped out, and the entire space was painted white to maximize the new feeling of openness and light.
"The great features of the space were kept to expose the intrinsic beauty of the building," Mr. Conant said. Second-hand furnishings, many of them designer chairs and tables, were bought and covered in Bergamo fabrics.
The complex was built around 1900 and used as a factory until Consumers Union bought the building for its corporate headquarters and testing labs from the General Optical Company late in 1953 for $235,000. The publisher of Consumer Reports sold it in 1991 for $325,000 after it had languished on the market for more than a year, said Dan Franklin, now director of labor relations and employee communications for Consumers Union and formerly its facilities planning manager. 
"It wasn't what you'd call an ideal property," Mr. Franklin, a 23-year employee of Consumers Union, said, explaining that the building was not even suitable for a storage company, because it did not offer large blocks of unbroken space. "I'm glad to see it being put to good use again." 
When Consumers Union moved to a 250,000-square-foot building on Truman Avenue in Yonkers, for which it paid $40 million, the next owner of the Mount Vernon property, Anthony Carpenito of White Plains, spent $500,000 to renovate it. Mr. Carpenito said that for the first few years he owned it, it was empty; at most, it was less than half occupied.
"To really do justice to the building, I would have had to invest even more money," said Mr. Carpenito, who sold it two years ago for $1 million to the present owner, a corporation called 256 Washington Street.
Moshe Altmark and Paul Holand, the two principals of the corporation, own about a million square feet of industrial real estate in the South Bronx. Mr. Holand said the family business, an offshoot of a company started 40 years ago by his father, David Holand, specialized in "diamond-in-the-rough-type buildings with lots of potential." The company also owns a contracting and building supply company, which helps it to keep renovation costs down. 
IN addition to replacing windows, rewiring and renovating space to suit tenants, the company has replaced the roof and upgraded the elevators. 
"When we first saw these buildings, we saw a large potential but also a lot of work, which is what we specialize in," said Mr. Altmark, the elder Mr. Holand's son-in-law. "We go into troubled neighborhoods and restore buildings and, in turn, restore the neighborhood."
Lawrence Talt, the broker for the property, said he was marketing the space to high-end design companies like Bergamo that "may need to maintain a Manhattan address for a showroom or corporate presence, but want to relocate the bulk of their business in an outlying and less expensive place within commuting distance to the city." The building is an eight-minute walk to the Metro-North train station in Mount Vernon.
Also, Mr. Talt noted that the state announced in June that it had designated a two-square-mile Empire Zone in an area of Mount Vernon that includes 256 Washington Street. To encourage private sector investment, job creation and economic growth for the local community, the state provides a wide array of tax benefits for eligible businesses in designated zones.
Businesses operating inside a zone are eligible for tax benefits on new capital investments. Those benefits -- including tax reduction credits, real property tax credits, sales tax exemptions, wage tax credits and utility rate reductions -- can cut a company's tax liability to zero.
For Mount Vernon, the designation will help the city realize its Downtown Revitalization Plan, which includes a $210 million investment for a sports arena project, a 300-room hotel, an office building complex, a convention center and a retail mall. It will also help several manufacturers expand, including any businesses locating at 256 Washington Street that apply for benefits.
Since the designation, the 10-year property tax abatement and sales tax breaks have already helped line up $282.2 million in new investment and nearly 2,000 new jobs for the city, said Mount Vernon's mayor, Ernest D. Davis.
Mount Vernon is the second Westchester community, after Yonkers, to get an Empire Zone designation since the business-incentive program began in 1987.
Mayor Davis said the city would plant cherry trees along Washington Street and install new street lighting "to send a signal that we want to improve the area and welcome new businesses." The timing of the building's renovation, Bergamo's arrival and the Empire Zone designation, he said, "couldn't be better."

LENGTH: 2703 words

HEADLINE: Growth Spurt 

BYLINE:  By ELSA BRENNER 

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS 

 BODY:
"IT'S music to my ears!" exclaimed Mayor Joseph M. Delfino one recent morning as he raised the windows in his City Hall office here and listened to the noise outside.
 As he often does these days, Mr. Delfino was monitoring the beeps and chugs of construction equipment coming from several different quarters of the city in recent months. "Even when the noise wakes me before 7, I still love it," said Mayor Delfino, who lives in an apartment close to the central business district, where most of the construction is taking place. 
 Never has the mayor, who was born at St. Agnes Hospital here 69 years ago, witnessed such activity in his hometown. The city, as he says, is undergoing a metamorphosis. In almost any direction one turns this summer, new buildings are rising, and cranes and bulldozers are everywhere. 
By contrast, as recently as the end of 1998, White Plains was a city in decline. The tax base had been falling for more than a decade. And at a time when the availability rate for office space in the county as a whole was 18 percent, this central Westchester city, which was slow to recover from the recession of the early 1990's when many large corporations downsized, was struggling with 30.2 percent of its offices empty.
Now along Mamaroneck Avenue -- the main street of the city where many retail outlets and office buildings have languished in recent years -- Louis R. Cappelli, the Valhalla-based builder, is building a $300 million City Center. In place of an abandoned Macy's department store and other small shops, there are plans for a 15-screen movie theater, a four-star Westin Hotel, stores like Target and Circuit City and six restaurants, some of them national chains, and 600 rental units, all taking up 1.2 million square feet.
Cappelli Enterprises, which built New Roc City, the family entertainment center, in New Rochelle, bought the White Plains site two years ago from Tishman Speyer Properties of Manhattan. The former developer, who planned a similar although smaller mixed-use development, bailed out, in part because of financial problems.
About six blocks from the City Center project, more development is taking place, on the corner of Bloomingdale and Maple Avenues, where Fortunoff, the jewelry and home furnishings retailer, is building a 260,000-square-foot store. The latest Fortunoff project -- where a 128,000-square-foot Saks Fifth Avenue store formerly stood -- will be Fortunoff's first full-size department store in Westchester and its fifth in the New York area suburbs. (Fortunoff has a store in Scarsdale that sells outdoor furniture only and is open from March through Sept. 1.)
Near the Metro-North train station in White Plains, LCOR, a construction firm based in Berwyn, Pa., is building a $137 million apartment complex on a 2.6-acre site that had been considered at different times for an office building, movie theater and hotel. Those proposals failed to move forward, in part because of adverse market conditions in the early 1990's. The site, for decades an empty dirt lot, was often referred to as the city's "hole in the ground." LCOR is building 500 rental units in two towers, which are expected to be ready for occupancy next spring.
IN addition, a $6 million, 70,000-square-foot Stop & Shop is under construction on Westchester Avenue. "We've been a city without a major supermarket, without a movie theater and without any real entertainment to speak of," said George D. Gretsas, the city's executive officer. "Up until recently, there was nada in White Plains."
New apartments had not been built in the city in more than a decade. Now more than 1,700 are under construction. Besides those at City Center, the Seltzer Group, a Manhattan-based development company, is planning to put up the Hamilton, a 106-unit luxury rental apartment building, at the corner of Church Street and Barker Avenue. 
Also planned are 260 apartments on Canfield Avenue by Clayton Park Development of White Plains and Stamford; 281 rental units on Mamaroneck Avenue by the Houston-based JPI Corporation; and 106 units on Church Street by Pappas Development of Boston. 
When they are occupied, all of these new buildings will mean a heftier tax base for the city, with Mr. Cappelli's project expected to generate up to $3.5 million a year in sales tax revenues for the city, according to a study commissioned by the city and Cappelli Enterprises, by the accounting firm Ernst & Young. Fortunoff predicts $60 million in annual sales tax revenues. And that's not to mention a still undetermined amount of revenue from property taxes that the store will pay, said Paul S. Wood, the city's coordinator of economic development. The city's current budget is about $94 million.
The big businesses in White Plains are AT&T, I.B.M., Heineken U.S.A. and New York-Presbyterian Hospital. Currently, 53,000 residents call White Plains home. On weekdays, during business hours, 250,000 people fill buildings and parking lots in the business district. But as Mr. Delfino has observed, when the workers go home at the end of the day, the city becomes a ghost town. "You could fire a cannon in the downtown area at night and not hit anybody," he said shortly after taking office four years ago.
The city, which has been the seat of Westchester County government since 1778, underwent a huge urban renewal in the 1970's and 80's, when large sections of the downtown area were bulldozed and residents were moved out to make way for office towers.
Leon Silverman, president of the Silverman Realty Group in White Plains, which owns 300,000 square feet of retail and office space in 11 buildings in the business area, is pleased to see White Plains finally focusing on the downtown residential component. "The city is finally seeing the light -- that the only way it can survive is to bring people back," he said.
Studies have shown that employees spend an average of $5,000 annually in the area where they work, compared with residents, who spend about $19,000 a year, said Kathleen Gunn, executive director of the nonprofit White Plains Downtown District Management Association. 
At the time it undertook the urban renewal project, White Plains also built its first major enclosed mall, the 889,000-square-foot Galleria. But the presence of the new mall forced the existing retail outlets on the city's streets to eke out a living in its shadow. Then in 1995, the shops lining the streets downtown, which was known in more prosperous times as the City of 1,000 Stores, suffered even more when the 1.1-million-square-foot mall, The Westchester, opened with high-end retailers like Neiman Marcus and Tiffany's.
Why has the city taken so long "to see the light," as Mr. Silverman said? Why is it only now luring the kind of development calculated to generate more activity on the streets of downtown and provide a larger pool of workers to fill some of the vacant space that persists in the office towers? (As of the second quarter of this year, the availability rate for offices in the central business district was 21.6 percent, compared with the rate for the county, which was 15.5 percent, according to Insignia/ESG, a commercial real estate firm.)
Some people, including Mr. Silverman, credit Mr. Delfino with turning the city around. Others, like William M. King, a member of the city's Common Council, said he and a fellow board member, Ben Boykin, campaigned two-and-a-half years ago for change, and voters responded. Their election, in addition to the mayor's efforts, he said, sent a signal to developers that White Plains was encouraging development and wanted results soon. 
"There was all the built-up frustration with projects that never got off the ground," Mr. King said. As an example, he cited the infamous "hole in the ground," over which many battles were fought by developers and the Common Council before LCOR won city approval to build apartments there.
Some have pointed fingers at the city's often-fractious Common Council, whose six elected members reviewed and often fought over development proposals. But a former councilwoman, Mary Ann Keenan, said in large part, the successes now are a result of luck and timing.
"The Common Council was never antidevelopment," she said. "When we objected to a project, it was for a good reason. It's coincidence that everything is happening all at once." 
She speculated that the economy and the current low interest rates are also playing major roles in the development now. Mr. Cappelli agreed, saying that the current recession is providing an ideal business climate in which to invest in White Plains, because construction costs are low.
But also, the city initiated a coordinated review four years ago to simplify procedures for developers. Builders now sit down at a table with all of the city officials needed to approve a proposal, instead of being forced to go from office to office. "That process has streamlined what was a long, arduous task," said Salvatore Campofranco, senior vice president of Reckson Associates Realty Corporation, which owns property in both Westchester and Fairfield Counties. 
Mr. Cappelli said he experienced no problems working with the city on his proposal. But the negotiations with Tishman Speyer, the previous developer, were reportedly frequently contentious, according to news reports of Common Council meetings at the time. 
There have always been compelling reasons for a builder to persist in White Plains despite the earlier economic problems that plagued the city and its alleged reputation for being against development, Mr. Cappelli said. The city's strongest selling point, he said, is its location in the center of the county, with a number of major north-south highways making it accessible.
"To me, building in White Plains is equivalent to building at 42nd Street and Madison Avenue in New York City," he said. "They're both prime locations."
Roads in the city were already in place when Mr. Cappelli first proposed his development, an advantage for any developer, he said. White Plains also offered an abundance of Class A office space and two major shopping centers. What it lacked was a large number of people living in the downtown. Thus, the need for apartments. 
Mr. Cappelli describes himself as a catalyst in White Plains, one of the first developers to break ground here in recent years. But, he said, "It hasn't taken much to stir up the others waiting in the wings."
David Seltzer, president of the Seltzer Group, agreed that Mr. Cappelli has played a critical role, especially by building a movie theater downtown. "White Plains is finally about to become a 24-hour city," he said, "and now people will want to live here." 
The Seltzer Group is marketing the Hamilton's luxury apartments -- a two-bedroom unit will rent for about $3,500 a month -- to empty-nesters who no longer want to maintain their large Westchester homes, divorced people, younger working couples who are not ready to buy a house and business people in White Plains on a one- or two-year assignment. For the most part, they will be affluent renters who would not want to move to a city where the sidewalks are rolled up at night, Mr. Seltzer said.
THE new demographics evolving in White Plains are a draw for retailers like Louis Fortunoff. In addition to its Fifth Avenue store, the chain has suburban stores in Westbury on Long Island, and in Wayne, Woodbridge and Paramus in New Jersey. Mr. Fortunoff, the grandson of Max and Clara Fortunoff who opened their first store in Brooklyn in 1922, said that Fortunoff today chooses areas where there are at least 200,000 households with an average income of $75,000 or more within a 15-mile radius.
As of 1999, the median household income for White Plains was $58,545, said Mr. Wood, the city's economic development coordinator. That is expected to go up when the new apartments -- most of them high-end rentals -- are rented out. White Plains also draws affluent shoppers from other Westchester communities like Scarsdale and Purchase. The Westchester mall is a particular magnet. 
Looking ahead, the goal will be to maintain the small-town feeling that has always characterized White Plains, even as the city grows and becomes more prosperous, Mr. King said.
"It has to continue to be a livable city," he said. "We can't just build something and say, 'O.K., that's all done.' We have to keep improving on what we have."
Dean J. Shapiro, the executive director of Insignia/ESG's Westchester and Fairfield office, predicted that the construction taking place now would generate more growth in the city.
"Low-end retail will become high-end, which will in turn generate more restaurants, a stronger tax base and more residents who will push for more and better schools," Mr. Shapiro said. "The city has sown a lot of seeds, but it has to make sure that these new developments don't become self-contained, like the malls. With them, people drive into White Plains, do their shopping and go home, without using the city's other amenities. Any new development must be pedestrian-oriented and spread outward."
Mr. Boykin, the president of the Common Council, said that some residents have expressed concerns about added traffic and worried that the city may be developing too fast. "You always get those who have some objections," he said, "but the council is carefully managing what is taking place. We're not anticipating problems."

Still Standing: A Landmark Skyscraper
THE cityscape is changing rapidly in downtown White Plains, but at least one building along Mamaroneck Avenue is staying the same. Except for its occupants, little has changed over the years at the People's National Bank and Trust Company building, which was built in the late 1920's on the eve of the Great Depression.
The first skyscraper in the city, the nine-story bank building with its bronze front doors is now the home of the Westchester Arts Council. No longer the tallest building in the city -- it is dwarfed by the Westchester County Courthouse, which is more than twice its height -- it remains a a rare example of early 20th-century neo-Classical-style architecture in White Plains. 
When Janet T. Langsam, the executive director of the Arts Council, first learned that the building was for sale several years ago, she decided that it deserved a future as distinguished as its past. 
When the group moved to its new headquarters in 1999, it became one of the first concerns to commit itself to the future of the city's central business district.
"An arts council should be in the heart of a downtown, accessible to the people," Ms. Langsam said, "no matter what the profile of that downtown is at a particular moment." 
The city razed many of its older structures in the 1970's as part of an urban renewal project, but the bank is now on both the National and State Registers of Historic Places. That status guarantees that all changes must be in keeping with the character of the building and must be approved by the State Historic Preservation Office. The Arts Exchange, as the building is now called, is next door to the construction site for the $300 million City Center.
The Arts Exchange, which has galvanized metal windows, decorative details on the facade, distinctive brickwork and a copper pitched roof, was designed by Harold P. Zoller, a White Plains resident. It has a penthouse, which was used as a boardroom and features a Palladian-style window overlooking the city. 
The building houses a performance and gallery space in the lobby, 21 studios for artists and offices for the Arts Council and several other cultural organizations. 
The Arts Council has raised $3.2 million toward its goal of $5 million to restore and renovate the headquarters and to establish an endowment of $1 million to support services to Westchester-based artists and cultural organizations.
The Arts Council, a nonprofit group, provides financial and technical support to artists, cultural organizations and education programs. 
J. P. Morgan Chase & Company, which held the $1.35 million mortgage on the 57,000-square-foot structure, donated the building last year to the organization on the condition that it continue its mission to take the arts to underserved populations throughout Westchester. ELSA BRENNER
