 Late Edition - Final 

SECTION: Section 11; Column 2; Real Estate Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 3130 words

HEADLINE: Keeping Wide Open Spaces Wide Open 

BYLINE:  By DENNIS HEVESI 

 BODY:
WHITE pine are tenaciously rooted in the craggy rocks of a spit of land jutting into Sterling Lake.
 The lake is a centerpiece of Sterling Forest in Orange County, N.Y., where -- from the top of its 65-foot fire tower -- an undulating horizon of treetops is barely perceptibly pierced by the highest slivers of the Manhattan skyline, 35 miles to the south. 
 Were it not for the coming together of the federal government and two state governments, New York and New Jersey, at the cajoling of a coalition of nonprofit land trusts and private foundations, 15,000 homes might have been built on the forest's 20,000 acres, right up to the lake's shoreline.
In western Connecticut, where for more than a century one water company had closely managed 18,000 acres of woodlands and reservoirs with an eye toward ensuring the quality of its product, the uproar sparked by members of one local land trust over plans to sell 740 acres for homes and a golf course led to the completion of a deal, on March 28, to protect all of the forest in perpetuity. 
From the wetlands of Barnegat Bay on the Jersey coast, where tract development has nosed toward the shoreline, to a drug smuggler's government-seized hideaway overlooking Lake George, to dozens of community gardens dotting the five boroughs of New York City, land trusts have made remarkable strides in preserving open space during the last 10 or 12 years.
Some developers are distressed; some, despite serious philosophical differences with the preservationists, seek compromise, a balance of interests.
The Land Trust Alliance, as its name implies, is a coalition of 950 of the 1,263 land preservation organizations in the nation. According to the alliance, the total number of acres protected in New York State through the efforts of local and regional land trusts (not including acreage held by federal, state and local governments) catapulted from 70,938 in 1990 to 552,220 acres in 2000 -- a 678 percent increase.
In New Jersey, the number of acres protected by land trusts rose 122 percent, from 62,347 to 138,249 over the decade. In Connecticut, there was a 95 percent increase, from 36,034 to 70,361. (An acre is 91 percent of a football field.)
And the pattern held across the country. The total acreage in the nation protected by land trusts rose 226 percent, from 1,908,547 in 1990 to 6,225,225 in 2000 -- an area twice the size of Connecticut. At the same time, the number of land trusts increased from 887 to 1,263.
The Land Trust Alliance also calculated the combined acreage protected in each state through actions taken by the federal government, state or local governments and the land trusts. Of New York State's total of 30,220,000 acres, 5,608,431 acres -- or 19 percent -- had been protected as of Dec. 31, 2000. Of the 3,101,000 acres in Connecticut, 438,754 -- or 14 percent -- were protected by the end of the decade. And of New Jersey's 4,747,000 acres, 1,314,554 -- or 28 percent -- had been protected.
"The growth in land conservation has been tremendous," said Andrew Zepp, the alliance's vice president for programs. "Local conservation groups flourished, particularly in the 90's, whether they were professionally staffed, like the Peconic Land Trust on Long Island, or all-volunteer groups like we see all over New Jersey."
"These represent increased efforts on the part of communities to shape their futures," Mr. Zepp continued. "So we're seeing stronger partnerships between land trusts and government."
Martin Ginsburg, a developer who has cooperated with preservationists, is concerned. Mr. Ginsburg is president of GDC, which has built about 3,000 homes, most of them town houses in Westchester, Rockland and Fairfield Counties. "There are tensions between developers and preservationists," he said, "because open-space advocates are totally focused on preservation, and it's not possible to have preservation of everything and also have development. Development, by its nature, requires that you disturb some segment of the environment."
These days, Mr. Ginsburg contends, every community perceives every potential development site as potential preservable space. "There used to be a perception that there were zoned rights, that if the property was zoned a certain way the property owner had rights to develop," Mr. Ginsburg said. 
"Well," he said, referring particularly to Westchester, "that perception is no longer valid in most communities."
These days, just about every project must go through an environmental review "that can throw out the project," he said. "If the community doesn't want the project, the environmental review becomes a tremendously time-consuming and expensive process that can cost millions with the end result that the community can say they don't want it, on environmental grounds. And then, of course, you go to court."
MANY communities think they are preserving space by upzoning -- allowing fewer homes on larger lots. "That actually plays into and contributes to sprawl, which everybody is against," Mr. Ginsburg said. "Their responses are contributing to exactly what they think is anathema."
Ezra Milchman, the northeast regional director of the Land Trust Alliance, concurs with that assessment. "We call that sort of development, 'loving it to death,' " Mr. Milchman said.
What is needed is "smart growth," Mr. Ginsburg said. "You have to say these are the spaces we want to preserve and these are the areas that are located appropriately for denser development."
Mr. Ginsburg pointed to Wildwood, 62 acres in Greenburgh, N.Y., where his company sold 42 acres to the town for open space for $2.5 million, then built 86 homes on just 10 of the remaining 20 acres.
With a particular eye toward the towns and villages that necklace the Hudson River, Mr. Ginsburg said, "Development should be in proximity to mass transit, such as railroad stations, ferries." 
And there is a difference between preservation and redevelopment, he said: "Where the river was the driver of the local economy and the economy went bad, the whole village suffered. If you take the potential resource for revitalization and waste it by just making it greenfields and ball fields, you don't benefit the local economy."
The Sterling Forest deal, however, had nothing to do with redevelopment.
The 20,000 acres of highland woods have been wild since dinosaurs roamed what was then a tropical forest 65 million years ago, and certainly since retreating glaciers carved out the Ramapo River and regional lakes 14,000 years ago.
In the early 1700's, the Earl of Stirling purchased the land from the Iroquois. And in 1776, Gen. George Washington and his battered brigades fled north through the forest after barely escaping the British occupation of New York City.
In the words of its manager, Jim Gell, Sterling Forest State Park remains "a keystone in a greenbelt of nearly unfragmented forest -- not even farmlands -- that stretches from the Delaware Water Gap across northern New Jersey, across the Hudson into Connecticut, on into Massachusetts."
"We have bobcats, black bear -- not just a few," Mr. Gell continued, "numerous rare and endangered species, including the timber rattlesnake, red-shouldered hawks. We have a tremendous variety of butterflies; people drive across the country to look at butterflies in the park."
"It's amazing that it's so close to New York City, less than 35 miles to the Empire State Building," he said, "and yet so wild."
Eric Kulleseid, the New York State director of the Trust for Public Land, began fighting to keep it wild in the mid-90's when, four decades and several ownership shifts after the Harriman family first sold the property, a subsidiary of the Swiss-owned Zurich Insurance Group sought to turn the forest "into a huge residential area for 35,000 people, about 15,000 homes."
A coalition comprising the Trust for Public Land, the Open Space Institute, the Lila Acheson and DeWitt Wallace Foundation and the Victoria Foundation lobbied government officials at all levels and raised private funds to protect the forest forever.
The would-be developer had not yet filed plans when, in 1997, the land trusts negotiated an option to purchase the first 17,000 acres for $55 million, with a year to raise the money. (Later, $9 million would be raised to buy another 1,000 acres.) The Zurich Insurance Group "chose to take cash rather than go through the vicissitudes of the development market," Mr. Kulleseid said. 
No single entity was willing to take on the $55 million price tag. "So, with the encouragement of Governor Pataki, New York State stepped in and pledged $16 million," Mr. Kulleseid said. "Then we secured an additional $10 million from New Jersey, even though it wasn't in New Jersey." 
Mr. Gell, the park manager, explained that more than two million people in New Jersey drink water from Sterling Forest. "It feeds the Wanaque Reservoir and the Ramapo Watershed," he said.
Mr. Kulleseid continued, "Then we secured $17 million from the federal Land and Water Conservation Fund, and an additional $12 million in private funding from both the Lila Acheson and DeWitt Wallace Foundation -- those are the founders of Reader's Digest -- and the Victoria Foundation in New Jersey." 
In February 1998, the property was transferred to New York State, guaranteed as open public parkland. "That was a huge, huge deal; that much land so close to the city," Mr. Kulleseid said.
Forty miles farther from the city, the Lundy estate -- 5,400 acres that connect a stretch of cliff called the Shawangunk Ridge to the Catskill Forest Preserve -- is another of those places where leaves whisper in the wind without even a hum from a highway.
The property had been the weekend retreat of Frederick Lundy, founder of the famous restaurant in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, who first began accumulating its 95 tax lots in the 1920's. 
Two weeks ago, picnickers from several land trusts and the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation gathered at a spot on the Lundy property along Vernooys Kill (kill is Dutch for brook) where rock sculptures are carved by the swirling stream just before it cascades.
The picnic at the swimming hole celebrated the transfer of the property to New York State in a $4 million deal that came about only after plans for a theme park on the Lundy land collapsed. "It's pristine woodlands," said Jennifer Grossman, vice president for land acquisition for the Open Space Institute. "This piece provides us with a key link to the Catskill Forest, and it is becoming public."
Andy Burgher, the land surveyor and title historian on the project for the state conservation agency, said: "Originally, the land was made up of patents granted by Queen Anne and King George in the 1700's to a few families, including the Vernooys." Over the next three centuries, descendants of those settlers, Mr. Burgher said, "worked mostly as millers -- grist mills for flour -- and blacksmiths; they made axes, and ax handles from the ash trees." 
By the 1950's, Mr. Lundy had bought all 5,400 acres. "It was his place to escape to from Brooklyn," Mr. Burgher said. Mr. Lundy died in 1977 and, eventually, the executor of his estate sold the property to the Litas Investment Corporation.
"They were planning a kind of Euro Disney -- a theme park about the size of Disney World, but like the Black Forest," Mr. Burgher said. "But Litas never could get all the money together." In January 2000, the land was purchased by the Open Space Institute and the Trust for Public Land for transfer to the state.
THE Sterling Forest and Lundy deals were both what preservationists refer to as fee acquisitions, direct purchases of property by a land trust or a government agency, as opposed to easement transactions in which the owner retains title to the property but agrees to bar development in perpetuity.
"Easements are always much more complicated than outright purchases," Mr. Kulleseid of the Trust for Public Land said, "because you need to negotiate how the owners will be able to use the property, how the easement is going to be enforced, how it will be monitored."
Typically, under an easement, the land trust will negotiate the price and conditions, then hold the contract until a government agency completes its due diligence and "brings the check to the table," Mr. Kulleseid said. "The attractive thing to landowners is that they get cash to add to their reserves or to make improvements, but still own that property."
The protection of what have come to be called the Kelda lands -- 15,340 acres of watershed in western Connecticut -- involved both types of transactions, said David Sutherland, government relations director for the Connecticut chapter of the Nature Conservancy.
"It used to be the Bridgeport Hydraulic Company, the major supplier of water in Fairfield County," Mr. Sutherland said. "They've been around for a century and always managed the land with the goal of preserving water quality." In January 2001, Bridgeport Hydraulic and its major subsidiary, Aquarion, were acquired by the Kelda Group, a British utility company.
But the idea of preserving all the Kelda lands got its start five years ago when Aquarion announced plans to sell 740 acres in the towns of Weston and Easton for $14 million to National Fairways Inc. "They planned to build about 130 houses -- little bitty 6,000-square-foot shacks -- and a golf course," Mr. Sutherland said.
"But in Connecticut," he continued, "there's a state law that says that if a water company is selling land, once they've signed a contract there's a 100-day period within which government or land trusts can take over the contract."
With 45 minutes to go before the deadline of 5 p.m. on June 5, 1998, a local preservation group, the Aspetuck Land Trust, with backing from the Nature Conservancy, declared its commitment to raise $8 million, which, along with $6 million from the state, covered the $14 million cost of the purchase.
"The controversy over that land was very visible," Mr. Sutherland said. "When the state, the conservancy and the Aspetuck Land Trust agreed to do that deal, it really laid the groundwork to acquire the entire Kelda property."
A regional group, the Connecticut Fund for the Environment, built a coalition of local land trusts calling for the preservation of all the Kelda lands, with the idea that the state would create a regional water authority. At the same time, Mr. Sutherland said, his group was "pursuing what you might call a traditional land-acquisition deal, both fee and easement."
"Even though ours is the one that ended up happening," he said, "the organizing they did certainly helped garner political support for the deal that eventually happened." The Kelda lands were appraised at $193 million, but the company agreed to sell parcels or easements in 24 different Connecticut municipalities for a total of $90 million. The state allocated $80 million; the Nature Conservancy donated $10 million.
"We had identified eight areas around Connecticut as our best opportunities to preserve large, primarily contiguous blocks of forest land," Mr. Sutherland said. "Over half of Kelda's land fell right in the heart of two of those areas." The deal closed on March 28.
Sometimes preservation is not a big deal. In New York City, about 120 community gardens that former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani wanted to auction off for housing have been purchased by the Trust for Public Land and New York Restoration, a group financed by Bette Midler. 
Along with its missions to provide technical assistance and foster cooperation between local land trusts, particularly for large-scale preservation projects, the Land Trust Alliance, based in Washington, also promotes legislation aimed at, among other things, creating tax incentives for owners who agree to preserve their property.
"We're pushing a new federal tax deduction that would make a 50 percent cut in your capital gains tax if you sell land to a nonprofit or a government agency for conservation," said Mr. Milchman, the northeast director for the alliance. And on a state level in New York, for example, Mr. Milchman said, the alliance has successfully lobbied for legislation to complement that federal initiative -- a Conservation Donor Tax Credit recently passed by the Legislature.
"Very simply, land owners who donate property or easements could claim half of the value of the gift on their state income tax return as a credit," Mr. Milchman said. "Let's say you owe $5,000 in state income tax and you donated a $10,000 easement -- you would get a credit of 50 percent of the value of the gift, or $5,000, which you can spread out over 11 years." Gov. George E. Pataki -- whom Mr. Milchman commended as having "demonstrated a strong commitment to public-private partnership in land conservation" -- now has the bill on his desk. The governor had proposed a 25 percent tax credit spread over six years.
IT was another sort of government action that led to the preservation of Pilot's Knob Ridge, a lookout point 2,000 feet above the south end of Lake George from which, on a clear day, the jagged peaks of the Adirondacks are visible.
Perhaps the owner of those 223 acres should have been looking down, not out, that day in November 1984, when, as Lynn Schumann, director of the Lake George Land Conservancy, put it, "federal agents in their black suits came from all directions to arrest him while he was drinking bourbon with a neighbor."
"This gentleman was running from the law, a marijuana smuggler," Ms. Schumann said. "He had built a road and a very unimposing home on the property. This was his hideaway."
All around the south basin of the 32-mile-long lake, Ms. Schumann continued, "people considered the house an eyesore for its clear-cut in the mountainside and bright lights at night."
The property was seized by the government and resold to a local family who held it for 10 years. In August 2000, the family sold the land to the Lake George conservancy for $575,000 -- $220,000 less than the $795,000 bid by a developer who planned to clear timber for several building lots.
And on a Friday in September 2001, "with dozens of spectators down below on their lawns and numerous boats anchored in the lake," Ms. Schumann said, "cheers went up as we razed the house, piece by piece."
In the last 14 years, using $14 million in private donations and state funds, the lake conservancy has protected 7,275 acres, including 26,500 feet of shoreline. And since its acquisition, Pilot's Knob Ridge has been opened to the public, with a two-mile loop for hiking and a gazebo overlooking Dome Island, just offshore, a nearly perfect cakelike isle of hemlock, beech and oak.
The ridge also looks down on two parallel peninsulas, Cleverdale and Assembly Point, stretching a mile or so into the lake -- each dotted by large homes.

HEADLINE: Mr. Nice Guy With the State's Toughest Job 

BYLINE:  By JOHN SULLIVAN 

DATELINE: TRENTON 

 BODY:
HERE, as in most political centers, you can eventually find someone with something bad to say about almost anyone. The more visible the person, the easier it is to find detractors. John E. McCormac, the state treasurer, might be the exception.
 Talk to power players lurking throughout the State House about the 44-year-old Mr. McCormac, and the conversation eventually gets around to the same point. 
 "He is a nice guy," says Senate John O. Bennett, the Republican who share's the chamber's presidency with his Democratic counterpart, Richard J. Codey. 
As Senator Robert E. Littell, a Republican who is cochairman of the Budget Committee, put it: "He is fine to work with. He is a very regular guy."
And that is the word from the opposition party.
What is even more impressive is that Mr. McCormac -- who was chosen by his longtime friend and colleague Governor McGreevey to be the state treasurer at a particularly perilous time for New Jersey -- seems to have pulled off a difficult political feat: helping to produce one of the most controversial and hard-fought state budgets in recent memory without making any visible enemies across the legislative aisle.
In the past several months, Mr. McCormac has faced a $6 billion deficit for fiscal 2003, a $3 billion shortfall for the fiscal year 2002 and a loss of $22 billion in state investments.
But perhaps he became best known early on his watch when he found himself at the center of a public relations battle during which the governor's press office refused to allow reporters to quote him during a question-and-answer session about the proposed budget. Mr. McCormac retreated from the room without speaking a word after the meeting degenerated into a shouting match. The session effectively ended when the roomful of reporters walked out soon afterward.
Even the people who opposed the governor's plan to raise revenue most vigorously -- particularly by increasing the taxes paid by corporations -- go out of their way to speak kindly about the tall, stocky bear of a man.
"I might not have liked his answers, but he always gave me answers," said Arthur Maurice, vice president of the New Jersey Business and Industry Association, the state's largest business organization. "It would have been easier to fight him if he wasn't so likable."
Normally, people cannot remember -- and don't particularly care -- who the state treasurer is, much less whether he is likable. But Mr. McCormac finds himself in the odd position of being a civil servant thrust into a harsh spotlight. Like a volunteer fire chief during a nationally televised rescue or a health commissioner during the outbreak of a virulent disease, Mr. McCormac accepted a $137,000-a-year job -- far less than he was earning in his own accounting firm -- that was supposed to be about the routine and was suddenly given the very public responsibility of fending off impending fiscal disaster.
It might be a good match, considering that the governor -- who has worked with Mr. McCormac for more than 10 years -- described him as a man who "is envigorated by challenges." So far that seems to be true.
"I enjoy this job tremendously," Mr. McCormac said during a recent interview in his State House office. 
And it is an unusual office for a state treasurer, reflective of Mr. McCormac's reputation as a die-hard baseball fan. The walls are covered with posters of players, and tiny models of stadiums crowd a table near the entrance. A photograph of Joe DiMaggio hangs in a spot of honor in the middle of the room's most prominent wall.
He said, "DiMaggio went up before my treasurer's plaque."
Mr. McCormac has been a baseball fan ever since his father and a group of friends traveled to Yankee Stadium when Mr. McCormac was 6. "I got a Tom Tresh bat," he said.
He doesn't recall who won the game, but he does remember almost catching a foul ball. "My friend's father got it," he said.
He still plays catcher for the Knights of Columbus softball team with friends from elementary school. The way Governor McGreevey puts it, Mr. McCormac considers softball "a combat sport."
"Slow pitch," Mr. McCormac said. "We're too old for fast pitch" -- not that his new job has left much time for batting practice. "I think I have missed more games this year than I have in the past years combined."
Born in Irvington and reared in Woodbridge, Mr. McCormac grew up in a boisterous house filled with three boys and two girls. As the eldest, he helped his father, the foreman of a steel plant, and his mother, a housewife, keep the mayhem to a minimum. He went on to marry his high school sweetheart, Tammy, and today they have a 12-year-old daughter. He received his bachelor's degree from Rutgers University in 1980, and then attended night school at St. John's on Staten Island, where he earned a master's degree. After working for a large accounting firm for eight years, he founded McCormac & Company in Woodbridge, specializing in government finance.
He received his introduction to politics 12 years ago when he met Mr. McGreevey -- also a resident of Woodbridge and a member of the Assembly, on St. Patrick's Day at the Knights of Columbus in Iselin. At the time, Mr. McCormac was the chapter's grand knight and Mr. McGreevey was an ambitious politician with a plan to change the system in their hometown. The two men talked briefly at a reception after the parade and agreed to meet for breakfast at the Landmark Inn in Woodbridge.
Mr. McCormac liked Mr. McGreevey's plan to streamline the town's financial management, and when Mr. McGreevey said he wanted to run for mayor, Mr. McCormac agreed to help with the campaign. After Mr. McGreevey won, he asked Mr. McCormac to become the town's chief financial officer. "It was a monumental task" to reorganize the town's finances, Mr. McCormac said.
He added: "It was, on a smaller scale, the same type of problems we faced this year in the state. There was a $24 million shortfall on a $60 million budget."
He took the job, and today he cites construction of the Woodbridge Community Center as his proudest moment in government. The 110,000-square-foot center, which includes a gym and a skating rink, was financed with corporate gifts and user fees.
"It was one of Mayor McGreevey's biggest achievements in 10 years in Woodbridge," he said.
He likes to explain that period this way: After Mr. McGreevey took office, the state audited the town's books and found more than 100 areas that needed improvement. "When we left office, the state only found one," he said. "We were issuing dog licenses out of sequence."
When Mayor McGreevey finally became governor after losing to Christie Whitman his first time around, he again turned to Mr. McCormac to handle the books, this time as the state treasurer. When some people balked, questioning whether Mr. McCormac had the experience to manage a budget as large and complex as New Jersey's, the new governor said he was confident in the selection.
"I needed a strong, competent fiscal officer," Governor McGreevey said in a recent interview. He said Mr. McCormac's experience in municipal finance, as well as his background operating an accounting firm, gave him the necessary experience.
Equally important, Mr. McCormac's loyalty to Mr. McGreevey was beyond question.
When he took on the job, Mr. McCormac sold his interest in his accounting firm. He said he was not worried about assuming responsibility for the state's finances because the principals of the state budget and the Woodbridge town budget were essentially the same. 
"It is the same way to manage the operations," he said. "I just had to get used to saying billions instead of millions."
But with the economy retracting and a crisis looming, Mr. McCormac was soon deep in negotiations with legislative leaders over how best to balance the budget. It is difficult to say how much independence Mr. McCormac had over decisions that the governor was constantly monitoring.
For his part, Governor McGreevey insists that Mr. McCormac has never been shy about voicing his opinion on -- or his opposition to -- the governor's ideas. But he said that cornerstone of the new budget, like the tightening of loopholes in the corporate business tax, were hammered out by a team of financial advisers rather than one person.
Unlike states like New York, where the chief financial officer is independently elected, New Jersey's treasurer -- like every other official in the state other than the legislative leaders -- serves at the pleasure of the governor.
And in this administration, there seems to be an exclamation point at the end of that.
"This administration likes to discuss budgetary matters from the front office," said Senator Leonard Lance, a Republican from Flemington who sits on the Finance Committee. Mr. McCormac, he said, "implements the policies of the governor."
Other legislators involved in the budget negotiations agreed that most of the crucial decisions were referred to the governor, although Mr. McCormac had the authority to negotiate many areas.
"He handles his own domain, but he takes orders from outside," said Senator Bennett.
Still, Senator Bernard F. Kenney Jr., a Democratic from Hoboken who is on the Budget Committee, said people underestimated how much influence Mr. McCormac had over the negotiations. Although the governor made the policy decisions, Mr. Kenney said, Mr. McCormac mastered the technical intricacies of the financial plan.
"He is able to grasp difficult material and to articulate it in terms that legislators can understand, and that is a skill that is rare," Mr. Kenney said.
More than that, Senator Kenney -- who sponsored the legislation to toughen the corporate business tax -- said Mr. McCormac "made it clear that he was not just a figurehead."
"He was in fact the top dog in terms of understanding the material and defending it," he said.
Mr. Kenney recalled one heated moment during negotiations over changes to the corporate business tax -- it was well after midnight and committee members from both sides were still closeted in a meeting room near the Senate chamber -- when "a senior official" called Mr. McCormac on his cellphone and told him that questions were being raised about the treasurer's budget calculations. Mr. McCormac, turning stern in an instant, made his position unmistakably clear.
"He is always very agreeable, but he is also very competitive and very sure of himself," Mr. Kenney said. "He got red in the face and said, 'Nobody knows numbers like I know numbers.' And that was that."

CORRECTION-DATE: August 25, 2002

 CORRECTION:
An article on Aug. 11 about the role played by New Jersey's treasurer, John E. McCormac, in eliminating the budget deficit misspelled the surname of a Democrat from Hoboken who commented. He is State Senator Bernard F. Kenny Jr., not Kenney.

HEADLINE: DOWN THE SHORE; 
One Hot Season

BYLINE:  By ROBERT STRAUSS 

DATELINE: NORTH WILDWOOD 

 BODY:
THE Ramirez family was in from Puerto Rico for the week, the three young children splashing up a storm at the Packard Hotel pool, chattering and giggling under the plastic palms.
 Lounging nearby were the LeClerqs, in from Quebec, trying to decide when to wander up to the Boardwalk. 
 On the Boardwalk at Morey's Pier, Sean O'Malley, a student from Ireland, had brought "The Autobiography of Martin Luther King Jr." to his post, where he operated a kiddy slide, but was too busy to read it.
While it might be a stretch to say that the Jersey Shore has become an international hot spot for vacationers, the presence of the LeClerqs and the Ramirezes is proof enough of boom times at the beach even though -- or perhaps because -- the stock market's breathtaking plunge makes Sean's sliding board look more like a curb. 
"Merchants may always like to grumble, but I really don't know anyone who is doing badly this summer," said Laurie Sullivan, an associate in the Wildwood Information Bureau. "It has been hot, so people are at the beach or in the pool in the daytime. But at night, oh my gosh, I've never seen it so busy. You just can't move."
Nor is it simply the summer surfer or sunshine patron looking for a little slice of heaven for a day or a weekend or a week somewhere along the 127-mile-long New Jersey coastline. Buyers are flocking to Wildwood in numbers that haven't been seen in decades. Last month, the city put up a property a block from the bay for auction. Swollen with optimism because of recent good times, the city hoped it would get $150,000. The property sold for $308,000, and it is hoped the buyer will build upscale condominiums there.
"I would have never thought I would see a $300,000 property in my lifetime here, but the shore boom is hitting all over, I hear," Ms. Sullivan said.
She hears right. In Stone Harbor, where the price of admission is considerably steeper, of the 41 single-family houses sold in the first half of 2002, none went for less than $300,000. In fact, the average selling price for those properties was $1,102,981. 
And in Sea Isle City, two towns north of Stone Harbor and long known as a middle-class resort, the average house sold for $499,631 this year, about three times what it was just six years ago.
"There has been no letup in the sales of shore properties," said Gwen Pastorelli, a real estate saleswoman with the Mary Holder Agency in Sea Girt. "People are taking money out of the stock market, and with interest rates so low, they have just kept buying."
What's more, Ms. Pastorelli said, the buying also makes things more attractive for renters. Even in Asbury Park, a city torn down but not even close to being rebuilt, properties have been gobbled up by those willing to stay, or at least to renovate.
"Eventually, that will mean more places for people to go at the shore, so that is good for everyone," Ms. Pastorelli said.
As with Asbury Park, Atlantic City -- another shore town trying to recapture its lost luster -- is showing evidence of better times this summer. The Trump Organization, for instance, which operates three casinos in Atlantic City and derives most of its revenue from them, realized its first second-quarter profit in seven years.
Gary Israel, a spokesman for the South Jersey Transportation Authority, which oversees the Atlantic City Expressway, said that so far this year, the number of vehicles to pass through the toll booths was up 12.8 percent over the same period last year -- 29.1 million versus 25.8 million.
"The Jersey Shore certainly benefits from whatever fallout there is over 9/11," said Mr. Israel. "But these numbers don't even count July 4, which was by far a record."
What's more, said Mr. Israel, people are not only driving to the Shore, but flying. The authority, which also oversees Atlantic City International Airport, has seen the number of commercial passengers increase 3.6 percent so far this year.
Still, there may be a bit of a cloud on the horizon for the rest of the summer, warned John Atwood, whose family has owned the Sun N Sand Motel in Stone Harbor for 50 years.
The weekends of Memorial Day and July Fourth were as busy as he has ever seen, said Mr. Atwood, but some of the air has escaped from the balloon since then.
"When the stock market went down again, I think people said, 'Hey, Martha, we just lost another $8,000, maybe we won't go to the shore this month,' " he said.
While that might not be apparent to weekend renters who book in the winter and spring, he said, motel owners make much of their money from last-minute business.
"I'm sitting on an empty room tonight," Mr. Atwood said last week. "That shouldn't happen this time of year. But I hear things are good in Wildwood and Ocean City, so, you know, everyone has slower times and other people have it good. I just hope this doesn't say anything about next year."
If the LeClerqs -- visiting North Wildwood for the fourth time in six years -- are any indication, it will not.
"It is still less expensive than going to Europe or California," said Rene LeClerq.

HEADLINE: HOME FRONT; 
How to Find a Job? Try Hiring a Sleuth

BYLINE:  By Leslie Eaton 

 BODY:
SO here's a little mystery. The New York State Department of Labor says that roughly 232,000 people in the state have collected unemployment benefits under the special program adopted by the federal government after Sept. 11. The program gives up to 13 weeks of benefits to anyone who uses up the traditional six months of unemployment insurance and still hasn't found a job.
 But of those 232,000 -- and that by no means represents all unemployed workers -- only 72,000 were still getting benefits in mid-July. So what happened to the other 160,000? Did they find jobs? Or did they just run out of benefits and luck? 
 The Labor Department says it hasn't a clue. "The official short answer is, we actually don't have that information," said Robert M. Lillpopp, a department spokesman.
But, he added, the department thinks at least some people have found work. The state's most recent job fair in New York City drew more than 3,000 people, he said; they could apply for 1,500 jobs with 70 employers, including airlines, department stores and the New York City Police Department.
Less optimistic clues to the mystery can be found in a new series of job-related data put together by the federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. 
Known as JOLTS, for job openings and labor turnover, the series is rather limited, covering only one year so far, and doesn't include details on individual states. But the picture it paints is none too pretty, especially in the Northeast. 
Start with the number of job openings, which are jobs that employers are actively seeking to fill within 30 days. 
In May, the most recent month for which there is data, 3.46 million jobs were open across the country, which sounds all right until you discover that last year at the same time there were 4.34 million openings. That works out to a drop of about 884,000, or 20 percent.
And in the Northeast, things were even worse. Even in 2001, this area of the country had fewer job openings than in the South, the Midwest or the West. And by May 2002, the number of openings had fallen by 29 percent, or about 250,000, to 604,000.
But it could be worse. In the Midwest, job openings plunged by 313,000, or 31 percent. Best off was the South, which had the most openings to begin with (about 1.5 million) and lost the fewest (122,000, or about 8 percent). Grits, anyone?
The big drops in job openings, nationally, came in two economically sensitive areas: construction and retailing.
The Labor Department also estimates the number of people hired in a month. In May, nationally, almost 4.9 million people got jobs (or got called back to their old ones, if they had been laid off). That's another figure that sounds pretty good, until you find out that in May 2001, almost 5.7 million people were hired. So hiring fell by 14 percent compared with last year. 
Once again, the situation was bleakest in the Northeast and the Midwest, and best in the South. The Midwest suffered a greater drop in the number of new hires, which fell by 283,000, versus 218,000 in the Northeast. But the Northeast experienced a bigger percentage decline (21 percent, versus 19 percent in the Midwest). In the South, hiring declined by less than 9 percent.
One bright note in all this dark data is that fewer people lost their jobs in May 2002 than in the same month a year earlier. 
Nationally, layoffs and discharges edged down from 1.6 million to 1.35 million; in the Northeast, they fell to 222,000 from 244,000. The declines were even sharper in the Midwest and the West, but in the South, layoffs actually rose (so much for those grits).
The statistics bureau also calculates something called the quits rate, which measures the number of people who leave their jobs voluntarily as a percentage of total employment. 
The quits rate, which according to the bureau "can serve as a barometer of workers' ability to change jobs," dropped sharply over the last year, to 1.8 percent from 2.2 percent. ( That may not seem like a sharp drop, but to economists, it's major.)
The Northeast already had the lowest percentage of quitters, at 1.5 percent, but it actually edged downward over the past year to 1.4 percent. Which suggests that people who have jobs aren't going anywhere.
None of these data answer conclusively the mystery of the missing 160,000 unemployed people. But, Dr. Watson, how many of them do you think found work?

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS; 
Gabrielle Chodes, Jeffery Young

 BODY:
Gabrielle Eve Chodes, a graduate student, and Jeffery Avery Young, a Foreign Service officer, are to be married today on Cape Cod. Henry H. Shultz, a justice of the peace in Newton, Mass., will officiate at the Wequassett Inn in Chatham, Mass.
 The bride, 30, is a candidate for a master's degree in Asian studies at the Australian National University in Canberra. She graduated magna cum laude from Boston University, from which she also received a master's degree in international relations and a law degree. 
 She is a daughter of Joanna Chodes of Chestnut Hill, Mass., and the late Stephen Chodes. Her mother is a property manager at River Street Realty in Boston, a family-owned business specializing in rentals. The bride's father was a producer of educational films for the Honeywell Corporation in Wellesley, Mass.
The bridegroom, 40, is an economic officer with the State Department in Washington. He was posted until last month to the United States embassy in Canberra. He graduated from Wesleyan University and received an M.B.A. from Columbia. His mother, Margaret L. Young of Hopkins, Minn., is a freelance librarian for consulting and accounting businesses. His father, Dr. Harold C. Young, lives in Blagoevgrad, Bulgaria, and is the library director there for the American University in Bulgaria. 
Ms. Chodes and Mr. Young met in June 1998 in Washington, where she was doing a summer internship at the Commerce Department and he was at the State Department, preparing for his first overseas assignment. On their first date, Mr. Young invited her out for dinner, soft-shell crabs, in Aberdeen, Md. "Jeff thought that the trip might be fun," Ms. Chodes recalled. 
"Although I don't really like crabs, I went," she said. "When we arrived at the crab shack, it turned out Jeff does not like crabs, either. And so we ordered one lone crab from our puzzled waitress."

HEADLINE: Personal Business; 
A New Way to Cut Payments on Your Old Car

BYLINE:  By MICHELINE MAYNARD 

DATELINE: DETROIT 

 BODY:
WHEN James E. Adsley bought his 1999 Cadillac Eldorado late last year, the best financing plan he was able to find was a three-year, 8.25 percent loan through the dealer. After a down payment, he needed to borrow nearly $24,000.
 He assumed the rate was the lowest he could get at the time. Used-car loan rates generally run a half to a full percentage point higher than those for new cars, and the average new-car rate at the time was hovering above 7 percent. 
 But listening to ads all winter for interest-free financing and other discount loan deals on new cars, Mr. Adsley, 61, a medical consultant who lives in Whidbey Island, Wash., near Seattle, wondered if he could have done better. Then a friend suggested that he investigate auto loan refinancing, something he never knew existed. 
Initially, Mr. Adsley was wary. "I was hesitant to get involved with turning over a loan," he said. But after researching the various deals on the Internet, Mr. Adsley wound up with a 6.9 percent loan, lasting 72 months, or twice the length of his original loan, from PeopleFirst.com, a San Diego-based online lender that is a division of CapitalOne. He expects to save around $2,000 in interest expenses over the life of the loan.
The transaction, which included a small title-transfer fee, was conducted entirely by e-mail and telephone. Within two days of completing his application, a check arrived, which Mr. Adsley signed over to his previous lender, GMAC, the financing arm of the General Motors Corporation. "The transfer went very smoothly," he said.
Mr. Adsley is part of a small, yet growing number of people who are deciding to refinance the loans on their cars, trucks and minivans, much as consumers have long refinanced the mortgages on their houses. As yet, the auto loan refinancing market is but a fraction of the annual $1.63 trillion that banks and lending companies do in new and used car financing. About 1.1 million loans were refinanced last year, according to CNW Marketing Research of Bandon, Ore.
Lenders contend the market will grow, especially as auto companies continue to advertise interest-free loans and other discount financing plans on new vehicles. Already, at LendingTree.com, one of a number of Internet lenders that offer the plans, auto loan refinancing requests have jumped 26 percent in the first six months of 2002.
"It's one of the best-kept secrets" for saving money, said Brian Reed, chief executive at PeopleFirst.com.
IT also seems to be a market that the Internet sites, a few banks and credit unions have to themselves. While financing companies owned by the automakers provide more than 60 percent of all auto loans, they have shown little interest in refinancing existing loans. The companies' primary focus is to help dealers arrange loans for new vehicles, not make it cheaper for consumers to own their current vehicles.
"I don't know of any of us that want to do refinancing," said George Borst, president of Toyota Financial Services, the credit arm of Toyota, based in Torrance, Calif.
Indeed, 25 years ago, when the average car or truck cost $10,000, auto loan refinancing was almost unheard of, even as mortgage refinancing became popular, said Joseph Kennedy, president of Eloan.com, which provides auto refinancing, and the former head of sales and marketing for the Saturn Corporation.
The reasons were simple. Consumers were eager to refinance mortgages, because the amounts borrowed were large, and even a half-point interest rate reduction could yield significant savings. Also, homes grew in value, especially if improvements were made.
But, with rare exceptions, cars and trucks were worth less the older they got. Loan amounts were much smaller than for homes, and there didn't seem to be a need to refinance a loan on something that might not be around when the payments were finished.
Now, however, vehicles are costing more and lasting longer than ever. The average life of a vehicle is around 13 years, and the average amount of time people keep their cars and trucks is around 7 years. The average sticker is more than $25,000, thanks to the growing popularity of high-priced sport utility vehicles and luxury cars. 
Today's typical car loan is longer than 60 months. (The average length of a refinanced loan is 49 months, though most people refinance a year into their initial loan.) The potential savings on refinanced vehicle loans have become attractive: each one-point drop in interest on a $25,000, 60-month loan can save nearly $1,000 over the life of the loan, according to calculations from PeopleFirst.com.
Convenience is another drawing card. PeopleFirst.com, for instance, promises an answer within 15 minutes and no inspection of an automobile is required, because the financial institutions are buying the loan, not the vehicle, Mr. Reed said.
Even though the number of people who have refinanced their auto loans is small, the potential audience seems to be huge. Auto loan rates now are two to three points cheaper than they were in 2000, when sales of cars and trucks hit a record 17.6 million in the United States.
Back then, "you were doing pretty well to get a number in the 8.5 percent to 9 percent range," said Mr. Kennedy of Eloan.com, which is based in Dublin, Calif.
This summer, Eloan.com's auto loan refinancing plans average 6.5 percent, while PeopleFirst.com is offering refinancing plans for as low as 5.79 percent, which are comparable to the prevailing rates on conventional new-car loans. But consumers need to know that, as with the interest-free plans available from auto companies, the best refinancing rates are available on the shortest-length loans, and to consumers with spotless payment histories.
"These are really for people with good credit," Mr. Kennedy said. "If you are struggling with your payments, this is not a way to hitch onto another lender." 
CNW's president, Art Spinella, is also skeptical of the idea. He thinks consumers may be better off selling their vehicles, buying new ones and negotiating more attractive interest rates from scratch rather than stretching out payments on an existing loan. "Refinancing is a terrible idea, because you don't want the vehicle around that long," he said.
STILL, refinancing can lower payments and extend them, which many people may find helpful during these tough economic times. At the same time, the wide variety of financing options available right now is giving car buyers even more flexibility in negotiating deals. 
Many auto companies are now offering consumers a choice between interest-free or discount loan rates and rebates, but don't allow them to take both. Because he was able to find cheaper financing on his own, Phillip Michael Brunetti, 46, a social worker from Columbus, Ohio, chose to take a rebate on a 2002 Chrysler Town and Country minivan instead of an interest-free financing offer. The rebate, plus some tough negotiating, brought the price down to $27,000, versus the $31,000 Mr. Brunetti would have paid for a vehicle with interest-free financing. 
Mr. Brunetti subsequently was able to find a 66-month loan for 6 percent. Even with interest payments, and the cost of an extended warranty, he still expects to pay less over the life of the loan than he would have paid had he bought the more expensive vehicle. He is glad to have such options. "There's a difference out there than there was two years ago," he said.
Lenders admit that a lot of people still are unaware of refinancing. "We have a lot of work to do to build consumer awareness and understanding of how it works and what to do," Mr. Kennedy said.

HEADLINE: What 80 Warren Street Knows 

BYLINE:  By BARBARA STEWART 

 BODY:
MARVIN GOLDSTEIN, a retired art professor, has lived for 22 years at 80 Warren Street, a brick and stone building on the southern fringe of TriBeCa in which co-ops fetch $1.5 million apiece.
 Even after the attack on the World Trade Center, whose falling towers Mr. Goldstein could see from the building's front door, a survey of real estate costs showed that TriBeCa was the city's highest-priced residential neighborhood last year, surpassing the Upper East Side. 
 But every now and then, Mr. Goldstein steps outside of his high-ceilinged loft and is reminded of the old days: "A guy looking like he just got out of the hoosegow will wander by and say, 'Is this where the employment agencies are?' " 
It was, some 30 years ago. Back then, the building was occupied by dozens of low-end employment agencies offering a day or two of unappetizing work -- washing dishes, shoveling snow -- for rock-bottom wages. Men who were down and out crowded the halls, vestibule and nearby sidewalks, pushing, smoking, fighting with fists and knives -- and waiting. 
The scene was so dismal, and so indicative of larger social problems, that Michael Harrington used it to help dramatize the ravages of urban woes in his groundbreaking book "The Other America," published 40 years ago. "Some of my friends call 80 Warren Street 'the slave market,' " Harrington wrote. 
The transformation, from a center of blue-collar desperation to shelter for the moneyed, is just one chapter in the life of 80 Warren Street. The building, directly south of Chambers Street and three blocks west of City Hall, is actually the consolidation of five structures erected in the mid-18th century. It has housed New York's legendary butter-and-egg men; the job agencies described by Harrington; impoverished artists; and, more recently, co-op dwellers willing to pay a fortune for a one-bedroom with a sauna. 
Old buildings retain memories of former lives, labors, sufferings and pleasures in their walls and moldings. Eighty Warren Street, with its 32 co-op apartments, is no exception. Its big windows with low sills evoke the days when workmen passed crates of dairy products through them. It is easy to envision grizzled drifters puffing away in the grayish, unornamented lobby. A row of windows in some of the first-floor apartments face a brick wall, a reminder that butter-and-egg men didn't care about good views.
Still, few current residents know about the building's colorful past. Boxy and unremarkable, like many of its neighbors, 80 Warren is easy to overlook. Quiet and unassuming, it merits not a single mention in the files of the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission. It is an old New York story: a plain facade behind which lurks a rich history.

The Butter and Egg Era
Three centuries ago, when Colonial New York was a small but thriving city, the future Warren Street stood at its northern edge. 
Even then, New Yorkers longed to get out of town, largely to escape the noise and claustrophobia of Wall Street, then the city's commercial hub. Many escapees made their way to Vauxhall Garden, built in 1765 on a hill overlooking the Hudson in the vicinity of Greenwich and Warren Streets. Its attractions included afternoon teas, a wax museum and fireworks. The property was owned by Trinity Church. 
Soon, members of the gentry built brick houses near the pleasure spot, creating one of Manhattan's first upscale residential neighborhoods. Commerce moved north, too. By the mid-19th century, the brick houses had been demolished and replaced by commercial buildings: elegant "skyscrapers," five or six stories high, featuring stone and marble facades, oversize windows and steam elevators big enough to transport a horse-drawn wagon laden with goods to the dizzying upper reaches. 
Among these structures were five five- and six-story brick buildings on the north side of Warren Street between West Broadway and Greenwich Street: Nos. 76 through 84. The exact date of construction is fuzzy, but by 1885 one of the five was already having a $1,600 face-lift to repair damage from a fire. 
The neighborhood evolved into the city's dairy wholesaling district, where warehouse laborers unloaded crates of butter, milk, cream and eggs. At least one of the five Warren Street buildings was home to a butter-and-egg wholesaler, the firm of Droste & Snyder.
During this period, a curious blocklong forerunner of the subway was built nine feet beneath Broadway from Warren to Murray Street: a pneumatic tube with giant rotary blowers pushed an upholstered car carrying 22 people. The first year of operation, 1870, 400,000 people rode the newfangled contraption, paying 25 cents a ride. The plan failed and was soon abandoned.
Meanwhile, the small companies in the five Warren Street buildings expanded, renovated, changed hands. An enterprising dairy wholesaler installed a basement refrigerator for eggs, and a hardware company spruced up its first floor with plate-glass windows, a mezzanine walkway and a marquee. In 1926, the company also caught an embezzler in its midst: a 27-year-old employee named Murray Septon was accused of collecting $160 from a dealer and, according to the police, "appropriated it to his own use."
The neighborhood was thriving. By the late 1930's, the wholesale markets of the Lower West Side had become the world's largest. "Caviar from Siberia," reported the New York City Guide (a W.P.A. publication) in describing Washington Market and other nearby wholesalers and grocers. "Sardines from Norway. Venison and bear steaks. 7,500,000 cases of eggs and 4,500,000 tubs of butter." This was not to mention radios, pets, garden seeds, sporting goods and church supplies.

Jobs of Last Resort
But by the late 1930's, the heyday of the area's dairy industry was coming to a close. Trucks, not horse-drawn wagons, were hauling food, and bottlenecks were occurring at the slow-moving steam elevators. Gradually but inexorably, the companies occupying the warehouses began to leave for less congested and more efficient quarters. Eventually the wholesale markets followed.
At this point, the story of 80 Warren Street took a darker turn. The Sixth Avenue Association, a merchants' group, had long sought to get rid of the crowds of scruffy job seekers who congregated outside the many storefront agencies along Sixth Avenue in the 30's. The relatively remote ranges of Warren Street seemed a more suitable setting for such an enterprise.
Trinity Church consolidated Nos. 76-84 Warren Street into a single building and subdivided the lofts to create small offices. The place was given a fine title -- the Employment Agency Center Building -- and in 1942 The New York Times described the new exterior as featuring "fine ruddy brick, dazzling white stone and gleaming glass blocks in the best modern style." 
More than 40 agencies moved in. A sign advised job seekers to "take the express elevator to the fourth floor and see all the agencies on the way down." Christopher Gray, the architectural historian, writing in 1993 in The New York Times, described the first day: "Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia opened the center in March 1942 to 5,000 applicants, handing papers for a chauffeur's job in Brooklyn to a Bronx man, 43-year-old Charles Glener, the first to apply."
The names of many of these agencies were upscale: Admiral, Cadillac, Ardor, Century, Colony, Eagle, Majestic, Paris, Vivaldi, Yale. The reality soon became quite different.
"Some of these places list good-paying and highly skilled jobs," Harrington wrote in his book, which was published almost exactly 20 years after the building opened. "But many of them provide the work force for the economic underworld in the big city: the dishwashers and day workers, the fly-by-night jobs."
He described the press of humanity: mostly blacks and Puerto Ricans, and often alcoholics, drifters and the mentally ill, who paid the agencies perhaps 50 cents for a $5-a-day job. The scene after lunch struck him as especially dispiriting. Although all the jobs had been handed out, men still milled around, eternally, pointlessly hopeful.
"Most of the people at 80 Warren Street were born poor," Harrington concluded. "They are incompetent as far as American society is concerned, lacking the education and the skills to get decent work."
Harrington's book provided powerful ammunition for President John F. Kennedy's war on poverty. In the late 60's, a group of students from the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism, moved by Harrington's vivid words, brought their cameras to 80 Warren Street to film a documentary about the place. What they found was, if anything, worse than what Harrington had described.
One part of the film focused on a knife fight over a bottle of red wine. "Blood from a slashed artery splattered the floor," said the script. "The owner of the bottle pinned his friend to the floor and held the blade against his neck."
Two days later, "A white man in his mid-60's was found dead on the steps of a dingy office building directly across the street from 80 Warren. A knife lay in a pool of blood underneath him." The man had been getting work as a waiter through 80 Warren since the year it had opened.

Artists, Followed by Cachet
In the late 60's, another development transformed 80 Warren Street. 
Hundreds of painters and sculptors were illegally moving into empty industrial lofts in the blocks below Houston Street, to a neighborhood soon to acquire the catchy name SoHo. Landlords were happy to receive even modest rents. Artists, especially those working in large-scale formats, were drawn not only by the prices but also by the oversize windows, generous natural light, raw open spaces and high ceilings.
By the mid-70's, galleries and boutiques had followed the artists, sometimes displacing their work and causing real estate prices to rise. In response, many artists headed south once more, to the trapezoidal district south of Canal Street. An enterprising realtor quickly labeled the neighborhood TriBeCa, in the hope that the new name would do for these blocks what SoHo had done for the neighborhood to the north. The artists moved illegally into lofts and lived as they had in SoHo. When a building inspector showed up, a tenant would ask for a few extra minutes to let the nude model dress, and quickly stash the pillows, pots and pans, and other evidence of habitation.
Like SoHo in its early days, TriBeCa was a desolate place.
That is how Mr. Goldstein, a lean man with a wry smile who was teaching at the Fairleigh Dickinson University branch in Teaneck, N.J., remembers the neighborhood when he moved into 80 Warren Street in 1980. The employment agencies had gradually departed, and the year he arrived, 80 Warren became one of the first TriBeCa warehouses to be legally converted for residential use. Although his new neighbors included many well-known figures, among them the writers Jonathan Schell and Judith Thurman and the painter Mark Tansey, the surroundings were dreary.
"Lots of parking lots," Mr. Goldstein remembered of the neighborhood. "A hot-dog cart fill-up place. Probably some murders. You cannot imagine what a dump it was."
On moving day, he sloshed through puddles on his new floor, a result of a leaky ceiling. "It was just awful," he said. "But, oh, it was magnificent! The very high ceilings. The old-fashioned skylight. And cheap."
He paid $25,000 for 3,000 square feet of raw space. He lived by himself beneath his 14-foot ceilings. The space was all his. 
At first, it was lonely. "Come 5 o'clock, no one was here," he said. "No schools. No conveniences. I brought food in from New Jersey."
But the first glimmers of TriBeCa's future cachet were emerging. In that year, 1980, Odeon opened in a former cafeteria on West Broadway, featuring what a writer described in The New York Times as "sparkling vegetables, delicate fish and beautifully cooked meat." Other additions to the neighborhood included outposts of avant-garde art like Franklin Furnace and residents who epitomized urban cool: Laurie Anderson, Bette Midler, Cyndi Lauper, Martin Scorsese, Meryl Streep.
In keeping with TriBeCa's new money and glitter, 80 Warren Street even surfaced in articles about a celebrity scandal. The affair involved John J. McLaughlin, a lawyer who ran the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation, and a washing-machine heiress named Ann Maytag.
Miss Maytag, as she was fetchingly identified in the newspapers, collected American Indian art and exhibited it at the Foundations Gallery, the space she operated in the lobby of 80 Warren Street. In 1986, Mr. McLaughlin was convicted of several felonies, including grand larceny and forgery, in connection with his handling of Ms. Maytag's multimillion-dollar personal trust.
Through this period, the building at 80 Warren remained much as it had been, sturdy and plain. Occasionally, new owners tried to persuade the board to decorate the lobby and hire a doorman, but they were always voted down. But private spaces were frequently made elegant; one tenant, for example, added a patio and lush gardens with grapevines to the two-tiered roof, a legacy of the days when 80 Warren was a cluster of buildings of different heights.
Still, the cost of apartments at 80 Warren Street continued to rise steadily. In the mid-90's, as the economy started to boom, they began to skyrocket. Newspaper reports of local real estate sales tracked the dizzying climb. In 1990, a 4,000-square-foot loft at 80 Warren fetched $560,000. In 1997, a buyer paid nearly that much for a space less than half that size. 
"Between Warren and Murray, the prices shot up to the multimillions," said James Sanders, who lives on nearby Duane Street and was a co-author of the PBS series "New York: A Documentary Film."
"Not only can artists not afford them," Mr. Sanders said, "hardly anybody can afford them."
The prices have stayed high. According to the Insignia Douglas Elliman Manhattan Market Report, the average price for a residential apartment in TriBeCa last year, $1.6 million, was twice as high as the average on the Upper East Side, the city's next-costliest neighborhood. 
The area's cachet has withstood even the trade center attacks, the stock market's plunge and a sputtering economy. Howie Krakow, a retired advertising executive who moved to 80 Warren Street in 1994, paid $500,000 for his 3,000-square-foot loft, which includes such additions as custom-designed stained glass obscuring a view of a brick wall. When he put his place on the market in May, he thought his timing was poor.
The apartment was gone in a week.
It sold for $1.5 million. The buyer was Michelle Dell, the owner of Hogs and Heifers, the Washington Street saloon where Julia Roberts once took off her bra and danced on the bar.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: ATLANTIC AVENUE; 
No Fair This Year, but Plans Aplenty for an Avenue

BYLINE:  By CHRIS ERIKSON 

 BODY:
The Atlantic Antic, one of the city's most popular street fairs and a harbinger of fall for Brooklynites for 26 years, will be a no-show again this year. Canceled last fall after Sept. 11, it has now fallen victim to a city regulation.
 The city has denied a permit for the event, which draws up to a million people to Atlantic Avenue's westernmost stretch on the last weekend of September. A given group can host only one street fair each year, the city said. 
 That is a problem this year because the group behind the Antic, the Atlantic Avenue Local Development Corporation, held a fair in the spring to try to plug the gap in its finances that resulted when last year's Antic was canceled. "It's sad," said Candace P. Damon, the president of the group, which had petitioned the city to bend the rule, citing the unique circumstances of 2001 and the economic boost the fair brings the local community. "We were hoping they'd make an exception."
But a spokeswoman for the mayor's office, Megan Sheekey, said that nearly 70 street-fair permits were canceled last fall, and that most of the affected groups also asked to double up this year, a load the city can't handle. 
"Everybody got hit hard," she said. "We had to be consistent." 
But there is good news for Atlantic Avenue, too. Long-held plans to revamp it took a step forward last month, when the development group and a coalition of local leaders commissioned a Denver firm, Civitas, to develop a master plan for the 1.25-mile segment between Fourth Avenue and the East River.
In the works since early last year, the effort represents the latest bid to spruce up a strip that has long fallen short of aspirations. Among the goals is to make the avenue more pedestrian friendly and to link the retail strips to the east and west, which are currently separated by a dead zone inhabited by a jail, two gas stations, vacant lots, and a steady flow of Brooklyn Bridge traffic along Boerum Place.
"That stretch has effectively served as a dividing line," Ms. Damon said. "All over the place, the avenue just divides the communities where it could unite."
The planners will consider a number of improvements, including pedestrian medians, new lighting, benches, planters and trolleys.
The master plan is moving forward as a wealth of public projects, like the planned Brooklyn Bridge Park and the proposed cultural district around the Brooklyn Academy of Music, are in the works along the avenue.
The goal of the master plan is to capitalize on this buzz of activity, and tap the street's potential to be a hub of culture and commerce. 
"We have a vision of a great urban boulevard," Ms. Damon said. CHRIS ERIKSON

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Atlantic Antic has drawn up to a million people. (Earl Wilson/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: VIEW; 
A Latina Eyes the Fad For Flounces

BYLINE:  By MIREYA NAVARRO 

 BODY:
SOMETHING strange happened to me the other day when I looked in the mirror: I felt I was impersonating a Latina. 
 I am no prisoner of fashion, but this season it has been impossible to go into stores and not pick up a few items from the latest fad -- a turquoise bracelet here, a matching necklace there, a ruffled blouse, a three-tiered skirt. The look tends to Latina in the extreme, almost folkloric, straight out of the closet of a Mexican ranchera singer or a Puerto Rican plena dancer. It is not one I remember ever wearing when I was growing up in Puerto Rico, except for school plays or Halloween. It can verge on the tarty side, resembling the get-ups the sultry cantina girls wear in Western movies. 
 So one day this summer I absent-mindedly dressed for work with a flowing, bright-colored skirt and some turquoise jewelry and -- Orale! -- I was suddenly as self-conscious as if I had put a basket of fruit on my head a la Carmen Miranda. 
The truth is, despite what J.Lo and the fashion magazines suggest, there is no single Latina look. I myself lean toward businesslike clothes. But that has not kept me from putting on dangling earrings or loud colors or other staples of my Latina sense of style. Of course, by my mother's standards, I have been hopelessly Americanized. "Put on some blush, at least!" she commands during my visits to San Juan, finding me way too pale and natural-looking and too much like the tourists who walk around the city in sneakers, T-shirts, shorts and no eye makeup.
The trick for me since I moved to the mainland more than 20 years ago has been to use these elements as accents, not throw on all of them at once and risk looking like "la puerca de Juan Bobo," the pig in a Puerto Rican folk tale that is overdressed and overperfumed by her owner, Juan Bobo.
But these days, it seems, I am out of touch.
Wanda Negron, editor in chief of Cristina, the Miami-based magazine published by the talk show host Cristina Saralegui, said that Latina styles tend toward overadornment, toward the provocative look of Shakira, the Colombian pop star -- long earrings, leather, beads, bandana -- and that's just for starters. (Shakira also dyes her hair blond and belly-dances on her videos.) 
It is a mix of trends, Ms. Negron said, in much the same way that Latino culture represents different races, ethnic groups and nationalities. 
And it's just like music, mixing it up, blending hip-hop with rock and Caribbean and South American rhythms. "There are no rules," Ms. Negron said. "You're fashionable when you have 20,000 things on. We want to have a little bit of each thing that reminds us of our ancestors."
But can you tell a real Latina underneath all the clothes as easily as, say, you can tell who learned to do the salsa in a studio?
A true Latina look, it seems to me, must also come from such intangibles as self-image and attitude. Sandra Guzman, author of "The Latina's Bible: The Nueva Latina's Guide to Love, Spirituality, Family and La Vida" (Three Rivers Press, 2002), said Latinas are partial to tight rather than loose clothing because the idea of hiding your curves is anathema to their idea of femininity. This is a reflection, Ms. Guzman said, of how comfortable Latinas feel about their bodies -- no matter what their size.
"The genuine Latina look is this sense of comfort in your own skin, whether you're wearing very tight jeans or a beautiful ruffled, flowing skirt," she said. Ms. Guzman wore leather pants well into her seventh month of pregnancy. 
But in their sensuality and femininity, she said, the latest fashions remind her of her mother and grandmother.
The fashions, she said, "are a reminder of this classy, feminine past."
"They feel much better than the midriff jeans that were in last year," she continued. "I've seen it referred to in magazines as the peasant look, too, but a lot of us came from the tropics, and that loose cotton blouse that allows you to survive the heat is the kind of dress women of all economic strata wore." 
Not every Latina is about to dress herself in ruffles and flourishes. In places like Stamford, Conn., casual wear geared to the urban chick -- low-rise pants and tank tops -- still rules with the high-school set. Many girls own big, chunky turquoise necklaces and bracelets, but wear the jewelry only with black or white clothing -- nothing much more colorful than that.
Karla Chavez, 15, who was born in Ecuador, said a flowing skirt makes her look bigger. "I'd like to wear it because it looks comfortable," she said, "but personally I don't think I have the body for something like that."
Elena Jetto, 16, a Puerto Rican Italian-American, said the Latina look had not caught on with her. "Gap is forever over here," she said.
Miss Jetto's mother, Celia Bosch, 45, said she was reminded of what she wore as a college student in the 1970's -- empire waists, embroidery on shirt collars or sleeves. But neither she nor her friends have re-embraced the look.
"I'd love to wear it, but where would I go?" she said. "The look here is Ann Taylor."
Ms. Bosch and I have known each other since kindergarten. When we lived in Puerto Rico, we did not wear anything resembling the Latina look. Instead, we followed the fad of the moment. Sometimes we were Twiggy in miniskirts and boots (in 85-degree weather!). At other times we were high-fashion models in the ankle-length skirt called the midi or hippies in hip-hugger pants. Ruffles? Only if our mothers made us, usually for First Communions and weddings.
But with age comes nostalgia, and I now embrace what I once found corny and overdone. That is why I bought ruffles this summer, even at the risk of becoming a walking stereotype. I draw the line, however, at anything off the shoulder with red lipstick.
Some Latinas did not have to shell out any money to look fashionable this season. Lys Mendez, 20, a student at the University of California at Santa Cruz, who was born in Mexico City and brought up in Riverside, Calif., said she had always loved and worn shawls and other indigenous Mexican styles. But she isn't sure the popularity these fashions are now enjoying is more than one season deep.
"What worries me is that they're not integrating it into the mainstream, but that it's a trendy thing that's going to be dropped," she said.
Betty Cortina, the editorial director of Latina magazine, also wonders if the Latina look will fall by the wayside as another look takes over. But, on the other hand, she noted that the Latino population in this country is now 35 million and a powerful influence not just in fashion but in popular music, entertainment and food.
"Latinas are saying, 'This is great,' " Ms. Cortina said. "The world is paying attention to us."
Si, but please don't call us cuchi-cuchi.
