HEADLINE: Dot-Commers on a Mom and Pop Track 

BYLINE:  By WARREN ST. JOHN 

 BODY:
ON a cold weekday afternoon last January, 34- year-old Brian Benavidez plopped down with his girlfriend on a big white shabby-chic sofa in his loft in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, to watch a documentary about hot dogs. Mr. Benavidez, an M.B.A. and former investment banker, had been out of work since October, when he was laid off from his six-figure job at Bolt, a Manhattan Internet company.
 After a couple months of reading and sleeping until noon, he had begun to interview for jobs, but things weren't looking so good. Mr. Benavidez described himself as "just professionally depressed." 
 But something about that hot dog documentary caught his attention. 
"I noticed that everybody who was being interviewed was happy," Mr. Benavidez said. "The people who worked behind the counters, the owners, the customers, they were all smiling. I told my girlfriend, 'I want to make people that happy.' "
A few hours later, Mr. Benavidez said, he had an epiphany: "I'll do hot dogs."
Selling hot dogs and cheese fries was hardly the career Mr. Benavidez imagined for himself when he earned his degree from Columbia Business School in 1996, in the early days of the Internet boom. 
Back then, everyone had a business plan in his knapsack and venture capital flowed like Evian on a corporate charge card. But these are times of adjusted -- if not diminished -- expectations, especially for those young ambitious professionals who were swept up in the technology bubble of the late 1990's only to be unceremoniously disgorged a few years later.
A few like Mr. Benavidez are refusing to let go of the entrepreneurial spirit and the dream of self-made riches that fueled start-up mania. 
Instead of spending billions to build a global brand, these recalibrated entrepreneurs are spending a few thousand dollars to make it big, or at least medium, in their own neighborhoods. They are opening concession stands, spas and bakeries, many with a post-millennial twist. Mr. Benavidez, for example, spent weeks searching for the perfect hot dog before settling on a hormone-free beef frank from grass-fed cattle on a California ranch. 
If the Internet economy was built on vapor, these new ventures are all too real. "I buy eggs, flour and cheese and turn it into things people like and will pay more for than I did," said Assaf Tarnopolsky, 31, a Wharton School of Business graduate who is now the proud owner of two crepe stands in San Francisco, under the self-bestowed title of the West Coast Crepe King. Mr. Tarnopolsky lost his $125,000-a-year job last September when his employer went bankrupt, so he turned to an earlier love. 
He had grown up eating crepes in Geneva, and as a hobby slopped batter on a hot iron at a San Francisco farmer's market on weekends. After a couple of "miserable" interviews, he said, "I decided, if it works on Saturday and Sunday, why not Monday through Friday?"
The lifestyle change has not been easy. "Despite what people think," he said, "it's more stressful and more work than my corporate job." Mr. Tarnopolsky frequently wakes up at night worrying about crepes, and he and his wife now live with "a Depression-era mentality." 
"We're pinching pennies, cooking at home and not going to weddings we'd love to go to because they're too expensive." 
Ari Ginsberg, director of the entrepreneurship program at New York University's Stern School of Business, says that's what it takes. Mr. Ginsberg said that in every generation of professionals there are some who seek the stability of corporate jobs and others who are driven to go it alone. 
The current wave of scaled-down start-ups, Mr. Ginsberg said, is being run by "a breed of people who came of entrepreneurial age when there was a gold rush."
"They were in a fantasy world. Now we're in a back-to-basics mode," he said. "Hot dog stands are about handling real merchandise and interacting with real customers. It takes hard work and time to see results when you build a business the old-fashioned way."
Alas, few choose the old-fashioned way voluntarily. Most are like Andrew Reback, a 32-year-old M.B.A. from Boston University who was a director of product management at Excite@Home until he was laid off last Sept. 25. 
Mr. Reback said he had received no severance pay and his final paycheck bounced. He liked baking, so as he looked for a job in technology, he started selling desserts like chocolate mousse cake. The technology job never materialized -- Mr. Reback said everyone in his six-unit Burlingame, Calif., apartment building is unemployed -- so he kept on baking.
Technology was all entree and no dessert, Mr. Reback said. With mousse cake, he said, "You get a sense of 'It tastes good, and I like it.' I never got that at Excite." 
Mr. Reback grosses only "hundreds of dollars a week," he said, not exactly New Economy wages. But he said it did not bother him. 
"In the brief period of time I've been in business," he said, "I've already been more profitable than Excite@Home ever was." 
And while life in technology seemed like one long strategy meeting, his current job is much simpler. "I don't need a team of M.B.A.'s to tell me what to do next," he said. "The strategy is: make more desserts."
For H. Joseph Ehrmann, a Thunderbird Business School graduate, it's soup. Mr. Ehrmann was laid off from his job at a California software company in July last year. Like many dot-com refugees, he took a monthlong soul-searching trip, to Indonesia. When he got back to San Francisco, he said, "There was a longer line at Starbucks than at any time in the boom." 
Mr. Ehrmann got the picture. He needed income, he said, so he joined a friend who had recently started an organic soup business called Heartland Soups. 
Where once a sales call meant driving to a mirrored glass building in Silicon Valley to pitch clients on $250,000 software packages, Mr. Ehrmann's pitches now involve handing out little plastic cups of soup to people on the street.
"People love soup," Mr. Ehrmann said. "I say I'm building a soup company and people say, 'Soup -- that's cool.' It's satisfying. You're giving people something that affects them right away."
After quitting their jobs at a rapidly failing technology company in Vancouver, British Columbia, Chris Scott, 31, and Jamie McKeough, 33, spent some time in local spas and noticed "this overriding seriousness, like, 'We're going to save your soul,' " Mr. Scott said. Their idea: a laid-back spa with no New Age pretense. As for music, Mr. Scott said, "No Enya."
For all the touchy-feely talk about life on five figures, there is one thing about these young professionals that has not changed. They still want to get rich. 
"The way to be really successful is through ownership, not through being the 5,000th hire at a company," Mr. Tarnopolsky, the crepe maker, said. 
In the middle of the dot-com boom, Mr. Tarnopolsky said he aspired to be like Sky Dayton, the prototypical dot-com whiz kid and founder of EarthLink, the second-largest Internet provider in the United States. His new heroes? Debbi Fields, who started Mrs. Fields Cookies from a counter in Palo Alto, Calif., and Howard Schultz, chairman of Starbucks.
"He successfully marketed and branded something that's been around for a long time," Mr. Tarnopolsky said. "I think the same thing can happen with crepes."
According to Po Bronson, an author who chronicled the technology boom and who profiled 75 people contemplating their careers for his upcoming book, "What Should I Do With My Life?" (Random House), for all the talk of scaling back, today's entrepreneurs have not given up entirely on the dot-com ethos.
"They come to it with the notion that the Internet may be dead but a lot of the values they believe in are the same," Mr. Bronson said. "They believe they can become an expert in something quickly, that brains might be better than experience, that most companies don't push hard enough. But the biggest is, 'Life had meaning, and I was juiced when I took risk.'
"I've seen a lot people say, 'I'm going to find that same thing somewhere else, maybe not in the Internet but with a hot dog stand.' "
If there's a thrill to be found in staring failure in the face, then small-business owners will have no shortage of excitement. According to the Small Business Administration, less than half of new businesses survive more than four years. 
For this reason, perhaps, the budding capitalists have encountered plenty of skepticism from family and friends. Mr. Benavidez approached several business school classmates about investing in his hot dog stand, for example, and was turned down by all of them.
"They said they had got so burned investing in their friends' tech companies that they were tapped out or just too hesitant," he said.
And the new business owners aren't past having their own doubts.
"I've vacillated between thinking I was an absolute genius and the village idiot," Mr. Tarnopolsky said. "I feel a lot of pressure to succeed. This business is all wrapped up in me and my identity."
When that pressure builds, new entrepreneurs seem to fall back on the same M.B.A. training they used to fuel growth in the dot-com sector. After a few days of feeling good about his hot dog epiphany, Mr. Benavidez "went into business-school mode," he said. 
He researched the margins of the hot dog market and analyzed neighborhood foot-traffic patterns, going so far as to count the number of customers going into local restaurants at certain hours. 
He used unwitting friends as market testers, serving them homemade relishes and mustards at a Super Bowl party and noting their preferences.
And he dashed off a four- page business plan -- about 75 pages shorter than the average business plan he toted around during the boom -- that led to a $50,000 investment by family and friends. 
Mr. Benavidez added $40,000 of his own money ("Everything I have," he said) and early next month he will open his stand on North Fifth Street and Bedford Avenue in Williamsburg. He named the place after his dog: "Sparky's American Food." 
"I'm going to be the one slopping chili on hot dogs and cooking burgers," Mr. Benavidez said. "The sky's the limit if we do things right. But my main goal, is, Please make this little shop work."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: LOWER EAST SIDE; 
A Tenement Owner Gets a Reprieve As a Museum Peers Over His Shoulder

BYLINE:  By DENNY LEE 

 BODY:
The hopes of a tenement's owners remain alive, in spite of a museum's effort to replace them with ghosts.
 Louis Holtzman and his wife, Mimi, live at 99 Orchard Street, a 138-year-old tenement with a dozen apartments, that his grandfather bought in 1910. But for the last year, his next-door neighbor, the Lower East Side Tenement Museum, has been trying to take over his building through the powers of eminent domain. 
 The paradoxical situation -- a museum devoted to tenement museum seeking to displace residents of a tenement -- has not been lost on observers. 
The issue became less immediate when the Empire State Development Corporation, the state agency entrusted with weighing condemnation against the public good, allowed the application to lapse on May 8 without any comment. But Mr. Holtzman labeled that development a "shallow victory," giving him and his tenants only a reprieve from condemnation.
He wants more. Last month, he wrote Gov. George E. Pataki, asking for a "memorandum of understanding" stating that no future proceedings will be brought against his property. 
"I want to get on with my life," said Mr. Holtzman, who runs a jazz recording studio.
Officials at the development corporation said the case was still active. 
"Our review of all the issues wasn't complete," said an agency spokesman, in explaining why a decision had not been reached. "Condemnation is not an action that we take lightly."
A new hearing, which would reactive the case, will probably be held, the official added.
The building is a virtual twin of the six-story museum, a national landmark, which is at 97 Orchard Street and dates to 1863. Expanding next door would allow the museum to install an elevator for the handicapped, double its annual capacity to 200,000 visitors, and recreate more apartments as they looked around 1900, when the Lower East Side was a singular gateway to the New World.
"The economic and cultural and educational impact is tremendous with this expansion," said Ruth J. Abram, the museum president.
The tussle over condemnation is just the latest chapter in the story of the Holtzmans and the museum. 
A few years ago, the museum made a $1.35 million offer for the Holtzmans' building, which the couple rejected. They then formed a partnership with their other neighbor, Peter Liang, whose company owns a Chinese restaurant with a back entrance at 101 Orchard Street. The deal gave Mr. Liang room to expand his restaurant into 99 Orchard Street and gave the Holtzmans money to refurbish and rent out their apartments, at $1,600 a month each.
During the renovation, a feud erupted between the museum and the Holtzmans. The museum says that the construction created cracks along the shared wall, something the Holtzmans deny. 
"We were looking for anything to stave off destruction of our building," Ms. Abram said. "We reached out to every government office and the state responded." That is when the condemnation proceedings began.
Now, it is Mr. Holtzman who is asking the governor for help in saving his building. DENNY LEE

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
Options Do Not Raise Performance, Study Finds

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT 

 BODY:
THE downside to stock options has become spectacularly evident in the last year or so. They can give executives an incentive to inflate their company's earnings or make irresponsibly optimistic forecasts to keep their stock prices high and their paychecks lavish.
 With executive indictments continuing, the benefits of options are easily forgotten. Enron and its brethren aside, however, isn't the economic rationale for awarding managers stock to align their interests with those of shareholders as solid as it has always been? 
 No -- and it was never really as solid as it seemed, says a new paper that will be presented tomorrow at an academic conference in Denver. Combining more than 200 studies over 30 years to create the largest possible sample, the paper finds that the amount of equity executives own does not affect their company's performance.
"There's no relationship whatsoever," said Dan R. Dalton, the dean of Indiana University's Kelley School of Business and one of the paper's four authors.
The conclusion is hardly intuitive, coming after years in which investors and executives hailed stock ownership as a solution to the age-old problem of how to ensure that people who run but do not own a business act in the best interests of the owners. Adam Smith noted the problem in 1776, writing, "negligence and profusion, therefore, must always prevail, more or less, in the management of the affairs of such a company."
The recent stock market bubble has shown that negligence and profusion can prevail, and investors can turn a blind eye to them, even when executives own large stakes in their company. Now that some investors want to reform executive pay, the new findings deserve a place in the debate. 
When scientists talk about the relationship between two variables, they like to use the numbers zero and one. Measuring the relationship between the height from which a ball is dropped and its speed when it hits the ground, for instance, will yield a number very close to one, showing a nearly perfect correlation. The relationship between the latitude of an American city and its average temperature will fall between zero and one -- a significant correlation but not close to perfect. 
The relationship between executives' stock holdings and their companies' performance is so close to zero that it is zero in statistical terms, the paper says. This means that an alphabetical ranking of companies is as apt to predict their performance as a ranking based on executives' holdings.
A number of explanations are possible. Other incentives, like cash pay and an executive's reputation, may be as strong as stock in motivating executives. Even if stock is a powerful incentive, the strength of the economy and the long-term health of a company may determine its results more than a group of executives can.
"It's possible that we attribute far too much control to executives relative to what they actually possess," Mr. Dalton said.
The researchers looked at a long list of performance measures, and the only one that seemed even slightly related to executives' equity was the easiest for managers to manipulate: earnings per share. Executives can lift that figure by directing the company to buy back shares or cut its dividend payments.
Buying back stock may not be ideal for the company, but it is likely to lift the stock price at least temporarily.
"You have to step back and ask yourself who is attending to the long-term interests of an organization?" said Catherine M. Daily, a professor at Indiana and one of the authors. "No one." The other authors are S. Travis Certo of Texas A&M University and Rungpen Roengpitya of Indiana. The paper will be presented at the annual meeting of the Academy of Management.
THE paper's conclusions are not wholly original and are not likely to be the last word on executives' stock holdings. Many economists believe that equity can affect performance but only when it is part of a more complicated corporate governance strategy, a possibility the authors do not dispute. Ira Kay, a compensation consultant who has read the paper, said the fact that the studies on which the paper is based dated to 1970 gave him hope that a new study would produce different conclusions.
"A lot of the studies are old and were done before there was significant stock ownership, which is what it took to have an effect on performance," Mr. Kay said.
For now, however, skepticism is in order. When executives receive enormous grants of stock or options, they like to say that they are acting in the interests of their investors. The executives might be more credible if they simply said they thought they deserved a lot of money.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH; 
With Dividends, Big Payouts Can Mean Big Gambles

BYLINE:  By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
WITH yields on United States Treasury securities in the subbasement, investors who are wary of plunging back into growth stocks are scouring the horizon for income opportunities. While buying stocks that pay relatively high dividends can be a fairly conservative and profitable approach, when investors lunge for yield, they often take on inordinate risk. The question with generous dividend payers is, how high is too high? 
 Many investors know that the higher the yield, the more treacherous the stock. Still, many big payers have done well in the past year, as interest rates have plummeted. Some of the best performers have been real estate investment trusts. Though they have lost some ground recently, the yield on the S.& P. 500 REIT index is above 7 percent. 
 But with further significant declines in interest rates unlikely, it becomes more important for investors to check on these companies' ability to keep making the payments shareholders have grown accustomed to.
Comparing a company's dividends to its cash flow can reveal a shaky payout. And an analysis of high-yielding stocks by the RiskMetrics Group, a financial analytics firm in New York, turns up a handful that are paying out more than they are taking in. 
The firm screened the top-yielding stocks that trade on the New York Stock Exchange, the American Stock Exchange and the Nasdaq. Among those that paid out more than they took in during the last fiscal year were America First Mortgage Investors, a mortgage real estate investment trust currently yielding almost 13 percent; Star Gas Partners L.P., a distributor of home heating oil that yields 13.25 percent; and Cornerstone Realty Income Trust, which yields 11.8 percent.
Michael Thompson, a global market commentator at RiskMetrics, noted that during the current year, Star Gas's cash flow is exceeding its payout, but its fiscal fourth quarter typically shows a small profit, often less than the dividend. And America First's cash flow appears to be ahead of its payments for the first six months of the year. Cornerstone continues to pay out more than its cash flow this year.
"There might be room for these in a portfolio, but their operations aren't generating enough to cover their payouts," said Mr. Thompson. "As a result they may represent two to three times the risk of a bond." 
Investors who want to analyze a dividend's security can do so by adding depreciation costs to net income, then deducting total dividend payments for the period -- making sure it's a positive number.
An easier way for investors to check on the solidity of their stocks is a new, free service on the Web, called CreditGrades.com, that analyzes how bond investors view the risk of default in a particular company. The service, launched by RiskMetrics in May, looks at the action in the bond market and gleans from it the probabilities of default at most large American companies. Companies with no publicly traded debt are excluded, as are financial institutions and real estate investment trusts, whose balance sheets and operations are too complex.
Input from bond buyers and sellers can be extremely valuable since they typically conduct more due diligence on companies than equity investors do. And unlike the advice given by stock analysts, bond investors provide a view of market participants putting their money on the line. 
Only time will tell if the CreditGrades analysis can identify defaults well before they happen at companies. But the service gives investors who are concerned about the safety of their holdings additional information. The bond market has always been more opaque than the stock market, but now investors can pull back the curtain and see how bond investors view their companies. Not a bad reality check for dicey times.

HEADLINE: This Oil's Domestic, but It'sDeep and It's Risky 

BYLINE:  By NEELA BANERJEE 

DATELINE: ABOARD THE BP MARLIN PLATFORM, IN THE GULF OF MEXICO 

 BODY:
ABOUT 100 miles southeast of the tattered Louisiana coastline, Marlin rises like a fortress from the flat sea, a gas flare at the tip of a boom fluttering like its banner.
 Marlin is BP's most profitable deep-water platform in the region, producing enough natural gas and oil to power a city of one million people. But as solid and steady as it looks, Marlin is not rooted to the ocean floor. Instead, the whole platform -- the width of two football fields -- floats in 3,400 feet of water on four thick columns linked by pontoons and tethered to the ocean floor with steel cables. 
 If a storm hits, Marlin can move as much as 300 feet from center, sloshing in a wide figure eight. Even in dead-calm seas, put down a cup of coffee and its surface will shimmer from the gentle bobbing. 
That is the kind of engineering and care needed to get oil from the deep waters of the Gulf of Mexico, which holds some of the most promising oil reserves in the world. BP, the world's third largest oil company and the owner of the biggest reserves in the deep gulf, estimates that the region contains 40 billion barrels of oil equivalents, a unit that includes crude oil and natural gas. In comparison, an estimated 20 billion barrels has been found so far in the North Slope of Alaska.
With politicians calling for a reduction in foreign oil imports, especially from the volatile Middle East, the best source of increased domestic production would be here in waters as deep as 7,000 feet. Already, oil from the deep Gulf of Mexico accounts for 16 percent of domestic oil production and will claim a greater share with time. Turn on a stove in New York, and chances are that the gas that sparks into flame comes from the reserves below Marlin.
But the vast opportunities in the deep-water gulf are accompanied by profound challenges. The process of extracting oil and gas through thousands of feet of water and even more earth costs exponentially more than producing the same resources on land. Yet the projects have to remain competitive with other fields.
For BP, the cost to find, develop, lift and transport a barrel of oil from the deep waters of the gulf is $5 to $6 and declining mainly because of economies of scale. Elsewhere in the world, the industry average is $3 to $4 a barrel. With the price of oil about $25, that difference is minimal. 
THOSE economics, far more than political considerations, have driven oil companies to stake out the Gulf of Mexico, and BP is eager to lead the pack. Ten days ago, the company's chief executive, Lord John Browne, announced that BP planned to spend $15 billion in the deep-water gulf from 2001 to 2010, much of which will go to bringing its reserves on stream. If successful, BP could overtake Royal Dutch/Shell as the largest producer of oil and gas from the area. BP now produces 340,000 barrels of oil equivalents but expects to increase that to 700,000 barrels by 2007.
Analysts have generally been impressed with the kind of deep-water reserves BP has amassed. The challenge, they said, is to bring that oil and gas to market.
"The question is how they will manage the embarrassment of riches they have," said Michael R. Rodgers, a senior director at the Petroleum Finance Company, a Washington consulting firm. "They have a bunch of projects and they need to coordinate people and contractors. There is the sheer scale of the facilities and the size of the investment required -- all this before a drop of oil ever comes out of the ground."
Oil production is an inherently difficult and dangerous undertaking anywhere, and water magnifies the hazards. Offshore oil production requires more equipment than onshore production, but everything is confined to a smaller space, which, in turn, has to stay afloat. At its Horn Mountain platform, 15 miles west of Marlin, for example, BP had to figure out how to keep risers that extend 5,400 feet down to the sea floor from being whipped about by the current. 
And, on an offshore platform, anything considered a tough problem on land quickly takes on the dimensions of catastrophe. An accident could mean the loss of hundreds of millions of dollars and a jilting by a stock market that demands high returns from oil companies. 
Safety is an obsession on platforms, from the computers that continuously check 10,000 operational points for problems to the many stashes of life jackets to the platform hands trained to go down sets of stairs with both hands on the railings. 
"People want us to take risks but carefully considered risks," said Lord Browne in a recent interview in Houston. "If we didn't take risks, we wouldn't be in the exploration business."
Since the mid-1980's, BP has spent about $8 billion in the deep-water gulf. Marlin alone has cost $600 million to develop. The company owns or has an equity stake in 25 fields that are in production or are being brought online.
Marlin was BP's first floating platform in the deep waters of the gulf, and it is where the company learned the kind of harrowing lessons that have informed and improved its work on subsequent fields. 
On Nov. 11, 1999, barely into the first month of Marlin's operation, Bob Merchant, the man responsible for running the platform, was called out of his office to look at a casing pressure gauge at a wellhead. He quickly realized he was watching a flame move along a fuse. The gauge, which measured pressure within the first well at Marlin, should have read about 50 pounds per square inch. It showed 4,300 pounds instead. 
Something had gone terribly wrong in the natural gas well, and Mr. Merchant and his crew thought there could be a blowout. Under the tremendous pressure, natural gas could rush from the well at any moment, and the smallest spark nearby could trigger an explosion. Mr. Merchant feared there could be casualties and enormous destruction on the platform. "It could go real bad, real quick," Mr. Merchant recalled thinking.
The crew immediately closed a safety valve deep in the well, shutting it down. But Mr. Merchant called in helicopters from Venice, La., to evacuate most of the crew and five boats to stand by for the remaining workers. Mr. Merchant estimated that the evacuation effort cost the project about $500,000, an expense that would never have been incurred on shore.
But BP had concerns about the design of the other wells in the field, and shut down Marlin until the company could figure out what happened. Six months after the accident, the company found the cause: the temperature in the well shot up and caused pressure to build, collapsing the sides of the well. Oil companies had not monitored wells for such temperature increases because they had never encountered such a problem. A little more than a year after the shutdown and after the addition of new monitoring to the wells, the Marlin field was brought back on stream.
"There is a progressive learning," Lord Browne said. "You go step by step, and the risks come down that way. And you learn from bad practice."
THE risks of working in deep waters were driven home in March 2001, when a series of explosions tore through P-36, at the time the world's largest oil platform, 78 miles off the coast of Rio de Janeiro state. Ten people were killed, and the 40-story-tall platform sank. The platform was owned by Petrobras, the Brazilian state oil company. 
Marlin is where workers come to train before being sent to new deep-water platforms. Its decks are now fairly empty of people but jammed with equipment, a byproduct of the project's success. Besides the original oil and gas fields Marlin developed, the platform is the hub of what the company calls "infrastructure-led exploration." 
On the ocean floor, within a 20-mile radius of Marlin, BP is pumping hydrocarbons from newer but smaller fields, including Nile and King. The fields were too small on their own to warrant separate platforms, but with Marlin nearby, BP could use technology to hook those fields to the systems on the platform. Marlin started with 100 million barrels of oil equivalents, and the new fields add another 100 million barrels.
The increased production adds to the challenge of keeping Marlin afloat. As oil companies stepped out into deeper waters, past 1,500 feet, they realized that they could no longer build platforms that rose from the ocean floor like buildings. So much steel would be needed to erect such platforms that they would be uneconomical. So engineers and shipbuilders were faced with the task of building vessels that could support the weight of what amounts to a large factory in the middle of the sea and that could withstand events like hurricanes. 
Every day, the crew on Marlin must tell a barge supervisor like Tommy Lejeune if they are planning to move equipment on the decks, so that he can counterbalance shifts in weight through the platform's ballast system. If, for instance, 10,000 pounds of equipment is moved to one end of Marlin, Mr. Lejeune, from his console at the platform's control center, floods tanks with seawater in the pontoons and column legs on the opposite side to keep Marlin level. 
Sometimes just tweaking a detail ensures survival. As Sammy McDaniel, operations manager for Marlin, showed a visitor around the platform, he pointed out a silver pipe, about 20 feet long, dangling from the deck above the ocean. Ships that come to Marlin are not permitted to tie up to the platform. Instead, they must use the pipe as a marker, moving with the platform like a dance partner. 
"That's because a boat that was tied up broke off once," Mr. McDaniel said, "and almost poked a hole in one of the platform's legs."
BUT the Gulf of Mexico is free of many of the financial risks that bedevil fields in places like deep-water West Africa and Brazil, where some other large new reserves are being developed. The United States government, for starters, takes a smaller portion of income in royalties and taxes than other nations do, and its tax regime and other laws remain fairly constant, in contrast with those of many developing countries. 
The United States also has a well-trained work force on shore, offering every expertise from roustabout to geophysicist. BP can easily turn to contractors in the United States to build components and service its operations. In places like Africa, the company might have to start an industrial yard on land to service its platforms offshore. 
Finally, the cost of transporting oil from the Gulf of Mexico is cheaper because of the existing undersea pipelines built when the shallower waters in the gulf were developed. In the developing world, companies often have to build everything from scratch. 
But the cost of even starting these projects remains staggering. "In 400 feet of water, you can drill a well for $3 million," said Kenny Lang, BP's vice president for Gulf of Mexico deepwater production. "In deep water, it's a factor of 10 higher."
That means the fields must be large to be worthwhile, and the drilling must find reservoirs with pinpoint accuracy. For two years, Judith R. Wagner and her team of engineers and geoscientists have been shuttling in and out of a darkened room at BP's offices in Houston and mapping the Holstein field, estimated to have 350 million barrels of oil equivalents. 
The room is called the HIVE, an acronym for highly immersive visualization environment. The maps on its walls, when seen through a pair of blocky, specially made glasses, come alive in Technicolor three-dimension, floating, turning and revealing the layers of oil and gas pancaked atop one another, 4,300 feet below the sea.
"WITH the kind of investments we're looking at, we have to determine the right spots to drill to get the oil out quicker," said Ms. Wagner, the Holstein project's general manager.
To collect its seismic data, BP hired a ship that runs long streamers behind it that send sound waves through the water and into the earth, gathering data every 40 square feet. But the company may sample a spot up to 90 times, just to corroborate its findings.
It cost $10 million to gather the data for Holstein and $4 million more to process the numbers with supercomputers in Houston. Those numbers are translated into maps that are a striation of red, orange and black, the red and orange showing where oil and gas might be.
The popular conception of drilling for oil is like the opening scene of "The Beverly Hillbillies": poke a hole in the ground and the stuff gushes out. But the reality is more like arthroscopic surgery, as well tubing wends its way down and then laterally through miles of earth, moving toward a pocket of oil.
The maps in the HIVE allow BP to see drilling and production in real time. As things proceed, people can also gauge changes to the surrounding geologic formations. Oil and gas production is disruptive, and the point is not to seal off one reservoir with sediment and rock while exploiting another. Holstein, whose wells cost about $20 million each, should be operating by late 2004, almost five years since it was discovered, a typical lead time for BP.
Although driven by the demands of the bottom line, BP and other oil companies realize that these projects could mitigate the United States' dependence on foreign oil. Much of the oil in the United States has already been developed, and geology has skimped on the country, affording it only 3 percent of the world's known oil reserves, compared with about 60 percent in the Persian Gulf. So it is unlikely that the United States could actually reverse its reliance on foreign oil.
Moreover, domestic production has been declining as oil consumption has ballooned, mainly because of gasoline-hungry vehicles. The United States imports about 60 percent of the 20 million barrels of oil and petroleum products it consumes daily. If production falls by one million barrels more a day over the next decade, that gap would widen to 71 percent, according to BP. 
"To hold our own, to stay at 60 percent, we will have to find an additional two million barrels of liquid hydrocarbons," said James H. Dupree, BP's former vice president for Gulf of Mexico deepwater production. "The only place in the U.S. where we have that chance is in the deep-water Gulf of Mexico."
He added: "This information is a great motivational piece. Right after Sept. 11, people on Marlin wanted to go to New York and dig people out of the rubble, and they wanted me to arrange it. But I told them that the country needed them here."

HEADLINE: Reality TV That Works 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "On Camera, Jobless Argentines Vie for a Livelihood" (news article, Aug. 7): 
 At last! A reality TV show with a purpose. 
The ingenuity of the Argentines shows through with their hourlong program "Human Resources." This is a country that has been on top of its game, and surely will be again. 
Perhaps we can take a cue from our neighbors to the south and give our viewing public a chance to feel good about watching a "reality" show. Even though our unemployment rate is not close to that of Argentina, I believe that such a show could work here -- just wish I had the cash to produce it myself.

JIM REYNOLDS

HEADLINE: Investing; 
Japan May Be Worth a Second Look

BYLINE:  By KEN BELSON 

DATELINE: TOKYO 

 BODY:
OF all the surprises to hit investors of late, one of the most curious is that Japan is home to the best-performing major stock market this year. While America's benchmark index, the Dow Jones industrial average, has plunged nearly 13 percent, its Japanese counterpart, the Nikkei 225, has held up relatively well, growing 3.9 percent in dollar terms this year. Though slender and partly inflated by the yen's rise against the dollar, these gains suggest that Japan is worth a second look for those willing to venture overseas to broaden their portfolios.
 As in past years, Japan's stock market has taken its cue from a mixture of positive news and relief. This year, a recovery in exports is pulling the country out of recession, lifting shares of electronic, semiconductor, steel and auto companies. Despite high unemployment and falling wages, the Japanese have continued to shop, stabilizing the largest part of the economy, consumer spending. Investors were also encouraged in February when the government took steps to head off a banking crisis. 
 Absent, too, are the accounting scandals and mammoth bankruptcies that have engulfed American and European markets, helping turn the Nikkei, in some small way, into a haven. Indeed, Japan's decade-long bear market has washed away much of its own bubble-era excesses and Internet-driven mania.
While that has pushed the Nikkei index 75 percent below its 1990 peak, it also means prices for some of the world's biggest manufacturers are at their lowest levels in years. "Don't overestimate the weakness in Japan," said Philip Lung, senior fund manager at UAM Investment Trust Management in Tokyo. "People are looking for the downside" but should consider the positives, too.
With $300 million under management, Mr. Lung's funds, sold through two Japanese banks, have returned more than 4 percent each this year. Japanese small-cap funds, too, have performed relatively well. According to a ranking of global offshore investments compiled by Business Week and Standard & Poor's, Japanese funds held 21 of the top 25 spots in the second quarter, with investments managed by Jardine Fleming, Fidelity and Mercury all returning more than 10 percent.
Fund managers in Tokyo, though, all temper their optimism. Domestic banks are still a mess, burdened with bad loans and struggling to eke out profits. With interest rates near zero and the deficit growing, the government and central bank have exhausted most of their fiscal and monetary arsenal.
The upheaval in American markets has also led foreign investors, who were big buyers of Japanese stocks earlier this year, to sell Japanese shares to lock in profits and offset losses back home. That has taken some of the shine off the Nikkei in the last six weeks. Fortunately, Japanese retail investors have picked up some of the slack, keeping a floor under the stock market, at least for now.
As worrisome, figures out last week showed the American economy growing at a slower rate than previously thought. Since one-third of Japan's exports are shipped to America, if the United States dips back into recession, it could take Japan with it.
"Quite frankly, the U.S. economy is crucial to everyone," said Simon Jones, who helps manage $14 billion for J. P. Morgan Fleming Asset Management in Japan. "We're not under any illusions; if the U.S. slows, Japan will, too."
Should America's economy and stock prices stabilize, though, pressure on foreign investors to sell their Japanese shares will diminish, said Kathy Matsui, a Goldman, Sachs strategist. In that event, the Topix index, a collection of all first-section shares on the Tokyo Stock Exchange, could hit 1,100 by year's end, she said, about 11 percent above current levels.
Even if the outlook remains in flux, analysts say there are well-managed companies whose stocks are trading at or slightly above 20 times this year's earnings, a low benchmark in Japan. For example, Toyota Motor, the world's third-largest automaker, is trading at 20 times earnings even though it recently raised its global sales target for 2002 by 3.8 percent and said it would expand production by nearly 8 percent at home.
Two other well-run carmakers, Honda Motor and Nissan Motor, are trading at about 25 times their earnings despite record profits and updated models -- the Accord for Honda and the Z for Nissan -- that are expected to sell well.
While technology shares have fallen out of favor with many investors, Goldman recommends looking at Canon, Japan's largest maker of office equipment, which is getting a lift from strong demand for its digital cameras. Sharp and Fuji Photo Film are two other leaders in the production of digital cameras and liquid crystal displays. Like Japan's three largest car companies, Canon and Fuji also list American depository receipts in New York, so United States investors can buy them in dollars.
ANOTHER company with American depository receipts that consistently reports record profits is the Kao Corporation, Japan's largest maker of household goods. The country's largest drug maker, Takeda Chemical Industries, and Shionogi & Company, which has a cholesterol-lowering drug called Crestor, have good long-term prospects as well.
Not just individual stocks, but the market over all is cheap compared with 1994 and 1999, just before two other rallies. Companies listed on the Topix are trading at 33 times their forecasted earnings for this fiscal year. That is just about half the level of 1994 and about two thirds of what they traded at three years ago. The lower valuation "is not quite the same as claiming that it is cheap, but at least it is not as expensive as before," said Richard Jerram, an economist at ING Barings in Tokyo.
Some of this decline is a natural ratcheting down of expectations about potential growth in Japan. Even so, at these prices, Japanese stocks are approaching levels in America, where the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index is trading at 18 times this year's estimated earnings. To trade a basket of Japanese shares without opening a mutual fund, consider one of the two exchange-traded funds listed on the American Stock Exchange.
These funds trade like stocks, so they can be bought and sold quickly, yet still mimic the broader market. Investors can also bet on the market's decline by selling the funds short, borrowing shares and repaying them with those bought later at lower prices. The iShares MSCI Japan fund is the more active of the two such funds and has outperformed the iShares S&P/Topix 150, gaining 2.2 percent this year.

HEADLINE: Pressuring Analysts: Hard Habit To Break 

BYLINE:  By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
SO much for Wall Street's promises.
 In a letter to the nation's top three securities regulators on July 15, Sanford I. Weill, the chief executive of Citigroup, and Michael A. Carpenter, chief executive of its Salomon Smith Barney unit, expressed dismay about the recent loss of investor confidence in stock research done by brokerage firms. 
 The two executives boasted that Salomon, Citigroup's investment bank subsidiary, had been the first to adopt reforms suggested by Eliot Spitzer, the New York attorney general, who is investigating Wall Street research. They also proposed additional moves that regulators might take to prevent a firm's investment bankers from exerting improper influence on its research analysts. 
But just a few weeks before, according to one of Salomon's junior analysts, Kenneth A. Boss, two Salomon investment bankers had exerted improper influence on him. The pressure came just weeks after Salomon had adopted rules to keep research independent. 
As Mr. Boss tells the tale, in late June, after spending weeks on a report analyzing three office furniture companies, he was lukewarm about the stocks' prospects and assigned them a neutral and high-risk rating. He argued that until the overall business climate improved, demand for these companies' products would be lackluster. When two Salomon investment bankers and Mr. Boss's immediate supervisor saw the draft report, they demanded that he revise it to be more upbeat. Mr. Boss refused. A few days later, on June 27, he was fired. Mr. Boss, 33, was offered $24,230 in severance from Salomon, which he refused.
"I was stunned," Mr. Boss said. "I just couldn't believe it."
Stories like Mr. Boss's illustrate how entrenched the old and lucrative practice of linking research to investment banking transactions has become at the nation's large brokerage firms and how hard it will be to root out.
"There was no pressure from investment bankers on Mr. Boss's report," said Arda Nazerian, a spokeswoman for Salomon. "He was terminated for performance reasons. He had a clear goal he was supposed to meet, and he failed to meet it." In two performance reviews, she added, Mr. Boss's failure to meet the goal was noted.
Six weeks before Mr. Boss was fired, Mr. Carpenter had announced new rules to "ensure the value and integrity of our research product." To eliminate the opportunity for investment bankers to influence research reports improperly, the firm restricted communications between analysts and bankers or traders.
Beginning on June 3, for example, the firm said that any fact checking by the investment banking division of draft research reports would be limited to the first research written about an initial public offering. Moreover, the rules said that any draft research sent to investment banking for fact checking "must omit the rating and target price as well as the investment thesis and valuation analysis sections."
Ms. Nazerian said the rules were voluntary until September.
According to Mr. Boss, two Salomon investment bankers, Richard Moriarty and Marc Schneider, flouted those rules the week of June 23, demanding to see Mr. Boss's report, which was in draft form on his laptop computer. 
Stephen S. Kim, the analyst covering home-building stocks at Salomon and Mr. Boss's immediate supervisor, told him to put the report on the firm's internal network so it could be reviewed by the investment bankers. Mr. Boss protested, noting the firm's new rules. Nevertheless, Mr. Schneider soon went to the research department and reviewed the report on Mr. Boss's laptop. Two of the three office furnishings stocks that Mr. Boss had advised investors to be cautious of -- Interface and Steelcase -- had recently issued bonds that were underwritten by Salomon. 
"Marc was beside himself based on the content and tone of the report," Mr. Boss recalled. "He wanted to know what kind of positives we could add. He left quite agitated. I began to really worry about my future." Mr. Kim told him to stop working on the report, and three days later Mr. Kim fired Mr. Boss.
Salomon declined to make Mr. Kim, Mr. Schneider or Mr. Moriarty available for comment.
Mr. Boss, who joined Salomon in 2000, is considering legal action against the firm and is represented by Jonathan Sack, a partner at Sack & Sack in New York. Mr. Boss has also discussed his termination from Salomon and the events leading up to it with investigators in Mr. Spitzer's office who are scrutinizing the relationship between Salomon's investment banking department and its research area. "They came out with new rules and it didn't make any difference, did it?" Mr. Boss asked.
Mr. Boss, who received an undergraduate business degree from the University of Massachusetts in Amherst, has worked in research departments for nine years at several firms, including Salomon. After college, he became a broker's assistant at a Shearson Lehman office. A year later, he landed a job in the research department.
SALOMON hired him two years ago from Needham & Company, where Mr. Boss was a senior analyst. He took the job as a junior analyst with the understanding that he would eventually get his own stable of stocks to cover. "I was recruited to help Steve get ranked in Institutional Investor and then I'd get the opportunity to cover my own group," Mr. Boss said. Institutional Investor magazine publishes a listing of the most popular analysts in dozens of industries each fall, and investment firms use the rankings to determine salaries and bonuses. 
Mr. Boss said he did his best to help; during his first year at Salomon, Mr. Kim was only a runner-up. In 2001, Mr. Kim rose to the "second team" in the home-builder category.
Last March, Mr. Boss said he went to Jeffrey Waters, associate director of United States equity research, and asked about his promotion. "I received all 10's on my review in 2001," he said, referring to the highest score possible. His bonus for the year was $100,000, almost 100 percent of his salary. Mr. Waters told him to be patient. Salomon was interested in adding coverage in the sector, he said, but spring was the busy marketing season, when analysts spend all their time trying to increase their Institutional Investor ranking by visiting clients who are polled by the magazine. After that effort was over, Mr. Boss would get his chance, he recalled Mr. Waters saying.
In his two years at Salomon, Mr. Boss said, it was standard for investment bankers who pitched securities transactions to clients to promise research coverage, if the companies were not covered already. Until this year, Salomon's research team did not have an analyst covering the three office furniture companies. "We added coverage in the sector because of investment banking deals," he said.
Unlike many other sectors of the stock market, shares of home and office furnishing companies were hot in 2001 and early 2002. After Salomon helped Steelcase and Interface raise money in the bond market, Mr. Boss said, Mr. Kim told him that the firm had promised them research coverage. "I was given a six-week window to do the report," Mr. Boss recalled, adding that he was also told that he would be asked to present his findings to the firm's stock steering committee. Thrilled, he set about researching the industry. 
As he proceeded, Mr. Boss said, he began to believe that the companies' stocks did not merit purchase, at least in the near term. The economic environment had remained slack, and the companies' shares had risen in recent months. "We believe the timing of a new investment in the office furnishings sector is somewhat premature," he wrote.
In a discussion with Mr. Kim about his progress on the report, Mr. Boss made clear his doubts on the sector. He said Mr. Kim began to fret. Mr. Boss, who sat within earshot of Mr. Kim, said his superior called the investment bankers and discussed the report, but was careful to do so on his cellphone. Mr. Boss said that Mr. Kim had told him to be careful to limit conversations with investment banking to cellphones because Mr. Spitzer's release of the now infamous Merrill Lynch e-mail messages had been so damaging to that firm. Furthermore, internal phone lines, which might be taped, were not to be used.
Mr. Boss said he was fired a few days later by Mr. Kim, who told him that because the research report had not been completed on time, the junior analyst was out. Mr. Boss said he was shocked. He collected some personal items and left the office. 
The Salomon spokeswoman said, "Though obligated as an employee, he never raised any complaints or concerns until after his release." Moreover, his complaint came in the context of negotiating a larger severance, she said.
Mr. Boss said he did not appeal his termination because he did not believe his superiors would back him over Mr. Kim. He said that Mr. Waters was not the type of manager to upset the apple cart and that Kevin J. McCaffrey, the department's director, did not deal with problems related to day-to-day operations or junior analysts.
Salomon declined to make Mr. Waters or Mr. McCaffrey available.
Mr. Sack, the lawyer, is negotiating with Salomon to get a better severance for Mr. Boss, and he said that over recent weeks Salomon had provided varying reasons for his client's dismissal. First, the explanation was that he missed the deadline for the report. But, he said, that did not make sense because Mr. Boss was fired on June 27 and the report was not due until July 1. Later, when Mr. Sack discussed the matter with Marcy Engel, general counsel at Salomon, she told him that Mr. Boss was terminated because he was not doing his job. Mr. Sack said she was unable to provide documentation, however, to support her claim.
"Here is a guy who fell out of favor with Salomon Smith Barney managers for all the wrong reasons," Mr. Sack said. "He was fired for failure to compromise his ethics by not supporting the mandate to write a positive research report. Rather than applaud this courageous whistle-blower, he lost his livelihood, and most likely, his career on the sell side."
Salomon declined to comment when asked if Mr. Kim had been placed on administrative leave. "Mr. Kim is an employee of the firm," said Ms. Nazerian. Mr. Kim could not be reached. 
In an affidavit that Mr. Boss submitted to Salomon and the New York attorney general, he said investment bankers at the firm regularly told Mr. Kim of pending banking assignments and merger and acquisition activities involving companies in his sector. "In violation of the rules, Steve issued favorable research reports on the companies involved (homebuilders) after he became knowledgeable of the transactions," Mr. Boss said in his affidavit.
Mr. Boss also said in his statement that shortly after the Masco Corporation, a maker of building products, sold 22 million shares to the public in an underwriting co-managed by Salomon this spring, and after Mr. Kim had raised his estimates for the company, Mr. Kim asked Masco management to help with the installation of a new kitchen in his Westchester home. According to Mr. Boss's affidavit, Masco spent more than $10,000 sending materials and two high-level managers from Michigan to Mr. Kim's home for several days.
Skip Cypert, a Masco spokesman, said, "We gave him the same service we give to any other customer." 
Mr. Sack said he was considering filing a claim against Solomon under the new whistle-blower legislation recently pased by Congress. "Salomon Smith Barney could have simply righted the mistake by reinstating Ken Boss," Mr. Sack said.
But even with the new legislation, Wall Street firms remain an especially difficult place for whistle-blowers to come forward internally, said Jeffrey Liddle, a partner at Liddle & Robinson in New York and an expert on employment law. "It's particularly difficult on Wall Street because the regulatory framework includes an internalized blackballing system for the industry," he said. For instance, regulatory forms outlining employees' work histories are filled out by their firms after they leave and are used, Mr. Liddle said, "for the purpose of informing other firms about problems with the terminated employee, whether true or not."
IF a former employee wants to change what is listed on his regulatory forms, he or she must make a case before an arbitration panel. "Even if you succeed there, by that time, you're old news; you're out of a job for a year or two years," Mr. Liddle said.
The hurdles are high for any employee trying to challenge common practice on Wall Street. And the almost complete control brokerage firms have over their former employees' futures may mean that true reform in the securities industry will be a long time in coming. 
"I think what you're going to see is these firms will escape real reform," Mr. Liddle said. "Where a few criminal prosecutions might throw fear into the hearts of corporate executives in other industries, there have been criminal prosecutions on Wall Street for three to four decades and it doesn't seem to have made things any less dicey there."

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends; 
The Fleeting Romance of the American Road

BYLINE:  By DANNY HAKIM

DATELINE: DETROIT 

 BODY:
AMERICANS are falling out of love with cars.
 In a speech last week, none other than William Clay Ford Jr., the chairman and chief executive of the Ford Motor Company, proclaimed the end of the affair. 
 "The love affair that people have had with automobiles has in some ways grown stale," he said. "Some would say it's even dying." 
Mr. Ford chalked it up to the long running conflict between carmakers and regulators, particularly in California, where "people used to write songs about T-Birds and Corvettes." 
"Today," he said, "they write regulations."
From his perspective, it will take continued effort on breakthrough environmental technologies and a more cooperative approach with regulators to turn things around. Then, he said, people might not be so offended by what their neighbors are driving. 
This sentiment cheered environmental activists, who think the growth of S.U.V.'s, like those Ford produces, has shifted automobiles from a symbol of American innocence to one of material and environmental excess. 
"He's reflecting the sort of love/hate relationship people have developed with their cars in the last couple of decades," said Dan Lashof, science director of the Natural Resources Defense Council's Climate Center. 
"Clearly, people like their individual cars, but they are very concerned with what their cars are doing to their neighborhoods and the planet," Mr. Lashof added.
Indeed, carbon dioxide emissions from automobiles have been rising, despite technological improvements, because of the growth of S.U.V.'s and, to a lesser extent, pickups. 
But it would be hard to argue that Americans feel a deep-seated enviro-guilt, since S.U.V. sales continue to rise.
In fact, Robert A. Lutz, vice chairman of General Motors, said last week that the average car buyer hardly cares about conserving gasoline, because it's so cheap.
"We can't go in the opposite direction of our customers," said Mr. Lutz, the former Chrysler president, who is determined to make G.M. designs as bold as they were in the 1950's. 
"At $1 to $1.20 per gallon, they're to be forgiven for buying Navigators and Hummer H2's," he said.
Further, it's equally hard to argue that people don't love automobiles anymore when sales have held up so well in a balky economy. 
So do Americans feel differently than they used to? For some cultural distance, we asked a Frenchman.
"It's like saying Germans don't want to drink beer anymore or the Japanese don't want to east sushi," said Dr. Clotaire Rapaille, the founder of Archetype Discoveries, a design consulting firm that works with most of the major automakers. He helped design Chrysler's PT Cruiser, one of the few truly distinctive cars on the road.
Dr. Rapaille said that, to the contrary, America's passion for cars is not waning. "The reality," he said, "is that the American carmakers aren't producing the cars people want anymore."
He put the blame on environmental engineering, safety engineering, overemphasis on aerodynamics and all sorts of mechanical factors conspiring to defang automobiles. 
"The automakers have been going too much into the cortex," Dr. Rapailled added.
Why else would some of the most prominent automobiles seen in movies today be from another era? 
In the new action movie "XXX," for instance, the star Vin Diesel drives a Pontiac GTO from the 1960's. 
And if Hollywood can't seem to cast female stars who are past their 30's, it also can't seem to cast Ford Mustangs that are younger than 30, like the one that Nicholas Cage tried to steal in "Gone in 60 Seconds."
Cars with that kind of emotional pull are rare now. Much of the juice of the auto industry has gone into S.U.V.'s, and you can't really love an S.U.V. the same way. 
An old Mustang, for example, was like a quarterback. You expected it to have some swagger, some style.
S.U.V.'s are like offensive linemen. You want them big and able to carry a load. 
"I've never heard anyone call an S.U.V. 'my baby,' " Dr. Rapaille said.
Falling in love with one "is like falling in love with a tank," he said, adding, "You never get the same feeling."

HEADLINE: The World; 
Giving Argentina The Cinderella Treatment

BYLINE:  By LARRY ROHTER

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES 

 BODY:
BRAZIL came away with a $30 billion bailout, and Uruguay got a much-needed $1.5 billion. But when Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill arrived here this week to survey the wreckage of Argentina's economy, all he had to offer was the same advice Argentina has been getting since its crisis began: tighten your belt even further and eventually a recovery will come.
 While a majority of economists might have endorsed that approach six months ago, when the Argentine economy had just imploded, it appears they no longer do. Upon further reflection, a growing number of independent analysts now maintain that many of Argentina's troubles stem from having followed Washington's advice in the first place and that the formula being insisted upon is only making matters worse. 
 As Mr. O'Neill and the International Monetary Fund see it, Argentina is a victim of its own profligacy and must cut spending until no budget deficit remains. But Jeffrey D. Sachs, an economics professor at Columbia University who has advised several third world governments, compares that prescription to the medieval medical procedure of bleeding sick patients, noting that advanced economies like that of the United States abandoned such practices long ago.
"They are telling Argentina to take a depression as a given and, since tax revenues aren't being collected anymore, to adjust their spending down to that level," Professor Sachs said. "They are not thinking straight at all. That's Herbert Hoover economics."
In fact, the last two times the United States confronted recessions, the Republican administrations then in office did exactly the opposite of what Mr. O'Neill is now telling Argentina to do. When the elder George Bush faced a downturn in 1992 far less severe than Argentina's, the federal deficit rose to nearly 5 percent of gross domestic product; under Ronald Reagan in 1983, deficit spending was more than 5 percent of G.D.P.
At the moment, Argentina's provincial governments are being chastised as especially prodigal. But the Center for Economic and Policy Research in Washington has calculated that the provincial deficits are relatively minor, amounting to only 0.5 percent of G.D.P. in 2000 and 1 percent last year, and may be providing the only real stimulus to the economy.
"In response to a depression, this is not a lot of spending, especially since the central government is not doing anything to alleviate poverty," said Mark Weisbrot, a director of the center. Since the inflation and growth rates in 2001 were negative, as they have been for several years, "that money was a boost to the economy by definition."
In reality, most of Argentina's deficit is simply the result of arbitrary accounting procedures and not a reflection of wastefulness. By privatizing the social security system in 1994, much in the fashion the Bush administration is now proposing in the United States, the Argentine government could no longer count social security payments as revenues and had to move them outside the budget.
Had Argentina not privatized social security at the urging of the I.M.F., it would actually have shown a budget surplus in recent years. Indeed, according to another study published by the Center for Economic and Policy Research early this year, government spending in Argentina has remained remarkably steady, at about 19 percent of G.D.P. throughout the 1990's.
T HE numbers were artificially distorted by the privatization," said Joseph E. Stiglitz, the author of "Globalization and its Discontents" and a winner of the Nobel Prize in economic science. "They did make enormous amounts of expenditure cuts in a real sense, and that is one of the factors contributing to the downturn."
Jose Ignacio de Mendiguren, a former minister of production and president of the Argentine Industrial Union, agrees. Not only was "the reform of the social security system the principal factor responsible for the fiscal imbalance," he said in an interview here, but "the state ended up having to turn to the private pension funds to finance the deficit caused by the very creation of that system."
Unlike economists, the Bush administration remains unwilling to adjust its initial analysis. Administration officials like Otto J. Reich, the assistant secretary of state for Western Hemisphere affairs, continue to argue that the problem is Argentina itself, not the policies that have been imposed on it.
"You shouldn't take Argentina as the failure of a particular model," Mr. Reich said during a news conference here last month. The real problem, in his view, is that "in some countries those policies were implemented properly and in others they were not." He offered, in contrast, El Salvador, which is heavily dependent on remittances from citizens living in the United States.
Even more than the Bush administration, the I.M.F. has much at stake here, especially now that Brazil has been loaned an additional $30 billion and the banking system in neighboring Uruguay is teetering. But Dr. Stiglitz, who was chief economist for the World Bank in the late 1990's, sees few signs of flexibility or creativity in the I.M.F.'s decision to send a team of four "wise men," all from central banks, to advise Argentina.
"Central bankers would like to claim that inflation is the most important thing for promoting economic growth," he said. "But there is absolutely no evidence of that," and in any case, Argentina is struggling with deflation, "which we recognize as being every bit as bad as inflation and maybe even worse."
So why does Washington continue to tell Argentina to make even more budget cuts instead of unleashing the spending and investment that could stimulate growth? Many here believe that the arbiters of the global economy want to punish Argentina so that other countries won't be tempted to default on their debts, and George Soros, who made billions of dollars playing the markets but is another with second thoughts about what is happening here, seems to agree. "Sovereign states do not provide any tangible security," he wrote recently. "The only security the lender has is the pain that the borrower will suffer if it defaults. That is why the private sector has been so strenuously opposed to any measure that would reduce the pain" of the 37 million people here who continue to find themselves held hostage to an experiment in economic orthodoxy.

HEADLINE: Every Market Collapse Is Different 

BYLINE:  By Nicholas F. Brady; Nicholas F. Brady was secretary of the Treasury from 1988 to 1993.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
This is an extraordinary period for American investors. Caution should be their compass. It would be an error to expect a speedy correction like the one that followed the last major stock market implosion.
 Fifteen years ago President Ronald Reagan asked me to head the commission to examine the market crash of October 1987. From the close of trading on Oct. 13, 1987, to the close of trading on Oct. 19, 1987, the Dow Jones industrial average fell 769 points, or 31 percent. In those four days of trading, the value of all outstanding United States stocks decreased by almost $1 trillion. On Oct. 19 alone, the Dow fell by 508 points, or 22.6 percent. Only the Crash of 1929 approaches the 1987 decline in magnitude. 
 The conclusion we reached in the fall of 1987 was that the market was not equipped to handle the volume that arose so suddenly. The recommendations of our report -- improved clearance and settlement procedures, the adoption of circuit breakers and an increase in capacity -- were put into place. The crash was the result of a structural problem. Valuations were not the culprit.
The present market collapse is different; it was caused by vastly overblown valuations. The stock market has been in a colossal bubble, a delusion born in the late 1990's that reached its zenith in 2000. While not common, bubbles have always been a fact of market life, a byproduct of runaway human emotions. They arise when people congregate and talk -- and today market commentary is constant on cable TV and the Internet. Unfortunately, investors are finding that the breathless talking heads and brokers are hardly objective.
We are now experiencing the bursting of a bubble. But there is no textbook that explains how an economy recovers from a bubble. It is clear only that we must work down the excesses in the system in capacity, consumption and debt that were created in the late 90's.
Meanwhile, Americans' investment habits have changed. Now they are as likely to have their assets in the market as in a savings account or invested in their home. But markets change rapidly, and the public is discovering much of their wealth is in someone else's hands. In times like these, assigning blame becomes popular; politicians, especially, are adept at identifying somebody else's mistakes. This is conversation, not wisdom. Take it with a grain of salt.
Now what to do? I have always believed that people make money betting against the end of the world. Certainly anyone who bet against an investment in the United States in the last 50 years has been on the wrong side of the wager. Still, it was easy, even in the 90's, to realize that the market was drastically overpriced. It's difficult to know now where the bottom is. Markets overrun on the downside just as they do on the upside.
There is an old Bahamian expression: "Never mind the noise in the market, pay attention to the price of the fish." But how will we know what the right price is or, perhaps more important, the quality of the fish? Real progress has come from the sorry events of the last year. Accountants and corporate executives must now produce accurate figures that are consistent and clear. Investors will have more reliable information. Our economic and political system has a marvelous capacity for improvement.
But in contrast to 1987, this correction will take time; the president and Congress have already enacted the necessary reforms. Meanwhile, the nerve-racking swings in the market will continue. But the confusion will eventually clear, as it always has, and the market -- and the economy -- will start to make sense again.
