HEADLINE: Slow Recovery May Still Feel Like a Slump 

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT with SHERRI DAY 

 BODY:
The United States appears to have slipped into an economic funk that analysts say bears a strong resemblance to the weak recovery of the early 1990's.
 With few companies adding jobs and Americans' net worth having dropped more than 20 percent in the last two years, the coming months are likely to feel like a slump even if the economy is gradually improving. 
 As the country continues to work off the excesses of the 1990's boom, including deceptive corporate accounting and large amounts of debt, economists expect both businesses and consumers to increase their spending only modestly. The possibility of further corporate scandals or an oil disruption in the Middle East heightens the uncertainty.
"The economy started to look like it was in the beginnings of a normal recovery, but then it seemed to grind to a halt in July," said Ethan Harris, one of two chief economists at Lehman Brothers. "It's got to make you very nervous." 
Federal Reserve governors are scheduled to meet tomorrow in Washington, still struggling to lift growth amid criticism that they -- particularly Alan Greenspan, the chairman -- may have overestimated the strength of the long boom.
Most economists do not expect the Fed to cut interest rates from their exceptionally low levels this week -- or even this year unless new economic problems emerge. But the Fed may signal its intentions when it meets, and there is considerable debate about what it should do, possibly as insurance against a downturn. Economists at Morgan Stanley said Friday that they expected the Fed to reduce its benchmark interest rate, perhaps to 1.25 percent from 1.75 percent, to encourage new spending, and investors bid up stocks last week partly in hopes of a cut.
On the day that the Fed meets, President Bush will convene an economic summit in Waco, Tex., where policy makers, executives, economists and others will discuss strategies for improving growth. The summit will in some ways resemble a 1992 gathering that Bill Clinton held in Little Rock, Ark., during the last so-called jobless recovery, which helped him win the White House from President George H. W. Bush. 
The White House is now concerned that nervous voters could turn Republican incumbents out of office in this year's midterm election and that the economy threatens President Bush's high approval ratings.
Fed officials and Wall Street economists continue to say that the economy is improving, if unevenly, and most data support those claims. But both groups also retained their optimism in the middle of last year, saying the economy would avoid recession, and it is now clear that one had begun by then.
In recent weeks, about 20 percent of Americans have described current economic conditions as "poor," the highest level since early 1996, according to the Gallup Organization. About 50 percent say conditions are "only fair."
At the same time, consumers have slowed their spending, weakening the strongest part of the economy over the last year and a half. They are still spending heavily on cars and houses, which are relatively affordable because of low interest rates, but many have cut back on items not on sale.
"We're finding the customer to be very discriminating," said Tom Murray, the president of Calvin Klein. "My opinion is that we're just going to see jagged performance through the next couple of months, just really slow growth."
Retailers' sales rose 2.6 percent in July from a year ago, less than the 5.1 percent gain in June, according to the Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi. Best Buy, the electronics retailer, set off a new round of concern by announcing Thursday that its spring sales were much weaker than it had expected. Consumers seem to be less willing to make large purchases like a $1,500 flat-screen television, analysts said.
But many economists expect the country to escape a double-dip recession largely because consumers show little sign of severely cutting spending, even though their assets are far less valuable than two years ago. Americans' net worth has fallen to about $35.3 trillion, from $45.1 trillion in late 2000, according to Economy.com, a research firm in West Chester, Pa. Rising home values have not been enough to offset stock market losses by the group's calculations, and consumer debt has risen.
Still, Americans' net worth has more than doubled over the last decade. Those long-term gains seem to have kept many people sanguine about the stock's market fall and willing to continue spending. 
At Starbucks, stores open at least a year, consumers kept sales growth steady at 7 percent in July, matching June. But growth has slowed from the 10 percent recorded in May. 
Orin C. Smith, the chief executive of Starbucks, said he was concerned about the economy and its effect on consumer spending. "Whether consumers will become wary of spending in a tight economy is top of mind for all businesses," he said.
With automakers again offering many no-interest and low-interest leases, vehicle sales surged 8.6 percent last month. People are "looking for bargains, and the auto sector was offering the bargains in July," said John M. Youngdahl, a senior economist at Goldman, Sachs.
Meanwhile, mortgage applications reached a record high in the week ended Aug. 2, thanks largely to a recent decline in long-term interest rates that reflects the new economic pessimism. Mortgages are a key economic indicator because people who refinance their home loans often have more disposable income, and people who buy new homes tend to buy appliances and other items.
"The best bet is that consumer spending will continue to advance, perhaps at a slower pace for a while," said Richard D. Rippe, the chief economist at Prudential Securities.
A drop in home prices, which have continued to rise over the last 18 months, would be one of the biggest threats to the modest recovery. Most economists do not expect home prices to fall significantly, citing low interest rates and the continued influx of immigrants.
With some people moving money out of stock and into real estate, though, some economists are growing concerned about the possibility of a housing bubble. Home prices have risen about 30 percent since 1995, after accounting for inflation, while rents have risen just 10 percent, according to government data.
This suggests that many people are buying real estate not for shelter but as a can't-miss investment, said Dean Baker, an economist at the Center for Economic and Policy Research, a liberal group in Washington. Real estate will eventually fall out of fashion, much as technology stocks did, bringing rents and purchase prices closer together, Mr. Baker predicted.
Businesses, after almost two years of deep cuts in investments in new equipment and factories, have begun to mimic consumers. They are cutting some types of spending (on new factories, for example), increasing others (on new machines and software) and remaining conservative until they are more confident in the economy's prospects.
Companies have not benefited from falling interest rates nearly as much as consumers thought. With once-respected companies like WorldCom having collapsed, bondholders have become wary of extending credit.
"The same issues about corporate governance and fraud are making it harder and harder to borrow in the corporate bond market," said Mr. Harris of Lehman Brothers. "Investors don't know what they're buying."
Facing high borrowing costs and uncertain sales growth, few companies have begun the kind of new projects that create jobs. Between April and July, companies added just 68,000 jobs to their payrolls, according to the Labor Department. 
The current pace of hiring closely tracks the pace during the tepid expansion of 1991 through 1994 but is far slower than the hiring that followed recessions in the 1960's, '70's and '80's, said Robert J. Barbera, chief economist of Hoenig & Company, an investment firm. State governments have begun cutting their work forces in recent weeks to close budget deficits, while the federal government's response to the Sept. 11 attacks continues to create jobs.
This mixed bag will be on the minds of Fed governors when they meet tomorrow in the second-floor boardroom of their headquarters in Washington, faced with an economy that looks less healthy than when they gathered in June. Last year, the Fed cut its benchmark interest rate for overnight loans among banks 11 times last year, leaving it at its lowest level in almost 40 years, and has kept it at 1.75 percent this year.
The reductions helped moderate last year's recession by making borrowing less costly. Still, a growing group of economists and executives have faulted Mr. Greenspan for not recognizing that the soaring stock market of the late 1990's was a bubble and for not trying to restrain it. Others say he has been too slow to recognize weakness over the last year and have criticized him in terms that would have seemed stunning a few years ago.
Scott G. McNealy, the chief executive of Sun Microsystems, pretended to raise binoculars to his eyes in a recent interview and said, "What is Alan Greenspan seeing through those?
"Chauncey Gardiner -- I mean Alan Greenspan -- is not in touch with what the rest of us are seeing," Mr. McNealy added, referring to a character played by Peter Sellers in the 1979 movie "Being There" who was known for making odd pronouncements that people considered brilliant.
Even if the economy is weaker than many forecasters expected it to be, unemployment remains at 5.9 percent, far lower than it was at the end of earlier recessions. Barring a shock, like a bigger drop in stocks or a spike in oil prices, the jobless rate will probably rise gently this year, economists say, and the recession that began last year will be regarded as mild. The legacy of the new expansion is much less certain.

HEADLINE: Bush Team Is Divided Over Getting Tougher With Saudis 

BYLINE:  By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 

 BODY:
Growing talk of the Bush administration's plans for war with Iraq has once again thrown into sharp relief Washington's delicate relationship with Saudi Arabia, a central ally in the Persian Gulf war that makes no secret of its opposition to any future attack on President Saddam Hussein.
 The twist is that some of the most vocal advocates of military action against Iraq are also among those pressing hardest in Bush administration circles for a tough new American posture toward the Saudis in the wake of the Sept. 11 attacks. Fifteen of the 19 hijackers in those attacks were Saudis. 
 Today the Saudi foreign minister, Prince Saud al-Faisal, again declared that his kingdom did not want American forces to use Saudi soil for any military campaign against Iraq. 
He insisted that the United States should "give a diplomatic solution a chance before going to war," adding, "There is no proof there is a threat imminent from Iraq."
At the same time, in an interview on the ABC News program "This Week" and another today in The Washington Post, Prince Saud went out of his way to emphasize Saudi cooperation in the Bush administration's campaign against terrorism. 
He announced that 16 suspected Al Qaeda fighters who had fled Afghanistan and who were reported to be Saudis were handed over in June by Iran to Saudi Arabia, which is interrogating them and sharing information with the United States. "The innocent will be let go and the guilty ones will be incarcerated and go to trial," he said on the ABC broadcast.
There has been rising bipartisan criticism of Saudi Arabia in Congress. It was reported recently that a Rand Corporation analyst contended in a briefing to a Pentagon advisory group last month that the Saudis should be treated as an enemy. 
The briefer called Saudi Arabia a prime sponsor of terrorism and instability in the Middle East and said it should be given an ultimatum to stop support for terrorism or face seizure of oil fields and assets.
Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld swiftly insisted that the briefing, presented to the Defense Policy Board and first reported by The Washington Post, did not reflect "dominant opinion" within the administration. Secretary of State Colin L. Powell telephoned Prince Saud to reassure him that the briefing did not represent President Bush's views.
But the diplomatic flurry could not conceal the growing impatience among some segments of influential opinion that the United States should take a much tougher line toward Saudi Arabia, despite its status as a longtime ally. In this view, Saudi Arabia should be faulted for its poor record on human rights and women's rights, its repressive institutions and its support and financing for anti-Western religious schools and militant Islamic movements.
The chairman of the Defense Policy Board is Richard Perle, who was a Pentagon official in the Reagan administration, remains close to many current Bush administration figures and has been one of the most aggressive advocates of overthrowing President Hussein. The briefing by the Rand analyst, Laurent Murawiec, contended that ousting Mr. Hussein would prompt desirable change in Saudi Arabia.
"Part of this is generated by people with a very strong ideological bent," said Edward S. Walker Jr., a former senior State Department official and ambassador in the Middle East. "Those people are going to be very outspoken, and they are part of a coalition that believes you're either with us or against us. But it makes it much harder for anybody in the region to help us."
American military strategists have devised contingency plans for staging combat operations in Iraq without Saudi support, but no one pretends that it would not be easier to have cooperation.
In a telephone interview from France, Mr. Perle said he saw no relation between the need for a new government in Iraq and the need for changes in Saudi Arabia. He added that it was hard to predict what effect Mr. Hussein's ouster would have on the Saudis.
"The argument for going after Saddam has to do with the danger that Saddam represents, not with a hope that it's going to affect Saudi Arabia," he said. 
He said that the policy board briefings were "often intended to stimulate discussions, and they're deliberately intended to be provocative," but that "we're not making policy." He said a vigorous debate about Saudi-American relations was desirable.
Mr. Perle is hardly alone in his view. Speaking today on the NBC News program "Meet the Press," Senator Carl Levin, Democrat of Michigan, complained, "We have sort of hot and cold support from the Saudis when it comes to this war on terrorism," and added, "They've not been a consistent ally of ours."
Senator Fred Thompson, Republican of Tennessee, on "Fox News Sunday," characterized Saudi Arabia's reluctance to support action against Iraq as self-preservation to blunt criticism from the religious extremists within Saudi Arabia.
He described United States-Saudi relations as "a marriage of convenience."
Walter Cutler, who twice served as ambassador to Saudi Arabia in the Reagan administration, said the "whole hesitancy on Iraq, not just in Saudi Arabia but in almost all Arab countries," was related in part to internal pressure on Arab governments from their own people, who are frustrated by what they see as American inattention to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.
Mr. Cutler said he did not believe that the harsh criticism of the Saudis expressed in the Pentagon briefing represented "a significant view" within the administration, but he said, "The way it comes across abroad is another matter, and it's simply going to exacerbate some of the negative views in that politicized Arab street."
An adviser to the Saudi royal family made a similar point about Saudi elites. He said an estimated $600 billion to $700 billion in Saudi money was invested outside the kingdom, a vast majority of it in the United States or in United States-related investments.
"People have an enormous amount of money in the United States, and they're getting scared," the adviser said.
Mr. Walker, the former State Department official, acknowledged that the Saudi-American relationship had long been complex but said: "We need each other. They do provide a valuable service to our forces. They have provided, over the years, almost on demand, an increase in oil production to keep prices at a reasonable level."
He added that his former colleagues in government, from the Treasury to the State Department, had told him that "we are also getting cooperation in the war on terrorism and tracking the financial flows that we weren't before Sept. 11."
In an interview last week with The Associated Press, Prince Saud said Saudi Arabia had not asked the United States to remove its thousands of troops from the Prince Sultan Air Base in the Saudi desert, from which American planes have patrolled Iraqi skies for a decade. "Nothing is happening in the present, and we don't consider that anything will change in the future," he said.

HEADLINE: A Role Unfilled 

BYLINE:  By ELISABETH BUMILLER

DATELINE: CRAWFORD, Tex., Aug. 11 

 BODY:
Throughout the business scandals of this tempestuous summer, President Bush has angrily denounced corporate criminals and cheerily declared that the economy is heading in the right direction. But his words have often had the opposite effect than he intended, sometimes seeming to send the financial markets diving.
 "He opens his mouth, and the market goes down," said Stephen Moore, the president of the Club for Growth, a political action committee that supports conservative Republican candidates. "I'm not saying he's responsible for the market crash. But he hasn't inspired a rush for investors to get back in." 
 The problem, Republicans, economists and the president's supporters say, is that the weakness of the White House economic team has forced Mr. Bush to become his own economic spokesman. That is a role, they say, that a president should avoid. 
Mr. Bush, they add, is not at his best when talking about the economy. Sometimes he has made odd off-the-cuff remarks, such as suggesting that Americans might look for stock bargains when the Dow is down. Sometimes he has been seen as cheerleading in the face of bad economic news. At other times his threats to throw corporate criminals in jail have seemed to agitate rather than quiet investors.
"He obviously has not been very effective," said Senator Chuck Hagel, Republican of Nebraska, recalling that President Bill Clinton had a forceful, calming presence in his treasury secretary, Robert E. Rubin.
"People knew when they listened to Clinton that there was something behind him," Mr. Hagel said. "There was Bob Rubin, there was an economic team. I don't think the markets see anything behind this president's words."
In part to address that problem, the White House is creating a stage to showcase Mr. Bush as the commander of the economy. On Tuesday, more than 200 mostly Republican guests -- a number are major party donors -- are to attend an economic forum at Baylor University in Waco, Tex., about a half-hour's drive from the president's 1,600-acre ranch, where Mr. Bush is spending most of this month.
At Mr. Bush's side will be Vice President Dick Cheney, who until recently has been largely invisible to the public while the Securities and Exchange Commission investigates accounting practices at the Halliburton Company, the oil services giant where Mr. Cheney was chief executive.
Although the White House initially said that Mr. Cheney would not attend the conference, the vice president will now descend from his summer aerie in the Grand Tetons of Wyoming to the prairie of central Texas, adding what Republicans say is much-needed heft to the administration's economic voice. Mr. Cheney's presence, they say, is a clear sign of how worried the White House is about the effects of the economy on Mr. Bush's political future.
"The Halliburton thing is not helpful at this time," Mr. Hagel said. "But he was a chief executive of a respected company, so he does bring some real-world experience. And they essentially need all hands on deck right now."
Some Republicans nonetheless praise Mr. Bush for his efforts, and say there is often little a president can do to change the markets. "Wall Street is not an accurate reflection of the economy," said Representative Roy Blunt, Republican of Missouri. "It's a reflection of how investors feel about the economy. My guess is that by the end of the year, we'll see that the president was an effective spokesman for the economy."
Many of Mr. Bush's supporters trace his problems to Paul H. O'Neill, the quirky and much criticized treasury secretary, whose habit of popping off has not been reassuring to the markets. 
"There are a lot of people who would like to see him gone in the next half hour," one influential Republican businessman said. Many Republicans say it is essential that Mr. O'Neill be replaced after the November midterm elections, when Mr. Bush will begin to turn his attention to his re-election campaign in 2004.
Otherwise, they warn, Mr. Bush may face the same fate as his father, who was enormously popular after the Persian Gulf war but lost the 1992 election in large part because of voters' perceptions that he had lost control of the economy.
"Bush needs to reassign Paul O'Neill to some other job in the administration and get a more effective spokesman for economic policy," Mr. Moore said.
Many Republicans say that none of the leading economic officials in Mr. Bush's administration can adequately fill the role. Mitchell E. Daniels Jr., the White House budget director, has alienated many in Congress. Lawrence B. Lindsey, the president's chief economic adviser, is not thought to have the presence or political skills for the job. Donald L. Evans, the secretary of commerce, is personally close to the president, but business leaders say that he does not have the stature or the portfolio to be the economic voice of the administration.
So speaking out on the economy is left to Mr. Bush, with sometimes embarrassing results. After the president delivered a major address on July 9 on Wall Street that was meant to reassure the markets, the Dow Jones industrial average fell 178.81 points, and was down nearly 700 points by the end of the week. On July 22, a day when Mr. Bush forcefully defended Mr. O'Neill and current stock prices, saying "there is value in the market now," the Dow ended down 234.68, or 2.9 percent.
On July 30, the day Mr. Bush signed a major corporate antifraud bill in a grand White House ceremony, analysts said investors were reassured by the news -- but stocks still seesawed and the markets ended that day almost where they began.
Former Clinton administration officials say the markets' response to Mr. Bush's words shows that presidents should talk about the broad fundamentals of the economy, not the ups and downs of Wall Street. Mr. Clinton, for example, was always eager to ring the opening bell at the New York Stock Exchange, but Mr. Rubin told him no, saying that if the market went down that day, the president would be blamed.
Other economists agree that presidents are generalists, not specialists, and that their role is to speak on a broad range of foreign and domestic policy. The intricacies of the market, they say, should be left to the treasury secretary. "I think very few presidents either can or should attempt to do this sort of thing themselves," said Benjamin M. Friedman, an economics professor at Harvard University. "They don't have the uniformity of focus that is required to make the message effective."
Sometimes Mr. Bush has tried to restore consumer confidence in the face of unwelcome statistics with an unusually sunny interpretation of the numbers, like on July 31, when he announced that "we're heading in the right direction" That was the day the Commerce Department reported that the nation's gross domestic product grew by 1.1 percent from April through June, down from 5 percent in the first three months of the year. 
"People won't be reassured by a pep rally," said Robert D. Hormats, vice chairman of Goldman Sachs International. "They will be assured by candid discussions and a frank assessment of the strengths and challenges the economy faces."
For that, the White House says it is offering the economic forum this week, which many Republicans acknowledge is as much about crucial public relations as collecting expertise. "It's a move in the right direction," Mr. Hagel said. "But I think the president knows he's going to have to do more to address these problems than putting on a show in Texas."

HEADLINE: Beyond the Waco Echo Chamber 

 BODY:
President Bush's vacation plans changed abruptly when he decided recently to summon more than half his cabinet to a convenient location for an economic conference. Well, Baylor University in the scorched prairie of Waco, Tex., a half-hour's drive from Mr. Bush's ranch, was at least convenient for the president. Now the question is whether tomorrow's forum, which is reportedly going to include Republican donors and exclude administration critics, will do anything to resolve the administration's failure to speak with one reassuring voice on the economy.
 The Waco forum is obviously a way to let Mr. Bush show that he is concerned about the economy. Few Americans could seriously doubt it. But in truth there is not much Mr. Bush or anyone can do to change the economic indicators as the November elections approach. And to give the president his due, he came into office warning of a recession, even though the tax cut he proposed to deal with it was a bad idea that looks worse the more he presses to extend it. The passage of legislation to promote trade was an important achievement, and Mr. Bush signed a solid bill to restore corporate responsibility after showing an early lack of enthusiasm. 
 But on economic policy, and especially fiscal policy, this administration has no convincing plan. What it has is an ideology -- and even that ideology lacks consistency. The commitment to free trade did not survive pressures from swing-state steelmakers for protection, and the dedication to fiscal conservatism was tossed overboard with the enactment of an obscenely expensive farm aid package. The impression left is that the White House's handling of the economy is driven by short-term political concerns. That image is not likely to be changed by the holding of a politically driven event like the Waco conference.
The Bush economic team has come under such heavy criticism these days that even many Republicans expect a reshuffling after the election. Treasury Secretary Paul O'Neill, Lawrence Lindsey, director of economic policy at the White House, and Mitchell Daniels, the budget director, are the ones most criticized, even by Republicans in Washington. Mr. O'Neill's crusty shoot-from-the-hip style is popular among some, but it doesn't necessarily make him the best choice for calming markets. Mr. Lindsey is supposed to manage economic policy, but he has done little beyond advocating tax cuts as the solution to everything.
But the biggest problem is that no one on the economic team seems to have the stature to work out a coherent policy and force the others -- particularly the political handlers -- to come on board. Mr. O'Neill was at least skeptical about tax cuts when he entered office, and he openly criticized the administration's expediency on trade. (Perhaps Mr. O'Neill could debate Karl Rove, the White House political director, at the conference tomorrow. That's one way to bring the crowds to Waco.) The Treasury secretary's supporters say he wanted faster action on corporate issues but was rebuffed. These reports have diminished his stature and cast doubt about how policy is made.
Mr. Daniels, director of the Office of Management and Budget, also has credibility problems. His forecasts have had to be revised constantly, and his lectures on spending restraint are undercut by Mr. Bush's signing the costliest farm bill in history. In political terms, this is the first Republican administration in a long while that will have a tough time beating up on Democrats over the budget, in part because it is Republicans who want to spend on the military and on homeland defenses and none of them want to think about rescinding the tax cut.
The president is not going to engage in any midcourse corrections until after the elections. But this gathering in Waco should mark the end of the administration's attempts to solve its problems by demonstrating that Mr. Bush cares. We know he cares. What we need is evidence that he knows what to do.

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES; 
An Opinionated Traveler Drawn to the Developing World

BYLINE:  By MICHIKO KAKUTANI 

 BODY:
THE WRITER AND THE WORLD
Essays
By V. S. Naipaul
Introduced and edited by Pankaj Mishra. 524 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $30.
 "I travel to discover other states of mind," V. S. Naipaul writes in one of the essays in his haphazard and lumpy new collection, "The Writer and the World." "And if for this intellectual adventure I go to places where people live restricted lives, it is because my curiosity is still dictated in part by my colonial Trinidad background. I go to places which, however alien, connect in some way with what I already know." 
 Mr. Naipaul's best known writings deal with the third world: those "half-made societies" in Africa, the Caribbean, Latin America and the Indian subcontinent, reeling from the twin legacies of colonial oppression and post-colonial turmoil and caught between the weight of tradition and the siren call of modernity, between ancient indigenous imperatives and shiny imported ideologies.
This volume of essays by the winner of last year's Nobel Prize in Literature is essentially a repackaging of his earlier work: its strongest entries appeared previously in volumes like "The Return of Eva Peron" (1980) and "Finding the Center" (1984), while its newer additions tend to be slighter and very dated pieces about unlikely subjects like the 1984 Republican Convention and Steinbeck country in California. Most of the pieces -- particularly those dealing with hot spots in Africa and Latin America where political and social change has been swift -- would have benefited enormously from postscripts, providing the reader with historical context and updated developments.
Mr. Naipaul is not an objective reporter but a highly opinionated traveler, and what this volume underscores, once again, are the recurrent, even obsessive themes in his work: his fascination with the developing world's simultaneous resentment and envy of the West; his bitter skepticism about the ability of former colonies to shed their habits of dependence, superstition and passivity; his impatience with both third world revolutionaries in thrall to borrowed ideologies and radical chic tourists with plane tickets to crisis zones and return tickets home. He writes, as he has in so many other books, about the dangers of trying to tailor people to imported theories and the rage created in places like Mobutu's Zaire by the aping of Western consumerism. He detects the substitution of drama and style for practical politics in places as varied as the Caribbean and the United States, and he laments the persistence of magical thinking -- and the willingness to submit to self-mythologizing dictators -- in Africa and Latin America.
Clearly many of his feelings about the countries he visits are rooted in his family background -- his grandfather, a Brahmin from Uttar Pradesh, India, came to Trinidad as an indentured worker -- and his fears, as he once put it, of "being swallowed up by the bush," by the "enemies of the civilization" he so prizes. He is at his most vitriolic, in this volume, in his early essays on India, a place, he writes, "for which one has a great tenderness, but from which at length one always wishes to separate oneself."
Though he would later adopt a more detached and sympathetic attitude toward his ancestral homeland in his 1990 book "India: A Million Mutinies Now," Mr. Naipaul bemoans "the Indian intellectual failure" in a 1967 essay and writes snidely of "a people grown barbarous, indifferent and self-wounding, who, out of a shallow perception of the world, have no sense of tragedy."
"The gap between India and the West is not only the increasing gap in wealth, technology and knowledge," he writes. "It is, more alarmingly, the increasing gap in sensibility and wisdom. The West is alert, many-featured and ever-changing; its writers and philosophers respond to complexity by continually seeking to alter and extend sensibility; no art or attitude stands still. India possesses only its unexamined past and its pathetic spirituality."
He is equally scathing and fatalistic about the islands of the Caribbean, and their inability, as he sees it, to surmount their past of slavery and colonial neglect. "They may get less innocent or less corrupt politicians; they will not get less helpless ones," he gloomily declares in a 1970 essay. "The island blacks will continue to be dependent on the books, films and goods of others; in this important way they will continue to be the half-made societies of a dependent people, the Third World's third world. They will forever consume; they will never create. They are without material sources; they will never develop the higher skills. Identity depends in the end on achievement; and achievement here cannot but be small."
In the most hypnotic essays in this volume, Mr. Naipaul's highly subjective views appear to emerge, organically, from the story he is telling. "Killings in Trinidad" -- which would provide material for his 1975 novel "Guerrillas" -- showcases Mr. Naipaul's skills as a storyteller while illustrating some of his most insistent themes. The essay tells the chilling story of a half-black Trinidadian named Michael Malik (or Michael X), who started out as a pimp and drug pusher, became the darling of white radicals in London and returned to Trinidad in 1971 as an avatar of Black Power; he would end up being hanged in 1975, after orchestrating the murders of two followers.
The meaning of the story, Mr. Naipaul suggests, is simple: "Malik's career proves how much of Black Power -- away from its United States source -- is jargon, how much a sentimental hoax. In a place like Trinidad, racial redemption is as irrelevant for the Negro as for everybody else. It obscures the problems of a small independent country with a lopsided economy, the problems of a fully 'consumer' society that is yet technologically untrained and without the intellectual means to comprehend the deficiency."
In "Argentina and the Ghost of Eva Peron," he is even more scornful of Argentina, as a country that can never transcend its colonial past: "Argentina is a land of plunder, a new land, virtually peopled in this century. It remains a land to be plundered; and its politics can be nothing but the politics of plunder." Such vehement and unforgiving statements point to the limitations that Mr. Naipaul's reportorial methods would reach in his extremely dark and judgmental 1981 book about his travels through the Islamic world ("Among the Believers").
Another, more nuanced approach can be found in "The Crocodiles of Yamoussoukro." This essay, which happens to be one of the author's few pieces to evince an optimistic view of a third-world country, recounts Mr. Naipaul's travels through Ivory Coast in the early 1980's and his journey to the pharaonic site of its president's ancestral village. The piece is studded with keenly observed portraits of individual residents, seemingly chosen at random, and it radiates an awareness not only of the horrors and stupidities of history but also of its wonders and strangeness, an outlook that would infuse the author's more recent fiction and nonfiction with a new benevolence of outlook.

GRAPHIC: Photo: V. S. Naipaul (Jerry Bauer/Alfred A. Knopf)(pg. E7)

HEADLINE: Don't Blame Immigrants 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 In "Immigration Cut Into Income in New York, Census Finds" (front page, Aug. 6), you conclude that the decline in median income in New York City during the 1990's is the result of an increase in the city's immigrant population. 
 But an analysis by the Economic Policy Institute shows that if the immigrant share of the population had not grown, poverty would have been only slightly lower and median income slightly higher. 
Between 1994 and 2000, the period for which data are available, the increase in immigration was offset by the fact that immigrants' poverty rates fell much faster than those of natives.
The census results for New York are more likely the result of two economic problems that hurt all less-advantaged workers, regardless of their nativity: increased inequality and high unemployment.

JARED BERNSTEIN
JEFF CHAPMAN
Washington, Aug. 8, 2002

The writers are, respectively, senior economist and policy analyst at the Economic Policy Institute.

HEADLINE: Dockside, the War on Terrorism May Hone Rivalry 

BYLINE:  By WAYNE ARNOLD 

DATELINE: SINGAPORE, Aug. 12 

 BODY:
The 790-foot container ship Norasia Sharjah sat dissected on Christopher Ong's computer screen, sliced into virtual sections. Inside each slice were colored boxes representing the nearly 3,500 containers on board and their destinations: Malaysia, Sri Lanka, Egypt, Malta, Italy.
 For Mr. Ong, the vice president responsible for one of the four container terminals owned by Singapore's dominant port operator, the PSA Corporation, the sophisticated system is a way to help customers like Norasia Container Lines save time and money. But soon, the PSA system will join the front line of the United States war against terrorism. 
 In June, Singapore became the first country to sign on to a container security initiative by the United States Customs Service. Though many details are being worked out, one important feature of the initiative will be the stationing of United States customs officials in the world's largest ports, where they can help prevent terrorists from sneaking weapons of mass destruction into the 5.7 million containers that travel to United States seaports each year.
The Customs Service has been promoting the program as a competitive advantage for ports that take part, arguing that the containers that the service screens abroad will pass though customs more quickly once they reach the United States.
Canada, the Netherlands, Belgium and France have followed Singapore's lead, and several other countries are thought to be close to signing on, too.
But many port operators and shipping companies remain unconvinced. The plan will mean costly delays, they say, at a time when ports are competing intensely for cargo. Japan and Hong Kong, for instance, have both expressed reservations about the cost of the proposal and what they see as its intrusiveness. PSA, however, is willing to gamble. "If we're able to do this more efficiently than our competitors, we will have an advantage in terms of transit time," said Grace Fu, the deputy group president for finance at PSA.
PSA's fortunes took a turn for the worse last year, with traffic and profit both falling roughly 9 percent, partly because of the global economic slowdown. PSA also faces increasing competition from a newer port in neighboring Malaysia, the Port of Tanjung Pelepas, where lower costs lured away two of PSA's biggest customers, Maersk Sealand and Evergreen Marine.
Singapore has always been primarily a port city, and the port, the largest in the region, remains a metaphor for Singapore's struggle to cope with rising competition from China and other neighbors for investment and trade.
Known as the Port of Singapore Authority before it "corporatized" in 1997 (it remains state-owned), PSA is the world's largest container port operator. Some 15.6 million containers are handled each year, most of them just passing through on their way to 600 other ports in 123 countries. Shipping companies mainly use Singapore as a transshipment hub, consolidating cargoes here on their way to markets elsewhere. 
Singapore's location on one of the world's busiest shipping routes clinched its position as the biggest port in Southeast Asia. High-technology efficiency has helped keep Singapore on top. PSA computer systems link shipping lines, freight forwarders, exporters and customs officials. They calculate where best to berth incoming ships and how to load or unload them as quickly and efficiently as possible, crunching a job that used to take five people 12 hours into a three-hour procedure, Mr. Ong said.
At Mr. Ong's terminal, PSA has introduced what it says are the world's first auto-piloted cranes. Instead of assigning an operator to each crane, PSA can have a single operator at its computer system manage up to six cranes, directing them to fetch containers from a stockyard. Human operators control the cranes only when they are ready to put the containers on trucks for transfer to a ship. And humans still run the cranes that load and unload containers from ships.
Still, there is only so much that technical wizardry can do to combat lower-priced competition. PSA has had to break with longstanding practices to win back traffic, which picked up a bit in June and July.
Last month, PSA said it would begin offering discounts and would stop refusing to allow shipping companies to run their own terminals, a privilege they commonly enjoy at other ports, according to Sim Chey Hoon, a Merrill Lynch analyst here.
"That's what they really want," Ms. Sim said of the shippers. "It's a lot easier if you have your own terminal."
PSA has also begun looking beyond its home port, taking stakes in two ports in Belgium, four in China and six others elsewhere.
Growth overseas has largely offset whatever revenue PSA has lost to its Malaysian competitor. "In China the ports are doing tremendously well," said Tan Ee-Lin, an analyst at Standard & Poor's. Chinese port traffic is growing 30 percent a year.
Until the United States customs officials arrive here later this month, PSA and the shipping lines can only guess about many details of the United States security initiative. So far it appears that shippers will have to submit cargo manifests earlier than before and that the manifests will be used to flag suspicious containers to be X-rayed on arrival.
The shipping lines are "a little bit leery about how the requirements will affect the flow of containers," said Chak Kwok Wai, director of NYK Line, a subsidiary of Nippon Yusen of Japan and a big Singapore port customer.
Right now, PSA can readily determine where containers have come from, but not what is in them. That information will have to be obtained from the shipping lines, which get it from exporters, and then will have to be put into PSA's database. "Some shipments have good information; some don't," Mr. Chak said.
Analysts say that the security initiative will not affect most of the millions of containers passing through Singapore. Only a few hundred thousand a year are destined for the United States, and although the port can move hundreds of containers an hour, most containers spend up to four days sitting in a yard waiting for ships to arrive -- plenty of time to be screened. "We are not overly concerned," Ms. Fu said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A container vessel berthed in Singapore, where the port operator PSA expects to enlist its sophisticated computer system in the United States' war against terrorism by helping customs officials screen ship cargoes. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TRAVEL; 
MEMO PAD

BYLINE:  By JOE SHARKEY

 BODY:
A Bright Side To US Airways Tale
There is a bright side to the US Airways filing in bankruptcy court, according to Hal Rosenbluth, the chief executive of Rosenbluth International, the third-largest global travel management company. 
 "I think it's great for everyone," said Mr. Rosenbluth, who is known as something of an iconoclast in the travel industry. 
 Mr. Rosenbluth explained himself. Besides the short-term relief for a floundering airline, and despite expected "minor interruptions" in some passenger service, the US Airways action brings into sharp focus the fundamental problem that has pushed the airline industry to the edge of a cliff, he said.
"The fare structure is broken," Mr. Rosenbluth said. The industry's travail will continue, he added, "until someone takes a leadership position and insists on a rational pricing structure."
How does that happen, even assuming one of the major airlines finally steps up to the plate and restructures fares? Merely simplifying hopelessly convoluted fare structures is not enough, suggested Mr. Rosenbluth, who has been crusading on this subject for over a year. Nor is it simply a matter of narrowing the current wide discrepancy between leisure and business fares by raising cheap leisure fares, though that would be a start, he said.
Rather, he suggested, fundamental reform will involve a radical change in the current behaviors both of airlines and of companies that negotiate discounts on standard business fares. 
For several years, he said, airlines desperate for cash and for market share have "haphazardly given discounts or matched others' discounts," while corporate travel departments have grabbed at increasingly enticing offers of negotiated discounts in exchange for guarantees of a certain amount of volume.
This has forced small businesses to reduce purchases of business fares or reduce travel altogether, he said. Meanwhile, order and discipline are collapsing in the overall corporate marketplace for business fares. 
In this wild fire-sale atmosphere, some companies have been "promising more than they can deliver" to get airline business-fare discounts, Mr. Rosenbluth said. And airlines -- desperate to hang onto any revenue whatever -- "have not been penalizing them" for failing to purchase as many tickets as they had promised to get the discounts, he added. 
At the same time, he continued, companies "who negotiate properly and honestly" on their airline discounts, are "subsidizing" the miscreants. The result is that "hundreds of millions of dollars have gone down the drain" instead of to the airlines, he said.
Late last year, Mr. Rosenbluth commissioned a study on the subject. The report -- "Who's Zooming Who?" -- is on the Rosenbluth Web site, www.rosenbluth.com. Click on "About Us," then "Press Releases" and then "2001."

U.S. Air Travel Continues to Languish
Domestic air travel continues to languish, according to data to be released this week by OAG, the international airline guide. According to published airline schedules for August, the number of domestic flights was down 7 percent, and international flights down 8 percent, OAG said. 
The actual situation is worse than those numbers make it appear because many airlines have been flying smaller-capacity planes since last year. In July, for example, US Airways reported that passenger traffic was off 17.6 percent. The other major airlines also carried far fewer passengers. United Airlines traffic was off 12.3 percent. It was down 9.7 percent at American Airlines, 8.6 percent at Continental Airlines, 8 percent at Northwest Airlines and 6.6 percent at Delta Air Lines. JOE SHARKEY

HEADLINE: Technology on Docks: Fears Despite Promises 

BYLINE:  By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: OAKLAND, Calif., Aug. 10 

 BODY:
As a bus packed with longshoremen headed to a giant Korean ship at Berth 36, Wendell Womack lashed out at management's contract proposal, saying it would be terrible for longshoremen and for the people of Oakland. 
 The proposal, to install new technology to cut costs and speed cargo handling, would eliminate 400 longshoremen's jobs on the West Coast, management officials acknowledge. 
 Thousands of longshoremen are so angry that they are threatening to strike, a move that would paralyze ports from San Diego to Seattle and weaken the nation's shaky economy.
"They've said they'd protect the jobs of current workers, but what about the future?" asked Mr. Womack, who works about 20 days a year on the waterfront and hopes to qualify as a registered regular longshoreman. "They'd be cutting off hope." 
For many people in down-and-out neighborhoods here, the promise of an $80,000-a-year longshoreman's job is like the promise of a lottery ticket. Union officials say they try to give poor residents many of the new jobs.
But negotiators for the shipping lines say Mr. Womack and other longshoremen fail to understand that by cutting costs the management proposal would make the ports more competitive, meaning additional jobs at the docks. Negotiators will grapple over the proposal when they resume talks on Tuesday, after a three-week break.
"The talks are very slow," said Joseph Miniace, president of the employers' group, the Pacific Maritime Association. "There's very little progress."
Mr. Miniace said he worried that the 10,500 West Coast longshoremen would conduct a slowdown or walk out. The Bush administration, fearing that a job action would hurt the economy, has signaled it might order an 80-day cooling-off period. 
In his office in San Francisco, Mr. Miniace took out a chart to show that under his proposal jobs would dip by 400 over three years and then increase, surpassing current levels in 2007. He has promised lifetime job security for unionized clerks, even though new technologies might eliminate their jobs, which include typing in what merchandise each truck carries into the port.
"The clerk numbers are going to fall, but the numbers of longshoremen, the people who do the loading and unloading, are going to continue to grow," Mr. Miniace said. "Remember that cargo flows are projected to double and triple in the next 10 or 20 years."
Many longshoremen say they do not believe that. The two sides have not been able to reach an accord since July 1, when the old contract expired, largely because many longshoremen do not trust management. 
Considering the history of the International Longshore and Warehouse Union, that is not surprising. Since the union was founded in 1932, helped by a legendary general strike that shut down San Francisco, it has often taken an us-against-them attitude toward management. 
Even though their pay makes the longshoremen the royalty of the nation's blue-collar workers, they often echo the oratory of the union founder, Harry Bridges, who was proud to be called a militant Marxist. For decades, J. Edgar Hoover, the F.B.I. director, sought -- unsuccessfully -- to deport the Australian-born Mr. Bridges, accusing him of being a Communist, a description that Mr. Bridge steadfastly denied. 
"It's hard to believe their talk of more jobs," said Richard Mead, president of I.L.W.U. Local 10, which represents dock workers here. "We handle 10 times the amount of cargo that we did decades ago, but now we have one-twentieth of the people." 
The ports are handling more cargo with fewer workers because ships now carry cargo in big metal containers that are easy to load and unload with cranes instead of carrying cargo in loose batches that took far more workers to handle. In 1960, union and management reached a turning point with the Mechanization and Modernization Agreement. In that pact, the union let shipping lines use containers, and management promised job security and high wages and benefits.
Now, the companies say it is time for another technological leap. They want to use optical scanners, the Internet and satellite geopositioning to monitor shipments and speed trucks into ports.
"There are huge truck lines at the terminals," Mr. Miniace said, "and if we automate the gates, we can process trucks in 30 seconds, rather than three minutes."
Union officials say they do not oppose new technologies that increase efficiency. But they fear that management will use the technologies to transform union jobs into nonunion management positions and move union jobs off the piers, so nonunion workers do the work.
"Technology and union jurisdiction cannot be separated," a spokesman for the union, Steve Stallone, said. "Technology is being used to shrink the number of jobs in some areas. But our philosophy is the jobs that remain should be union jobs."
The union wants certain managers' jobs and nearly 100 jobs of vessel planners, who map cargo placement on ships, to be union positions. In its proposal, the union said it would accept new technologies, but only if it retained, or was given, many positions. 
Just as the union ridiculed the management proposal, some management officials did not take the union proposal seriously. 
"Their proposal was developed so it could not possibly be accepted," Mr. Miniace said. "On a net basis, their proposal actually adds employees to the work force."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TRAVEL: ON THE GROUND -- In San Diego; 
Hot Economy and Mild Temperatures

BYLINE:  By MELINDA LIGOS

 BODY:
Don't tell San Diego that the country recently suffered a recession.
 If any American metropolis has boomed during the rocky economy, it has been California's southernmost large city -- home to Sempra Energy, Qualcomm and IDEC pharmaceuticals -- with its diversified economy and its thriving technology, biotechnology and tourism industries. Employment is up, as is attendance at the San Diego Convention Center, which was recently expanded. 
 And you really can't talk about San Diego without mentioning the balmy climate, where temperatures hover in the mid-60's in the winter and the mid-70's in the summer.

HOTELS
Those who have an image to uphold should consider the LODGE AT TORREY PINES (858-453-4420, $450 to $900), which opened in La Jolla amidst a great deal of fanfare in April. Some executives book one of the Palisades suites, which span 1,100 square feet, for business powwows. Guests also have privileges at the adjacent Torrey Pines Golf Course.
Equally luxurious, but much more low key, the nearby HOTEL PARISI (858-454-1511, $325 to $485) features 20 ultraprivate rooms with high-end stereo systems and computer hookups.
For ease to the San Diego Convention Center, it's hard to beat the SAN DIEGO MARRIOTT HOTEL AND MARINA (619-234-1500, $260 to $285), which is connected to the center, as well as several restaurants and lounges. All rooms have high-speed Internet access.
The MANCHESTER GRAND HYATT SAN DIEGO, (619-232-1234) also near the convention center, is offering a special summer rate of $165 a night for a single room. In mid-September, rates will climb back up to $189.
If you're traveling northward and want to relax after a round of client meetings, you might check into the FOUR SEASONS RESORT AVIARA (760-603-6800, $505 to $615) in Carlsbad and order an avocado wrap at the spa.
The HOTEL DEL CORONADO (619-435-6611, $265 to $615), Coronado's historic hotel, is ideal for small meetings and dinners. Entertain guests in one of the hotel's new Cottages at North Beach, which offer large living rooms with fireplaces and French doors opening to decks that overlook the Pacific. A special cottage staff will prepare a candlelight, four-course dinner -- and draw you a customized bath when everyone's gone home.

DINING OUT
For a scenic lunch, try the PRADO (619-557-9441, $65 for two, including wine and tip) in Balboa Park, the largest urban park in the country. Dan Novak, a vice president at Cox Communications in San Diego, enjoys its eclectic menu, which changes frequently. After lunch, Mr. Novak likes to take out-of-towners on a stroll by the Old Globe Theater, a local landmark within walking distance of the restaurant.
If you've got some serious schmoozing to do, make a reservation at DONOVAN'S STEAK AND CHOP HOUSE (858-450-6666, about $100) in La Jolla's University Town Center. Once you've been there a few times, the waiters have your name, and table preferences, committed to memory. Even the restaurant's general manager, Carl Essert, who works the room each night, will treat you like an old pal. "I only go there about every other month, and the staff puts a little plaque with my name on it on the table, which impresses the heck out of clients," Mr. Novak said. Diners can choose from more than a dozen cuts of beef, or go for the lobster, which Mr. Novak calls "phenomenal."
The TURF SUPPER CLUB (619-234-6363, $80) in Golden Hill is a hip, off-the-beaten-path establishment where guests can sip martinis while cooking their own steaks at an indoor grill. "It's way cool," said Ron Donoho, executive editor of San Diego magazine. Once the meat is done to your liking, sit back and listen to piano music on Fridays, Saturdays, and Sundays. Open for dinner only.
Take sports fans to SEAU'S (619-291-7328, $45), a casual Mission Valley burger and sandwich joint owned by the San Diego Chargers linebacker Junior Seau. You'll get a variety of inexpensive eats, and your own television screen at your table, tuned to whatever channel you like.

ENTERTAINMENT
Downtown's Gaslamp Quarter is the hottest spot in town for bar hoppers. 
For late-night planning over drinks, try the WESTGATE PIANO BAR (619-557-3650) in the Westgate Hotel. With bow-tie-clad waiters, top Scotch and Champagne, classical piano music and velvet furniture, "it's a really classy place," said Gregor Shanks, a senior account executive for Weyerhaeuser. The best part? "Hardly anybody knows about it, so it's quiet," Mr. Shanks said.
For something a little more upbeat in the Quarter, head to JIMMY LOVES (619-595-0123), which features live jazz six nights a week, and Top 40 cover bands on Thursdays, Fridays, and Saturdays.

ON YOUR OWN
Too busy to visit the SAN DIEGO ZOO (619-231-1515) during the day? Don't worry. It's even better at night, when you can take in "The Stilt Birds," a show running through Sept. 2 that features 10-foot prehistoric-looking puppets operated by elaborately costumed technicians. 
Also to be enjoyed at night is "Park at Dark" at the SAN DIEGO WILD ANIMAL PARK (619-718-3000). The evening show features the sounds of beating drums and soft flutes set against a backdrop of African savannas.

This feature about places to stay, eat and visit in leading business destinations appears every Tuesday.

HEADLINE: Seeing Long Trading Slump, Schwab Sets More Cutbacks 

BYLINE:  By PATRICK McGEEHAN

 BODY:
The Charles Schwab Corporation said yesterday that it would shut one of its five customer call centers, eliminate 375 jobs and look for ways to save an additional $200 million a year as it braces for an extended slump in trading by individual investors.
 Executives at Schwab, based in San Francisco, said they saw little reason to hope that customers would regain enough confidence in financial markets to return in force. They said they would cut an undetermined number of additional jobs, in addition to about 7,500 eliminated in the last 18 months. 
 "As we thought long and hard about the current environment, we did not have conviction that things were going to rebound quickly," said Christopher Dodds, Schwab's chief financial officer. "Too much wealth has been lost, too much sentiment has been damaged for there to be a quick and painless recovery."
Mr. Dodds offered that assessment despite reporting that Schwab's business picked up in July. Last month, the average number of daily trades by the company's customers was more than 20 percent higher than in June or in July of last year. Customers also deposited $4.4 billion in new money in accounts at Schwab.
But more of that money stayed in cash and less went into stocks and mutual funds, Mr. Dodds said. Schwab's customers also sold more stocks and mutual funds than they bought in July. 
The scariest development, though, came last week. Mr. Dodds said customer trading activity had reverted in August to the depressed levels of May and June.
"Despite one good month, we're just not satisfied with current financial performance," Mr. Dodds said. "We felt some further actions were needed."
Those actions will include closing the company's call center in Austin, Tex., and laying off 300 people who work there. Opened in mid-2000, that center is Schwab's newest. It handles about 10 percent of the calls from customers seeking help or advice on investments.
Schwab will eliminate 75 jobs in its other call centers, in Denver; Indianapolis; Orlando, Fla.; and Phoenix, Mr. Dodds said. Then, over the next several weeks, Schwab's executives will identify other expenses to cut, in areas ranging from consultants and other professional services to advertising. After making those decisions, the company will decide how many more jobs to eliminate, he said.
Analysts said they expected that the number of jobs to be eliminated would exceed 1,000 and that the company's staff would fall below 18,000 people, from a peak of 26,300 in late 2000.
Shares of Charles Schwab fell 11 cents, to $8.46.
"There's growing concern among investors that the company is moving away from cutting fat into the meat," said Henry McVey, an analyst at Morgan Stanley. "We think the slowdown in retail brokerage is not an aberration but a trend."
With investors scared out of the market, Mr. McVey and other analysts said, Schwab had no choice but to cut costs to deliver on its promise of better returns. Schwab has promised to raise its profit margin to 12 percent to 14 percent, but has been stuck at about 10 percent through July. 
"This is a realization that the market isn't going to come back any time soon for the retail investor," said Richard Repetto, an analyst with Putnam Lovell Securities.

HEADLINE: Colombia President Declares Limited State of Emergency 

BYLINE:  By JUAN FORERO

DATELINE: BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 12 

 BODY:
True to his campaign promise for aggressive action against leftist rebels, Colombia's new president, Alvaro Uribe, authorized emergency measures today that broaden the government's powers and allow for a quick expansion of the armed forces.
 The measures, invoked in a "state of domestic commotion" decree, give the government the right to create a new tax to pay for the military buildup. The government can now also restrict movement, make arrests without warrants and control television and radio airwaves, if deemed necessary. 
 The decree comes five days after rebels of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia lobbed mortars into the center of this Andean capital during Mr. Uribe's inauguration, killing at least 19 civilians who were struck by errant missiles.
Mr. Uribe and his ministers met on Sunday to draft the decree, as permitted under the Constitution. The government said today that "insecurity in the government" was growing more critical every day.
"The state and the Colombian society should respond to recuperate the national security, now that the violent ones have become more aggressive and destructive," said Fernando Londono, the justice and interior minister. 
Some leading human rights groups expressed concern about the measures, noting that such decrees have led to rights abuses when invoked by various Colombian governments.
"By its very nature it gives new powers and authority to the military and police," said Eric Olson, Latin America specialist at Amnesty International in Washington. "And there's a long track record of lack of accountability and abuse by those authorities."
But there is strong support here for a tough response against the rebels, who have increased bombings in recent months, after Mr. Uribe's predecessor broke off peace talks. Mr. Uribe, a former provincial governor educated at Oxford and Harvard, won office in a landslide by pledging to bring order to this violence-ridden country.
Mr. Londono, in announcing the decree, said the government would "safeguard with obsessive vigilance the respect for human rights." 
 Gen. Luis Ernesto Gilibert, who was widely expected to be removed by Mr. Uribe as chief of the country's National Police, resigned Monday night, Reuters reported. 
The decree is not as strong as a state of siege, under which the government could impose curfews, penalize those who broke them and severely limit freedom of movement.
But it remained unclear what restrictions would be applied; Mr. Londono said the measures would be announced in a week or two. The decree lasts 90 days, but can be extended an additional 180 days.
The decree gives the president the authority to recruit quickly up to 6,000 soldiers for two elite, mobile brigades, as well as 10,000 new police officers and 100,000 civilian informers, who would receive a small remuneration to provide authorities with intelligence on the rebels. The government also wants to increase the number of special prosecutors and judges.
To pay for the military expansion, estimated to cost up to $800 million, the government would assess a 1.2 percent tax on anyone with assets exceeding $60,0000. During his campaign for president, Mr. Uribe stressed that the only way to improve Colombia's troubled economy was to expand the military's abilities against the rebels.
Although the State Department declined comment on the usefulness of the decree, many officials in the Bush administration are sure to welcome the measure.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS; 
Last Week's Rally Stalls as Investors Take Profits or Wait

BYLINE:  By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Wall Street stalled yesterday as investors took profits from last week's rally and considered the possibility that the Federal Reserve might not cut interest rates. Blue chips dropped slightly, while technology shares managed a small gain.
 Analysts said investors wanted to see what retail earnings and other economic data looked like and whether companies would meet a government deadline later this week for certifying financial statements. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average closed down 56.56 points, or 0.7 percent, at 8,688.89. Broader stock indicators were mixed. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index slipped 4.84 points, or 0.5 percent, to 903.80. The Nasdaq composite index was little changed, rising 0.72 points, to 1,306.84. 
Analysts noted that trading volume was light.
"There's just not much going on today," said Robert Streed, portfolio manager of Northern Select Equity Fund in Chicago. "People are just waiting to see what the Fed is going to do Tuesday, who does or doesn't sign their financial documents on the 14th and to see if the market can continue its uptrend."
Stocks rose steadily last week on a mix of bargain hunting after a huge sell-off and hopes that the Fed might cut interest rates again because of data suggesting that the economy was faltering. The Fed's Open Market Committee is scheduled to meet today, but most analysts played down the possibility of a reduction. 
US Airways' decision to file for bankruptcy protection over the weekend soured the session for airlines. UAL, the parent of United Airlines, fell $1.40, to $3.80, a decline of 26.9 percent, on concerns that the airline might be the next carrier forced into bankruptcy protection. US Airways shares did not trade.
Boeing, which makes airplanes, fell 50 cents, to $40.50.
Technology stocks, which posted sizable gains last week, struggled. Intel fell 36 cents, to $17.50, after Salomon Smith Barney reduced its estimates on the stock, citing soft demand. Applied Materials, which counts Intel as one of its biggest customers, slipped 28 cents, to $13.58.
Imclone rose 68 cents yesterday, to $8.02, after its founder and former chief executive, Samuel D. Waksal, pleaded not guilty to insider trading charges. Mr. Waksal also said he still thought that his company's cancer drug, Erbitux, had the potential to help thousands of patients.
Investors were also focused on retailers, many of whom are expected to report earnings today, including J. C. Penney and Wal-Mart Stores. Penney rose 12 cents, to $16.75, while Wal-Mart fell 79 cents, to $48.41. 
Investors are also expected to watch whether the companies required to certify their financial reports meet the Securities and Exchange Commission's deadline tomorrow. Among the companies certifying results yesterday were J. P. Morgan Chase and Kellogg, but that failed to lift their stock prices. J. P. Morgan Chase fell 89 cents, to $25.46, while Kellogg dropped 2 cents, to $34.70. --------------------

Treasury Prices Rise
By Bloomberg News
Treasury prices rose yesterday as a decline in stocks bolstered demand for fixed-rate government securities.
The yield on the Treasury's 10-year note dropped to 4.21 percent, from 4.26 percent on Friday, while the price, which moves in the opposite direction, rose 13/32, to 101 9/32. The yield on the 30-year bond fell to 5.07 percent from 5.11 percent; its price rose 22/32, to 104 18/32.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL; 
Questions, Answers: A Look at the Dispute

BYLINE:  By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
Q. Wasn't the union expected to set a strike date yesterday?
 A. Yes, but the union decided it could afford to give negotiators a few more days to try to reach a deal. 
 Q. If no agreement is forthcoming, when might the union take that step?
A. The executive board is scheduled to hold a conference call Friday, and that would be a likely time unless further progress is made.
Q. Have the players and the owners ever negotiated a new agreement without a work stoppage?
A. No. In the last three decades, the players have gone on strike five times and the owners have locked out the players three times.
Q. Why are the players considering a strike? Can't they keep negotiating through the rest of the season, the postseason and even the off-season?
A. The owners have pledged not to lock out the players or unilaterally implement new work rules through the end of the World Series, but not beyond. The players believe if they continue to play but don't have an agreement when the World Series ends, the clubs will declare an impasse in negotiations and implement a new labor system.
Q. Didn't the owners try to do that in 1994?
A. They did, but the National Labor Relations Board, at the union's urging, went to court, arguing that the clubs did not bargain in good faith and had not reached an impasse. The players returned to work when a federal judge granted the injunction the N.L.R.B. had sought and ordered the clubs to restore the rules that existed under the old agreement.
Q. What do the players want? 
A. As has been the case in the last few negotiations, the players have not asked for anything new of real significance. The players are trying to hold on to the substantial economic gains they have made since the advent of free agency in 1976.
Q. What do the owners want?
A. The owners want to share more of their local revenue to reduce the disparity between club payrolls (Yankees $137 million, Tampa Bay $33 million) and improve competitive balance. They also want to slow the escalation of player salaries.
Q. Why should the players have a say in how clubs share revenues?
A. With the wealthier clubs giving significant money to the less-wealthy clubs, salaries paid by the wealthier clubs could be affected. The owners recognize that revenue sharing is a mandatory subject for bargaining.
Q. What have the owners proposed as a revenue-sharing plan?
A. They initially wanted to share 50 percent of local revenue, less stadium rent, and allocate the money to recipients on an equal, or straight-pool, basis. They also wanted to have a $100 million discretionary fund so the commissioner could give additional money to certain clubs. 
Q. What have the players proposed?
A. The players offered to have the clubs share 22 1/2 percent of their local revenue but distribute it on a split-pool basis, that is, part of the fund would go to the teams with the lowest revenue and the rest would be divided equally. They also proposed a $40 million discretionary fund, though not necessarily under the control of the commissioner.
Q. Have positions changed since those initial proposals?
A. Neither side has talked publicly about what it has done, but the initial $70 million difference in the amount of revenue to be transferred among clubs has been whittled to something less than $50 million, and the clubs reduced the proposed discretionary fund to $85 million. 
Q. Are they close enough to make a deal on revenue sharing?
A. It's not a matter of being close enough. The players won't agree on revenue sharing without knowing where they stand on a luxury tax.
Q. What is the luxury tax?
A. The owners want to impose a tax on the highest payrolls as a way of inhibiting teams from spending so much on player salaries. They initially proposed a 50 percent tax on parts of payrolls exceeding $98 million but recently raised the threshold to $100 million and offered a reduced, phased-in tax rate on payrolls over $115 million.
Q. How do the players feel about the luxury tax?
A. They don't like it. They say the tax and the revenue-sharing contributions will leave the highest-spending teams with far less money to spend on players. A luxury tax did exist for part of the last agreement.
Q. Are there any other major issues separating the two sides?
A. The third issue the clubs have identified as vital is the amateur draft. Until now, the draft, held each June, has included high school and college players from the United States, Canada and Puerto Rico. Players from other countries, like the Dominican Republic, have been available to all clubs as free agents. The clubs want to extend the draft worldwide, covering those other players.
Q. Why do the owners want a worldwide draft?
A. Some clubs have been more aggressive than others in scouting players in Latin countries and in Asia, and officials want to put everyone on the same level. They also want to reduce the signing bonuses the best foreign players receive as free agents sought by several teams. When a player is drafted, he can negotiate and sign only with the team that drafts him.
Q. What is the players' position on a worldwide draft?
A. They have accepted the concept, but they have differences. One is the number of rounds in the draft. The players want 16, the clubs 38.
Q. What is happening with the clubs' desire to test players for steroids, other performance-enhancing drugs, supplements and so-called recreational drugs?
A. The union made a proposal on steroids testing that the clubs' negotiators liked, but the two sides disagree on some elements of testing. 
Q. If there is a strike, will it be a long one?
A. The only reason for the two sides to reach agreement in a matter of days if the players walk out would be if the owners were skeptical about the players' willingness to strike and had to see them do it before compromising on what they want.
