HEADLINE: Energy Pricing Suspicious, Report Says 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 

 BODY:
Federal energy regulators, struggling to get to the bottom of the California energy crisis of 2000-01, said for the first time today that there was evidence that natural gas prices might have been manipulated, helping to drive up power prices. 
 They also said that they had found evidence of possible manipulation of electricity prices by Enron and two other companies, Avista and El Paso Electric, and began formal investigations to determine whether they broke federal electricity-trading rules. 
 The preliminary report prepared by the staff of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission contrasts with the agency's approach at the outset of the California crisis two years ago, when it played down the possibility of manipulation. The report comes closer to endorsing the view of many California officials that the state's energy crisis resulted at least in part from manipulation of the market by energy companies like Enron.
If the commission endorses the findings, it could then increase the size of the refunds it might order energy companies to pay consumers in California for overcharging. That is because, if prices had been manipulated, many energy sellers could no longer use high natural gas costs as an excuse for charging high power prices. The difference could mean more than $1 billion in additional refunds, one official said. 
While Enron sought bankruptcy protection in December, many other large companies that sold power to California are still profitable, though some are struggling.
An administrative law judge at the commission is scheduled to begin a hearing soon to determine the refunds owed. 
The investigation by the energy commission has also found that the common method for reporting prices for natural gas and electricity trades -- surveys published by industry publications -- does not use statistically valid procedures and is subject to manipulation by traders who have an incentive to report false data to benefit their own trading positions.
Reaction in California was mixed tonight. Senator Dianne Feinstein, the California Democrat who helped instigate the investigation, said she was "encouraged that FERC finally is taking seriously its responsibility to protect consumers." She said she was particularly gratified by the finding that manipulation might have increased natural gas prices, which she said was among the major factors in the escalation of electricity costs during the energy crisis.
But Gov. Gray Davis of California, a Democrat locked in a battle for re-election against Bill Simon Jr., a Republican, called the actions today a "whitewash, pure and simple." The commission "hasn't sanctioned anybody, it hasn't issued any refunds to us, it's done nothing to stop the manipulation which everyone agrees occurred here in California." Mr. Davis has sharply criticized what he called profiteering and overcharging by energy companies -- a stance critics have attacked as ignoring severe flaws in how the state created its deregulated electricity marketplace.
In fact, the report does assign some blame to the state, noting that shortages of electricity and underlying problems with the structure of the marketplace created an environment in which prices could be driven up. And while officials of the energy commission stressed that the inquiry was not complete, the report today did not name many of the largest companies that California officials have accused of driving up prices, including Reliant Energy, Dynegy and Duke Energy.
The report also said that the disclosure of memos outlining trading strategies that Enron used in California -- with colorful names like Death Star, Get Shorty and Fat Boy -- has "adversely affected" electricity markets far beyond the "dollar impact" of the strategies themselves.
"We've still got further ground to plow, but the agency is doing its job, and we look forward to getting to closure," said Patrick Wood III, the chairman of the energy commission, who was appointed last year. He emphasized that the commission was still investigating whether energy companies had withheld power to drive up prices or had manipulated prices to increase profits on financial derivatives whose value was tied to electricity or natural gas costs.
In the report, Enron came in for severe criticism from the commission, which said its strategies "involved deceit, including the provision of false information" in an attempt to manipulate prices. In addition, the report found that Enron's once-dominant Internet-based exchange, EnronOnline, "was potentially susceptible to manipulation."
The commission said that one strategy used in 2000 -- exporting power from California to evade price caps -- had worsened the shortage. An Enron spokesman, Eric Thode, said, "We're continuing to cooperate with the FERC's investigation," but declined further comment.
In the two years before filing for bankruptcy protection on Dec. 2, Enron made about $1.8 billion in profits trading electricity in California and other Western states, the report found based on Enron's raw data, with profits exceeding $20 million on many single days.
In announcing investigations of Avista, based in Spokane, Wash.; El Paso Electric in Texas; and several Enron subsidiaries, including Portland General Electric in Oregon, the commission said regulators could eventually revoke the traders' ability to sell power at market rates and force them to disgorge certain profits. El Paso Electric is not affiliated with the El Paso Corporation, the large Houston natural gas company.
One area the commission has focused on is whether the dealings of Enron with Portland were improper and collusive. Transcripts of phone conversations among Enron and Portland General employees include discussions questioning whether trades involving the two companies were legal, and one in which a Portland employee refers to an arrangement with Enron as a "scam," the commission said. Investigators are also studying what the commission said was Avista's admission that it routinely acted as a middleman for Enron and Portland on deals that the two companies were "forbidden to undertake directly" -- deals Avista's own traders had questions about. 
Also, the commission said it had "uncovered preliminary evidence that El Paso and Enron may have engaged in actions that adversely affected prices." Both companies, working with each other, may have violated other federal rules, the commission said, like gaining improper preferential access to El Paso's transmission lines to "engage in highly profitable sale/buyback transactions with Mexican entities."
Tonight, Avista said "its trading practices were ethical and legal" and that its employees "had no knowledge of the strategies Enron may have been pursuing." El Paso Electric said it would "answer all of FERC's questions candidly, openly, and completely."
The 103-page report is only the initial finding of the commission staff. Once the final report is completed, its conclusions are subject to the approval of the four-member commission. It is investigating the matter with the Justice Department, the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission.
The energy commission found that the system for reporting prices for gas and power trades -- surveys done by industry publications -- may have been manipulated by traders. In one case, a trader at one company engaged in repeated back-and-forth trades with Enron with no economic purpose other than to win a TV in a contest for the highest trade volume.
"We found a lot of strange behavior that affected natural gas prices," said Donald Gelinas, the commission's associate director for the office of markets, tariffs and rates, who is leading its investigation.
"Some appears to be pure price manipulation, some was wash trades, and some was just clicking a key to win a prize," he said.
The investigation of price reporting, he added, has found activity that "looks very suspicious and appears to increase volumes and prices, casting enough doubt on these indices to no longer recommend that the commission" use them for setting rates.
Mr. Gelinas, however, cautioned that the commission staff had not come to any final conclusions. "We've still got some more digging to do," he said.

HEADLINE: CHILD-ONLY CASES GROW IN WELFARE 

BYLINE:  By NINA BERNSTEIN 

 BODY:
A surprising change has overtaken the welfare rolls in New York City and the nation. In more than a third of welfare households, the only recipients of benefits are children.
 The growth of such "child only" welfare cases has crept up almost unnoticed on policy makers focused on using welfare-to-work strategies to shrink caseloads and combat poverty. And recent studies show high rates of hunger and hardship among the young recipients of such aid. 
 Officials have barely begun to address the different challenges posed by these cases, including the amount of the grants themselves, as little as $68 a month in some states. 
But the share of child-only cases, up from 10 percent nationally in 1988, is becoming too big to ignore. The number of such cases, too, has been edging up since 1998, to 782,000 cases and more than a million children nationwide in 2000, and to 58,137 children in 34,337 cases now in New York City, which recently transferred 12,000 to a new welfare center without work requirements.
One reason for the rise is that some of the same rules and practices that sharply reduced the regular welfare rolls are gradually expanding the pool of children eligible for child-only grants.
Some live with disabled parents who receive Supplemental Security Income for themselves, often after having been found unable to work for family aid. Some are children born in the United States to immigrant parents, either illegal or legal immigrants barred from welfare by strict new rules in the 1996 federal overhaul. In a few states, though not in New York, some live with parents who have exhausted welfare time limits or violated the rules for aid.
But most of the children -- those in 54 percent of cases nationwide -- live apart from their parents, reared by relatives who have no legal responsibility to support them. Often they are with a grandmother, like the four grandchildren whom Rosalia Castillo retrieved from foster care three years ago: Stephanie, now 8, who wants to be a teacher one minute and a starlet the next; Anthony, 10, who plans to be a police officer; Francisco, 11, a would-be inventor of video games; and Crystal, 12, an aspiring dress designer.
Ms. Castillo, a former housecleaner with arthritis who speaks little English, has lived in a public housing project on the Lower East Side for 22 years. She recently qualified for Supplemental Security Income for herself. The welfare grant that she collects on the children's behalf is less than a quarter of what the government paid foster-care agencies to care for them.
But in her small apartment, where the aroma of Dominican-style chicken and rice lingers long after the last grain has been eaten, the children have a home. "My mother, she was living in a shelter a long time," Crystal explained. "I'm happy that my grandmother is taking care of us for now."
Stephanie hugged an old baby blanket and whimpered her dissent. "I want to live with my mommy," she said.
A spokesman for the city's Human Resources Administration, David Neustadt, said the new center in Jamaica, Queens, was handling 12,000 child-only cases by fax and telephone. New applications for child-only aid must still be made at local welfare centers, he added.
The city still has little information about households where only the children receive welfare, said Mr. Neustadt, who expressed surprise when he discovered from city statistics how large a share of the welfare roll was taken up by child-only cases. Officials do not yet know how many children from the 12,000 cases, which were transferred to the center in March, live with relatives. But a recent detailed study of New Jersey's child-only caseload found that 63 percent involved family members other than parents. Half were older than 60, and many were in ill health.
A stark picture emerged from the New Jersey study, which the state paid Mathematica Policy Research to conduct. One in four grants went to a family headed by a disabled parent on Supplemental Security Income, and more than half of those families had trouble getting enough to eat last year, the study found. Three in 10 went hungry. That is double the rate of food shortage that is typical at their income level, the researchers said, suggesting that high medical costs or parental handicaps may have played a role.
Among immigrants, who accounted for one in 10 New Jersey cases, half the families had incomes below 50 percent of the federal poverty threshold, 84 percent had no health insurance, and many were in severely crowded households, though they had lived in the United States for nine years on average.
"Clearly the work-first approach is not relevant for them," Robert G. Wood, a Mathematica researcher, said of child-only welfare recipients. "They need to be thought of as a separate population with their own problems and needs."
Not everyone agrees. Though few participants in the welfare debate have drawn attention to child-only cases, some critics see them as the last bastion of unlimited aid, and describe many adults caring for such children as people exploiting the system to avoid work.
Those critics urge that all able-bodied caretakers of children receiving child-only benefits be required to work, and that illegal immigrants who seek aid for their children born in the United States be deported.
The leading welfare-related bills in Congress do not include such measures, but the view underscores a basic conflict between the work-first philosophy that shaped the welfare overhaul, and the idea of raising welfare grants, which have not changed in most states since the mid-1980's.
Goals like reducing out-of-wedlock births and making work pay more than welfare have led to a system that increasingly ties additional aid to adult earnings, through tax credits and work subsidies like child care, rather than to the costs of rearing children.
If relatives do not care for children, foster-care payments cost about $1,000 per child each month in New York, and at least $450 in New Jersey, Mr. Wood noted. Child-only grants, on the other hand, start at $68 a month in low-benefit states like Texas, $162 in New Jersey, and $352 in New York, and increase only modestly with each additional child.
Nationally, more than 60 percent of all families headed by nonparent relatives have low incomes. Nearly half of these had trouble buying enough food, and about 40 percent had trouble meeting housing costs, according to a recent study by the Urban Institute, a nonpartisan research center.
The number of child-only welfare cases peaked nationally at 978,000 in 1996 after rapid growth during the late 1980's and early 1990's. It dropped to 743,000 in 1998, as other welfare cases fell much more steeply, then began to climb again. Even in New York, where regular cases have continued to drop in tough economic times, child-only cases have been edging up every year since 1998, and are now nearly 37 percent of the caseload. The most recent national welfare figures, released to Congress in May, show child-only cases accounted for 35 percent of the caseload in 2000.
Rob Geen, one of the study's authors, estimates that a quarter of all the nation's welfare cases involve caretakers who are relatives and collect welfare benefits themselves or on behalf of the children. But he stresses that in the larger category of children living without their parents, three out of four households headed by relatives receive no public cash aid, though virtually all the children are eligible. Some relatives do not want welfare because of the stigma, he says; some are unaware that help is available; and some have been wrongly denied help.
Several states are experimenting with programs that pay relatives more than welfare, but less than foster care, if children would otherwise be in state custody. But some economists suggest that approach has its pitfalls, too. If meager grants already encourage hard-pressed parents to leave their children with relatives -- a contention that grandparent advocates vigorously dispute -- higher subsidies for relatives could compound the problem.
Moreover, such programs do not address the needs of welfare children living with disabled or immigrant parents, who experience greater financial hardship, studies find.
In New York, where these categories often overlap, welfare-to-work pressures can bring additional hardship to grandparents like Maria Lemons, 63, the diabetic widow of a truck driver, who reared two grandsons in Brooklyn on a child-only grant and is still caring for a 16-year-old granddaughter. She said the city stopped the children's aid for eight months in 1996, saying that she had missed a caseworker appointment.
"Borrowing money, being afraid we'd lose the roof over our heads," Ms. Lemons recalled of that period. "Struggling to pay the electric bill so the lights would stay on."
She added: "They wonder why children feel left out and despondent. They tell you, have a computer in the house. A lot of people can't afford the electricity for the computer, much less the computer."
City officials have acknowledged that mistakes do occur, while stressing that the rate of errors has declined and that recipients have the right to appeal a proposed cutoff. They said that because of confidentiality rules, they could not discuss specific cases.
But Ms. Lemons's account was echoed in the research of Denise Burnette, a professor of social work at Columbia University who followed up a sample of 59 elderly Latino grandparents rearing grandchildren in New York City. After 1996, she found, many had lost cash aid, food stamps and Medicaid because they had run afoul of administrative rules aimed at moving recipients into the work force. A third had been required to work for benefits, before being found to be too old or disabled.
Even infirm grandparents seem to have taken the city's work-first message to heart. Maria Ortiz, a 70-year-old grandmother with legal custody of her son's youngest child, Christian Siacca, now 4, tried for three years to support him on her Supplemental Security Income benefit of $460 a month. When asked if she had ever skipped meals so her grandson could eat, she wept.
The underlying problem, she said, is that Christian's 68-year-old grandfather has prostate cancer, and needs four more months of work to qualify for a Social Security pension. "I told them, my husband is willing to go polish shoes and sell oranges," she said. His last job, she added, was cleaning telephone booths in exchange for welfare.
"I live from S.S.I. and I was afraid I was going to get in trouble if I asked for a cash grant," she said in Spanish, holding Christian on her lap. "I went to the welfare office and asked if they could at least help with food stamps. Twice they rejected me."
Workers at the Educational Alliance, a 113-year-old settlement house that sees many such cases, knew that Mrs. Ortiz was entitled to food stamps and urged her to apply again. At the welfare office, which also handles food stamps, no one mentioned that Christian was also eligible for a child-only welfare grant, she said, but she was finally granted $112 a month in food stamps.
She buys more groceries now, she said. "Spaghetti, juices -- I spend it all on him."

HEADLINE: BUSH AND THE ECONOMY: SPENDING CUTBACKS; 
Citing Economy, Bush Won't Spend $5.1 Billion Approved for Security and Other Uses

BYLINE:  By CARL HULSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 

 BODY:
President Bush said today that he would not spend $5.1 billion approved by Congress last month for domestic security, the military and a variety of other initiatives, saying reduced spending would help stabilize the economy.
 "More money spent in Washington means less money in the hands of American families and entrepreneurs, less money in the hands of risk takers and job creators," Mr. Bush said as he wrapped up his economic forum in Texas. 
 Some Democrats attacked the president's decision, saying that in an effort to look decisive and confront Congress over spending, he was blocking money for projects that he had supported. New York lawmakers were critical, because the money withheld included $90 million for a health study of rescue and recovery workers at the World Trade Center site. 
"Withholding these funds is a cynical attempt to avert attention from the administration's failure to revive a stagnant economy," said Representative Nita M. Lowey, the New York Democrat who is on the Appropriations Committee.
Other Democrats said they were not going to be drawn into a fight over the spending. They said they read Mr. Bush's tough tone as a White House effort to portray the withholding as a struggle between him and Democrats, even though the appropriations had broad Republican support, as well.
"We are not going to engage him on this," one Democratic aide said, adding that the party wanted to keep the focus on the economy and corporate wrongdoing. "He wants to make it a fight over Democrats and money."
Besides the health study, Congressional experts said the $5.1 billion included $600 million for the National Guard and Reserves, $273 million for the Coast Guard, $165 million for the F.B.I., $25 million to equip military aircraft with radios to communicate with civilian jets and $50 million for equipment to ensure that emergency agencies can communicate, a problem on Sept. 11.
"Which of these priorities does the president think is wasteful spending?" asked Senator Robert C. Byrd, the West Virginia Democrat who is chairman of the Appropriations Committee. Mr. Byrd accused the White House of putting politics before the "safety of the American people."
The money included $400 million for election changes, $200 million to fight AIDS overseas, $200 million for Israel, $50 million for Palestinian relief and $275 million for veterans' medical care.
Mr. Bush acknowledged that he had backed some of the initiatives like the money to deal with AIDS, Israel and the Palestinians, but said that he would return to Congress and seek specific approval for those priorities, which total $1 billion.
Congress approved $28.9 billion in domestic security, recovery and military spending last month, including the final installment of $20 billion in aid to New York. Mr. Bush signed the legislation on Aug. 2. 
To resolve a conflict between the administration and Congress over spending levels, lawmakers made a list of $5.1 billion in projects contingent on Mr. Bush's declaring them emergency spending in 30 days.
To maintain pressure, Congress said that Mr. Bush would have to accept all or none of the projects, that he could not pick and choose among ones he supported and those he did not.
"Those are the rules they placed upon my administration," Mr. Bush said today. "I understand their position. And today, they're going to learn mine. We'll spend none of it."
An invited audience at the forum applauded.
Congressional aides said the fight represented an escalation in the tensions between the White House and Congress over control of spending.
"They think Congress should not have any input at all into the spending decisions," a Democratic staff member said.

HEADLINE: BUSH AND THE ECONOMY: THE ECONOMISTS; 
Far From Waco, Uninvited Scholars Ponder the Way to Recovery

BYLINE:  By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
The Bush administration invited only three economists to its seminar on economic recovery yesterday. If the room had been filled with economists instead of chief executives, the discussion would have been framed this way: Can consumers and business people generate enough demand to revive the sluggish economy? Or must government play a greater role to avoid another recession?
 Those are the questions a dozen economists who were not invited to Waco said they would have tried to answer had they been at the conference. While their responses in interviews differed, most shared the view that the private sector, for all its frailty, still had enough momentum to carry the economy to full recovery with modest additional help from government. 
 Even that could be delayed, said the Nobel laureate Robert M. Solow, who served in the Kennedy administration, in an era when stepped-up government spending to support a weak economy was standard practice.
"I would recommend waiting until fall to see what happens," Mr. Solow said. If the Federal Reserve's sharp reduction in interest rates turns out to be insufficient, then he would accelerate the spending of already appropriated money, but, to avoid running up a budget deficit larger than necessary, would not appropriate more.
"We might have to take projects planned for 2003 or 2004 and move them up to this year," he said, referring to road construction, airport expansion, education and other job-creating outlays earmarked for the future.
While there was much talk in Waco of a "fragile economy," President Bush nevertheless declared his confidence in the economy's "long-term health," suggesting in effect that a healthy recovery would materialize pretty much from the optimism and spending of consumers and companies.
"I think one of the things you'll hear," Mr. Bush said, "is that even though times are kind of tough right now, that we're America."
For William Niskanen, the libertarian chairman of the Cato Institute, that is too vague. "There was no focus in Waco," he said. "The administration did not present a coherent proposal for comment."
Nonetheless Mr. Niskanen said consumer spending and business investment were already getting a sufficient lift from the Fed's sharp cuts in interest rates and the stepped-up federal spending since Sept. 11.
Many Wall Street economists are similarly sanguine; certainly James Glassman, a senior economist at J. P. Morgan Chase, is. On the government-spending side, he said, there has been sufficient stimulus from tax cuts, military spending, emergency relief, extended unemployment benefits, farm subsidies and the like.
"Obviously the economy is floundering," Mr. Glassman acknowledged, "but we have not yet spent half the government money that has been appropriated."
Even that would not be enough for Robert J. Shiller of Yale, who in the late 1990's warned more than any other economist that a bubble had developed in stock prices and that when it burst, the damage would weaken the economy. 
"I would probably cut interest rates again now," Mr. Shiller said yesterday. "I am worried that the economy will dip back into recession from the unwinding of the bubble mentality still under way."
Mr. Shiller made that comment shortly before the Federal Reserve's policy makers decided yesterday against another cut in short-term rates. The key rate they control, the one that influences the others, now stands at only 1.75 percent, down from 6 percent 18 months ago. 
While the Fed acknowledged in a statement that demand had softened, it also said that the stimulus from the current low rate, coupled with an efficiently functioning economy, should be enough "to foster an improving business climate over time."
For James K. Galbraith, an economist at the University of Texas, that sort of talk from the policy makers and their chairman, Alan Greenspan, sounded almost as optimistic as Mr. Bush in Waco.
"Mr. Greenspan should have cut rates," Mr. Galbraith said, "and one reason he did not was that he did not want to undercut what they were saying in Waco." 
More than most economists, Mr. Galbraith believes that government must support the private sector, stepping up public spending when consumer demand flags and, with it, business investment. He doubts that the private sector on its own can save the country from another recession or prolonged stagnation.
At the very least, Mr. Galbraith would have the federal government subsidize state and local governments, even if that meant rising deficits. Cutbacks in spending at state and local levels are diluting the effect of government spending at the federal level.
Mr. Galbraith's pessimism that the economy can recover on its own is shared by John Makin, an economist at the conservative American Enterprise Institute. 
"Spend if you have to, but cutting taxes is better," Mr. Makin said. "Give everyone a tax cut, and let them spend it as they wish."

HEADLINE: Surfing The Economy 

BYLINE:  By MAUREEN DOWD; E-mail: liberties@nytimes.com

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
President Bush tried to fix the economy before lunch yesterday.
 He managed to last for 20 minutes each in four economic seminars at Baylor University. He dutifully scribbled some notes as participants talked, looking as happy as a high school kid in trig class, and bounded out of his chair when Treasury Secretary Paul O'Neill told him he could be excused. 
 "Yes, well," a visibly relieved Mr. Bush said, jumping up after an exhausting 18 minutes in "Economic Recovery and Job Creation," "that's the life of the president. Always has to go." 
Or as the radical economist Groucho Marx once observed: "Hello, I must be going."
The seminars lasted only an hour and a half. But Mr. Bush and Dick Cheney divided the eight so as not to overly tax themselves.
By the final session, Mr. Bush was staring into space, finding the talk of stimulus unstimulating. As the president told one group: "I can assure that even though I won't be sitting through every single moment of the seminars -- nor will the vice president -- we will look at the summaries." The CliffsNotes presidency. 
Before wrapping up with chicken salad, key lime pie and "Stars and Stripes Forever," the president did some cheerleading.
"Even though times are kind of tough right now," Mr. Bush drawled, "we're America." As usual when the president talks up the economy, the Dow dived under the bed, dropping 206 points.
He thanked all the "good folks" for "putting on a great show." Like his dad, W. reads his stage directions. It was a "Message, I care" P.R. pageant, so why not just say so?
His father, accused of being out of touch on the economy, got in trouble for checking his watch twice during a debate with Bill Clinton. That's why W. didn't even wear a watch while debating Al Gore. But, perhaps because of his short attention span, the younger Bush always gives the impression of checking his watch.
Although it seemed that Mr. Bush wanted to go deeper into his job after 9/11, he's still riding the surface, treating photo-ops like real events and passing off fortune-cookie comments as policy pronouncements.
This president's speed-dial economic summit was an interesting contrast with the last president's preening cult-of-personality economic summit a decade ago.
Mr. Bush, as always, seemed to be trying to get through the morning without saying anything that would expose him as empty-headed. He has a pathological fear of talking.
Bill Clinton has a pathological fear of not talking. He held a talkathon in Little Rock before he started his presidency -- also for self-serving P.R. reasons.
While Mr. Clinton wanted to convey concern about the economy he inherited from Bush pere, he mostly wanted to show off his wonkishness. Putting on the glasses he had rarely worn during the campaign, the smartest kid in the class dominated the room for two long days without yawning once. (The vice president, dragged back from fishing in Wyoming to scurry around the Waco sessions with Mr. Bush, was caught on camera stifling yawns twice.)
While Mr. Clinton designed his summit to show that Democrats could be cozy with Big Business, Mr. Bush designed his summit to show that he is not too cozy with Big Business.
At one of his drop-bys yesterday, Mr. Bush admitted to longing to see a few corporate malefactors in handcuffs. And White House planners were careful to scatter token blue-collar folks among the customary blue-chip folks.
The Bush family used to sit outside the Clinton White House, stewing that Bill had besmirched the honor of the Oval Office that they held dear. Now the Clinton family sits outside the Bush White House, stewing that W. has besmirched the spectacular (but somewhat artificial) boom they held dear.
The Clintons would love to see President Bush, lately of Harken Energy, endure his own equivalent of Kenneth Starr.
The scandalous condition of American capitalism has even provided Hillary Clinton with the political opening she needed. By insisting that the average American's financial well-being was better in Clinton times than Bush times, she is breaking ground for her presidential campaign in 2008. If she can wait that long.

HEADLINE: Mixed Economic Messages 

 BODY:
President Bush's stage-managed economic forum in Texas yesterday was billed as a chance for average Americans to express their views on the economy. Much was made of the wisdom of ordinary people, as opposed to Washington. It was thus striking that the Federal Reserve Board seemed to capture much better the American anxiety about the economy right now. The Fed did not lower interest rates, but it did suggest that the economy was not gathering strength -- a change from recent pronouncements. Understandably, the markets, which fell again, seemed to be paying more attention to the Fed than to Texas. 
 All economic projections are uncertain, but the present period seems more uncertain than any in recent memory. No one knows whether the nation is on the verge of recovery or another downturn. It used to be considered orthodoxy that economic fundamentals and the gyrations of the stock markets operated independently. The Fed's statements underscored how much its members had come around to the view that the unsettled markets had taken an economic toll and could do more damage in the future. It was almost as if the Fed was saying that it had done what it could by cutting rates but that other forces, not least the bad behavior of business, had upset everything. 
 The markets were also the major focus of attention at Mr. Bush's rushed half-day of economic discussions in Waco. The president again warned economic evildoers that "we will hunt you down" in tones reminiscent of his approach to terrorists. But there were no new ideas about the fundamental problem of restoring investor faith after a shattering series of scandals and business collapses. Mr. Bush once again called for passage of terrorism insurance to get construction started and pension reforms to protect employees whose savings are tied up in their bankrupt companies. These are worthy initiatives, but they will not galvanize the economy.
The forum drew more than 200 workers, business people and others to Baylor University, a short hop from the president's Texas ranch. He did well in conveying his faith that the economy would get back on track -- better than he does at news conferences, or even in his Wall Street speech earlier this summer. But it was dismaying that after promising a forum of diverse views, the White House ended up with something so transparently scripted that the words of many of the speakers echoed Mr. Bush's own speeches.

HEADLINE: BUSH AND THE ECONOMY: SYMBOLISM; 
The Options Limited, Bush Turns to Imagery

BYLINE:  By PATRICK E. TYLER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 

 BODY:
President Bush offered the country a carefully chosen set of symbols today to press a point that always seemed to elude his father: that he is quite committed to fixing the economy.
 By staging his economic forum in a populist environment where oil entrepreneurs have weathered booms and busts ever since the first gusher came in at Spindletop in 1901, Mr. Bush presented himself not as an intimate of corporate America but as someone who relates to everyday workers and small-business executives. As he aggressively defended his policies, Mr. Bush's word of the day was "optimism." He was bathed in placards with uplifting messages like "helping workers." 
 Some economists suggested that the focus on imagery was Mr. Bush's only real option, given that there is little official Washington can do -- or is willing to do -- that is likely to spur any short-term relief.
For all their nervousness that the economy could trump the war and emerge as the dominant issue in the midterm elections, Mr. Bush and his political advisers have ruled out any dramatic new steps to address a looming budget deficit that will appear in place of the surplus that had been expected to grow throughout the decade.
Already, the Federal Reserve has squeezed interest rates to very low levels. There is nothing the president can do with his newly acquired authority to negotiate trade deals that will deliver any short-term prosperity.
For his part, Mr. Bush has been adamant in not reconsidering last year's tax cut legislation -- and that leaves him little leeway to increase federal spending to prime the economic pump. The exception will be defense spending, which will expand rapidly with the expected testing and deployment of a ballistic missile defense system and a possible military campaign against Iraq.
"The real culprit in fiscal discipline is last year's tax cut, and you can safely assume they won't reconsider that," said William G. Gale, who as a staff economist in the first Bush administration witnessed the political debacle of the first President Bush's rollback on his no-new-taxes pledge.
Mr. Bush is clearly mindful that his father was sometimes attacked by his critics for caring more about his golf game than the worries of average Americans. Though the current President Bush is off again on a lengthy vacation, he seemed to be seeking to give the appearance that he is deeply engaged in economic policy.
The president stood at a podium flanked in the diversity of black and white faces, union and management representatives. The tableau was arrayed against the Christian conservative backdrop of the Baylor University campus. The symbols all were intended to underscore Mr. Bush's unifying leadership and strong moral compass. 
"People here are the people who really make America work: the entrepreneurs and the visionaries, the carpenters, the union heads, the educators, grandmothers," Mr. Bush said, adding that he wanted "a report from what I call the front lines of the American economy."
The report that Mr. Bush heard today from the carefully picked group, was respectful and seemed far removed from the hard edged reality of the unemployment line, the agony of bankruptcy and the grind of economic retrenchment that is roiling through the American economy.
When Delia Garcia, who heads the Arizona Hispanic Chamber of Commerce, spoke, her complaint was that "when there is turmoil" in the boardrooms of giant corporations "it trickles down." 
Though he was born to the Yankee traditions of the East, Mr. Bush often knows how to connect with the populist Southwest, where public testimony, prayer and a little swagger to show your confidence are as comfortable as a cardigan in Kennebunkport. 
Texas is a place where people instinctively understand a president, engaged in a war against terrorism, when he says, "Let's roll," because words are seldom as effective as a well-timed gesture or phrase, the same kind of phrase-making that sunk Mr. Bush's father with, "It's the economy, stupid."
Earlier this week, as preparations for the economic conference were underway, Mr. Bush told a reporter, "Most Americans don't sit in Martha's Vineyard, swilling white wine." The allusion was aimed at the elitism of his Democratic critics and the policy salons Bill Clinton organized at Martha's Vineyard.
"I am not one who joins the bandwagon of criticizing the president for having an event like this," said Gene Sperling, who was President Clinton's economic adviser. "But I think it seems hollow when this is a moment when the country could use as true economic summit with Democratic and Republican lawmakers on how to make tough choices."
"I think that the administration succeeded in getting a nice picture of the president focusing on the economy during his vacation, but if there is no followup, there are continuing spiraling deficits and conflicting economic messages, this type of thing won't matter in the long run," Mr. Sperling said.
Perhaps for this reason, Mr. Bush spent much of his time today in Waco, Tex., touching the chords of American concern with a sense of compassion and a resoluteness about taking action, even where he did not offer a prescription. Among those concerns is the frustration of investors and pensioners that many captains of industry, a number of them Bush friends and political patrons, have yet to be called to account for the collapse of ponzi schemes they erected inside major corporations.
The president spoke to the nation's chief executives in the same terms he has reserved for Osama bin Laden: "If you break the law, we will hunt you down, we will arrest you, and we will prosecute you." But Mr. Bush said that the good news for the economy is that the "vast majority of C.E.O.'s are good, honorable people" who "care deeply about their shareholders and their employees."
He promised that he would take the newly passed corporate responsibility law "and we will hold those to account who do not uphold the high standards Americans expect from those of us in positions of responsibility." Mr. Bush said "us," though the president is not covered by the law. But accountability is something that every president understands.

SECTION: Section A; Column 6; National Desk; Pg. 1

HEADLINE: BUSH AND THE ECONOMY: THE ECONOMIC FORUM; 
ECONOMIC OUTLOOK IS POSITIVE, BUSH TELLS TEXAS FORUM

BYLINE:  By ELISABETH BUMILLER with EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: WACO, Tex., Aug. 13 

 BODY:
President Bush said today that he was optimistic about the long-term health of the beleaguered American economy as he heard from a selection of 240 carefully chosen guests who praised his policies at an economic forum created to showcase his concerns.
 "I think one of the things you'll hear is that even though times are kind of tough right now, that we're America," Mr. Bush said at the three-hour forum at Baylor University, a short helicopter ride from his ranch, where the president is on what the White House calls a working vacation for most of the month. "We've got the hardest-working people in the world. We've got the best tax policy in the world. I mean, we got a lot going for us." 
 The president offered no new programs or ideas to repair the economy, although he did choose the literal center stage of the forum to announce that he would not release $5.1 billion in emergency spending requested by Congress to fight terrorism, saying he wanted to move toward a balanced budget as soon as possible. 
"We'll spend none of it," Mr. Bush said. 
The money represents a minuscule part of the government's $2.1 trillion annual budget, and administration officials said the action was a signal that the administration that has plunged back into deficits could crack down on spending.
Even as Mr. Bush expressed confidence in the economy and defended his policies, the Federal Reserve issued a more pessimistic assessment. It said the decline in the stock market's and disclosures of corporate wrongdoing had prolonged a sharp slowdown that might require it to cut interest rates further.
Stock prices fell after the announcement, with the Dow Jones industrial average dropping 206.43 to close at 8,482.46. Page C1. 
Mr. Bush heard no dissent and no debate at an event where the theme was that the economy was going through difficulty, but that things were headed in the right direction. The forum has been heavily criticized by the Democrats and a number of Republicans as a staged pep rally for the second Bush White House, which is ever mindful of the fate of Mr. Bush's father. Former President Bush was enormously popular after the Persian Gulf war but lost the 1992 election in large part because of voters' perceptions that he no longer had control of the economy.
Most of the eight participants who spoke at a closing session of the forum echoed support for the president's agenda, including tax cuts and the proposed energy bill and, in some cases, reflected his phrasing from recent speeches. Seven participants -- three blacks, two Hispanic speakers and two white women -- mirrored the political concerns of the White House in the presidential campaign of 2004, when Mr. Bush will reach out to minority groups and women in an effort to expand support.
"The thing we all agreed about was that those tax cuts should not be temporary," said Phyllis Hill Slater, owner of an engineering and architectural services company, Hill Slater Inc., in Floral Park, N.Y. "They should be permanent."
Ms. Slater, who is black, enthusiastically praised Mr. Bush, saying, "I'm so glad to see you're on track." 
Karl Rove, the president's chief political adviser, said after the forum that he was "not aware" that the White House had supplied the participants talking points, but "that's not to say there weren't any."
Other participants spoke up for favorite Republican concerns. One said the estate should be permanently repealed. Another who called for limits on medical malpractice suits, an issue that Mr. Bush campaigned for last week in Mississippi.
Some participants, coming from nearly 40 states and including executives, economists, students, union leaders, professors, owners of small businesses and a sprinkling of Democrats, did sound concerns to Mr. Bush.
"The bear market that we're suffering right now is probably one of the worst I have ever gone through, and that's not a comfortable place to be," Charles Schwab, chairman and co-chief executive of the Charles Schwab Corporation, said in a panel on small investors and retirement security. Mr. Schwab, whose company manages eight million individual accounts, totaling $800 billion in assets, also told the president that the confidence of American investors was "at a very fragile point."
While Mr. Schwab was at the forum, his company announced that it was eliminating nearly 400 jobs.
Simultaneously, American Airlines, the world's biggest airline, said it would lay off 7,000 workers.
Democrats immediately attacked the event as a public relations extravaganza put on by a White House seriously worried about how the economy will affect the president's political future. Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the Missouri Democrat who is the House minority leader, called it a "one-sided affirmation of a failed economic policy." 
Senator Tom Daschle, the South Dakota Democrat who is the Senate majority leader, said it was a "made for TV forum."
Some Republicans criticized it as well. William Beach, chief economist at the Heritage Foundation, a conservative research and advocacy group in Washington, said the main purpose of the gathering was to shore up shaky public confidence.
"These are frightened people," Mr. Beach said, "and I think that is the main reason for having this fairly meaningless conference." 
Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill, one of seven cabinet members on hand, said the participants had not been told what to say. 
"I didn't prompt anything -- nothing," Mr. O'Neill said.
When a reporter pointed out that the White House had invited the participants, Mr. O'Neill broke in and said: "You know, give me a break. Frank Raines was here." 
Mr. Raines, chief executive of Fannie Mae, was budget director under President Bill Clinton. 
Mr. O'Neill added that "as much as you want to say this was cooked up, this had high energy."
Mr. Bush, who opened his remarks by thanking Baylor University for "putting on a great show," spoke with more of a Texas drawl than usual. He delivered his nearly half-hour of remarks surrounded by large placards with slogans like "Helping Workers" and "Improving Education." 
He sat between Vice President Dick Cheney and the president of Baylor, Robert B. Sloan Jr., and pounded his hand on the table for emphasis at least once. Mr. Bush's manner was more casual and folksy than normal for such a high-profile speech, and he appeared to be consulting note cards, not a prepared text. 
Mr. Bush said rescinding the next phase of his tax cuts, as many Democrats have called for, would be an "unmitigated disaster." At another point, he used language that he normally reserves for terrorists -- that his administration will hunt them down -- in referring to corrupt corporate executives.
"I say as plainly as I can to c.e.o.'s," Mr. Bush said. "If you break the law, we will hunt you down. We will arrest you, and we'll prosecute you."
Mr. Cheney, who flew here on Monday night and left immediately after the forum for a fund-raiser in Montana, said very little publicly, leaving the president at center stage. 
"I find that these sessions are best if I don't make a long-winded set of comments when I come in," Mr. Cheney said at a panel on education and workers, one of eight simultaneous 90-minute sessions. 
He added, "I look forward to sitting quietly and listening." 
At the main session for all the participants, the vice president twice stifled yawns. Mr. Cheney and Mr. Bush spent 20 minutes each at four panels.
The gathering was markedly different from one staged by Mr. Clinton in Little Rock, Ark., in the transition after the 1992 elections. That forum lasted 20 hours and stretched over two days, a period when Mr. Clinton became immersed in arcane dialogues about taxes, education programs and subsidies for agricultural exports. Mr. Clinton made it clear that taxes had to be raised and spending reduced. But his forum ended with few clues about whose taxes should be raised and which programs should be cut.
Many participants today expressed wonder and gratitude that they had been invited at all. Van Eure, who owns the Angus Barn restaurant in Raleigh, N.C., said her family would have had to sell its restaurant if it had not been able to tap insurance policies to pay inheritance taxes. Ms. Eure was seated between Mr. O'Neill and Mr. Bush at the panel on corporate accountability.
"I'm just honored to be sitting beside one of my heroes," she said as Mr. Bush took his seat. 
The president responded, "Who, O'Neill?"

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Bush, at Economic Forum, Calls for a Balanced Budget
President Bush, speaking at a forum created to showcase his concerns for the economy, offered no new programs or ideas. But he did announce that he would not release $5 billion in emergency spending requested by Congress to fight terrorism, saying he wanted to move toward a balanced budget as soon as possible.
 The $5 billion is a small part of the government's $2.1 trillion annual budget. Administration officials described the action as a signal that it could cut spending. Page A1. 

The administration invited only three economists to its seminar. If more economists had attended, the discussion may have been framed this way: Can consumers and business people generate enough demand to revive the economy? Or must government play a greater role to avoid another recession? A18.

Interpublic to Restate Its Results
The Interpublic Group of Companies will restate its financial results back to 1997 because it improperly accounted for $68.5 million in expenses. Interpublic, which delayed its earnings report last week to give its audit committee time to review its accounting, attributed the restatement to intracompany transactions involving its European operations. C3.

Former Chief of AOL Unit Departs
David M. Colburn, the former chief of America Online's business affairs unit, has left the company, a company spokesman said. C3.

Industry Fought Quit-Smoking Drugs
A study in The Journal of the American Medical Association says tobacco companies put pressure on drug companies to limit the marketing of nicotine gum and skin patches that help people quit smoking. A17.

Markets Fall After Fed Decision
The main market gauges fell more than 2 percent after the Federal Reserve announced it was leaving its benchmark short-term interest rate unchanged. The Dow closed down 206.50, at 8,482.39, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 19.59 points, to 884.21. The Nasdaq was off 37.56 points, to 1,269.28. C11.

The downturn in equity markets is threatening to claim Nasdaq's trading venture in Japan. Nasdaq says it has made little headway against a number of regulatory hurdles, persistent economic weakness and an aversion to change. World Business, Section W.

A Loss of Confidence in Brazil
Less than a week after Brazil received a much-needed shot of confidence from a $30 billion bailout from the International Monetary Fund, fears over its economic prospects dragged down bond prices and its currency. World Business, Section W.

UBS's Drop Is Less Than Forecast
The Swiss bank, UBS, reported net profit of $876 million for the quarter, a smaller drop than had been expected. But the chief executive, Peter Wuffli, left, said that earnings for the year would decline because of sour stock markets and slipping profits from investment banking. World Business, Section W.

Biotech Companies Face Fines
The Environmental Protection Agency is threatening to fine two biotechnology companies for not complying with their permits for field trials of genetically modified crops. C5.

Retail Sales Increased in July
Retail sales rose for the second consecutive month in July, lifted by zero-interest financing for cars and an increase in gasoline prices. But the increase of 1.2 percent masked declines in the sale of appliances, building materials, clothing, electronic goods and furniture. C11.

Timing and Luck on Boston Project
A 36-story office tower, nearing completion in Boston, represents the culmination of 15 years of false starts. But for John B. Hynes III, who was able to make the deal happen, it represents a remarkable stroke of timing. Commercial Real Estate. C4.

HEADLINE: Playing Hooky? Can't Fool a Database 

BYLINE:  By JULIE FLAHERTY 

DATELINE: BOSTON 

 BODY:
FOR years, the daily grind of a Boston Public Schools truant officer has been pretty much the same. Hit the streets, seek out wayward youths and check for their names on your trusty list of students. Trouble is, that list is a computer printout (usually out of date) of about 63,000 student names, making it thicker than several phone books. It is, to say the least, awkward. 
 "You need a dolly to carry it around," said Elliot Feldman, who oversees Boston's attendance officers, as they are called. "You need a microscope to read it." 
 And on a gusty fall day in New England, forget about flipping through it. 
"A lot of people say Chicago is the Windy City," Mr. Feldman said. "They're wrong."
In September, Mr. Feldman plans to say goodbye to the printouts. With the help of the mobile telecommunications giant Nextel and a software and Web services company named AirClic, Boston's attendance officers are experimenting with souped-up cellphones that supply them with up-to-the-minute information on any student in the street. 
An officer types a student's name into the phone, and soon the display fills up with vital statistics, including age, address, attendance record and (gulp) parents' phone numbers. It even shows bus routes and allergies. The program also supplies the student's schedule, so the officer can quickly see whether the class skipped was Spanish or gym. 
"We grab the information from the Boston Public Schools system and get it back to the truancy officer in real time," said Phillip Riese, chief executive of AirClic. "We're talking seconds."
If an uncooperative student gives a friend's name instead of his own, the truant officer can quiz him to check his identity. As a next step, AirClic plans to outfit the phones with scanners that can read the bar code on a school ID card and find a student's file even more quickly. 
The Java-enabled Nextel phones work with the AirClic platform to cull information from the school system's servers. Soon, Mr. Feldman says, truant officers may be able to use the program to "bop a kid" as well, meaning check with the Bureau of Probation to see whether a truant has any outstanding warrants and may belong in jail instead of class. 
AirClic, which is based in Blue Bell, Pa., is adapting the system for other school districts. It has an application that can track students as they get on and off of school buses, another one that teachers can use to order classroom supplies and a third that tracks textbook inventory. The software does everything short of checking to see whether the dog really did eat the homework.
Because the system uses consumer-grade telephones and adaptable software, it may be economically feasible even for cash-strapped school systems. Boston is currently experimenting with the phones at no charge, but the actual cost would be about $20 a month for each of the 35 phones in use. 
The cellphone system was well received by veteran Boston attendance officers, some of whom have depended on their bulky lists for 30 or 40 years.
"They love their phones," Mr. Feldman said. "Hopefully, the big book will be put away in September." 

GRAPHIC: Photos: ROLL CALL -- Elliot Feldman, who oversees Boston's truant officers, with a single day's truancy list. The data will be available online by cellphone. (Rick Friedman for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A War Zone Downtown 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "Proposals Could Expand Memorial Site" (news article, Aug. 11): 
 I recently went to Wall Street on business and found that we do not need to build a memorial for Sept. 11, because Wall Street already looks like a cemetery under repair. 
The once-bustling district was devoid of people and cars, streets were closed and security made you feel as if you were in a war zone.
Wake up, Governor Pataki and Mayor Bloomberg! A year has passed, and the money is available to revive the city. What are you waiting for? Clean, beautify and repave the streets of Lower Manhattan and resuscitate the financial district.
Rebuild the World Trade Center into a symbol of 21st-century technology and innovation, as well as our strength in the face of terrorism.
We are seeing the demise of the financial district. We need leadership now. 

ANTON T. LOEW
New York, Aug. 12, 2002

HEADLINE: Iran Will Force Many Afghan Refugees to Leave by Month's End 

BYLINE:  By NAZILA FATHI 

DATELINE: TEHRAN, Aug. 14 

 BODY:
Iran has announced that it will require tens of thousands of refugees to return to Afghanistan as of Aug. 27, angering the United Nations refugee agency and human rights groups. 
 The government plans to expel those who have not taken part in a census of immigrants that began a year ago. 
 The government, faced with a huge influx of immigrants and finding them an economic burden, has already refused to register children of illegal immigrants at schools and has started fining employers who hire Afghans who do not have the proper documents. Those who have registered for the census are still expected to return home eventually. 
Close to 2.6 million Afghans took part in the immigrant census. But the Iranian government contends that there are at least another 250,000 who have refused to take part in the program and must leave the country at the end of the month. Most fled into Iran as a result of fighting and famine in Afghanistan, and the numbers increased during the American-led campaign to oust the Taliban last year. Last month, Iran set an Aug. 11 deadline for unregistered refugees to leave, and then extended it to Aug. 27. After that date, they are subject to arrest and deportation.
On Tuesday, Ahmad Hosseini, chief of the country's immigration agency, said that Iran considered the government in Afghanistan responsible for the immigrants. "The displaced Afghans are considered immigrants, not refugees, and so they should return to the home country," he said. 
Iran's decision has angered human rights groups as well as the United Nations high commissioner for refugees, whose office says it has a right to review the cases of those Iran wants to expel, based on an agreement it signed with Iran. The agreement was signed in Geneva in April by Iran and Afghanistan and by the refugee agency. It lays down the main legal and operational framework for the voluntary return of Afghan refugees in Iran. 
The refugee agency contends that there could be people entitled to remain as refugees among those forced to return and that Iran's plan violates its commitments as a member of the United Nations Refugee Convention. 
Physicians for Human Rights, based in Boston, also condemned Iran's move and said that not allowing Afghan children to go to school would be in violation of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child, which Iran has ratified. 
The refugee agency's spokesman in Kabul, Maki Shinohara, told The Associated Press that the pressures on the immigrants from Iran's government have already prompted a large influx of Afghans back into Afghanistan and that the agency had insufficient tents to shelter even those who have returned already.
Afghans have become a burden on Iran's stagnant economy, which has an official unemployment rate of 14 percent. Many of the construction and agricultural jobs are taken by Afghans, who work for lower wages and under hard conditions.
Interior Minister Abdolvahed Mousavi Lari said last week that the Afghan immigrants benefited from the huge subsidies the government provides to hold down the prices of basic goods, but without paying income tax as Iranian citizens do.
Officials have also complained that the United Nations refugee agency's existing repatriation program has failed in Iran because only 1,500 Afghans have been returning to Afghanistan each day as opposed to the 2,500 initially expected.

HEADLINE: Inter-Korea Talks Offer Signs Of Progress, and Frustration 

BYLINE:  By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 14 

 BODY:
In the highest-level meeting between North and South Korea in almost a year, the North agreed today to discuss economic cooperation with the South and to allow another round of reunions of families divided by the Korean War, but it balked at setting a date for key military talks that would allow construction of road and rail links across the highly militarized border.
 The talks, part of a round of diplomacy with the United States, Japan and South Korea, come after North Korea has faced pressure from all sides. Japan stopped its food aid this year. South Korea reduced its aid sharply. President Bush included North Korea in an "axis of evil." 
 With food shortages looming, today's steps seemed to show that other countries have new leverage over aid-dependent North Korea.
"North Korea seems to want to improve relations with South Korea, Japan and the United States to tide over economic difficulties," Deputy Foreign Minister Lee Tae Sik of South Korea told foreign reporters today. "It looks like they realized they can't get any financial aid from the international society as long as military tension persists on the Korean peninsula."
The reunions, to be held next month, would be the fifth meetings in two years. The economic talks are scheduled for later this month.
Agriculture Minister Kim Dong Tae of South Korea announced separately today that Seoul would increase the amount of rice it planned to provide the North on credit beyond the 300,000 tons it had already offered. South Korea increasingly ties its shipments of food aid to progress in the bilateral relationship. 
On the thorny issue of military approval for road and rail construction in the demilitarized zone between the two nations, differing versions of the final statements seemed to indicate that North Korean officials were not able to reach agreements before consulting with the country's powerful military. 
The version presented by South Korea said, "The two Koreas agreed to hold military talks as soon as possible and also agreed that each side needs to secure military steps shortly to help build railways and roads between the two Koreas." 
The North's simply said, "Both sides agreed to make a proposal to their military."
Reacting to the lack of a date for the military talks, Mr. Lee said, "We're not 100 percent satisfied with the outcome."
In the two years since the leaders of North and South Korea met in Pyongyang, North Korea's capital, and promised to open road and rail links, the South has completed its railway and road to within a few yards of the edge of the border. Satellite photographs indicate that there has been virtually no construction work on the northern side.
"Promises were made but haven't been realized," Unification Minister Jeong Se Hyun of South Korea told North Korea's chief delegate, Kim Ryong Song, on Monday.
Military cooperation is needed because thousands of land mines dot the abandoned demilitarized zone. 
South Koreans have been eagerly awaiting the renewal of reunions. In the South, about 10 million people, or one-fifth of the population, are estimated to have relatives in North. But the four rounds of reunions in the last two years have involved less than 2,000 South Koreans. The South Korean government recently calculated that of the 117,576 South Koreans, largely elderly people, who have signed up for reunions in recent years, 12.4 percent have died.
The economic talks, scheduled to take place at the end of this month in Seoul, will discuss the cross-border transportation links as well as a long-stalled industrial park in the North Korean city of Kaesong which would be open to South Korean factories.
The economic talks take on extra significance because the North Koreans have just taken a few cautious steps toward the kind of market economies embraced by China and Russia. According to diplomats in Pyongyang, North Korea this month devalued its currency, raised some prices toward market levels and granted large pay raises.
Trying to cultivate its richest neighbor, North Korea will hold talks with Japan on Aug. 25 and 26 on re-establishing diplomatic ties. An editorial Monday in the Rodong Shinmun, a North Korean state newspaper, advocated normalization of relations between the two countries.
The United States has yet to fix a date or an agenda for expected talks with North Korea.
"Movement in the North-South dialogue has always been a prerequisite for any progress in the North Korea-United States relationship," Victor D. Cha, a Korea expert at Georgetown University, said today in a telephone interview.

 Late Edition - Final 

SECTION: Section B; Column 3; Metropolitan Desk; Pg. 2

LENGTH: 911 words

PERSON: Herman Daniel Farrell III 

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES; 
From Political Theatrics to Theatrical Narratives

BYLINE:  By ROBIN FINN 

 BODY:
HIS summer sublet is steps away on West 44th Street. But as the playwright Herman Daniel Farrell III, namesake of the New York State Democratic chairman, Herman D. Farrell Jr., surges up the steps of the New Dramatists club, he's a little late and a lot out of breath. He wears his cherubic 6-month-old daughter like a shoulder accessory; his mother, on baby-sitter duty because his wife is busy directing a rehearsal of his new play, pushes the stroller. His excuse for being tardy is so corny it must be true: it wasn't the oven-intensity Midtown heat that slowed him, but a celebrity sighting. 
 They had passed Al Pacino on the sidewalk, hence Mr. Farrell's inadvertent hyperventilation. Al Pacino! Imagine the casting possibilities! Somehow he gets over it, hands the baby to his mother, and produces the keys to the club, locked and vacant on summer Fridays, a perfect place to talk shop, or rewrite dialogue. Sadly, no dialogue flowed between Mr. Pacino and the playwright. With Mr. Farrell smack dab in the middle of writing a cycle of presidential-theme plays -- his Clinton-centric "Portrait of a President" is onstage at the New York International Fringe Festival and his off-kilter takes on G. W. Bush and George Washington are incubating -- it was tempting to envision Mr. Pacino in that plum Father of Our Country role. But kismet did not strike. 
 So Mr. Farrell, 41, bull-necked and graying of goatee, switches gears and gives a tour of New Dramatists, the playwright's haven that took him in on the strength of "Bedfellows," his 1994 ode to dad and inner-city politics. The club is in a reconstituted church, where Mr. Farrell writes beneath a stained-glass window of Jesus, occasionally bunks in the unlovely William Inge Suite, and test-drives new plays in workshop productions three times a year. He met his wife, Nancy Jones, when she stage-managed a "Bedfellows" workshop here; the same stage was host to their wedding reception.
New Dramatists is a godsend, but he still decries the corporate structure of "the institutional American theater."
"It shouldn't be economic forces driving the art," he says. "It should be art driving the economic forces. Sorry, I'm on my soapbox."
For the last month he's been holed up here working on rewrites for "Portrait of a President," which concludes a five-performance run at the Theater for the New City on Aug. 25. Four weeks of rehearsals for five shows? "That's the Fringe," says Mr. Farrell, unperturbed. It's the exposure that counts. Plus it gets him a breather from Midway, Ky., where he lives with Ms. Jones, a theater professor.
His play, set at the White House in the waning days of the Clinton administration, explores the iconic role American presidents inhabit in the national psyche. Four artists are summoned to the White House, ostensibly in the running to paint Bill Clinton's official portrait. In the course of competing and commiserating, they not only dissect his flaws but reveal their own.
"Within the play there are multiple narratives and a multiplicity of truths," says Mr. Farrell, who realized at law school that he wanted to comment on politicians rather than be one. "This is the postmodernist thing I'm so jazzed about, that we've come to accept the complexities of the human soul; it's the idea of both/and rather than either/or."
Simply put, the idea for "Portrait of a President" came to Mr. Farrell, a liberal Democrat whose disappointment in Mr. Clinton gave him party loyalty nightmares, after he tagged along with his father to a White House dinner in 2000. He agonized over what to say to Mr. Clinton, and whether to shake his hand, on the reception line. The scene is replicated in the play, where Mr. Clinton's sorrow counteracts the censure the character means to convey.
Presidential handshakes are touchstones for Mr. Farrell: he was 15 when he shook Jimmy Carter's hand at Mama Leone's restaurant and promptly announced to his father, a Manhattan assemblyman, that he intended to become president. Inaugurations, even that of George W. Bush, move him to tears. "I'm really not pleased that Bush is president, but I buy into the pomp." Still, he gets back at Mr. Bush in his next play, "43rd." 
He grew up in Washington Heights in a mixed-race home (his father is African-American, his mother Irish) but moved to Riverdale with his mother after his parents split up when he was 5. Racism became an issue: Mr. Farrell is light-skinned and often presumed white. The day the leader of his Boy Scout troop made a welfare joke he decided to heed his father's advice: "It taught me the lesson that the right thing to do is to out myself, that silence is passing." He was one of the writers of "Boycott," an HBO movie based on the Montgomery, Ala., bus boycott, and racism is the focus of a coming cycle of plays.
Mr. Farrell attended Vassar, then dropped out of Fordham Law School after seven weeks, consumed by the need to write a play about Eugene O'Neill. In 1985, he was deputy campaign manager for his father's failed mayoral run, which provided fodder for "Bedfellows," the play that got him into Columbia University's M.F.A. program after he received a law degree from New York University in 1989. 
He was having coffee with a law school classmate, John F. Kennedy Jr., when talk of running for elected office came up: "He asked me if I thought of following in my father's footsteps, and I told him I thought I wanted to write plays. And he said, 'Well, we've got time.' "

HEADLINE: New Designs for a New Downtown 

 BODY:
The people in charge of rebuilding Lower Manhattan have decided, literally, to go back to the drawing board. One month after six preliminary plans for a new World Trade Center site were unveiled to almost universal scorn, the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation announced yesterday that it would extend the design competition three months and invite architects from around the world to submit plans. The corporation said it was seeking excitement, creativity and energy -- three qualities that were conspicuously missing from the original designs. 
 Those designs were heavily burdened by a requirement imposed by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which owns the site, that any plan must replace all the office, hotel and retail square footage lost in the Sept. 11 attack. The new design teams -- which will be asked to include some of the more popular features of the original plans -- are expected to be given greater flexibility, allowing them to accommodate not only a spectacular memorial and significant commercial space but also the residential and cultural components that everyone agrees are essential to a vibrant neighborhood. 
 It did not go unnoticed that the Port Authority, which was closely identified with the six original plans, played no role in yesterday's announcement. And while officials tried to play down any dissension, it seemed clear that the development corporation had taken the initiative in the design process and that this was not entirely welcomed by the Port Authority or by Beyer Blinder Belle, the firm that put together the initial plans.
There is no room here for institutional jealousies. Rebuilding downtown is a huge and noble project, with plenty of work -- and credit -- to go around. The Port Authority, for instance, is now searching for ways to rejigger its contractual obligation to the World Trade Center's primary leaseholder, Larry Silverstein, that allows him to replace the original square footage. One possibility is a swap that would allow Mr. Silverstein to rebuild elsewhere in the city, thus freeing space at the trade center site for other purposes. That by itself would be a major contribution, giving the designers the room to create the downtown New Yorkers deserve.
