HEADLINE: Hong Kong Journal; 
Love and Money Bring Woe to a Rising Politician

BYLINE:  By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, Aug. 9 

 BODY:
When Antony Leung became this Chinese territory's financial secretary and third-ranking official last year, many looked at his 28 years as a banker at Citicorp and Chase Manhattan and predicted that he would prove a bland technocrat, like nearly every other top Hong Kong official.
 They were wrong. 
 In the last few weeks his love life, economic views and financial management have left gossip columnists and conservative economists sputtering, civil servants demonstrating in the streets, investors calling for his resignation and many would-be brides disappointed.
Mr. Leung's charisma, connections and now a new celebrity wife may still make him a strong contender to become the territory's next chief executive in 2007 when the current leader, Tung Chee-hwa, must step down. 
But for now Mr. Leung, 50, is struggling for political survival.
He recently appointed a two-member panel of inquiry to investigate a collapse of penny stock prices here. The collapse, on July 26, occurred after the local stock exchange briefly circulated a proposal to stop trading in some of the cheapest stocks. Mr. Leung declared that if the panel found fault with anything he had done, he would resign.
Coming a day after he announced his marriage to China's most famous athlete, Fu Mingxia, a four-time Olympic gold medal winner less than half his age, Mr. Leung's decision to take a prominent role on the stock market issue has put him on the front pages of tabloids and financial newspapers alike.
The marriage and stock scandal have captivated local residents of all ages. They have also prompted some to question whether Mr. Leung should have been spending less time on romantic courting and more on Hong Kong's economic troubles, which include record unemployment of 5.8 percent.
"He's a charming guy, I must say, and I hope that this is not the result of being too concentrated on his relationship," said Chu Mei-fong, 28, a secretary.
Tall, lean, dapper and rich, Mr. Leung was declared one of Hong Kong's most eligible bachelors when gossip columnists noticed soon after he took office that his earlier marriage, which produced no children, had ended in divorce four years ago.
Mr. Leung began to be portrayed as one of this money-conscious territory's heartthrobs, despite being the territory's equivalent of an American treasury secretary. When rumors began circulating last December that he was secretly dating Ms. Fu, tabloids began hunting for photos of them together.
He and Ms. Fu have been remarkably successful so far in protecting their privacy -- the local paparazzi had no luck until a week ago. On Aug. 11, Mr. Leung, with Ms. Fu, accidentally drove his Porsche over the foot of a photographer. 
Nor has Ms. Fu granted any interviews, even though she is a household name here and in much of China, not just because of her sports stardom but because of her many celebrity endorsements of Sprite and other products.
When Mr. Leung announced on July 30 that the couple had been secretly married two weeks earlier in Honolulu, some local newspapers compensated for the lack of photographs by pasting Ms. Fu's face above a wedding dress for their front-page illustrations.
Since then, the local news outlets have been buzzing with questions over whether Ms. Fu will be moved to the top of the long list of mainland Chinese spouses waiting for visas to move to Hong Kong. Mr. Leung insists that she will not receive special treatment.
Born and raised in Hong Kong, Mr. Leung is the son of a cook in a barbecued pork shop. He attended a government-subsidized Anglican high school on a scholarship and spent the last two school years sleeping every night on a cot in the school cafeteria because there was scant space to sleep or study at home as the third of nine children.
Ms. Fu, who turns 24 this week, is the daughter of laborers in Wuhan, in central China. At the age of 10 she left home to live and train at a state-run diving school 600 miles away in Beijing, only seeing her parents twice a year. Her first gold medal came in platform diving at the Barcelona Olympics in 1992 at age 13.
Mr. Leung has won the ire of some local business executives and foreign economists by publicly abandoning Hong Kong's nearly laissez-faire economic policy, outlining a vision of the government as a "proactive market enabler."
He says the government should invest more in education and, in a few cases, "take appropriate measures to secure projects beneficial to our economy as a whole when the private sector is not ready to invest in them." 
Conservative American economists have been aghast at apostasy in one of their favorite cities. "I don't care how you rationalize it -- it's a different way to talk about markets," said Jerry O'Driscoll, the director of the Center for International Trade and Economics at the Heritage Foundation in Washington. "If you have the view that markets work, I don't know what the enabling is for."
He has also stirred controversy by trying to reduce the budget deficit through pay cuts of up to 4 percent for Hong Kong's civil servants.
His plan prompted a march last month by 30,000 demonstrators, the largest protest here since the killings of protesters near Tiananmen Square in Beijing in 1989.
While Mr. Leung's marriage may have provided a short public distraction from his political troubles, his new wife's status as a mainland Chinese citizen has also brought a new kind of scrutiny on Mr. Leung.
A political figure here who has discussed Mr. Leung's relationship with senior officials in Beijing, and who insisted on anonymity, said some of China's leaders were dismayed by Mr. Leung's romancing of a much younger woman who had spent nearly half of her life cloistered in a state-run athletic training school.
It may not have helped Mr. Leung that several Communist Party dignitaries are said to have unsuccessfully paid court to Ms. Fu in recent years.
In an interview in his office, Mr. Leung has said he received no advice or suggestions from Beijing regarding either his economic policies or his relationship with Ms. Fu.
"I think they do respect my private life," he said.

CORRECTION-DATE: August 21, 2002

 CORRECTION:
An article on Thursday tracing the political rise of Antony Leung, Hong Kong's financial secretary, misstated the territory's unemployment rate, cited by critics as a matter from which he has been distracted by his marriage to China's most famous athlete, a woman half his age. The rate is 7.8 percent, not 5.8.

HEADLINE: BLOCKS; 
Messages in Concrete: The Aesthetics of Safety

BYLINE:  By David W. Dunlap 

 BODY:
CENTRAL SYNAGOGUE did more than simply rebuild its fire-ravaged sanctuary last year. With meticulous care, the congregation reanimated the profuse Moorish Revival splendor of its landmark home in Midtown, conjuring once again the fearless pride expressed architecturally when the synagogue opened in 1872: this is a place of Jewish worship and we are part of the fabric of New York.
 Then, this summer, it wrapped its building in a belt of spalling, rust-stained concrete along the Lexington Avenue and 55th Street sidewalks; a barricade almost three feet high whose message is: this may be a target and we have to isolate ourselves. 
 "It's heartbreaking," said Peter J. Rubinstein, the senior rabbi. "We're living in a heartbreaking world." 
The installation followed a warning in June from the Federal Bureau of Investigation that terrorists could use fuel tanker trucks against synagogues or Jewish schools. Two months earlier, just such an attack on an ancient synagogue in Tunisia killed more than 20 people.
"I think I can say universally -- even among those who believe that such structural barriers are necessary -- that there's a discomfort with both the look and feel of their presence," Rabbi Rubinstein said. "We'll do what we need to make it more aesthetic, certainly for the High Holy Days. More than that, we're looking long term toward a brutally new world."
"On the one hand," he said, "you want to project the psychology of protection and safety, to transmit to those who would do you harm that we're on guard against you, at the same time as you project an aesthetic, pleasing sensibility to those who would not do you harm. That's the dilemma we're facing and that will be facing others."
Many others.
Since Sept. 11, bollards, planters, fences and Jersey barriers (as the slope-sided concrete barricades around the synagogue are called) have become almost as much a part of the streetscape as newsstands and hot-dog carts, with little debate about their role in diminishing the public sphere.
Jersey barriers, developed in the late 1940's by the New Jersey State Highway Department, may be effective deterrents. But they signal on another level that we are in a state of siege. This is deeply unsettling in a city where fluid movement is the cultural and economic lifeblood.
Clearly, street-level security will be an important concern of planners at the World Trade Center site. For instance, how would a memorial be set apart from the streets around it? Corralled behind barricades that implicitly acknowledge that a terrorist attack could happen again at this very spot?
Officials at Lincoln Center felt they had no choice after Sept. 11 but to stretch a line of Jersey barriers across the front of the main plaza, softened ever so slightly by seasonal plantings -- cabbages in autumn, evergreens and berries in winter, petunias now -- along the top of the concrete blocks.
"Openness is part of our history," said Vincent Talamo, director of security for Lincoln Center. "We're trying to provide a safe environment for our clientele while keeping as much as possible of the artistic openness that's a central component of what we do." As many as 20,000 people might gather at the center.
The planned reconstruction of Lincoln Center will allow security "that's not so aesthetically displeasing," Mr. Talamo said. But it also means the barriers will remain for at least a while, since there would be no point in installing a new system that would have to be ripped out.
AROUND existing landmarks, there is little opportunity to incorporate barriers unobtrusively and almost no incentive to remove them once installed. After all, what institution wants to be thought of as risking public safety? Or to pay a penalty if an insurer believes that security is inadequate?
"Understandably, the quickest and cheapest means of protection are likely to go up when heightened security first arises," wrote Nancy Somerville, executive vice president of the American Society of Landscape Architects. "But the propensity of many such measures to become permanent fixtures should concern all of us."
"Hastily erected security measures signal the nation and the international community that we are afraid and care little for our national symbols and traditional values of accessible government and freedom of movement," she wrote, explaining the impetus for the new Security Design Coalition with the American Planning Association, the American Institute of Architects and others.
Next month, the coalition will sponsor a three-day symposium in Manhattan, taking up such questions as whether the deterrent effect of overt security measures outweighs the fear they may instill in the public. (Information may be found online at www.designingforsecurity.org.)
"This is a learning curve for the whole United States," said William B. Kuhl, the trustee for the New York chapter of the landscape architects association.
There is little time for the lesson. The transformation is already well under way.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Shares Rally, But Wall St. Shows No Sign Of Direction

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
A day after registering their disappointment over the Federal Reserve's decision not to cut interest rates, investors sent stocks sharply higher late yesterday.
 In part, they were relieved that few big companies restated earnings as the deadline passed for executives of many big companies to certify their financial statements. Page C3. 
 Bargain hunters also stepped in to buy the shares beaten down a day before. 
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 4 percent, finishing at its highest level since the market sank to five-year lows in July. The Nasdaq composite index surged 5 percent, and the Dow Jones industrial average rose 3 percent.
On Tuesday, the Federal Reserve's decision not to reduce its short-term interest rate benchmark, now at 1.75 percent, led to a sharp sell-off at the end of the day.
As investors fled stocks, they turned to bonds. The bond market rally continued early yesterday, sending the yield on the Treasury's 10-year note briefly below 4 percent, the lowest yield since 1963 for a note with 10 years to maturity. 
But by the end of the day, the bond market gave up its gains. The yield on the 10-year note was at 4.12 percent, up from 4.09 percent, a record low, on Tuesday. Just two months ago, the yield was 4.80 percent.
Because the note is an important element in setting mortgage rates, home-loan rates appear headed to their lowest levels in decades and could unlock billions of dollars in additional consumer spending from homeowners who refinance.
"The upshot of the current situation is that mortgage rates are now more favorable to consumers than they have been since 1965," said Phil Colling, an economist at the Mortgage Bankers Association.
In the stock market, investors seemed to take comfort from the Fed's signal that it might cut rates further if conditions worsen. The decline on Tuesday was fueled not only by the lack of an immediate rate cut, but also by investors' taking profits from the previous week's rally, the strongest since September.
To a large degree, the ups and downs of the last two days show many investors are playing the daily swings, buying and selling quickly to take advantage of volatility. Their trading decisions are not really driven by a longer-term view about the economy and what the Fed might do.
"A long-term view in this market is what is going to happen tomorrow," said Bob Froehlich, chief investment strategist at Deutsche Asset Management. "There is no confidence in financial statements; there is no confidence in corporate governance. Right now, investors are afraid of the next crisis, so they cash out when they can."
Some of that uncertainty was assuaged yesterday as the deadline passed uneventfully for the senior management of hundreds of companies to certify the accuracy of their companies' financial reports to the Securities and Exchange Commission.
The stock of Aon, the big insurance broker, got a boost after its executives said they were certifying financial statements. Less than a week ago, it disclosed that there was a federal inquiry into its accounting, but it resolved the issue yesterday by agreeing to restate earnings for the final quarter of last year.
Aon stock jumped 22 percent.
At the close, the Dow was up 260.92, or 3.1 percent, at 8,743.31, just below its post-July high of 8,745.45. The S.& P. 500 climbed 35.41 points, or 4 percent, to 919.62, eclipsing the recent high of 911.62. The Nasdaq index surged 65.02, or 5.1 percent, to 1,334.30, just short of its recent high of 1,344.19.
Oracle and Intel were among the stocks that led the sell-off on Tuesday but rose sharply yesterday. Oracle surged 10.6 percent yesterday after a 6.6 percent decline the day before, and Intel rose 9.5 percent yesterday after a 4.7 percent stumble.
General Electric fell 4 percent on Tuesday as companies dependent on airline business dropped sharply, and rose 3.1 percent yesterday. But other airline-sensitive companies, including Boeing and United Technologies, fell again yesterday.
Merck rose 2.8 percent yesterday after falling 3 percent on Tuesday, and Walt Disney climbed 5.3 percent after declining 3.2 percent Tuesday.
The fast pace of mortgage refinancing is reflected in the Mortgage Bankers Association's index of mortgage applications. It hit a new high in the week ended Aug. 2, with almost 70 percent of the applications for refinancing. The average contract interest rate for a 30-year mortgage fell to 6.13 percent, a new low, in the week ended Aug. 9.
"We are in a pretty big refinancing wave," said Yubo Wang, senior mortgage strategist at Morgan Stanley.
If the yield on the 10-year note moves down to and stays about 4 percent or below, the interest rate on the average Freddie Mac 30-year mortgage should fall to 6 percent, said Robert Van Order, chief international economist at the mortgage agency. This would be the lowest since Freddie Mac began keeping data in 1970.
Rates this low would make about 80 percent of outstanding mortgages eligible for refinancing, Mr. Wang said.
That refinancing, he estimated, could pump as much as $69 billion by the end of this year into the hands of homeowners who borrow new money when they refinance. Refinancing to lower monthly payments could bring total savings of $2.5 billion to $5 billion over a year, he said.
The importance of this refinancing cannot be underestimated at a time when the economy appears weak enough for the Federal Reserve to indicate, as it did on Tuesday, that it is ready to cut its short-term interest rate benchmark below the current 40-year low of 1.75 percent.
Over the last year and a half, the refinancing wave has bolstered consumer spending and the economy. Last year was a record for refinancings, and this year could be another.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS; 
Paying the Price in Losses Overseas For Replicating U.S. Online Service

BYLINE:  By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
At the same time that America Online's domestic service is faltering, the strains in its nine overseas operations are becoming more apparent, too.
 As in the United States, AOL overseas is confronting a weak advertising market, slowing growth in subscribers and trouble competing with phone companies for high-speed service. In addition, it faces high telecommunication costs in some markets, economic turmoil in others and the disadvantage of being a late entrant in most. 
 AOL Time Warner has attracted 8.6 million subscribers outside of the United States by trying to replicate its cheerful formula for family-friendly Internet. But it has done so by incurring huge losses in largely trying to copy its blitzkrieg marketing style, with frequent television advertising, bountiful dissemination of software disks, and in some cases generous subsidies to make pricing plans attractive. 
This year, AOL expects the losses to come down sharply, as it scales back marketing costs. And it is close to turning a profit in Britain and maybe France. But Germany, its largest overseas market, with 2.6 million members, is still hobbled by high telecommunications costs.
And its Latin American unit, which is publicly traded, is in grave shape. Its shares now trade for 44 cents, giving it a market value of $30 million and prompting Nasdaq to start delisting proceedings.
Indeed, analysts wonder that as AOL's new management, Don Logan and Jonathan Miller, look to streamline operations, they may well focus on its international units, especially AOL Latin America.
"This is not a business," said Grant Smith, a Latin American analyst at the Yankee Group, a telecommunications research firm. "We don't think they will exist in 2004."
Indeed, AOL executives make no promises they will pony up more cash early next year, when AOL Latin America runs through the $160 million lifeline it extended in March.
"We are committed to the long-term success of AOL Latin America," said Michael Lynton, the president of AOL International. "As to funding, we will cross that bridge when we come to it."
Moreover, Mr. Lynton said that AOL had indefinitely shelved plans to enter other countries, like Italy and Spain. It is too late to enter some of the most technologically active markets in Asia like South Korea, he said. AOL's Japanese affiliate has fewer than 750,000 subscribers.
AOL had tried to minimize its risk by forming joint ventures with local partners, who would subsidize most of the start-up costs. AOL would provide technology, marketing support and content rather than cash.
This has created stable, self-sustaining operations in a few countries, like Canada and Australia. But in Latin America, AOL has had to finance much of its affiliates' losses. And after AOL agreed to buy Time Warner in 2000, it restructured its European operations, forcing it eventually to buy out its partners, paying $6.75 billion in cash to Bertelsmann and $750 million in preferred stock to Vivendi Universal. It is hardly clear that even if AOL Europe does become profitable it will produce a return to justify such a big cash outlay and the indignities of the debt AOL Time Warner incurred to pay it.
Last year, AOL Europe, which includes operations in Britain, Germany and France, lost $629 million (based on earnings before income taxes, depreciation and amortization) on $905 million in revenue. AOL Latin America, including Brazil, Argentina and Mexico, had a net loss of $307 million but had revenue of only $66 million. The company does not disclose results for its Canadian and Asian affiliates.
So much of the fate of AOL overseas stems from its decision to replicate its domestic offering around the world. It felt that its proprietary software and content created a product differentiation, although that required translating its service into seven languages.
More troublesome, the company strongly believed that the best offering was a flat monthly fee that included local telephone service. When AOL introduced its flat-rate plan in the United States, for instance, use shot up sharply, making customers more loyal and creating far more opportunities for online advertising. 
But at first, this was almost impossible overseas, because in most countries Internet users had to pay per-minute charges to their phone companies to dial in to the service, as they do for all local calls.
Indeed, these per-minute charges proved so lucrative to the phone companies that many started splitting them with Internet providers to encourage Internet use. This gave rise to the so-called free Internet services, which had no monthly fee though customers still paid the per-minute phone charges.
In Britain, some 500 free Internet service providers were started by newspapers, retailers and others. When the Dixon's electronics store introduced its Freeserve service in 1998, AOL's fledging British service stopped adding subscribers. 
AOL finally joined the party with a free Internet service using the Netscape brand. But it stuck to its guns on its main AOL brand, offering a variety of packages that bundled a set number of online hours for a fixed price. Eventually, many of the free providers simply closed and even Freeserve, which was bought by the Wanadoo Internet affiliate of France Telecom, began promoting subscription plans. AOL even closed the Netscape service this year.
More important, after a year of pleading by AOL, British regulators forced British Telecommunications at the end of 2000 to offer flat-rate connections on a wholesale basis to AOL, allowing it to offer an unlimited service of $:14.99 ($23) a month, since raised to $:15.99. Even though that rate is three times what the average Freeserve customer pays in a month, AOL has been growing since it introduced the plan, attracting nearly two million members.
"Flat rate is what customers are looking for," Mr. Lynton said. "When you offer it, you get a big surge in subscriber growth."
Indeed, the fruits of a similar lobbying effort in France will emerge on Monday when AOL introduces an unlimited-service plan that costs 24.99 euros ($24.49) a month to its 1.2 million members. In Germany, however, Deutche Telecom is appealing a government ruling that would force it to sell unlimited service to AOL.
Even as AOL moves to profitability in a few countries in Europe with its traditional dial-up service, it may face similar challenges all over again offering high-speed service, mostly using a phone technology known as digital subscriber line, or D.S.L.
European phone companies are setting the wholesale price of their high-speed service so high, said Michael Steib, an analyst at Morgan Stanley, that AOL and other Internet companies can barely make a profit.
In Latin America, things have gone badly for AOL from the start. AOL Latin America was formed in 1998 as a joint venture with the well-connected Cisneros Group of Venezuela. Banco Itau of Brazil joined the venture in 2000.
An effort to raise money through an initial public offering in 2000 was troubled as the stock price was cut from $15 to $8, and AOL and Cisneros were forced to buy a third of the shares of the offering.
The service has run phenomenal losses, as its marketing expenses were three times its revenue. What's more, AOL has found it difficult to be paid, especially in Brazil, because people generally prefer paying bills by cash rather than by credit card, as AOL prefers. 
Indeed, Mr. Smith of the Yankee Group estimates that more than 60 percent of AOL's 1.3 million Latin American subscribers are on free trials or otherwise not paying their bills. (AOL says Yankee overestimates the number of free subscriptions, but it will not give numbers of its own.) 
"AOL is a new entrant and very late to the game," Mr. Smith said. "They haven't been getting the right sort of customer, and they have a higher cost structure than their competitors."
The Latin American local phone companies have an even greater advantage than those in Europe in offering their own Internet service. Not only do they control the networks, but they also have existing billing relationships with customers, who typically pay cash in bank branches and storefront locations. 
Making things worse, of course, has been the economic turmoil in Argentina and Brazil, which led to sharp currency devaluations. AOL raised its prices faster than its local competitors. In 2001, AOL and its partners invested another $150 million. But when that money ran out, Cisneros and Itau decided not to invest again. Last month Itau wrote off $82 million, its entire 12 percent stake. 
So in March, AOL Time Warner advanced a $160 million credit line to the Latin unit. But that money will run out next year.
Charles Herington, chief executive of AOL Latin America, says AOL Latin America's losses have been heading down each quarter. It is concentrating its marketing on attracting better customers. And it is developing new payment methods.
Mr. Lynton said that while AOL's service in Brazil and Argentina faced significant challenges, its offering in Mexico appeared on track to be a strong No. 2 to the Prodigy service of Telefonos de Mexico, or Telmex.
Competitors say that AOL is facing a quandary. It is retreating to the market segments, and perhaps countries, in which it has the greatest advantages. But in many ways the Internet business is most profitable, as AOL has found in the United States, for those with the broadest reach.
"They have cherry-picked the most attractive markets," said Renato Soru, the chief executive of Tiscali, the Italian Internet service provider. "To make money you need a very large scale, and there is no one country that will give the large number of customers that you need."

HEADLINE: The Rising Cost of Health Care 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Your Aug. 11 front-page article about the factors that have contributed to the explosion of spending for health care didn't mention the impact of end-of-life medical care. Too often, extremely ill and dying patients are subjected to multiple interventions and prolonged stays in the intensive-care unit without a realistic chance of long-term survival. 
More than one-quarter of Medicare dollars are spent in the last year of life. 
 Until we are better able to confront end-of-life issues as a society and shed our belief that life must be prolonged at all cost, we will continue to have difficulty controlling health care inflation. With more technology, procedures and medications, and with an aging and more ill population, the problem will only be compounded.

TODD A. BORUS, M.D.
Ann Arbor, Mich., Aug. 13, 2002

HEADLINE: The Economy, Rah, Rah! (Right?) 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "No Cut in Rates as Fed Lowers Its Assessment of the Economy" (Business Day, Aug. 14): 
 If lower interest rates aren't passed on to consumers, nothing the Federal Reserve does will affect the economy. 
Lower interest rates have increased the profits of the credit card companies but have done nothing to help consumers, the engine of economic growth. Credit card debt approaches $500 billion. 
Instead of passing on lower interest rates, the banks have raised credit card interest rates (now 15 to 28 percent) and raised fees for late payment and overlimit balances. 
Unless the windfall is shared, consumers will slow their credit card spending, the recovery will falter, and the Federal Reserve will be helpless to prevent the decline of consumer spending. 

JASON REYNOLDS
Exec. Dir., Oregon Consumer League
Portland, Ore., Aug. 14, 2002

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
United Warns of Bankruptcy Without Union Concessions
United Airlines, burdened by debt and by tense relationships with its employees, who own more than half the company, said it might file for bankruptcy this fall if it did not get concessions from its labor groups within a month. The unions said they would oppose any filing.
 The announcement from United was the latest in a series of upheavals that have racked the industry during its most torturous week since the Sept. 11 attacks. Page A1. 

Ozires Silva has offered to resign as chief executive of Varig, the debt-laden Brazilian airline, as it negotiated to secure $300 million. World Business, Section W.

Conseco's Accounting Investigated
Conseco, the financial services company that is teetering on the brink of bankruptcy, said its accounting was under investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission. C9.

Plans for Gene Research Center
J. Craig Venter, left, who raced government-financed researchers to decode the human genome before he was ousted from Celera Genomics, the company he made famous, is expected to announce plans for a huge laboratory that would rival efforts by his former company and his public competitors. A18.

F.D.A. Closes Human Tissue Lab
Federal regulators have closed a part of CryoLife, the nation's largest processor of donated human tissue, saying the company could not adequately assure patients that its products were free of deadly bacteria and fungi. A1.

Executives File Certifications
Executives from at least 440 companies have filed certificates with the Securities and Exchange Commission attesting to the accuracy of the financial reports with their quarterly earnings reports with the government. C3.

U.S. Asked to Activate Power Line
Long Island power officials have asked federal regulators, over the objections of Connecticut lawmakers and environmental groups, to order the activation of a transmission line that runs across Long Island Sound. B5.

ImClone Sues to Recover Severance
ImClone Systems filed suit against its indicted former chief executive, Samuel D. Waksal, seeking to recover more than $7 million in severance and other compensation. C3.

Board Offers Rule on Options
The Financial Accounting Standards Board plans to offer a proposal that would require companies to disclose the values of stock options in the footnotes of every quarterly statement. Floyd Norris: Market Place. C5.

Aon Settles Auditing Dispute
Aon, the insurance broker, said it had resolved an agency's questions about its accounting practices by agreeing to restate its earnings for the final quarter of last year and the first quarter of this year. The restatement involved a write-off of $56 million after taxes for a disputed insurance claim. C5.

S.E.C. Reviews Tyco's Accounting
The Securities and Exchange Commission is reviewing Tyco's latest financial statements, and Tyco has expanded the inquiry of its accounting practices to as far back as 1999. C3.

Data on Income Called Misleading
To critics of economic liberalization and trade, it is an article of faith that the gaps in income between the poorest and richest countries have continued to widen. But the statistics used to support this portrait can be misleading. Virginia Postrel: Economic Scene. C2.

HEADLINE: Putting Garbage To Good Use 

BYLINE:  By Steven Cohen; Steven Cohen directs the graduate program in earth systems, science policy and management at the School of International and Public Affairs and the Earth Institute, both at Columbia University.

 BODY:
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's recent proposal to develop garbage-transfer stations to compact refuse and send it away by barge is a step in the right direction. The stations, to be placed in waterfront locations throughout the city, would replace a system that uses thousands of polluting, diesel-fueled trucks daily to haul garbage through the city's streets to landfill sites in other states.
 Now the city should find, indeed create, better destinations for the 11,000 tons of household refuse that New Yorkers produce every day. In doing so, New York could help itself and several cities and towns along the Hudson River that need to revive their economies. 
 Currently, the city contracts with private vendors to ship its waste and dispose of it in out-of-state landfills. But the private waste-management business is composed of a small number of large companies and is thus not very competitive. This has contributed to astronomical garbage disposal costs. The Sanitation Department's operating costs reached $1 billion last year.
A better approach would be for the city to build its own sites in some of the depressed localities that dot the Hudson's shores. Under such a plan, sponsored together with the state, New York City could build high-temperature incinerators that generate electricity, known as waste-to-energy plants, in industrial sections of these towns. In exchange, the city could offer free or reduced-cost garbage disposal for participating towns and perhaps low-priced electricity (generated by the incinerators) to businesses that put offices or factories in these localities.
If needed, additional incentives, like help with building new public schools or recreational areas, could be offered under such a state-sponsored program.
This approach has already been used for a clean-water project within New York City. About 15 years ago, the city and state worked with the West Harlem community to build a sewage treatment plant in that neighborhood. As an incentive, the state (with city and federal help) built the 28-acre Riverbank State Park on top of the plant, complete with a soccer field, indoor and outdoor swimming pools and an ice skating rink.
Indeed, when it comes to garbage, neighborhoods in New York City might also want the kind of economic or social benefits the Bloomberg administration and the state could offer to upstate localities participating in a waste-to-energy program.
All methods of garbage disposal produce some environmental pollution. But waste-to-energy incinerators, especially when they are built to be as environmentally protective as possible, produce less pollution than diesel-fueled trucks and landfills do.
Waste-to-energy plants also reduce by 90 percent the volume of refuse that must be placed in landfills, all of which eventually release pollution into the surrounding environment.
New York City needs to own its entire garbage disposal system to ensure that costs are predictable and as low as possible. Parts of the operation could still be contracted out to private firms via competitive bidding. But the city must be in charge from the beginning of the process to the end. Otherwise costs will continue to grow.
To be sure, upstate incineration plants are not the whole solution to New York City's garbage crisis. The city must also reduce waste and do a better job of recycling. It can start by raising the deposit on bottles from a nickel to 50 cents or a dollar so that fewer bottles are simply discarded for convenience. And deposits should be required on all bottles and containers, not just those holding carbonated beverages.
The city should also reinstate its recently halted recycling of glass and plastic. It took many years to get New York City households into the recycling habit. We have tossed out years of effort for short-run budget savings, when in the long run waste reduction through recycling can save dollars. If there is no market for recycled glass and plastic, why not build our own recycling plants and create our own market?
The Bloomberg administration's waste-transfer proposal is a creative step toward solving New York City's garbage crisis. Now let's finish the job just as creatively.

GRAPHIC: Drawing (Peter Kuper)

HEADLINE: The Democrats and the War 

BYLINE:  By Ted Widmer; Ted Widmer, director of the C.V. Starr Center for the Study of the American Experience at Washington College, was director of speechwriting at the National Security Council from 1997 to 2000.

DATELINE: CHESTERTOWN, Md. 

 BODY:
The subtext to the current debate over America's foreign policy is history -- in particular, the Democratic Party's history of international engagement. Republicans are dismissive of it; Democrats have forgotten it. Neither approach serves the country.
 The most recent example was the reaction to Senator John Kerry's speech last month about United States foreign policy, in which he criticized the Bush administration's conduct of the war in Afghanistan and its looming but still sketchy plans for an invasion of Iraq. Reaction from the White House was unsurprisingly partisan: "The closer it gets to the election," said Ari Fleischer, the White House spokesman, "the more the Democrats will be tugged to the left and the more divisive they'll become." Many Democrats, meanwhile, were unenthusiastic. One strategist said Democrats should focus on national issues and not talk about foreign policy at all. 
 These responses suggest that Mr. Kerry is on to something. First there is the curious Republican notion that it is somehow "divisive" to seek a better-defined foreign policy. Then there is the strange Democratic reluctance to engage in a serious discussion about one of the most important issues now facing the country.
Thus both parties are ignoring the constitutional responsibility of the Senate and the long history of Democratic internationalism. A genuine bipartisan debate, reviving this history, will go a long way toward sharpening our policy and enlisting the support of all Americans.
Fifty years ago, the Republican Party was unambiguously the party of isolation. In 1952, Americans elected a Republican president, Dwight D. Eisenhower, and a Republican majority in the Senate. After decades of Roosevelt and Truman, America-firsters were ecstatic -- and soon after the inaugural, the Republicans nearly succeeded in crippling the president's ability to conduct foreign policy.
The Bricker amendment, introduced by Senator John Bricker, Republican of Ohio, would have severely curtailed the executive's ability to negotiate treaties and engage American troops, making him accountable not only to Congress, but also to 48 state governments. It was Senate Democrats, as Robert Caro shows in his latest book, who blocked this amendment.
Throughout the 20th century, Democrats led America's great international efforts -- including both World Wars, the thwarted attempt to join the League of Nations and the more successful struggles in the late 1940's to create the United Nations and NATO. Those policies were improved when great Republican voices, like Arthur Vandenberg's, helped to shape them. And those policies were threatened when knee-jerk resistance came from the isolationists, usually in Republican precincts in the upper West and Midwest. Some honestly believed that any attempt to send American boys overseas was immoral. Others, like Joe McCarthy, criticized what they saw as "Democratic" foreign policy -- the Marshall Plan, containment, anything said by Dean Acheson -- to advance their own darker designs.
McCarthy's accusations were ludicrous. But there may be some truth to the idea that Democrats are generally more eager to join American interests to the rest of the world. Democrats are not always right, to put it mildly. But they generally get the idea that America is stronger leading others than standing alone.
This activist legacy should be a source of pride for Democrats in Congress. Yet surprisingly few include foreign policy in their portfolio. Senate Majority Leader Tom Daschle has been notably reticent about foreign policy since his patriotism was questioned in February after he criticized the Bush administration's war on terrorism. Leading Democratic senators, for their part, have not offered him much support.
Part of the problem is the subtle perception, fed by Republican strategists, that Democrats lack the credentials to conduct foreign policy and oversee defense matters. It is difficult to know when Republicans began to make this argument -- or when Democrats began to believe it.
Certainly there was no trace of the idea a generation ago; from 1960 to 1984, every Democratic presidential candidate except Jimmy Carter was a current or former senator with strong foreign-policy credentials. Perhaps the travails of our hostages in Iran had something to do with it, and the fact that their release coincided so neatly with President Ronald Reagan's inauguration. Some damage was surely self-inflicted; Michael Dukakis's ill-advised ride in a tank did little to reassure voters of his defense expertise.
Another part of the explanation is demographic, not political. Ten years ago, Democrats sensed a growing ennui with foreign policy -- an accurate perception that helped win Bill Clinton the White House. The 2000 campaign focused less on foreign policy than any campaign in memory.
Now foreign policy is a growth area again. Democrats -- particularly presidential contenders -- have much to gain by shaping their posture to a set of issues around the world that demand real leadership. Not just because these issues are vitally important, but because many of our most enlightened policies are traceable to the Clinton administration. Clearly, the Republicans are quick learners. More than a few of the policies denounced by the Bush campaign have been quietly embraced by the Bush administration, to its credit: economic bailouts, so-called nation-building and strategic cooperation with Russia and China.
But more needs to be done. Any attempt to build peace in the Middle East will have as its starting point the Clinton proposals. In North Korea, the Balkans and Northern Ireland, we need to avoid the tragedy of backsliding after years of hard work. An urgent case like Iraq warrants a full and open conversation between political leaders of all persuasions.
Partisanship may explain the nervous response to Mr. Kerry's critique. But it is wrong to stigmatize a senator -- especially one from the party of Fulbright, Mansfield and Muskie -- as "divisive" merely because he demonstrates a healthy curiosity about the future of our foreign policy. Not only is this accusation historically inaccurate but, to use one of McCarthy's favorite words, it is also un-American.

HEADLINE: The Anger of Arab Youth 

 BODY:
Throughout the Arab world, millions of young people resent America and the West. They cite specific grievances, including American support for Israel, the Bush administration's threats to attack Iraq and Washington's support for repressive Arab dictatorships. But their rage has much deeper roots. To a large degree it is the result of the sharply felt contrast between the past glories of Arab civilization and its current dismal prospects. 
 These young people are painfully aware that their societies are falling behind the rest of the world economically and technologically, limiting their own future prospects. The America young Arabs protest against is often an image built on caricature and contradiction. Some see the United States as thoroughly corrupted by materialism and immorality. Others blame Washington for not doing more to bring prosperity and democracy to the Arab world. 
 Yet these are perceptions America cannot afford to ignore. The Arab League's 22 countries are home to some 280 million people, more than one-third of them under 15. Beneath their soil lies well over half the world's known oil. Political stability in most Arab countries rests on hereditary ruling families or repressive one-man dictatorships. If Washington fails to develop effective new initiatives aimed at Arab society at large, America will face threats from this region for years to come. 
As a first step, Washington needs to become a more convincing and consistent advocate of democracy in the Arab world. It also has to do a better job explaining its policies on Iraq and Israel, a point the Bush administration has become more attentive to since Sept. 11. 
Earlier this year President Bush asked the State Department to look for ways to expand economic and educational opportunity and political rights in the Arab Middle East. Education is highly valued in the Arab world, but budgets are starved and teaching is heavily weighted toward traditional subjects that poorly prepare graduates for today's jobs or for the kind of critical thinking that would lead to internal reform. At the primary level, Washington should support efforts to expand access to educational opportunities to girls as well as boys, and to modernize curriculums. At the high school and college level, a publicly funded American foundation could help with everything from construction and teacher training to expanded American studies programs. 
Washington needs to offer stronger financial and diplomatic support to independent organizations working to promote electoral democracy. America should take up the cause of these groups when governments try to shut them down. 
The Bush administration must commit substantial resources to these long-term efforts to promote education, democracy and a more informed understanding of America. Without a sustained campaign to reach the next Arab generation, Washington is likely to face hostility and distrust in the Mideast for many years to come. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Washington Talk; 
Looking at the Books, The Government Way

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 

 BODY:
Today was the deadline for hundreds of corporate chief executives to certify that they have not cooked their books, so Senator Ernest F. Hollings, the South Carolina Democrat who styles himself a crusader for fiscal responsibility in government, challenged the Bush administration to do what it is demanding of the private sector: sign an oath that its numbers are for real.
 Mr. Hollings, who contends that the government hides its debt no less egregiously than Enron did, asked Mitchell E. Daniels Jr., the White House budget director, to swear personally to the accuracy of the government's financial reports. 
 Of course, the government is not a corporation, and Mr. Hollings's request, which the White House largely ignored, was a classic political stunt. 
But it got at a real issue that has transcended administrations and parties and grown in complexity with the government. By any standard, Washington does not do a good job of keeping its own books. Mr. Daniels issued a report card this year on government performance that gave poor grades for financial management to every major cabinet department, and his own agency to boot.
"This is a serious subject," Mr. Daniels said. "No one could attest to the accuracy of the government's books."
It is also clear that hardly anyone, from President Bush on down, has a firm grasp of the government's finances -- and that taxpayers, perhaps now more than ever, find this failing to be somewhere between annoying and infuriating. 
Consider this exchange on Tuesday at the president's economic summit in Texas between June Lennon, an accountant from Greenville, S.C., and Mr. Bush.
Government, Ms. Lennon told Mr. Bush at a session on corporate responsibility, should lead by example.
"Some of these reports we hear of agencies who lose track of equipment and agencies who can't balance their books are not much better than the corporations who do the same or balance them wrongly," she said. It would be wonderful, she added, if the government could show that it "wants to be responsible and accountable, too."
Mr. Bush replied that the government's accounting system was pretty hard to explain. "I've been there for nearly 18 months trying to figure it out," he said to laughter.
The government does present a detailed accounting of its financial condition. For the last five years, the Treasury Department has prepared what amounts to an annual report, complete with a statement from "management" -- the executive branch -- and an auditor's opinion prepared by the General Accounting Office, an arm of Congress.
The most recent report, covering 2001, was signed by Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill. It concluded that the government ran a deficit of $515 billion, using the accounting rules that are supposed to govern corporations. 
By the accounting techniques normally used by Washington, the government posted a surplus last year of $127 billion. The difference stemmed largely from competing methods of accounting for health and pension costs.
Administration officials said the report showed progress in putting the government on a businesslike footing. But the General Accounting Office said there were still so many weaknesses in the government's financial systems that it could not certify the report -- the equivalent of a company's accounting firm declining to sign off on its client's books.
The government's finances continue to be opaque, complex and driven by politics in a way that private-sector bookkeeping generally is not. 
Congress, by all accounts, does not help matters. 
Just in the last few years, it has proposed or passed all kinds of gimmicks. Among them were shifting tax payments from one fiscal year to another to make the nation's fiscal condition look better and declaring one of the government's most predictable functions, the once-every-10-year census, to be an emergency that needed to be paid for out of a special pot of money.
Mr. Hollings and Mr. Daniels agreed that one of the biggest problems was the way the government failed to account for its promises to pay future Social Security and Medicare benefits, payments for which it has not set any cash aside.
But as companies scrambled today to reassure investors that their numbers could be trusted, the differences between corporate and government standards were a tempting political target.
"Corporate C.E.O.'s were willing to face the truth and tell the public if their books were honest or cooked," Mr. Hollings said. "Just one day after the administration's much-hyped 'Economic Forum,' Mr. Daniels failed to provide the honest economic leadership that this country obviously needs right now."
Mr. Daniels said he would have a reply to Mr. Hollings ready in a day or two.

HEADLINE: Bush Takes His Optimism on Economy to Iowa State Fair 

BYLINE:  By ELISABETH BUMILLER 

DATELINE: DES MOINES, Aug. 14 

 BODY:
President Bush today took his message of cheer about the gloomy American economy to the fertile political grounds of the Iowa State Fair, where he spoke between appearances by two of his potential 2004 Democratic competitors, Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri and Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut.
 The sprawling Iowa fair, a must stop for politicians, was still too small for all three men at once, and their arrivals were timed so that they could avoid one another. Mr. Gephardt left shortly before the president's entourage pulled onto the grounds this afternoon, while Mr. Lieberman came in the evening, when the crowded walkways were clear of Mr. Bush. 
 "We get a lot of that here," said Scott Hunter, 36, a Des Moines immigration lawyer who watched Mr. Bush speak against a backdrop created by the White House that showed gleaming red and green tractors and bales of hay.
The president used his time in a crucial electoral state, where the fields are bursting with corn and soybeans, to promote a bill he signed last week, called trade promotion authority, which he said would improve the lives of Iowa farmers. "What we're good at is growing food and hogs and cattle," Mr. Bush said to a crowd that included flush-faced children, a Miss Iowa State Fair in a tiara and the farmers the White House needs to win in the 2004 election. "And it's my job and the job of this administration, now that I've got trade promotion authority, to do everything we can to knock down the barriers so you can be selling your products all over the world."
The bill allows the president to negotiate trade agreements with foreign countries without intervention by Congress, and Mr. Bush said today that the nation's trade representative, Robert B. Zoellick, and Agriculture Secretary Ann M. Veneman would make trade deals a top priority. "My man, Zoellick, who is a trade guy, and Ann Veneman, are going to work hand in hand to make sure agriculture is the cornerstone of good international trade policy, and it needs to be," Mr. Bush said.
The president also told the crowd that he had held an "economic summit" on Tuesday at Baylor University in Waco, Tex., but he spent little time talking about an event that was derided by Democrats, some Republicans and much of the news media as a stage-managed public relations stunt to showcase the president's concerns about the economy.
"We may have hit a bump in the road," Mr. Bush said. "That road is going to smooth out, and people are going to find the economic security they want here in America."
Mr. Lieberman said that Mr. Bush and Vice President Dick Cheney, because of their own business dealings, should not be "lecturing" Americans about the responsibilities of corporate executives to keep their books clean. Mr. Lieberman was referring to questions about Mr. Bush's stock dealings at Harken Energy, an oil company on whose board the president once served, as well as the Securities and Exchange Commission investigation into accounting practices at the Halliburton Company, the oil services giant where Mr. Cheney was chief executive.
"They are kind of lecturing the rest of America on the ethics of corporate America," Mr. Lieberman said, adding that "they ought to be lecturing each other."
Showing that the Democrats will continue to use the nation's corporate scandals as a weapon against the White House, Mr. Lieberman said that "the president and vice president themselves have been involved in stories about Halliburton and Harken Energy that still have not been adequately explained to the American people."
Mr. Gephardt spoke at a news conference and criticized the Bush administration for its efforts to shift part of Social Security into private investment accounts. "We all know there are risks in the stock market," Mr. Gephardt said. "We don't want risks in Social Security because we want it to be there."
Mr. Bush began his day at his 1,600-acre ranch near Crawford, Tex., then flew to Milwaukee, where he promoted his economic agenda and raised $600,000 for Gov. Scott McCallum of Wisconsin, who polls have shown as running even with or behind likely opponents. Then Mr. Bush traveled to the fair and Des Moines and appeared this evening at another fund-raiser, this one for Doug Gross, the Republican candidate for governor against the incumbent, Tom Vilsack.
Mr. Bush happily recognized Mr. Vilsack in the afternoon crowd at the fair, then raised $1.3 million for Mr. Gross this evening.
Mr. Bush is to visit Mount Rushmore in South Dakota on Thursday, then return to his ranch that evening.

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Bush greeted the crowd yesterday at the Iowa State Fair in Des Moines. At right is Representative Greg Ganske, Republican of Iowa. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Musharraf Assails Islamic Militants, but Stands Firm on Kashmir 

BYLINE:  By DAVID ROHDE 

DATELINE: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Aug. 14 

 BODY:
In a nationwide address to observe Pakistan's independence day, President Pervez Musharraf lashed out today at Islamic militants, calling last week's attacks on a Christian school and hospital "shameful" and "despicable."
 "Where is the tolerance, the magnaminity, the chivalry and the large-heartedness that characterized true Muslims?" asked General Musharraf, who vowed to "break the back" of the groups. "We were never so cowardly as to hide, and then to try kill women and children." 
 At the same time, the general vowed that Pakistan would not back away from its demand for a United Nations-monitored referendum to allow the people of the contested Himalayan territory of Kashmir to choose whether to join Pakistan or India or become independent. 
India, which controls roughly half of Kashmir, adamantly opposes a referendum and has accused Pakistan of supporting Islamic insurgents fighting against Indian rule in the mostly Muslim region. The two nuclear-armed rivals nearly went to war last spring over the long-running dispute. 
"The struggle for self-determination of our Kashmiri brothers is a sacred trust with us, which can never be compromised," General Musharraf said. He went on to issue a not-so-veiled threat against India, saying the Pakistani armed forces were ready "not only to defend every inch of the borderline, but to carry the fight across the border." 
General Musharraf delivered his speech as Pakistan celebrated the 55th anniversary of its independence from Britain, a day before India celebrates its own. 
Western diplomats noted that the general spoke mostly in English, and said he apparently was aiming his harsh statement about militants at the United States. The general, who seized power in a coup in 1999, is one of Washington's most important allies in its campaign against terrorism. 
Many Pakistanis and Westerners here fear that continued attacks could drive away foreign investment and further weaken Pakistan's anemic economy. General Musharraf did his best to play down the importance of the militants today, saying "an insignificant minority has held the entire nation hostage to their misconceived views of Islam." 
But diplomats said the general's statements, while sharp, did not mark a decisive shift in policy. "It doesn't do anything to reduce tensions with India," one Western diplomat said, "and I'm not sure it was a step forward on terrorism." 
General Musharraf dismissed elections that India plans to hold in the portion of Kashmir it controls in September as an attempt to legitimize its "illegal occupation" of the area. Indian officials, who charge that Pakistan has been sending Islamic militants into Kashmir to disrupt the elections, denounced his remarks as examples of Pakistani belligerence. 
"We have taken note of his intention to disrupt peaceful elections in Kashmir, and to continue his hostile postures towards India," an Indian government spokeswoman, Nirupama Rao, said in a statement. 
American and European diplomats are urging separatist groups in Kashmir to take part in the election, which they say could be an important first step in resolving the dispute. 
But most Kashmiri separatists have vowed to boycott the vote, saying no election can be free while hundreds of thousands of Indian troops are deployed in the area.

HEADLINE: Bloomberg Seeks Doubling of Recycling Fines 

BYLINE:  By DIANE CARDWELL 

 BODY:
As a moratorium on issuing tickets for violating the city's new recycling rules comes to a close, the Bloomberg administration has been quietly urging a reluctant City Council to double the fines the city can impose.
 The increase was originally included in Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's proposed budget back in April, but it was not passed with the rest of the fiscal package. The measure would raise the first fine for, say, mixing paper with glass, to $50 from $25. The fines for repeated violations, currently from $50 to $500, would double as well, officials said. Officials in the mayor's office estimate that the increase would bring in $1.7 million to the city's depleted coffers. 
 As a cost-saving measure, the city suspended the collection of recyclable plastic for one year and glass for two years, while a task force studies ways to make the program more economical. Bloomberg administration officials say they believe they also had an agreement with the other side of City Hall -- though the Council does not concur -- to increase the fines, and want the Council to move ahead. Legislative aides to the mayor have been raising the issue frequently with Council staff members, Council officials said, nagging them to hold hearings and pass the fine increase.
But Council officials, who had opposed the suspension of some of the program in the first place, say that they do not wish to pursue raising fines right now, because the city has just changed the rules and has not sufficiently educated New Yorkers about their new responsibilities. 
"There's still a great deal of confusion out there, and it seems that they've been a little slow in getting notices out there," said Forrest Taylor, the Council's chief of staff. "People have to get used to a new way of dealing with things, and that takes time."
Michael E. McMahon, chairman of the Council's Sanitation and Solid Waste Management Committee, called the proposed increases "nothing more than a hidden tax," and said he would block any attempt to raise the penalties until the recycling program was back to normal.
"We've done the suspension, which nobody understands, and we're planning to do a lifting of half of the suspension in 11 months," Mr. McMahon said, adding that the city had not presented a television advertising campaign or a sufficiently broad-based education program. "You can't change the rules, not publish the change and then tax the people for not adhering to the rules." 
Vito A. Turso, a Sanitation Department spokesman, said that the department had always planned to re-evaluate enforcement as the grace period came to a close, at the end of this month, and decide whether to begin issuing tickets or to extend the moratorium. Judging by the number of e-mail messages and views on the department's Web site, he said, "word of the recycling change has certainly gotten out to the public."

The Pope's Trip Home Fuels Retirement Rumors
Pope John Paul II's coming trip to Poland is fueling new rumors that he will announce his retirement. Vatican officials have denied it, but the media frenzy of speculation offers a forecast of the onslaught awaiting the papal succession. A1

HEADLINE: Corrections 

 BODY:
 An article on Aug. 8 about speeches by President Bush and Vice President Cheney defending the administration's stewardship of the economy referred incorrectly to the 2001 recession and to the direction of the stock market on Aug. 7. Economists agree that the recession has ended, not continued. The Dow Jones industrial average rose the day of the speeches, by 182 points; it did not decline.

HEADLINE: For W.T.O.'s Next Chief, A Long List of Headaches 

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH OLSON 

DATELINE: GENEVA, Aug. 15 

 BODY:
Supachai Panitchpakdi, a soft-spoken Thai economist, has been a passionate chess player since he took up the game as a teenager. Starting next month, he will give those tactical skills a good workout when he becomes director general of the World Trade Organization, a fractious lot of countries all pledged to the same end -- global free trade -- but always divided over how to achieve it.
 The divisions have been particularly apparent in recent months as the elation that followed the start of the Doha trade round in Qatar last year has waned, a victim of disputes between the European Union and Washington over farm subsidies and steel tariffs, and a potentially costly fight over tax breaks for American corporations. 
 Mr. Supachai will be the organization's first leader from the developing world, and is seen as a champion of poorer countries. But he will have to deal with their lingering discontent over what they see as unfair treatment in global trade. 
Already, interim deadlines in the trade round's timeline to open access to the world's markets have slipped in Geneva, where the day-to-day negotiations take place, and the January 2005 completion date is looking increasingly unlikely.
He will have to herd this disparate lot toward that deadline without antagonizing either the big trading powers or the smaller developing nations, who make up the bulk of the organization's 144 members.
So far, while watching from the sidelines after being appointed three years ago in an unusual compromise, he has had to draw on some of the humility and patience he learned during a brief period two decades ago as a Buddhist monk.
Mr. Supachai, who has held various government posts in Thailand, including deputy premier and trade minister, offered to mediate the big traders' steel dispute. The response: no, thank you.
"He doesn't occupy the position of leadership," Anthony Gooch, until recently the European Commission's trade spokesman, said at a news briefing in June. "His views will be valued and considered when he does occupy that position."
Mr. Supachai, a well-regarded economist who has written books on globalization, shrugged off the rebuff. "I was just trying to say we should explore options," he said in a recent interview.
He has had plenty of time to cultivate his patience, along with his extensive collection of bonsai trees, while waiting in the wings to take over the director general's job. After a hotly disputed race for the top spot at the World Trade Organization, a compromise was struck in 1999 that split the term, giving the first stint to Mr. Supachai's rival, Mike Moore of New Zealand.
At the time, Mr. Supachai, who had been the front-runner until Mr. Moore entered the race, took the unusual step of publicly complaining, saying that his chances had been poisoned by accusations that he twisted arms and promised favors to get the job. The contest turned because some European and developing countries believed that the United States was railroading its choice of Mr. Moore.
That was the first of several frank remarks for which Mr. Supachai, 56, has been reproached as someone who "shoots from the lip." The impression was reinforced the next year when he tangled with Pascal Lamy, the European Union trade commissioner, over how broad the Doha trade round should be. Mr. Supachai preferred a more narrowly focused round. More sweeping trade rounds are harder to conclude, but they give more maneuvering room to industrial powers.
In recent months, he again ruffled superpower feathers by espousing a code of conduct for multinationals to follow in trade negotiations -- an unwelcome suggestion on both sides of the Atlantic.
"He has to be careful and not be too outspoken," one European trade envoy said. "Otherwise, the greater danger is that the big powers could start to ignore him completely."
Yet, now that he is taking the reins, Mr. Supachai will be global trade's most visible cheerleader, appearing around the world to push the benefits of open markets. He will also be trade's chief conciliator, encouraging countries to take on entrenched domestic interests. And while he can cajole or nudge, he has no formal authority in this member-driven organization to shove the countries into agreement.
"What he can do is create an environment where positions can be harmonized," said Nepal's envoy, Shambu Ram Simkhada, who is leading his country's effort to join the W.T.O. 
Mr. Supachai's formal, low-key manner contrasts markedly with the breezy, chummy style of his immediate predecessor. Mr. Moore prides himself on grabby one-liners to make trade relevant to average people; Mr. Supachai is seen as a sort of egghead, more preoccupied with the theory of trade than with its actual practice.
"He's an individual who's very reflective, where Mike was very instinctive" said Sergio Marchi, Canada's ambassador to the W.T.O. "But that doesn't mean he's going to be a pushover."
In fact, Mr. Marchi said, Mr. Supachai's willingness to "throw out solutions" impresses him as "better than having a director general who sticks his finger in the air, and waits to see how the breeze is blowing."
Mr. Supachai says he takes criticism in stride, although prefers it to be "well intentioned and constructive." But either way, he said, it will not deflect him from pursuing his vision of a wider marketplace where trade ties the world together.
Mr. Supachai is taking over as the organization is trying to steer a steady course after a stormy period that included in December 1999 when anti-globalization protesters disrupted the W.T.O. summit in Seattle, a debacle that grabbed headlines around the globe.
Less than three years later, the accord at Doha, hailed as a turning point for the W.T.O., has been undermined by resurgent protectionist sentiments.
Mr. Supachai says he can get the talks on track. He has overcome challenges before, he said, pointing to the 10 years he spent in the Netherlands getting his Ph.D. in economics. Before he could even start classes at Erasmus University in Rotterdam, he had to spend more than a year learning Dutch.
"I was a guinea pig at the time," said Mr. Supachai, the first Thai to study there.
When he returned to Bangkok, he worked for Thailand's central bank. There, he met his wife, Sasai, who quit her job to help run his political campaigns. "She's a very good, and tough, campaigner, better than me," he laughed. Mr. Supachai vaulted from representing a district on Bangkok's outskirts to being the finance minister -- and boss of the central bank -- by the time he was 40.
He headed Thailand's delegation at the end of the Uruguay round of trade talks, which took seven years to conclude.
Wrapping up the current round in three years, Mr. Supachai said, means that "we can't stop working at any time." He has made no secret that he believes that success depends on some concessions to developing countries, especially in crucial areas like apparel.
But despite his zeal for free trade, Mr. Supachai admits it is only "one means to improve people's lives."
"There is a limit," he said. "We can't cure all social ills."

HEADLINE: DRIVING; 
What Awaits A Dream Car When Dreams Change?

BYLINE:  By ABBY ELLIN 

 BODY:
IN the small subset of automobiles that can properly be called American sports cars, the undisputed king is the Corvette. The original two-seater Thunderbird, which had a good run but wasn't made after 1957, was not really a sports car; today's successor isn't either. The Dodge Viper, a challenger since 1991, has not reached Corvette-level appeal or sales. The AC Cobra, now a beloved collectors' car, flashed in and flamed out in the 60's. The Corvette endures -- 32,000 made every year, 32,000 sold every year. Those who love the Corvette love it fanatically.
 To Martin A. Drutz, a Miami accountant who has owned a dozen Corvettes and has an office full of Corvette memorabilia, it is the sine qua non: "To me, there is no other car." 
 The Corvette touched America's yearning for excitement and glamour as perhaps no other car ever did. Martin Milner and George Maharis sped to adventure in a Corvette on "Route 66." A Corvette entered James Bond's life in "A View to a Kill." William Shatner, still the youthful Captain Kirk, proudly posed in his, and Alan Shepard, who really did fly in space, was just one of several astronauts who drove them. The Corvette spoke of power, speed and Marilyn Monroe look-alikes, usually in the passenger seat. 
As a boy growing up in the 50's and 60's, Mr. Drutz, now 54, spent hours gluing model Corvettes together. Like millions of other boys and young men (85 percent of Corvette owners are male, according to Chevrolet), he dreamed of the day when he would own one, and like many others, he made his dream come true. But it might be hard to find a boy with that dream today.
This year the Corvette turns 50, and many of its fans have reached that milestone before it. According to Chevrolet, 49 percent of new Corvette buyers are over 50, and 76 percent are over 40. Only 7 percent are 30 and under.
George Kerbeck, an owner of Kerbeck Chevrolet in Atlantic City, one of the largest Corvette dealers in the country, said most of his customers were between 48 and 52.
Other Corvette sellers cater to a similar market. "A guy came in here yesterday saying, 'I got my kids in college, all my expenses are over and done with, now I want my Corvette,' " Bob Baker of Corvette Mike New England in Plymouth, Mass., said Wednesday.
Price is a factor, of course. ("What kid has 50 grand?" as Mr. Baker put it.) But David Glaze, vice president and creative director at Genex, an Internet consulting company in Los Angeles, said people in their 20's and 30's who have money to spend and like what he calls "racer cars" want smaller, sleeker cars, not automobiles they associate with, say, Robert Novak, the 71-year-old political commentator who is repeatedly teased on CNN's "Crossfire" about his new black Corvette.
"A Corvette?" said Jennifer Thompson, 30, an art director in New York. "Aren't they for guys in gold chains who are trying to recapture their youth?" 
Mr. Glaze said Chevrolet would have to work hard to reignite interest in the brand with young people. Based on his research as a designer of automobile Web sites (Corvette's 50th anniversary site is among them), he said that the racer cars that appeal to the youth market are "little star-fighter things, the small Audis, the Acura Integra and the Honda Si."
Jamie McDonald, a 32-year-old producer at Fox News in New York, called the Corvette passe. He aspires to own a Porsche 911 -- "That's a car," he said reverently.
Generations X and Y may not think so, but the Corvette is very much a car. It has a top speed of 170 miles an hour, and it's reasonably comfortable and practical. Its V-8 engine achieves a remarkable combination of performance and fuel economy -- this is a racer car that gets nearly 30 miles a gallon on the highway. And its low-slung shape is unmistakable.
"I've driven other sports cars -- Porsche 911's and Panteras, for instance -- and they're all fun in their unique way," said Kevin Wanner, 40, a manager at America Online in South Orange, N.J., who takes his 1996 LT4 to amateur competitions. "But the Corvette seems to have limitless power, great adhesion and is very forgiving." 
Arnie Tanowitz, 50, the chief executive of the Rutan Polyethylene Supply and Bag Manufacturing Company in Mahwah, N.J., expresses his enthusiasm for his Corvette more lyrically. "Have you ever listened to a throaty V-8 with a dual exhaust up Route 9W, over the Bear Mountain Bridge and up Route 9 with some great music and the roof off?" he said. "Do you know the difference between driving a car and being driven by a car?"
General Motors has produced more than 1.4 million Corvettes since its chief stylist, Harley Earl, decided in 1951 to design a new American sports car. In January 1953, the prototype went on display at the Motorama show at the Waldorf-Astoria, and production began that June in Flint, Mich. From the beginning, the Corvette catered to a highly selective, wealthy audience, and production was deliberately limited. "When you overbuild," said Bob Tripolsky, the communications manager at Chevrolet, there is a "likelihood of reducing the mystique of the cars."
When the Corvette first rolled into showrooms, Americans were bursting with postwar pride. As the Corvette reaches its 50th anniversary -- the 2003 model is already in some showrooms -- many Americans are once again full of patriotic resolve. More than anyone might have expected a year ago, a celebration of the Corvette, an icon of American design and engineering and a hardy competitor in a field dominated by foreign models, has turned out to be in step with the times.
Besides being quintessentially American, the Corvette has the democratic quality of being more broadly affordable than most sports cars. The Porsche 911 costs $70,000 to $120,000; the Ferrari 575M Maranello is close to $250,000. The most expensive new Corvette today is the Z06, at just over $51,000; the cheapest is the coupe, at $42,350. 
Corvette is celebrating its 50th year with a range of promotions. The most notable is planned for June in Nashville, featuring caravans, displays, concerts, exhibitions, engineering talks and thousands of Corvettes. 
In any year, there is no shortage of outlets for the Corvette-obsessed: Corvette clubs, Corvette competitions and meets, and Corvette magazines. This year's Corvette Celebration at the National Corvette Museum, in Bowling Green, Ky., on Labor Day will be the eighth annual such event. Corvette owners can also indulge themselves with myriad collectibles -- model cars, decanters, knives, lighters, plates and, of course, multiple Corvettes, new and old. (A good 1957 model now goes for $50,000; it cost $3,000 new.)
Executives at General Motors speak bravely of attracting a wider market. Rick Baldick, the director of marketing for Corvette in Detroit, said the company was targeting younger buyers. Marketing for the 2003 Corvette will include ads in magazines like Golf, Men's Journal and MBA Jungle aimed at the "dreamer" category -- the youngish man aspiring to own an exciting car.
Whether younger buyers discover the Corvette or not, Chevrolet doesn't foresee any imminent decline in Corvette sales. Mr. Tripolsky, the Chevrolet spokesman, says he is confident that Corvettes will be produced for a very long time. And certainly its baby boomer fans have time to buy many more.
Jay Leno, 52, the host of "The Tonight Show," owns two Corvettes, a 1999 and a 2002. He also has 80 other cars, mostly antiques, and 80 motorcycles; he keeps them in a warehouse, but he actually drives his Corvettes.
Mr. Leno explained the special quality of the Corvette -- what he calls "an attainable lure" -- by comparing it to the actress Sandra Bullock. "She's a beautiful movie star," he said in a telephone interview from his office in Los Angeles, "and she seems like a regular girl." That, he said, is what the Corvette is like. It "just does everything right -- it can be glamorous or a car you can park at the market."
But if he can see taking one of his Corvettes to the grocery store, he would never dream of driving them to Hollywood parties. "You'd have to be an idiot to leave them with a valet," he said. "I take my banged-up '91 Syclone truck."
