HEADLINE: Stock Slide Adds to Fear On Liquidity Of Vivendi 

BYLINE:  By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: PARIS, Aug. 15 

 BODY:
Investors dumped Vivendi Universal stock for a second consecutive day today, apparently unconvinced by the announcement on Wednesday that management would try to ease a severe cash squeeze by shedding assets in a $9.8 billion sell-off.
 The shares, after losing 25 percent of their value on Wednesday, fell 11 percent more today in European trading. In New York, Vivendi's American depository receipts lost 86 cents, or 7.4 percent, closing at $10.80. 
 Sarah Percy-Dove, a bond analyst at Merrill Lynch in London, said there was "very serious concern" over Vivendi's liquidity. 
On Wednesday, the new chief executive of the company, Jean-Rene Fourtou, announced plans to sell assets, including the publisher Houghton Mifflin and perhaps Vivendi's stake in the American satellite television company EchoStar Communications. The proceeds would help offset a dwindling cash flow and obtain the liquidity needed to service $18.6 billion of debt, most of it amassed in a two-year acquisition spree by Mr. Fourtou's predecessor, Jean-Marie Messier.
In a note to investors today, Michael Picken of Credit Suisse First Boston estimated that Vivendi's short-term liquidity requirements through next March would total 5.6 billion euros, or $5.4 billion. Mr. Fourtou said on Wednesday that he hoped to raise $9.8 billion over the next two years, with roughly half of that amount to be raised in the next nine months.
Mr. Picken said that to meet short-term needs, he expected Vivendi to reach an agreement with a group of banks for a credit line of 3 billion euros by the end of August. He estimated that such a cash injection would suffice until the end of the year.
Mr. Picken also said that none of the planned disposals, including that of Houghton Mifflin, reflected actual deals yet. "We consider it to be a buyer's market," he added, suggesting that Vivendi would fetch far less in most cases than it paid for its assets.
Ms. Percy-Dove of Merrill Lynch said that she and other analysts were disappointed with the proposals announced Wednesday. She called them "at best, amateurish; at worst, blind ignorance."
"Management do not yet have sufficient grasp of the extent of their problem," she said.
Stewart Applebaum, director of corporate affairs at the Random House division of Bertelsmann, said that Random House would be interested in Houghton Mifflin's trade book unit, if the group is sold piecemeal, but he added, "It's going to be a tough market."
On Wednesday, Mr. Fourtou gave no hint that he intended to put on the block, at least for now, the Universal music, film and television production businesses in the United States that Mr. Messier acquired in his quest to turn Vivendi into an American-style media conglomerate.
Barry Sosnick, a media analyst at Fahnestock & Company in New York, agreed with that decision. 
"One of the troubles is that when large conglomerates go through hard times, the knee-jerk reaction is to cut out businesses where there is no synergy," Mr. Sosnick said.
Universal's music and video businesses offer a "tremendous upside" as the economic slowdown compels consumers to seek out cheaper forms of entertainment, he said, and should bolster Vivendi's anemic cash flow. "When there's a drop in income, consumers move back toward lower-cost forms of entertainment," he said. "And that's what Universal has."
Other experts said they doubted that the process of unwinding the media empire assembled by Mr. Messier would stop at the plans announced on Wednesday.
"I feel they're definitely becoming a French company again," said Richard Lorber of Lorber Media, a New York consultant, adding that he thought Mr. Fourtou would eventually spin off the Universal holdings. "Management clearly lacks the ability to create synergies with their French businesses," he said.
Mr. Picken of Credit Suisse said he thought Vivendi would hang onto the core American media assets, including Universal, "creating a traditional conglomerate structure in the medium term." That means, however, that investors will apply a "significant conglomerate discount" to Vivendi shares, he said, as much as 40 percent.

HEADLINE: Measuring Downtown's Future 

BYLINE:  By Denise Scott Brown; Denise Scott Brown is an architect and urban planner and a principal at Venturi, Scott Brown and Associates.

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA 

 BODY:
In the 1950's, every city planning commission had its "vision for the year 2020." The frontispieces of urban plans across America showed towers, beautiful and ethereal, rising from the city. Ten years later, these images were sarcastically called "perfect vision" plans. The reality they became -- the urban renewal projects of the 50's and 60's -- forcefully discredited the old Cities of the Future. Now, as we consider the future of the World Trade Center site, we are confronted, once again, with perfect-vision plans. One irony is that they are intended to replace what was itself one of the last urban renewal projects of the 1960's.
 And there is criticism again today. If the idea behind the recent unveiling of a set of perfect-vision drawings was to shift the debate to design -- and, in the process, get tacit acceptance of the type and amount of space to be built -- it hasn't worked. New Yorkers would not buy the basic premise. 
 So why have municipal agencies gone on to invite us to create yet more visions? Answers for the city will not lie in such perfect visions, or even in countervisions. Another type of vision is in order: a social vision that can direct the move to form and design. We need to step back, if briefly, to evolve a conception of the meaning of New York today -- to consider what it is and what it should be. 
New York is a giant, a multilayered conjunction of activities, set within larger patterns of the region, nation and world and related to them on many scales. This site downtown is a subset of the whole, tied to all around it in ways only partly fathomable. What will make it all work again after an unimaginable disruption? What connections are needed to bring back its vitality? Can we expect the same patterns as before? How might they be altered?
Before Sept. 11, activities in Lower Manhattan were changing, perhaps rapidly. Analysis of trends just before the destruction should be part of the stepping back and thinking. But given the giant discontinuity, who knows what trends will last, even in the near future? The figures behind the published plans are merely hopes. We should certainly build on hope -- but hope on what scale?
We can take some guidance from our own first steps after the destruction. New patterns appeared on the site as soon as emergency services were set up. A heart-rending one was photocopied sheets pinned along routes where people walked: Have you seen my father, brother, wife? The location of these unwitting memorials can teach us something about how cities really work; it illustrates the classic relation that exists in cities between patterns of activities and paths of circulation. This "city physics," compared with grand urban visions, is short-term and human-scale. It is how things should be done and ought to discipline the replanning of the site, ensuring that its reconstructed streets and transit facilities become the basis for locating and sizing new activities.
Canny developers understand city physics and take it into account. They study markets to decide on the amount and type of space that can be absorbed in specific locations at a given time. Too ambitious an implementation of long-term plans can spell disaster for a developer. So the individual developer, absent pressure or support from government, is likely to estimate the size of each increment conservatively. This gives the project a foothold in reality.
It gives better prospects for the city, too. Plans that locate retail uses where people pass, envisage new office buildings only when the rents can be afforded and tie these to the larger patterns of the neighborhood -- such plans, more than the published visions, will have a chance of developing cities of character, agreeability, utility, immediacy and vitality.
Developers' plans cannot, however, entirely avoid the unpredictability and discontinuity that the attacks introduced into our city's life. Trends that were violently disrupted cannot merely be projected, and planners do not have the power of prophecy. With unusually strong limits on the ability to forecast, I believe the first phase of implementation should be cautious. One tower? Two? Local retail only? This first increment could then serve as a gauge for further demand.
No matter how cautious the first step, its design will call for a long-range view of what Lower Manhattan can and should be. If creative services and information technology firms are to be prominent here in the future, we should consider what types of urban environment they require and induce. Companies in these industries, like those of the garment industry up the street, tend to form links among themselves, as if on a production line. This is especially true of advertising, media and software development companies, where creativity is at a premium. Up-and-coming enterprises require the lower rents that existing older buildings offer, whereas established organizations may lease space in the planned towers. Growing companies require opportunities to expand within the neighborhood. People in these firms tend to live near their work and patronize the restaurants, galleries and cultural activities that should be a visible and exciting attraction in the area.
Given these patterns, rebuilding the site will call for developing a strong relationship between old and new and establishing vitality at street level where urbanites congregate. Start-up firms may play a role like that of artists in the city. They find the good places to work and live; when they move in, others follow.
Residential plans for the revived neighborhood should respond to the pluralism of New York. While little new housing may be constructed on the site, some low-rent office space will become available for residential conversion as growing businesses move into new spaces. That's another natural progression. The need for moderate-income housing, however, will remain.
Streets and transit facilities, especially those underground, must be returned to the site quickly. A consequence of phased rebuilding may be that on-site space is left unbuilt for a while and that underground transportation facilities, constructed now, will need to be designed to allow for a variety of ways of building over them. The decision to maintain the footprint of the World Trade Center buildings as public space is justified, I feel, by the weight of the loss. Public buildings and spaces on the site will need to serve national, city and local needs and should be attuned to change in the area. Manhattan has a long tradition of building commercial buildings, housing and public institutions. It builds skyscrapers better than anyone else. It has a spectacular history of large public parks and important institutional buildings. But there is also a tradition of modest public buildings and parks. A small church or synagogue, set within a row of town houses or surrounded by office buildings, holds its own with dignity. Small city parks provide benches, a canopy of trees, seclusion from traffic and shady respite for locals. Despite the scale of proposed rebuilding, these small institutions and spaces should serve as our best models for the refurbished public sector.
Tragedy will always overhang the site. For me, recognizing the events of Sept. 11 would entail endeavoring to assure that private-sector buildings, whatever their size, are modest in their design and expression. The major symbols should be in the public sector. Those of the destroyed World Trade Center have seared minds and spirits worldwide; some of these remains belong on their site. They will bring gravitas and inspire contemplation. The photocopied sheets, too, should be here. Perhaps they could be reproduced in permanent materials and placed in the sequence in which they were first arranged, along a walk through the spaces of the buildings' footprints. This would be a processional, without bombast.

HEADLINE: Fed Officials Were Confident Economy Was Improving in June 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 

 BODY:
Federal Reserve policy makers were confident seven weeks ago that the economy was on the path to recovery, according to minutes of their discussions on June 25 and 26. 
 While investors and consumers "had been shaken by revelations of accounting irregularities," the minutes said, "the economy had continued to expand and the prospects for accelerating aggregate demand remained positive." 
 In the minutes, some central bankers said they had expected the recovery to be further along by late June. "The timing and strength of an upturn in the expansion," the minutes said, "remained subject to considerable uncertainty." 
Policy makers changed their assessment on Tuesday and announced that they saw a threat to the economy from weakening growth. In June, the central bank had left its benchmark bank-lending rate unchanged at a 41-year low of 1.75 percent and retained its view that risks to the economy were balanced between weakness and higher inflation. 
Some members of the Fed's policy-setting Open Market Committee said in June that they "had expected to see firmer indications of a strengthening recovery" by midyear. Still, according to the minutes, they anticipated that "in the absence of major further adverse shocks to confidence" the economy would soon return to a growth rate of 3 percent to 3.5 percent. 
"Members cited the accommodative stance of both fiscal and monetary policy and the continuation of impressive growth in productivity that should buttress household incomes and spending and encourage a pickup in business investment," the minutes said. 
Corporate spending on new equipment was viewed as a "key to sustained solid growth" and doubts about when it might rebound were a "major source of uncertainty about the pace of the expansion in coming quarters," the minutes said. 
Although the panel voted unanimously this week to leave interest rates unchanged and to shift its statement on the balance of risks, some central bankers suggested in June that the current policy stance "was too accommodative" to be consistent with the Fed's aim of making sure inflation does not accelerate. 
Still, most said keeping the federal funds rate at a four-decade low was "desirable to counter the lingering effects of financial and other shocks to the economy that were continuing to exert a depressing impact on output and resource use." 
The report also noted that inflation was "still edging down" with expectations about its future performance "low and stable."

HEADLINE: Reports on Manufacturing Suggest Sluggish Growth 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 

 BODY:
Manufacturing slowed in July, the Federal Reserve reported today, as factory production nudged up 0.1 percent, compared with a 0.6 percent increase in June.
 In addition, the Labor Department reported today that more Americans filed new applications for jobless benefits last week. 
 In the factory production report, output rose 0.2 percent in July for the entire industrial sector, which includes factories, mines and utilities, compared with an increase of 0.7 percent in June. The rise in factory production reflected a 4.2 percent increase in output of cars, trucks and parts. Excluding them, factory output would have fallen 0.3 percent in July, the Fed said. 
At mines, production fell 1.2 percent in July, while output at gas and electric utilities rose 2.3 percent as hot weather pushed up demand. 
Even though production slowed for the entire sector in July, the 0.2 percent increase was the seventh consecutive month that output rose. 
In a separate regional survey, the Philadelphia Federal Reserve reported today that manufacturing in the mid-Atlantic region fell sharply in August. The bank's general economic index dropped to minus 3.1 in August, its first negative reading since December, from 6.6 in July. A reading below zero indicates a contraction.
The Labor Department said in the jobless report that new claims for unemployment insurance rose last week by a seasonally adjusted 6,000, to 388,000, a level associated with a sluggish job market.
The reports "suggest that the economic train is still moving, but on the slower freight track," said Tim O'Neill, chief economist at the Bank of Montreal.
He and other analysts said the recovery was hitting a temporary rough patch related to the accounting scandals that have shaken Americans' confidence in companies, the roller coaster stock market and a stagnant jobs market. 
Faced with economic uncertainties, companies have been reluctant to hire back laid-off workers and make big capital spending commitments, keys to reviving the economy. 
The number of unemployed Americans continuing to draw jobless benefits rose to 3.58 million for the work week ended Aug. 3, the most recent period for which the information is available.
The unemployment rate remained at 5.9 percent in July as companies added just 6,000 jobs.

HEADLINE: Estee Lauder Posts Loss for the Quarter 

BYLINE:  By Reuters 

 BODY:
The Estee Lauder Companies, a leading cosmetics company, posted a quarterly loss after restructuring charges yesterday, and said earnings in the current quarter would fall below analysts' estimates because of higher spending on advertising and promotions.
 But the company, which has been hurt by sluggish consumer spending in the United States and Japan, said it expected earnings for the year to meet analysts' estimates, and its stock rose 3 percent. 
 Estee Lauder, which sells the Clinique and Aramis brands, posted a loss of $25.4 million, or 13 cents a share, for the quarter, contrasted with a profit of $14.6 million, or 6 cents, a year earlier.
Excluding restructuring charges, the company said, profit fell to $51.5 million, or 19 cents a share, from $60.7 million, or 23 cents a share, a year earlier. The company said in June that it expected earnings of 18 cents a share before one-time items.
Sales in the period, which ended June 30 and was the fourth quarter of Estee Lauder's fiscal year, rose 8 percent, to $1.13 billion.
Estee Lauder took a fourth-quarter restructuring charge of $76.9 million after taxes to cut supply-chain and distribution costs and trim its Internet business expenses.
In the last year, Estee Lauder's sales have fallen because of the soft economy and a slump in business at duty-free shops and other travel-related sites after the Sept. 11 attacks on the United States. 
The company said it expected to see soft but improving economic trends in the current quarter, and it forecast an increase of 2 percent to 3 percent in sales, excluding foreign currency changes.

HEADLINE: A Celebration to Remember Liberation Unites Koreans for a Day 

BYLINE:  By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 15 

 BODY:
Barely six weeks after North and South Korea fought a gun battle at sea, the largest delegation of North Korean civilians in memory joined South Koreans here today to celebrate the anniversary of the end of World War II and the end of Japanese colonial rule.
 Chanting "Korea is one" at a joint National Liberation Day art performance, 116 North Koreans waved blue and white "unification" flags featuring a united Korean peninsula. 
 The celebration is the kickoff to a series of North-South civilian exchanges, many of them sporting events, as both countries seek to rebuild relations on the peninsula. 
The activities include a "friendly" North-South soccer match, the first in almost a decade. In mid-September, inter-Korean exchanges of tae kwon do teams are to begin, with a South Korean martial arts group traveling to North Korea.
At the end of September, 600 North Korean athletes, journalists and fans are to travel to Pusan, South Korea, for the Asian Games.
Ever since the end of the Korean War, in 1953, North Korea has shunned international sports events in the South.
North Korea's participation in these competitions seems intended to win a restoration of food aid from South Korea and repair relations damaged by the naval conflict.
In the battle on June 29 off the west coast, South Korea's navy lost five sailors and North Korea is thought to have lost 13 men.
The joint events are not without their complications. South Korea bans the use of North Korean symbols, the flag and the national anthem for propaganda purposes, posing a problem at sporting events.
This week, with anti-Communist demonstrators burning a North Korean flag outside the site of inter-Korean talks here, it was clear that any mishandling of the flag issue could have political consequences.
Judging by newspaper editorials this week on the flag issue, it appears the government will restrict the flying of North Korea's flag to ceremonial areas of stadiums and to athletes' villages, but will try to prevent fans from waving it in the stands.
Meanwhile, about 1,000 leftists demonstrated outside the main American military base in Seoul today. Separately, an equal number of conservatives, many of them Army veterans, demonstrated for increased vigilance about North Korea, which maintains an army with a million troops north of the border, only 35 miles from here. --------------------

Koizumi Avoids War Shrine
 TOKYO, Aug. 15 (AP) -- In a gesture to Japan's neighbors, Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi did not visit a controversial war shrine today on the 57th anniversary of Japan's surrender in World War II.
But as Mr. Koizumi expressed regrets about Japan's aggression, conservative lawmakers still paid their respects at the Yasukuni Shrine in Tokyo. Nearly 2.5 million war dead, including executed war criminals, are worshiped at the shrine as deities. Mr. Koizumi prompted outrage, particularly in China and South Korea, when he visited days before the anniversary last year. This year, he observed a moment of silence and laid flowers at a nearby cemetery. 
"During the war, our country inflicted great damage and pain to the people of many countries, especially in Asia," Mr. Koizumi said. "As the representative of this nation's people, I again reflect deeply and express humble condolences to those who lost their lives."

HEADLINE: Computer Sciences Seeks Leaves 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: EL SEGUNDO, Calif., Aug. 15 

 BODY:
The Computer Sciences Corporation, the computer-services company, said today that it would ask its 66,000 workers to volunteer to take at least six months' leave with 20 percent pay. 
 A spokesman for Computer Sciences, Frank Pollare, said the program would allow workers to receive some income and the company to "reduce costs for that time." Mr. 
Pollare said he could not forecast possible savings or say how many workers would take the extended leave. 
 Computer Sciences and two larger rivals, I.B.M. and Electronic Data Systems, have had falling or slowing sales as customers have cut information-technology budgets in response to a lagging global economy. Computer Sciences shares have fallen 25 percent this year. 
According to an e-mail message to workers in Australia, full-time employees will get approval from their managers to take six to nine months of leave with an 80 percent pay cut to help the company "control costs and improve operating efficiencies."
Computer Sciences said that it had bolstered profit as workers became more productive and that the company cut 2,000 jobs last year. 
On July 31, the company said first-quarter profit rose 66 percent, to $79 million, through cost cuts and an accounting change. Sales rose 1.9 percent, which was lower than expected. 
The company has about 37,000 workers in the United States, 21,000 in Europe and 8,000 in Asia. All of them will be offered extended leave if laws in the workers' nations of employment allow it, Mr. Pollare said. 
It is "too early to speculate" whether the company will force workers to take the leave if too few workers volunteer, he said.

HEADLINE: Mind the Gap 

BYLINE:  By PAUL KRUGMAN; E-mail: krugman@nytimes.com

 BODY:
How much has Japan's economy shrunk since its bubble burst? It's a trick question; Japan's economy hasn't shrunk. It had only two down years over the past decade, and on average it grew 1 percent per year. 
 Yet Japan's is a genuinely depressed economy. Because growth has been so slow, an ever-increasing gap has opened up between what the economy could produce and what it actually produces. This "output gap" translates into rising unemployment and accelerating deflation. Slow growth can be almost as big a problem as actual output decline. 
 Now the non-trick question: What would a similar analysis say about the United States?
The U.S. economy's "potential output" -- what it could produce at full employment -- has lately been growing at about 3.5 percent per year, thanks to the productivity surge that began in the mid-1990's. But according to the revised figures released a couple of weeks ago, actual growth has fallen short of potential for seven of the last eight quarters. 
The conventional view is that we had a brief, shallow recession last year, and that recovery has begun. But the output gap tells a different story: Two years ago we went into an economic funk, and it's not over. In a way the whole double-dip controversy is a red herring; the real question is when G.D.P. will start growing fast enough to narrow the output gap. And so far there's no sign of that happening. 
There's no mystery about the causes of our funk: the bubble years left us with too much capacity, too much debt and a backlog of business scandal. We shouldn't have expected a quick and easy recovery, and we're not getting one.
Some readers have already guessed where I'm going with this. The U.S. stock bubble in the second half of the 1990's was just as big as Japan's bubble in the second half of the 1980's. Will our two-year funk turn into a five-year or ten-year funk, the way Japan's did?
A loud chorus is already shouting "We're not Japan!" Half the time, depending on what I had for breakfast (rice and pickles?), I'm part of that chorus. But let me share some disquieting thoughts.
Back when I first got professionally obsessed with Japan's problems, around four years ago, I made myself a mental checklist of reasons that Japan's decade of stagnation could not happen to the United States. It went like this: 
1. The Fed has plenty of room to cut interest rates, which should be enough to deal with any eventuality. 
2. The U.S. long-term budget position is very strong, so there's plenty of room for fiscal stimulus in the unlikely event interest rate cuts aren't enough. 
3. We don't have to worry about an Asian-style loss of confidence in our business sector, because we have excellent corporate governance. 
4. We may have a stock bubble, but we don't have a real estate bubble.
I've now had to strike the first three items off my list, and I'm getting worried about the fourth.
More and more people are using the B-word about the housing market. A recent analysis by Dean Baker, of the Center for Economic Policy Research, makes a particularly compelling case for a housing bubble. House prices have run well ahead of rents, suggesting that people are now buying houses for speculation rather than merely for shelter. And the explanations one hears for those high prices sound more and more like the rationalizations one heard for Nasdaq 5,000.
If we do have a housing bubble, and it bursts, we'll be looking a lot too Japanese for comfort.
A recent Federal Reserve analysis of Japan's experience declares that the key mistake Japan made in the early 1990's was "not that policy makers did not predict the oncoming deflationary slump -- after all, neither did most forecasters -- but that they did not take out sufficient insurance against downside risks through a precautionary further loosening of monetary policy." That's Fedspeak for "if you think deflation is even a possibility, throw money at the economy now and don't worry about overdoing it."
And yet the Fed chose not to cut rates on Tuesday. Why?
Last year some economists began privately referring to the Fed chairman as "Greenspan-san." The joke faded out as optimism about recovery became conventional wisdom. But maybe it's not a bad nickname after all.

HEADLINE: Mississippi Floods Drain Life From River Towns 

BYLINE:  By PETER T. KILBORN 

DATELINE: KASKASKIA, Ill., Aug. 14 

 BODY:
The only sound in this flat green settlement on the Mississippi River is the whisper of leaves. Just off the Grande Rue, at a shrine beside the abandoned rectory of the gothic brick Immaculate Conception Church, visitors press a green button on a wall to look inside. An automated door swings open to reveal a view of the Liberty Bell of the West. No one is in there.
 No one seems left in Kaskaskia, the first capital of the state of Illinois, from 1818 to 1820. The bell, 11 years older than the one in Philadelphia and almost as large, was King Louis XV's gift to French settlers here. More than 2,000 people lived here once. But the Census Bureau found only 9 in 2000, down from 32 in 1990. Flood upon flood, most recently the Great Flood of 1993, have left Kaskaskia an island with more egrets than people. 
 Kaskaskia may be the extreme. It is one of a crop of near-ghost towns spreading along the nation's great arterial waterway, as other towns are expiring in the West and the Great Plains. Their economies and populations stagnant and falling, dozens of towns along the 1,000-mile stretch of the central Mississippi from Wisconsin to northern Arkansas, are stuck like stopped clocks. 
Various factors have conspired in the towns' travails: tired local leadership, vanishing farm families who brought corn to riverbank grain elevators, declines of lumbering and commercial fishing, barge operations that closed or decamped to Minneapolis, St. Louis and Memphis, surging competition from railroads and trucks. 
But for a number of languishing Mississippi towns it is the Great Flood of 1993 and, as important, its aftermath that have drained life away. The floods, which caused $10 billion in damage, were devastating enough. But the effort to reconstruct the towns, paradoxically, has played a role as well. Federal and state governments resettled 20,000 houses away from the river throughout the flood zone, and while it made sense to prevent people from rebuilding on land that was prone to flooding, the decision also exposed a harsh reality: The towns had lost their reason to exist, making attempts to reconstitute them virtually impossible.
People dispersed, and vital community routines, like breakfast at the cafe in town, stopped because many institutions shut down rather than relocate. It was not an unexpected consequence of the rebuilding, but it was an unfortunate one, said James Lee Witt, director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency under President Bill Clinton and the architect of the rebuilding effort along the Mississippi.
"It's a good thing to keep people from going through the pain and anguish of a flood again," Mr. Witt said. "But it's tough, too, when you relocate a town and you lose that heart of a community. As time grows, they will get the community back, I hope."
But chances of economic recovery are slim, said Thomas F. Pogue, an economics professor at the University of Iowa. "The government may have been trying to move the towns and have it continue as it was," Mr. Pogue said. "But that's not economically viable. What is being lost is the sense of community and history. That can't be replicated."
That seems to be the case in downtown Winfield, Mo., 50 miles north of St. Louis. The town lies on the flood plain, three miles west of the riverbank. Already shrunken by mechanized farming, Winfield was inundated by the flood nine years ago.
"It came and stayed three months," said Mearle Lindsey, 57, a crane operator in St. Louis and one of Winfield's 723 residents. 
Over coffee at Bill and Leisa's Hometown Cafe on Main Street, Barbara Coons, a city alderwoman, said: "There no people in Winfield any more since the flood. It's going to be a ghost town."
To discourage building on flood plains, Congress and the Federal Emergency Management Agency steered many residents to high ground a half mile from downtown. The agency offered to buy houses and shops that were more than 50 percent damaged, less any insurance payment the owners received; state and federal agencies helped pay to develop sites above the path of floods, with roads and water systems as well as schools and town halls. 
Still, many businesses tried to hold on. Across from Bill and Leisa's is Main Street's largest structure, the shuttered Rick's Hardware. To serve a shrinking downtown community, the store had expanded into appliances, lumber and groceries. But the third generation owner closed it and moved a couple of years ago. 
"He went into the traveling salesman business, selling for someone else," Mr. Lindsey said.
Winfield's next vacancy might be Dixon's Quick Stop, a convenience store down the street from Rick's. Dixon's has been getting by, said Caroline Kight, manager and daughter of the owner. "My grandpa started this in the 1930's," she said. "My dad has had it for 30-some years."
But her father is reaching retirement age, so two years ago he put the store up for sale. No one has made an offer. "If no one comes by the end of September," Ms. Kight said, "it will be sold at auction."
Seventy-five miles down the river from Winfield, the town of Valmeyer, Ill., has met a similar fate. The flood washed out the school, three churches, the bank, the grocery store, two service stations and two taverns. 
"We lost our town," said Edward Kempen, 62, who retired recently from a Chrysler plant in Fenton, Mo., where he was a painter. His wife, Brenda, 56, said, "It was real eerie at first."
The Kempens live in what townspeople call Old Valmeyer, which now consists of a dozen or so houses, down from 300 or so before the flood. Along with a few other people, they refused government aid to move and ignored town officials who told them they would no longer have town water and sewerage. They drilled a well and put in a septic tank and used insurance money and savings to rebuild their house.
The government wanted them to move to New Valmeyer, a mile away, on the bluffs overlooking the river. There is a civic building, a school, a post office, a bank, three churches and row upon row of small vinyl-sheathed houses.
Some Old Valmeyer residents moved to the new subdivision, but many left the area entirely. Younger families from elsewhere, attracted by the school, have moved in, but they shop and play somewhere else. About 600 people live there.
In the meantime, the businesses that remained in Old Valmeyer have shut down or moved. The community's cohesion, and any sense of a place with a history, went out with the flood.
"I hardly know anybody going down the road," said Bernice Meadors, who moved her tavern, the Corner Pub, from the old town to the new town after the flood. "I thought the people would come back. But those people who live up here, they don't come from here. The heart is gone."
For a few river towns, like Mark Twain's tattered Hannibal, Mo., or the Mediterranean-like beach in Prescott, Wis., the answer is tourism and recreation. Most, however, offer visitors little more than a boat ramp, a park, a casino or a curiosity, like the tomb in Oquawka, Ill., for Norma Jean, a circus elephant struck by lightning in a visit there. 
Not everyone is unhappy that there are fewer people around. Tim Picou, a 41-year-old highway worker, was the only person in Kaskaskia one recent sunny afternoon. Though Mr. Picou lost his house in the flood, he decided, against the advice of the Federal emergency agency and local officials, to stay in town, and now lives with his family in one of Kaskaskia's half dozen occupied houses. He is getting by, he said. The mail is delivered, the garbage is picked up and the church, built to hold about 200 worshipers, still has services.
"It doesn't matter where you live," Mr. Picou said, flicking away a grasshopper that had landed next to him on the stoop of his house. "You make do with what you can."

HEADLINE: Cots Can't Solve a Homeless Crisis 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
With homeless families sleeping in a jail, New York City can't afford to wait for the federal government to act (news analysis, Aug. 13). 
 Community-based housing groups are leaders in local efforts to meet housing needs and have created and preserved tens of thousands of affordable apartments. 
Yet the programs that are most effective were targeted for elimination or downsizing in the last city budget. 
 Worse, federal community development block grant funds were shifted from housing to other uses. To end homelessness we must expand the supply of affordable housing, which can only happen if the mayor makes housing a top budget priority.

IRENE BALDWIN
New York, Aug. 15, 2002

The writer is executive director of the Association for Neighborhood and Housing Development.

HEADLINE: Cots Can't Solve a Homeless Crisis 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 As a young girl, my family and I spent a homeless spring and summer in a series of motels. It was a time of deep shame and confusion for my siblings and me. 
This is a trauma that I assure you reverberates through generations (front page, Aug. 15). 
 Even in my family, which has recovered economically, the scars can be witnessed in the child-rearing practices and chronic illness of some of us.
I am astonished that the Bloomberg administration would use a former jail building as a temporary shelter for families with children older than 6. How will these boys and girls maintain any sense of their families' goodness when they are placed in a facility meant for criminals? The long-term costs will be paid by every other system in the city -- and of course by the children themselves.

LEAH M. OPPENHEIMER
Sag Harbor, N.Y., Aug. 15, 2002

HEADLINE: Metro Briefing New York: Manhattan: Unemployment Rate Drops 

BYLINE:  By Leslie Eaton (NYT) (Compiled by Anthony Ramirez)

 BODY:
 Fewer people than usual were looking for jobs in July, which led to a drop in the unemployment rate in New York City, according to data released yesterday by the New York State Department of Labor. The drop is due to the way unemployment is measured. 
Excluded from the measure are people who are not working but not actively looking for work. The smaller number of job seekers led to a drop in the unemployment rate to 7.7 percent from 8 percent in June, after adjustment for seasonal factors. Typically, there is a surge in unemployment in July as young people out of school seek work, but bad economic news may have discouraged some potential job seekers, said James P. Brown, an analyst with the Labor Department. Leslie Eaton (NYT)

HEADLINE: Low-Cost Airlines Push Forward As TheirLarger Rivals Cut Back 

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WONG 

 BODY:
As full-service airlines cut flights in coming months, they will create the kind of opportunity that in the past has allowed low-cost carriers to steal passengers.
 Economic downturns allow no-frills airlines to flex their cost advantages, and analysts say some of those carriers could scoop up abandoned slots at airports, not to mention add flights to poorly served routes. 
 AirTran Airways, already a strong rival to US Airways and Delta Air Lines on the East Coast, is poised for such a move, analysts say. It is growing quickly, with plans to increase capacity by 20 percent from last year. In the first and second quarters, it raised its capacity -- measured in a unit called available seat miles -- by 12.8 percent and 23.2 percent. 
"We're looking for those cities that are underserved and overcharged," said Tad Hutcheson, director of marketing at AirTran. "As the other airlines are looking to scale back and cut back in capacity, we're doing just the opposite."
Since the Sept. 11 attacks, AirTran has already added service to 7 cities and 24 routes. It has taken delivery of 9 Boeing 717's this year, with 11 more to come by December. The airline managed a profit of $5.1 million last quarter, though that was down 61 percent from a year earlier.
Four of the country's largest full-service airlines said this week that they would reduce capacity in the next several months. American and United, which is a unit of the UAL Corporation, both said they would reduce their November schedules by 9 percent, compared with July's schedules, and Northwest announced a 13 percent cut. It is unclear how much those moves are a reflection of the usual transition to autumn, which is historically slower, and how much are a result of the economic slowdown and the decline in travel after Sept. 11.
US Airways said it would cut flights and reroute some to different hubs as it operated under bankruptcy protection. It said it intended to maintain service to almost all its cities, but announced yesterday that it was dropping regional flights to Saginaw, Mich., starting Sept. 7.
"Historically, the low-cost airlines have certainly taken an economic downturn to increase market share," said Susan Donofrio, an analyst at Deutsche Bank. "This was the strategy that Southwest did in the early 1990's."
AirTran also used that tactic last fall, when the major carriers were still icing their bruises from the Sept. 11 attacks. It went into Baltimore-Washington International Airport in December and grabbed five gates that US Airways had used for its recently failed low-cost operation, called MetroJet. It now runs 25 flights a day from the airport.
"They cut down quite a bit," Mr. Hutcheson said of US Airways. "We found clearly that that was an opportunity for us, and we took advantage of it."
The nation's two most profitable airlines, Southwest Airlines and JetBlue Airways, said the planned cuts by the full-service carriers would have no immediate effect on their operations. It is too soon to tell which routes will be affected, and that limits the moves that rivals can plan. Ed Stewart, a spokesman for Southwest, said, "Long-term planning in the airline business is just two days."
In 1991, Southwest snatched up gates at Midway Airport in Chicago that were abandoned by Midway Airlines when it filed for bankruptcy protection. Southwest had been running 44 flights a day from Chicago, and eventually surpassed its initial goal of 100 daily departures.
JetBlue's expansion plans for the rest of the year are limited by the fact that it is taking delivery of only seven more Airbus jets, said Gareth Edmondson-Jones, a spokesman. Most of those will be based in Long Beach, Calif., with a few in Florida. JetBlue increased its second-quarter capacity by 101 percent over the period last year, and it is growing about 15 aircraft a year.
"We're plane-constrained, and we recognize it," Mr. Edmondson-Jones said. "Each plane that we take, there are way more options for it than what we can do. We mull over all the options and ask which one can we make the most money at."
Routes run by the full-service carriers might not meet the criteria set by the low-cost airlines. All of them said they looked for markets where there was a clear demand for low fares. AirTran and JetBlue operate out of a mix of central and secondary airports, but Southwest traditionally goes after slots only in secondary airports like Midway.
In one case, JetBlue started flying a route partly because rivals had cut back. The airline had intended to start running a route from Washington to the West Coast last October, but held back because of the Sept. 11 attacks. Then in November, when it saw that full-service carriers were cutting back on service to Florida, it decided instead to add flights between Washington and Florida, Mr. Edmondson-Jones said.
"The low-cost carriers are clearly in a cost position to take advantage of the situation," said Steven A. Morrison, a professor of economics at Northeastern University who studies the airline industry. "Although such carriers are hurting, they're hurting less than their network brethren."
Despite their need to cut costs, the full-service airlines will not necessarily sit by and watch the low-cost carriers steal their passengers. When JetBlue moved into Long Beach, American Airlines began haggling with the city to expand its slots beyond four. It received an additional four slots, which it can hold until January, and it began advertising cheap flights between New York and Long Beach.
"We know that the low-cost competitors are out there, and in these times perhaps they do have an advantage in certain marketplaces," said Marty Heires, a spokesman for American. "But we are not about to relinquish market share. We have shown in the past that we can respond."
American's largest rival, United, is fighting bigger battles. Many Wall Street firms downgraded its stock and credit ratings yesterday after it said on Wednesday that it might file for bankruptcy protection, though the stock ended the day up 25 cents, at $2.70. Executives began putting together a restructuring plan to present to its unions, and the carrier sent an e-mail message to members of its frequent-flier program saying that it will honor their miles on "a safe and reliable airline."

HEADLINE: After the Bubble: Are Low Rates Enough? 

BYLINE:  By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
"While bubbles that burst are scarcely benign, the consequences need not be catastrophic for the economy. The bursting of the Japanese bubble a decade ago did not lead immediately to sharp contractions in output or a significant rise in unemployment. Arguably, it was the subsequent failure to address the damage to the financial system in a timely manner that caused Japan's current economic problems. Likewise, while the stock market crash of 1929 was destabilizing, most analysts attribute the Great Depression to ensuing failures of policy." Alan Greenspan, June 1999
 NO economic policy maker has become a star in the way that Alan Greenspan has. The coming year may seal that reputation, or severely damage it. 
 By next summer, we should have a good fix on whether the Federal Reserve was right to ignore the stock market bubble in 1999. Mr. Greenspan could have used his bully pulpit to warn of overinvestment in certain areas of the economy, notably telecommunications. He could have raised margin requirements to make it more expensive to gamble on stock prices.
Instead, he punted, with the assurance that there would be plenty of time to act after the bubble burst. "To spot a bubble in advance requires a judgment that hundreds of thousands of informed investors have it all wrong," he told a Congressional hearing.
The way he saw it, there had been no need for the Depression to follow the 1929 crash, or for Japan to enter its long slump after its bubble burst in 1990. Central banks just had to be willing to act quickly after the bubble did burst. He noted that all worked out well when the Fed eased rates after the 1987 crash.
By this spring, it looked as if Mr. Greenspan had been right. The 2001 recession was among the mildest on record, even with the shock of Sept. 11 superimposed on an economy that was already in decline. Consumers treated layoff announcements as being of little import to them, and lower interest rates kept housing booming.
Then came the Wall Street summer swoon, and with it the realization that the industry most affected by the bubble -- telecommunications -- showed no signs of recovery. WorldCom is not just the latest example of corporate fraud; it is a company that made investments predicated on bubble demand, and then covered up the damage from those investments.
Mr. Greenspan likes to give hints before he changes rates, an inclination that may have prevented a rate cut this week. But if the statistics continue to look bad -- and yesterday's report by the Philadelphia Fed on manufacturing in that region was worse than anyone expected -- then look for a half-point cut next month.
During the great bubble, many feared the effect of stock market losses when the bubble burst. But there was less discussion of the economic effects of what William Dudley, the Goldman, Sachs economist, calls the "tremendous misallocation of capital," and that is what we now confront. Interest rates are low, but credit is tight for companies that need to borrow. Lower rates can stimulate housing, which does not need much help, but cannot prompt capital investment, where demand does not exist.
At best, consumers will keep spending and a sluggish recovery will continue, with a recovering stock market providing reassurance. But there are signs of international weakness and of growing protectionism that can only hurt global output. Mr. Greenspan could use a little help from fiscal policy. Why not make additional tax cuts this year while repealing cuts scheduled for later years?
Mr. Greenspan was correct in concluding that central banks did a poor job after earlier bubbles burst. Now we will see if he was right to assume that post-bubble easing is sufficient this time.

HEADLINE: U.S., Protesting Rights Leader's Sentence, Halts New Aid to Egypt 

BYLINE:  By CHRISTOPHER MARQUIS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 

 BODY:
President Bush has warned President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt that the United States will not deliver any new aid to Egypt in protest against the prosecution of a leading human rights activist, the White House said today.
 Mr. Bush's action would curtail only an increase in military and economic aid being sought by Egypt. It would not affect the nearly $2 billion in annual aid that Washington provides to Cairo under the Camp David accords, White House officials said. 
 The move nevertheless highlighted an unusual standoff between the administration and an Arab nation of great strategic importance in American efforts to promote Middle East peace and in any eventual confrontation with Iraq. The administration's stance drew praise from international rights groups and an angry response from Egypt.
In a letter to Mr. Mubarak on Wednesday, Mr. Bush voiced distress over the treatment of the activist, Saad Eddin Ibrahim, a sociologist and government critic sentenced last month to seven years in prison for activities that included registering people to vote and supporting the rights of Egyptian minorities.
"President Bush has expressed his concern to President Mubarak," Sean McCormack, a White House spokesman, said today. He declined to provide details of the letter.
"Egypt is a close friend and an important ally," Mr. McCormack said. "The United States will meet its Camp David aid commitments." But, he added, "at this time, we are not contemplating any additional funds beyond that commitment."
Egypt had sought an additional $130 million this year after Congress approved an increase of $200 million for Israel in aid to fight terrorism. Traditionally, the United States has increased aid to Egypt by two-thirds the amount of new funds for Israel. The two nations are the top two recipients of American assistance.
The White House action may be largely symbolic in the near term because Mr. Bush has said that in an effort to curb spending, he will not sign the $5.1 billion package that included the new aid for Israel. 
American diplomats met today with Egyptian officials in Cairo and Washington to reiterate their concerns about Mr. Ibrahim's case, officials said. The letter to Mr. Mubarak -- even though the decision not to approve the larger spending bill had already been made -- demonstrates that the administration was intent on making a point to Cairo.
Even so, Egypt's foreign minister, Ahmed Maher, said the American protest would not influence his country's judicial process. "Egypt does not accept pressure and will not bow to pressure, and everyone knows that," he told reporters.
Hesham El Nakib, a spokesman for the Egyptian Embassy in Washington, denied American allegations that Mr. Ibrahim had been tried for political beliefs and activities that threatened the government.
Mr. Ibrahim, he said, "has been working in Egypt for over 20 years, freely, with no interference, and sometimes he has been critical of the government," adding, "At no point has he been persecuted."
But rights advocates say Mr. Ibrahim, who holds joint Egyptian and American citizenship and is in delicate health, is a target because he has tried to promote democracy in an autocratic country. 
Mr. Bush's action "is especially welcome because aid has never before been tied to the promotion of human rights in the Arab world," said Tom Malinowski, the Washington advocacy director of Human Rights Watch.

HEADLINE: Dell Profits Are Up 11% For Quarter 

BYLINE:  By JOHN SCHWARTZ 

 BODY:
The Dell Computer Corporation, continuing its elbows-out assault on the rest of the computer market, announced yesterday that its second-quarter profits had improved and product shipments had increased at a time when other computer makers are suffering.
 The company, which is the second-largest maker of personal computers, said that it would be making a big push into the markets for computer printers and hand-held devices, and also raised its revenue projections for this quarter. 
 "Clearly, we're winning and gaining market share," Michael S. Dell, the company's chairman and chief executive, said during a conference call. 
The company, which is based in Round Rock, Tex., said its product shipments rose 18 percent worldwide in the quarter that ended Aug. 2, while overall industry volumes declined 4 percent. Sales of powerful servers and workstations increased 20 percent, the company said. 
Second-quarter revenue was $8.5 billion, up 11 percent from the quarter last year. Net income was $501 million, or 19 cents a share, meeting the expectations of analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. In the quarter a year ago, Dell reported a loss of 4 cents a share, mainly because of a $742 million charge against earnings for cost-cutting measures like closing factories and cutting jobs. Without the charge, income would have been 16 cents a share in that quarter. Shares of Dell closed at $27.14, down 1 cent, and rose slightly in after-hours trading to $27.63. Mr. Dell said that the computer industry sales could rise in the third quarter, with an eventual snap-back as businesses that have put off computer purchases finally gain the courage to upgrade their aging machines. Mr. Dell predicted that his company would be the biggest winner of the sales surge to come. 
When spending returns after a slump, he said, "I don't think it returns in the same way as before," because companies differentiate themselves through factors like costs and low prices. "The recovery will not lift all boats, equally," he said. "You're seeing Dell clearly differentiate itself here, and that will continue." 
He did not venture a prediction about the larger technology market or the overall economy, saying, "I'm not going to try to compete with economic forecasters."
The company said that whether industry shipments were flat or were slightly higher in the third quarter, the company expected to increase its own sales volumes by 5 percent over the second quarter, with revenue of $8.9 billion. That would be a record for Dell, and constitute an increase of 19 percent from the quarter in the previous year, with earnings per share of 20 to 21 cents.
One industry analyst said that by moving aggressively on so many different fronts was providing Dell with opportunities that competitors did not have. "There are multiple engines of growth, such as the enterprise, storage, servers, services -- as well as geographic opportunities in China, Germany and Japan," said Andrew J. Neff of Bear, Stearns. "From a structural standpoint, it gives Dell opportunities for growth, and a greater probability of hitting that than someone who has only one or two opportunities."
Mr. Dell warned against reading too much into the company's planned move into the market for hand-held devices, saying that it was a relatively small market compared with the enormous and lucrative market for business computing. "The real opportunity is in the enterprise," he said.
The company already sells printers, but recently Hewlett-Packard, its chief PC competitor, said it would no longer supply printers to Dell. Dell, in turn, has said it is seeking partners to manufacture printers. During yesterday's conference call with reporters, Mr. Dell said that printers were a potentially rich market to tap, especially with recurring profits to be made from selling ink cartridges. 
He declined to say when those initiatives would be formally announced, however. "I think you'll be hearing from us later -- it's not the time right now," he said. "Stay tuned."

During the bull market, no one was more euphoric about the promise of upstart telecommunications companies than Mr. Grubman.  Mr. Grubman's severance will be more than $31 million -- he will receive about $12 million in stock and stock options, and a $19 million loan will be forgiven. Page A1.

HEADLINE: Suddenly, Raises for Congress Seem Less Certain 

BYLINE:  By CARL HULSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 

 BODY:
There is only one thing members of Congress hate more than voting on giving themselves a raise: voting on giving themselves a raise in an election year when a shaky economy is shrinking the retirement funds of many constituents.
 While the annual cost-of-living increase for representatives and senators next year once appeared to be gliding through, opponents of the raises now say the economic and corporate climate has emboldened them to try to derail the automatic increase of about $5,000 when Congress returns next month. 
 "The idea of an automatic pay raise for members of Congress that they don't have to vote on smells a little like some of the corporate monkey business and games in the corporate world," said Senator Russell D. Feingold, Democrat of Wisconsin, who is already something of a Senate outcast for his insistence on changing campaign finance laws. "It is really like a form of cooking the books." 
Leaders of nine conservative, libertarian and liberal interest groups joined Ralph Nader on Wednesday in sending a letter to all senators urging them to reject any increase in their current salary, $150,000.
"There is no shortage of highly qualified candidates willing to run for Congress at the current salary," the letter said. "If senators wish to earn more, they may do so in the private sector."
Votes on pay increases are among the most cringe-inducing decisions faced by any politician. After years of political anguish and public anger over raises, Congress in 1989 constructed an elaborate mechanism to avoid future votes on raising members' pay. An ethics package adopted that year gave lawmakers in both chambers a raise to $125,100, from $89,500, by 1991. Future increases were tied to the Employment Cost Index.
"It was meticulously calculated to grease the skids and make it as easy as possible with little controversy," said Gary Ruskin, director of the Congressional Accountability Project, founded by Mr. Nader, and one of the signers of this week's letter protesting the raises. Mr. Ruskin said public opinion surveys had consistently shown that increasing their own pay "may be the single most unpopular thing that members of Congress do."
The sensitivity to the 1989 raise ran so deep that the leaders of both national political parties issued a written pledge to refrain from using the vote as fodder for campaign attack advertisements.
"As the leaders of the political committees, we are well aware of the political dangers that members of Congress might face if this issue were to be misused in the campaigns of 1990," said the letter signed by Ron Brown and Lee Atwater, then the chairmen of the Democratic and Republican parties, respectively.
Mr. Feingold and his allies face a struggle in rescinding the raise. He will have to successfully offer an amendment to block the increase, probably to the Treasury Department's spending bill, something he he has failed in the past to accomplish. It would then have to be accepted in negotiations with the House.
The House last month quickly rebuffed a similar effort by Representative Jim Matheson, Democrat of Utah. After the vote, the majority leader, Dick Armey of Texas, chafed at any suggestion that lawmakers should not get their salary adjustment, considering that members of Congress gave up outside speaking fees in exchange for the annual increase. 
"I personally gave up $22,000 a year in outside earnings to have that nominal cost-of-living adjustment," Mr. Armey told reporters.
The raise would apply to more than just members of Congress. Hundreds of judges and senior government executives -- among a total of about 3,300 people -- would get an identical percentage increase, estimated to be 3.3 percent this year.
Senate aides predicted that the effort to thwart the increase would fail, though one conceded it could pick up momentum if opponents of the raise can link it to corporate accountability issues and the economy.
"It is sort of becoming a traditional thing for Senator Feingold to do and a traditional thing for the Senate to reject it," one Senate aide said.
Opponents were able to block raises five times after the automatic increases were adopted in 1989, but the adjustments have become routine in recent years and were accepted the past three years with scant notice.
In their letter, the critics said that members of Congress made almost four times the median income of typical male workers and that this was "an especially improper time for yet another Congressional pay grab."
Pete Sepp, a spokesman for the National Taxpayers Union, said, "For them to think they can get away with a raise the way they did in 2001 would be a mistake." 
Mr. Feingold said he believed his cause "is even more compelling this year because we should exercise restraint."
"This is clearly a year when members of Congress should not be getting a pay raise," he said.
He said that he expected to anger his colleagues by trying to force them into a vote and that the resentment over this issue was more pronounced than the hostility over campaign finance changes. That was about campaign accounts, this is about bank accounts. 
"This is one where I pick up some real anger," he said. "It is not a fun moment, but it has to done."

HEADLINE: A New Downtown: More Ideas Wanted 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"New Designs for a New Downtown" (editorial, Aug. 15) said that the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation's new design competition was "not entirely welcomed" by our firm, Beyer Blinder Belle. In fact, we responded to news of the initiative by saying, "We strongly support inviting the best architects and planners from around the world to contribute to the planning study." 
 We ask only that the public understand what "planning" means: the relationships among terrain, infrastructure, building mass, building use and open space. The six initial proposals were not architectural designs per se, but rather studies of these basic issues. Their value lay in prompting a lively discussion. 
 The Port Authority and development corporation are on the proper path, toward a memorial and a redeveloped site that will reflect the enormity of Sept. 11, but still allow for a rebirth of the Lower Manhattan economy.
Taking seriously the views of the public and bringing in additional architects and planners will increase the range of options and lead to the goal we all seek: a dignified, striking memorial and a rebuilding plan worthy of our great city.

JOHN H. BEYER
JOHN BELLE
New York, Aug. 15, 2002

The writers are senior partners of Beyer Blinder Belle.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; 
Nasdaq Decides to Quit Its Joint Trading Venture in Japan

BYLINE:  By KEN BELSON 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Aug. 16 

 BODY:
Plagued by the slump in stocks here and by a host of regulatory and market frustrations, Nasdaq said today that it would pull out of Nasdaq Japan, its joint venture stock market here, on Oct. 15.
 The American parent, which owns 43 percent of Nasdaq Japan, said earlier this month that it had written off its entire $20 million investment in the venture. Softbank, the Japanese technology conglomerate, also owns 43 percent; it said the breakup of the venture would have minimal effects on its balance sheet. The remaining 14 percent is owned by 13 brokerage houses, including Merrill Lynch, Morgan Stanley and Lehman Brothers. 
 The breakup of Nasdaq Japan leaves the country with two markets for smaller-company stocks -- the Jasdaq over-the-counter trading system, operated by the Japan Securities Dealers Association, and Mothers, operated by the Tokyo Stock Exchange. The 98 companies whose shares now trade on Nasdaq Japan can retain listings on the Osaka Securities Exchange, which provided the operational base for Nasdaq Japan, or apply for listings elsewhere.
Nasdaq Japan began operating in June 2000 as a home for young, high-growth companies, and was seen as a crucial link in Nasdaq's ambition for a 24-hour global equity market. But it opened its doors just as investors' taste for risky stocks was evaporating. It lost 2.8 billion yen ($24 million) last year, mainly because of the dearth of initial public offerings. Since April, trading volume has fallen by half, and only four listings have been added.
"A review of our strategic options going forward led us to the conclusion that due to economic and market conditions, this was the only option remaining," said Richard G. Ketchum, the president of Nasdaq and a director of Nasdaq Japan.
The venture also had trouble persuading the Osaka exchange to adopt Nasdaq's computerized market-making systems and to introduce investment vehicles like exchange-traded funds.
Some prominent companies, including local subsidiaries of E*Trade and Starbucks, listed their shares on Nasdaq Japan, but many others went to its rivals. Nasdaq Japan reportedly held talks with Jasdaq about a combination, but they went nowhere.
"Nasdaq came in at the top of the bubble and paid a price for it," said Fiachra MacCana, an equity strategist at West LB Securities in Tokyo. "Nasdaq never had the credibility and longevity to put down deep roots, so the fact that it is no longer functioning should not hurt that much."

HEADLINE: CONNECTIONS; 
The Man Who Wrote the Book on Spies

BYLINE:  By Edward Rothstein 

 BODY:
When James Bond flies into Istanbul in "From Russia With Love" to collect a Russian encryption machine along with an alluring Soviet defector, he is reading Eric Ambler's 1939 spy novel, "A Coffin for Dimitrios." It is an inside joke for Bond's creator, Ian Fleming, since Ambler's book also involved skulduggery in Istanbul. The joke even takes on an edge when Bond later returns to the novel but can't keep his eyes open.
 Bond, though, may not have gotten his license to kill without Ambler's influence. And though Bond became an absurdly glorified figure, the spy according to Ambler has far more relevance to contemporary debates about espionage. 
 Until recently, for example, the United States has been on a campaign to eliminate Bondlike swashbuckling from its cloak-and-dagger activities. Embarrassed over grotesque excesses and catastrophic failures, the country yearned for a kind of "clean" espionage. No action would be taken that might seem too seamy and no source used that might cause embarrassment. Espionage would take on the trappings of law enforcement. But since last September, it has become more urgent to worry about intelligence's failures than about its excesses. Effectiveness can now seem more urgent than transparency. Intelligence has been spooked. 
But espionage, with its lies and deceit, is no easy undertaking in an open society. And here, Ambler might be called in for a consultation. Born in 1909, he was trained as an engineer, worked as an advertising copywriter and at one time aspired to be a playwright. He thrust his hapless heroes -- teachers, engineers and writers -- into a world of political intrigue. During the years before the Second World War, Ambler helped create the image of the modern spy. He was hailed by Graham Greene as "our greatest thriller writer"; films have been made from his books (most famously "Topkapi"); he also wrote screenplays to movies like "The Guns of Navarone" and was nominated for an Oscar for "The Cruel Sea." 
Yet by his death, in 1998, Ambler was eclipsed and his works out of print. Now, on the spy-novel right, Robert Ludlum and Tom Clancy celebrate the superhuman agent and his equipment. On the spy-novel left, John le Carre evokes a world riddled with moral ambiguity. As for Ambler's 1930's universe, with its train compartments and border crossings, Comintern agents and Fascist sympathizers, that is the terrain of Alan Furst. 
Now, though, Vintage Books is bringing Ambler back. Four early novels are available -- "Background to Danger" "A Coffin for Dimitrios," "Epitaph for a Spy," and "Cause for Alarm." In December will come "Journey to Fear" and "Judgment on Deltchev." At least four others will follow. 
These are novels of education. The protagonist typically thinks of himself as a highly subtle reader of personality and motive -- and then gets everything wrong. In Ambler's classic "Dimitrios," Charles Latimer, a political economist who has left academic life to write murder mysteries, ends up knowing little about either political economy or murder. That confusion extends to moral issues as well. In "Cause for Alarm," a British engineer works for a munitions firm in Fascist Italy, blind to ethical complications until he is lured into an even more lurid series of compromises. 
The pioneering British spy thrillers like John Buchan's "Thirty-Nine Steps" (1915) and Erskine Childers's "Riddle of the Sands" (1903) treated espionage as war fought by other means. With Ambler, war might be seen as espionage fought by other means. Everything in Ambler's world is a reflection of secret forces. The master spy peers under the superstructure and reads the essences of things. The education of the Ambler hero is an induction into that netherworld.
But the contrast between Ambler's strategic and literary subtleties and his Crayola outline of the netherworld could not be more jarring. In "Background to Danger" assassinations are planned in the board room of the megacorporation Pan-Eurasian Petroleum. The villain in "Dimitrios" sits on the board of the Eurasian Credit Trust, a bank with tentacles grasping all over prewar Europe. 
Ambler once said that during the 1930's he was a "very far left wing socialist" and "ready for the barricades." The hero of two novels is actually a Soviet agent who refers to the "so-called democracies France and England" and argues that the regnant authorities had become "the Stock Exchange Yearbook and Hitler's 'Mein Kampf.' " So while novelistically the books try to evoke ambiguity and explore the dangers of misinterpretation, ideologically a rigid and distorted grid is imposed. For Ambler, the essential battles of 1930's Europe are between fascistic capitalism and Soviet socialism.
Ambler's celebration of the Soviet agent, of course, has had little shelf life. Another rigid grid later developed for the espionage novels of the cold war. But many aspects of Ambler's early vision persist. Corporate evil is a recurrent theme in spy fiction and film and so, too, is a sense of systemic corruption. Many of Mr. le Carre's books suggest, for example, that when you penetrate to the essences, nothing is fully revealed. Espionage doesn't disclose the truth, it perpetrates illusion; the battles it fights are often unnecessary, the results of delusion. 
But in Ambler's later novels, these ideas are overturned in intriguing ways. Ambler's 1951 "Judgment on Deltchev" (available in an audio version from Blackstone Audiobooks) reveals just how drastically the world had changed for Ambler during the Second World War. In a fictional Eastern European country, the once-allied anti-Fascist fighters and Communist ideologues are split apart, leading to a Stalinist show trial of one of the country's beloved leaders. 
Ambler's novel could have been a portrait of bleak tyranny and trumped-up charges -- the kind of story his protagonist, a British playwright commissioned to observe the trial, believes he will write. But the playwright soon finds that matters are more complicated -- that there are degrees of guilt and tyranny. Distinctions matter: the West is not like the East. There are battles that must be fought, but all other choices are inherently flawed. Every decision requires compromise and sacrifice. Something similar is revealed in "State of Siege" (1956) in its account of an Islamic coup in a Far Eastern country. 
Ambler, in other words, began to wrestle with the shadow-world of realpolitik. In one of his best works, "Doctor Frigo" (1974), with its climactic coup in a "coffee republic" in Central America, the bourgeois protagonist can barely make sense of the betrayals, the poverty, the manipulations, the corruption. "As a keeper of secrets I have been a failure," he confesses, "and as a man of action ineffectual." But there is no doubt that if change ever takes place, it will be up to the keepers of secrets and the men of action. 
These postwar books carve out their own space in the world of espionage fiction, and it is not a comfortable one. The essence of things is that there are uncertainties and fallibilities and venalities, shades of gray and even black. But there is no way to avoid choosing, and every choice matters. 
It may be that this is where things stand in contemporary life, with a guarantee of complications and traumas yet to come. The spy must come back into the cold.

CORRECTION-DATE: August 23, 2002

 CORRECTION:
The picture caption with the Connections column in Arts & Ideas on Saturday, about the novelist Eric Ambler, misstated the subject of the film "Topkapi" and the Ambler novel "The Light of Day," on which it was based. They were about thieves, not spies.
The Connections column in Arts & Ideas on Aug. 17 about the novelist Eric Ambler included a film credit for him erroneously. The screenplay for "The Guns of Navarone," based on the novel of the same name by Alistair MacLean, was written by Carl Foreman, not by Ambler.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Shares Mixed, but Dow and S.&P. Maintain 4-Week Run

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Stocks were mixed yesterday but the Dow Jones industrial average and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index still managed to finish higher for the fourth consecutive week.
 That four-week run is the first for the S.& P. 500 index since May 2001 and the first for the Dow since March. While the week's gain for the Dow was only 0.4 percent, the S.& P. 500 was up 2.2 percent. The runs for both gauges may give investors more hope that the bottom of the market, which hit a five-year low in July, might have been reached. 
 "My sense is that people are feeling a little bit better," said Henry Herrmann, chief investment officer at Waddell & Reed, a money management firm in Overland Park, Kan. But, he added, "I think we're up four weeks in a row mostly because the previous four weeks were so horrendous."
Only the Nasdaq composite index managed to climb higher yesterday, rising 1.2 percent. Both the Dow and the S.& P. 500 were down a fraction of a percentage point. The mixed performance came in the face of some disappointing news: consumer confidence fell in August and housing starts slipped last month. The bond market also sold off sharply, pushing interest rates higher.
There was some positive news on inflation, however, with the Consumer Price Index for July up only 0.1 percent.
At the close, the Dow was down 40.08 points, or 0.5 percent, at 8,778.06, while the S.& P. 500 index had fallen 1.48 points, or 0.2 percent, to 928.77. The Nasdaq rose 16 points, or 1.2 percent, to 1,361.01.
The Nasdaq climbed 4.2 percent in the week. It was up 4.7 percent the previous week but had declined 14.7 percent in the five weeks before that. Applied Materials, Nextel Communications and Oracle led the Nasdaq yesterday.
In the bond market, prices fell as yields, which move in the opposite direction from price, rose. The downbeat news on housing and consumer confidence, combined with the upbeat inflation data, would normally be positive for bonds. But the market has had a huge rally since the beginning of June. And on Wednesday, the yield on the Treasury's 10-year note plunged briefly below 4 percent, the lowest yield on a note with 10 years to maturity since 1963.
So with stocks appearing to have found a bottom, investors began to wonder how much farther the bond rally could go. The selling that resulted pushed the yield on the Treasury's 10-year note up to 4.33 percent yesterday, from 4.18 percent on Thursday, as the price fell 1 4/32, to 100 13/32. It was the first time since the beginning of July that the yield on the 10-year note was up for the week. The yield was 4.26 percent a week ago.
Even if the 10-year Treasury yield does not fall much more, it has pushed mortgage interest rates to or near record lows. That decline has helped support consumer spending by encouraging mortgage refinancing, which lowers monthly payments and can provide homeowners with extra cash. Federal Reserve officials may be waiting to see how this interest rate decline affects the economy before deciding to cut rates again.
The initial reading of consumer confidence for August fell to a nine-month low of 87.9, according to the University of Michigan. That was down from 88.1 in July and below the Wall Street consensus forecast of 89.
Housing starts fell for the second consecutive month, with a decline in July of 2.7 percent, to an annual rate of 1.649 million.
But some investors may see a positive in some of this bad news. If the economy continues to be weak -- but does not fall into a steep decline -- investors could see another short-term interest rate cut from the Fed without the negative effect that a sharp decline in economic growth would have on corporate earnings.
At an annual rate, consumer prices are up 2.5 percent through the first seven months of the year, compared with an increase of 1.6 percent for all of 2001. Much of the difference, however, is in energy prices, which are up 14.5 percent at an annual rate so far this year after falling 13 percent last year.
The restrained rise in inflation would make it easier for Fed policy makers to cut interest rates because they would not have to worry much about the inflation fallout.
Mr. Herrmann of Waddell & Reed says he thinks the Fed will cut interest rates. But he does not think the stock market is ready to move decisively higher, in part because top corporate executives have not begun to talk enough about a turnaround. "I don't see the spark that gives us some upside," he said.
